webTitle: Injury rules Batty out of Euro 2000

fields.headline: Injury rules Batty out of Euro 2000
fields.trailText: England's preparations for Euro 2000 have been dealt a significant blow with the news that David Batty will almost certainly be ruled out by injury.
fields.body:
England's preparations for Euro 2000 have been dealt a significant blow with the news that David Batty will almost certainly be ruled out by injury.

The Leeds midfielder is not expected to play again this season after suffering a setback while recovering from the calf problem that has sidelined him since December. If his worst fears are realised it will effectively write off his chances of being named in Kevin Keegan's squad for this summer's tournament in the Netherlands and Belgium.

The Leeds manager David O'Leary said yesterday: "At the moment David is nowhere near ready to play again and it's a real worry to us that he will not be back before the end of the season. You're always hopeful that he'll suddenly start making rapid progress but there has been nothing to indicate that will happen."

Everton's Back to the Future policy of recruiting players who are in sight of retirement yesterday saw the manager of Wales, Mark Hughes, join the Merseyside club at the fourth time of asking.

Successive Everton managers since the early 90s have tried, but failed, to lure Hughes to Goodison Park. The present manager Walter Smith succeeded because he was willing to offer the 36-year-old former Manchester United, Barcelona and Chelsea striker a 14-month contract, worth about £15,000 a week. Hughes joins a roster of experienced players including Dave Watson, Richard Gough and John Collins.

He completed a free transfer from Southampton yesterday morning and will probably make his debut in tonight's Premiership clash with Coventry City at Highfield Road. The Coventry manager Gordon Strachan, who is likely to field the veterans Gary McAllister and Colin Hendry, joked: "It will be like Jurassic Park."

Hughes insisted he still had much to offer despite arriving initially as cover for the injured Kevin Campbell and Francis Jeffers. "I believe that I can still influence the outcome of games and I will argue with anyone who might question whether I can still do it on a regular basis," he said. "People must look beyond my greying hair and see what I can still do out on the pitch."

"Mark is one of those players who has trained hard and avoided serious injury throughout his career," said Smith. "I do not regard this deal as a gamble. I think he will have a big influence on the team."

Everton yesterday announced a four-year kit deal with Puma UK which will net them in excess of £6m.

Middlesbrough have protested to the FA over the three-match suspension handed to Paul Gascoigne. The manager Bryan Robson is unhappy at the five-week gap between the incident and the start of the ban. Usually it is two weeks but, as part of a clean-up campaign, the FA delayed it until Gascoigne recovered from the broken arm sustained in his challenge on Aston Villa's George Boateng.

Neville Southall's return to the Premiership stage may be cut short after the Sheffield United keeper Aidan Davison, 31, performed a u-turn to join Bradford days after rejecting a permanent move.

Nottingham Forest have signed Colin Calderwood, 35, from Aston Villa for £70,000.

webTitle: Souness picks up baton at Blackburn

fields.headline: Souness picks up baton at Blackburn
fields.standfirst: Walker to pay Scot £20,000 a week to revitalise Rovers
fields.trailText: After an unsuccessful five-year dalliance with coaches, Blackburn Rovers yesterday appointed an authentic teacup-throwing manager to put them back on the right track.
fields.body:
After an unsuccessful five-year dalliance with coaches, Blackburn Rovers yesterday appointed an authentic teacup-throwing manager to put them back on the right track.

Graeme Souness, the former Rangers and Liverpool manager who also served four other clubs with considerably less success, had spent three days negotiating personal terms and transfer strategy and apparently signed on the dotted line only after an 11th-hour difference of opinion over the length of his contract.

An astute man with sound business acumen, the 46-year-old Scot held out for, and secured, a 3-year deal which is expected to bring him £20,000 a week.

So the much-travelled former Liverpool captain returns to English football as one of the country's best-paid managers, earning more from the First Division club than Everton's Walter Smith, Coventry City's Gordon Strachan and even Newcastle United's Bobby Robson do in the Premiership.

He is also believed to have negotiated a bonus of £500,000 which will be payable if he restores Rovers to the Premiership.

"Graeme Souness is precisely the man we need and he can count on our full and unswerving support," said Jack Walker, Blackburn's benefactor.

Souness, who takes over from Rovers' perennial caretaker manager Tony Parkes, is an impatient man. He will assess his squad swiftly and dispassionately and can be expected to dismantle and reassemble it with such speed that some players will find themselves at new clubs before the first piece of crockery has hit the dressing-room floor. The more so as the transfer deadline is in 15 days' time.

Souness made no secret of his interest in managing Blackburn back in November when Brian Kidd was dismissed. But the job went to Parkes, who has now been named as Blackburn's assistant manager.

"I'm absolutely delighted that Tony is to stay on with us," Walker said. "Twice in recent seasons he has helped to guide us from the possible threat of relegation and done really well."

However, the arrival of Phil Boersma, Souness's long-time friend and a former Liverpool team-mate, will probably not be long delayed. "Wherever I go in football I want him to be there," Souness wrote in his recently published book, The Management Years.

Souness, a man who has never doubted his own abilities, was yesterday both content and a mite relieved. "This is a wonderful opportunity and just the sort of challenge I relish," he said.

"I am delighted to be back in day-to-day management, particularly as the chance has come at a club as ambitious as Blackburn Rovers. This club is geared for top-level football and has a proven record. My job is to help bring back the good times to Ewood Park. I can't wait to get started."

His installation marks a significant change in emphasis at the Lancashire club, one which will undoubtedly be welcomed by supporters who have grown weary of existing on a diet of half-baked ideas and fractured promises.

Having lost Kenny Dalglish shortly after he had improbably steered the club to Premiership success in 1995, Rovers embarked on a journey which was to see them embrace men who managed with their heads rather than their hearts.

Ray Harford, Roy Hodgson, Kidd and Parkes all failed to arrest a decline in fortune which reached its climax last May, when Blackburn were returned to the First Division.

Despite failing to realise the potential at Liverpool, Souness remains a players' manager, a tub-thumping demonstrative Mr Angry who will be fiercely loyal to those in whom he will place his trust. There will, however, be casualties, many of them.

The rumour mill is already in full swing. It will say that Souness's first target may well be the gifted Liverpool striker Titi Camara.

Certainly Walker will have to be at his most generous if he is to satisfy a man who has developed a fondness for investing other people's money at his six clubs. "There is a big job to be done here and I believe we have found the right man to do it," Walker added yesterday.

He has said that before, of course, but by appointing Souness he can at least rest assured he has hired a man of commitment, dignity, honour and, most important, enormous desire.

Career moves

May 6 1953 : Born Edinburgh
May 1970: Joins Spurs
Jan 1973 : Signs for Middlesbrough. Wins 1974 Second Division title. Scotland debut in October 1974
Jan 1978: Joins Liverpool for £300,000. Plays 247 league games: wins five titles, three European Cups
May 1984: Joins Sampdoria for £650,000
June 1986 : Wins last of 54 caps. Joins Rangers as player-manager for £300,000. Wins three titles
Jan 1991 : Appointed Liverpool manager
April 1992 : Triple heart by-pass after FA Cup semi. Liverpool beat Sunderland in final
Jan 1993 : Hits out at players after FA Cup defeat by Bolton
Jan 1994 : Resigns at Anfield
1995 : Appointed manager of Galatasaray
May 1996 : Sacked but appointed manager of Southampton in July
May 1997 : Resigns
October 1997 : Sacked by Torino after three months
November 1997 : Hired as Benfica coach until 2000
April 1999 : Sacked but told to see out the season.

webTitle: Vintage Wright keeps the Clarets flowing

fields.headline: Vintage Wright keeps the Clarets flowing
fields.trailText: Gillingham 2 - 2 Burnley
fields.body:
Ian Wright scored for the first time for Burnley and earned his team a point that keeps them above Gillingham in the play-off places. The former England striker came on as a substitute and lashed home the equaliser with only four minutes remaining.

It cancelled out a thrilling strike from Carl Asaba that had promised to give Peter Taylor's side an important win. They had chances to build on Asaba's smart finish but appeared to assume that they had already done enough. Wright, however, had other ideas.

The substitutes' bench at Priestfield, a make-do affair beneath a stand still under construction and through which the wind blew cold last night, is nevertheless unlikely to feature prominently in Wright's memoirs.

Burnley started Andy Payton, who scored his 200th career goal at the weekend, and Andy Cooke up front. Stan Ternent would have wanted them to make their mark early on and justify his team selection but instead it was the Gills who took hold of the game with a fourth-minute goal.

A strong far-post challenge by Iffy Onuora earned a corner on the left. Andy Hessenthaler's kick first found Guy Butters' head and that may have distracted Lenny Johnrose, who back-headed the ball into his own net.

Burnley had shown nothing of the form that had brought them victories in each of their past three away games when, from out of the blue, they scored an equaliser. Nayron Nosworthy's clearance was poor and when the ball eventually landed with Payton he had only the goalkeeper to beat.

 Preston jumped to the top of the division with a 3-1 win over Oxford United. Brett Angell's double gave him five goals in five games for Preston.

webTitle: Francis falls short in blank return

fields.headline: Francis falls short in blank return
fields.trailText: Stockport 0 - 0 Bolton
fields.body:
Bolton, chasing a possible three Wembley appearances this season, were blocked by Stockport in their hopeful pursuit of promotion last night.

Bolton may yet appear in the FA Cup final, to add to their semi-final appearance against Aston Villa next month, but after collecting only a point here a play-off appearance at Wembley looks unlikely.

The giant 32-year-old Kevin Francis, back at the scene of the best moments of his journeyman career, should have struck for Stockport early on.

The 6ft 7in striker, signed at the end of last week on a free transfer from Oxford, was on the end of a neatly constructed move after 13 minutes. Kevin Cooper's exhilarating run created the opening as he raced from the edge of his own area into the opposite one, leaving Gudni Bergsson and Mark Fish in his wake, before crossing to the unmarked Francis, who miskicked eight yards out.

This was a much-improved first-half display by County, looking for their first win since Boxing Day, a run that has seen them fall from a potential play-off side to relegation candidates.

Claus Jensen produced Bolton's only first-half chance, a 25-yard free-kick which Stockport's goalkeeper Carlo Nash deflected round his right-hand post with a competent dive.

Bolton, having weathered the best that County could throw at them, opened the second half in improved fashion, Dean Holdsworth connecting with a Paul Ritchie pass to lift an effort wide of the post.

An impressive 50-yard pass from Fish sent Eidur Gudjohnsen sprinting down the right, his cross eventually breaking for Jensen, whose shot from the edge of the area was deflected for a corner.

Bolton were in no doubt this was not their night when, later, Jensen's right-foot shot beat the wall and goalkeeper only to cannon off the bar.

webTitle: Here be dragons with their flags in a twist

fields.headline: Here be dragons with their flags in a twist
fields.trailText: When it comes to football, no one has pulled more eligibility stunts than Jack Charlton, former manager of the Republic of Ireland, who should be a Welsh Rugby Union consultant.
fields.body:
Strictly speaking, having searched in vain for my death certificate and failed to disentangle my grandmother from the twisted branches of the family tree, I am not sure whether I am eligible to write for you this morning.

Seriously, when was there anything so absurd as the eligibility crisis that has left the faces of Wales's rugby officials as red as their famous shirts?

The New Zealand-born pair of Shane Howarth and Brett Sinkinson, who have won 33 caps for Wales between them, have been banned until they can provide irrefutable evidence that they are qualified to wear the Wales jersey. They make Graeme Hick and Andrew Caddick, those uneasy giants of this country's cricket, appear as English as Mr Pickwick.

These are difficult times for those of us who have recently returned from England's protracted cricket tour of South Africa and Zimbabwe to discover, with dismay, that the king is dead, thrupenny bits are no longer legal tender and that friends and family need convincing you have not been banged up in chokey all the time.

It gets worse. After surveying the queendom afresh, with a view to getting back into the business of columnism, it is difficult not to come away with the impression that the world and his wife have lost their marbles.

It is bad enough reading about the disgraceful sacking of the Davis Cup captain David Lloyd and the latest adventures of Stan Collymore, not to mention the portrayal, in a German magazine, of David Beckham supposedly wearing stockings and suspenders.

The rugby tale, however, is the weirdest because it questions the essence of nationality, the very nature of identity. The full-back Howarth and flanker Sinkinson have been told they will not be selected again until the matter is sorted out.

This was not the end of the farce. When a third New Zealander, the Llanelli full-back Matt Cardey, was called up to play against Scotland on Saturday, his first cap, he turned up cheerfully clutching the death certificate of his grandmother, who was born in Nantyglo, Gwent.

It is only a couple of weeks since a number of British footballers were left bitterly disappointed because they could not represent the Cayman Islands. The Caymans, with an eye on the 2002 World Cup finals, attempted to exploit a Fifa-ratified ruling that allows any British player to turn out for any country that operates within Britain's jurisdiction.

They made formal approaches to 24 players, in the hope of finding eight, and were astonished to receive 22 positive replies, including one from Tranmere Rovers' captain Wayne Allison.

All this is not entirely new. We know of Czech tennis players who have taken out American citizenship and who fondly imagine they are no longer Czech. We all remember Jock Wilson, otherwise known as Bob, keeping goal for Scotland, and Taffy Jones, otherwise known as Vinnie, playing in midfield for Wales.

And, when it comes to football, no one has pulled more eligibility stunts than Jack Charlton, former manager of the Republic of Ireland, who should be a Welsh Rugby Union consultant.

Further back there are plenty of examples of sportsmen who have got their flags in a twist. Billy Murdoch, Albert Trott and Sammy Woods all managed to play Test cricket for England and Australia. The last, a colossus of a sportsman, also captained England at rugby and was an accomplished goalkeeper. And he still had time to chain-smoke cheroots and put away a bottle of whisky a day.

But these Victorian cricketers could hardly be accused of being mercenary. What we are seeing today is sportsmen who are prepared to sell their birthright and make a mockery of bizarre rules.

The question is, do we care? The tomfoolish suggestion that the England football coach should be able to select from those playing in England, foreigners included, was actually supported by some people.

Perhaps national sport will come to resemble the club game. Chelsea supporters have little difficulty in identifying with their side's exotic colourings. The shirt is becoming more important than the man inside. The colours are dominating the contents.

webTitle: United told to qualify in style

fields.headline: United told to qualify in style
fields.trailText: Manchester United ought to defeat Fiorentina at Old Trafford tonight to ensure their place in the quarter-finals with one Group B game to spare. Whether they can do it in a style to suggest they will successfully defend their European title remains to be seen.
fields.body:
Manchester United ought to defeat Fiorentina at Old Trafford tonight to ensure their place in the quarter-finals with one Group B game to spare. Whether they can do it in a style to suggest they will successfully defend their European title remains to be seen.

For much of the season United's football has been a mixture of the fitful and the fallible, at best sufficient rather than spectacular. Yet here they are, one win away from a place in the last eight of the Champions League and leading the Premiership by four points.

Sooner or later Sir Alex Ferguson's side will need to rediscover their higher gears and this evening would appear to be as good an occasion as any. Certainly Ferguson himself is under no illusions about how good his team will eventually need to be if the European Cup is to stay at Old Trafford.

"It's a big opportunity to be able to clinch a place in the quarter-finals of the Champions League and it would be a great achievement to do it with one game to spare," the manager said yesterday. "But I can't help feeling we're about to qualify the hard way.

"We could have had it all tied up before now if it hadn't been for our carelessness in Florence [where United lost 2-0 in November]. We also made it hard for ourselves on the way to a 2-1 win in Bordeaux last week. Our overall performance has left me feeling that we can do better, and I'm getting this feeling too often these days."

Ferguson's misgivings are not misplaced. Against Bordeaux, United gave away a soft goal through an elementary goalkeeping error by Raimond van der Gouw and although Roy Keane soon equalised they struggled for more than an hour against 10 men after Lilian Laslandes had been sent off.

Several times Bordeaux threatened to regain the lead before Ole Gunnar Solskjaer came on as a late substitute and won the match with an excellent piece of individualism seven minutes from the end.

fields.bodyText: Manchester United ought to defeat Fiorentina at Old Trafford tonight to ensure their place in the quarter-finals with one Group B game to spare. Whether they can do it in a style to suggest they will successfully defend their European title remains to be seen. For much of the season United's football has been a mixture of the fitful and the fallible, at best sufficient rather than spectacular. webTitle: Rampant Chelsea surge into last eight

fields.headline: Rampant Chelsea surge into last eight
fields.standfirst:
Kalou 59 | Zola 39, Wise 64, Flo 69
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Feyenoord 1 - 3 Chelsea
fields.body:
The magic seemed to have deserted Chelsea of late. But last night they conjured up their most convincing win of this tournament to take their place in the quarter-finals.

The scoreline, thanks to a rare goal from Gianfranco Zola, yet another from Dennis Wise and a stunner from Tore Andre Flo, did not flatter a side which dominated the game and now meet Lazio at home next week to decide who wins the group.

Gianluca Vialli's players had emerged on a cold, wet Rotterdam evening knowing they needed a much brighter performance against the Dutch champions than the two unconvincing displays against Marseille which had brought a defeat and a narrow victory.

Chelsea quickly stamped their authority in midfield and aided by clever running from the forwards, created enough chances to have taken a comfortable lead with them into the dressing room at half-time.

A late back injury suffered by the right-back Albert Ferrer had necessitated a slight Chelsea reshuffle, with Dan Petrescu dropping back from midfield and Roberto di Matteo coming in on the flank. But that only appeared to increase the visitors' attacking options.

It was from the Romanian's long pass that Chelsea took the lead six minutes from half-time. Although the ball was headed away by Bert Konterman it fell straight to Zola about 20 yards out.

The little Italian steadied himself and, as Ulrich van Gobbel closed in, unleashed a shot which flew in off the post. Jerzy Dudek in the Feyenoord goal stood rooted to the spot, seemingly unsighted by his own player. Zola jigged with delight. It was his first goal in open play since October 20.

It was no more than Chelsea's domination deserved, and should have made the scoreline 2-0. For after just eight minutes, Frank Leboeuf had missed a penalty, only the second of his long career.

It arrived after a brilliant through-pass from Wise had found Flo running into the home area where he was unceremoniously brought down by the defender Kees van Wonderen. But Leboeuf placed the spot-kick too close to Dudek who saved with relative ease.

It was one of a series of first-half saves made by the highly rated goalkeeper who had been forced to push away an early volley from Zola, after a one-two with Gustavo Poyet, and then on the half-hour tipped a Wise shot over the bar.

Minutes earlier Tomasz Rzasa had headed off the line from Poyet, who went close at the far post just before the break, Dudek again saving.

Feyenoord were nowhere as an attacking force and it was no surprise when they brought on the Ivory Coast striker Bonaventure Kalou at half-time despite doubts about his fitness. He became the striking partner for Julio Cruz, with the former Newcastle forward Jon Dahl Tomasson dropping back just behind the front two.

The attacking redesign, allied to a new zest and determination to press the man on the ball, paid speedy dividends for Feyenoord. Ed de Goey, whose main contribution until then had been acknowledging the home supporters' affectionate applause for their former player before kick-off, was suddenly under siege.

Cruz had already gone close when, on 58 minutes, the ball found its way to Rzasa on the left. The defender speared in a low cross and De Goey's touch only diverted the ball to Kalou, who scored easily.

Chelsea's reply could not have been more emphatic. Six minutes later Celestine Babayaro overlapped down the left, hoisted in a hanging cross which flew over a posse of players before reaching the unmarked head of Wise. The captain duly scored his third goal in three games.

Five minutes later Flo added a third, cutting into the area from the right past Van Wonderen and rifling an unstoppable shot into the far corner. Chelsea were through.

 Lazio moved into second place, a point above Feyenoord, with a 5-1 home win over Marseille. Simone Inzaghi scored their first four goals, including a 22-minute first-half hat-trick.

Feyenoord (4-4-2): Dudek; Van Gobbel, Konterman, Van Wonderen, Rzasa; Bosvelt, Van Gastel, Paauwe (Kalou, h-t), De Visser; Cruz, Tomasson.

Chelsea (4-4-2): De Goey; Petrescu, Desailly, Leboeuf, Babayaro; Di Matteo, Wise, Deschamps, Poyet (Morris, 76min); Zola (Ambrosetti, 90), Flo.

Referee: K Fisker (Den).

fields.headline: Manchester United 3 - 1 Fiorentina
fields.trailText:
Manchester United: Bosnich, G. Neville, Berg, Stam, Irwin, Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs, Yorke, Cole.
Substitutes: Van Der Gouw, Butt, Sheringham, P. Neville, Solskjaer, Fortune, Silvestre.
fields.body:
Manchester United: Bosnich, G. Neville, Berg, Stam, Irwin, Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs, Yorke, Cole.
Substitutes: Van Der Gouw, Butt, Sheringham, P. Neville, Solskjaer, Fortune, Silvestre.

Fiorentina: Toldo, Repka, Adani, Pierlini, Torricelli, Di Livio, Rossitto, Rui Costa, Heinrich, Batistuta, Mijatovic.
Substitutes: Taglialatela, Fircano, Okon, Chiesa, Bressan, Amoroso, Tarozzi.

Referee: Ryszard Wojcik (Poland)

United start with pretty much their strongest line-up. Yorke has rediscovered his goal-scoring touch. Both him and Cole can expect good service from Beckham and Giggs. Fiorentina will be pinning their hopes on Portuguese playmaker Rui Costa feeding Batistuta. The Argentine may well be seeing much more of Old Trafford next season...

1 min A slightly delayed start after some floodlight shenanigans. United are one win away from a quarter-final berth. Beckham has an early chance from the centre-left, 35 yards out. The ball falls inviting at the far post but Fiorentina manage to clear.
3 Gary Neville takes his eyes off Batistuta for a second and the Argentine international is able to fashion a strike from 25 yards on the left. The effort hits the side netting - an early sign of what this player is capable of.
5 A great chance for the visitors as Rui Costa is sent through one-on-one with Bosnich. The Australian keeper does enough and smothers the shot. The follow-up challenge is deemed illegal and United clear from the free-kick. The home side are still asleep at the back.
7 Fiorentina are very eager to press forward. Heinrich races down the left wing and forces a good challenge from Neville. United are having trouble getting their feet on the ball in this opening spell.
9 Giggs's determination in a tussle with Repka pays off as the ball runs his way. The Welshman squares to Cole on the left edge of the box. His control buys him enough space to shoot across the face of Toldo's goal, and the keeper's parry falls at Yorke's feet but the ball gets stuck underneath him and Pierlini is able to clear.
12 Andy Cole does all the hard work on the left. On reaching the by-line the cross is delivered to the far post where Beckham rises and somehow fails to make a telling contact into an empty net. Lots of United pressure after a shaky start.
14 Ryan Giggs recalls his FA Cup semi-final goal against Arsenal last year, turning two defenders on the left before pulling the ball back for Roy Keane, who slices his shot and manages to hit a defender's head.
16 Goal: Manchester United 0 - 1 Fiorentina United should sign this guy purely to stop him scoring against them. Batistuta takes two touches before unleashing a wickedly swerving shot from 25 yards that beats Bosnich with pure venom. An excellent strike that gives United a challenge to rise to.
19 Goal: Manchester United 1 - 1 Fiorentina Andy Cole drags United level with a goal of real class. Beckham's pass is chested down 5 yards outside the visitors' area. A smooth turn-and-shoot whistles through Repka's legs and beats Toldo at his right-hand post. This match could develop into a classic encounter. Cole has equalled the club record for European goals, drawing level with Denis Law on fourteen.
23 Heinrich almost profits from some head-tennis in the United area, but Beckham is back and clears for a Fiorentina throw from the right. United are able to regain possession.
26 United are enjoying good penetration down both flanks. Yorke spins away down the right and his lay-off is met by a deep cross by Beckham. No United players are able to meet the centre and Repka clears. There are more goals to come in this game.
29 A corner to Fiorentina from the left, to be taken by Rui Costa. The cross is hit towards the near post and Batistuta is able to manage the flick but Bosnich manages to save and hold.
30 Bosnich's clearance finds Cole on the left-centre edge of the Fiorentina area. After riding two challenges, he tries a clever chip that has Toldo racing backwards to tip the effort over the bar. The corner is a disappointment in comparison.
32 Goal: Manchester United 2 - 1 Fiorentina Another United corner from Beckham on the right. A deep centre is met by Henning Berg who directs his header to Toldo's far post. The keeper is stranded and can only watch as Berg's header cannons off the bar and falls to Keane, who winds up and crashes the ball into the roof of the net from 10 yards. A great finish made to look easy when it was anything but.
34 Fiorentina look a little shell-shocked after the events of the previous fifteen minutes. Beckham springs an 'energetic' challenge on Di Livio and is booked for his efforts - he will miss the Valencia game next week which may well turn out to be an academic fixture.
37 Heinrich reacts badly to a late challenge from Beckham and resorts to some shirt-pulling. The ref has his eye on matters and lets it go. Beckham is bundled over on the next move by the same man and again the referee exercises restraint. The England international has to watch it as he's the one on the yellow.
41 Di Livio tries a speculative effort from 30 yards out in a central position. Stam and Berg dropped off him almost offering him the chance of a pop at Bosnich. He doesn't disappoint, spooning the ball into the crowd well wide of the goal.
43 United are moving the ball around well, with Roy Keane the lynchpin. Cole is exuding confidence and dropping deep to pick up the ball and take on Torricelli, who is having a torrid night dealing with the United frontman in addition to Giggs.
46 A great first half comes to an end with United well on top and Fiorentina looking dangerous on the break. More goals look a certainty for the second half.

45 Can both sides maintain the tempo and standard of play shown in the first half? Fiorentina restart the match.
46 Beckham a little casual as he loses possession to Heinrich on the left. His centre is met by Mijatovic, who hits his volley high into the Stretford End. Some accusing glances are directed at Beckham.
47 Rui Costa cuts in from the left after receiving the ball fairly deep and his effort from 25 yards centre-left is well struck but straight at Bosnich.
50 Giggs all the way again from the right wing this time, cutting into the centre, beating and outpacing one, two, three defenders before blazing his shot high over Toldo's bar.
55 A brilliant move by Keane and Beckham who combine on the right. The cross from Beckham finds Giggs. His header deflects off Repka for a corner. The centre from Beckham on the right is punched out unconvincingly by Toldo. Berg scuffs his opportunity and eventually Toldo is able to collect and clear.
60 A free header from Batistuta from a Rui Costa corner on the left that is almost too easy for the Argentine. His effort at the near post is horribly wide and he knows it was a great chance as for once United's marking was slack.
62 Sent off: Rossitto (Serious foul play). An X-rated 'challenge' on the back of Yorke's right leg earns the Italian his marching orders. Fiorentina have it all to do.
63 Fiorentina substitution: Chiesa for Mijatovic.
66 A corner to Fiorentina. Chiesa takes from the right but the delivery is poor. United clear and break through Yorke, who feeds Beckham on the right touchline. A trademark cross is aimed at Cole and Toldo does well to intercept the centre.
68 Giggs accelerates away from the half-way line until he is upended by Adani 25 yards from goal. The defender is booked and will miss the next game.
69 Beckham drives the ball into the Fiorentina wall, and the rebound is distributed to Scholes, who drives low and gains a corner off Repka.
70 Goal: Manchester United 3 - 1 Fiorentina The goals are shared out as Dwight Yorke puts his name on the scoresheet. Beckham's corner from the right is overhit and Giggs returns the ball from the left to the far post. Yorke rises and heads across Toldo into the far corner of the goal.
73 United rip into Fiorentina again as Keane takes the ball all the way down the left wing. He squares to Scholes, who scuffs his shot. Di Livio and Keane contest a 50-50 ball a little too intensely for the referee's liking. Fiorentina clear from the free kick.
75 Fiorentina substitution: Tarozzi for Toricelli; Amoroso for Di Livio.
77 Free kick to United from the left. Beckham takes and Toldo palms it way for a throw from the right. United build again. The home side are content to keep possession whilst Fiorentina have to chase the game with ten men.
80 The ball is threaded through to Cole on the right, who drills a low shot at Toldo from 20 yards at the right apex of the area. Toldo blocks with his chest and Adani tidies up.
82 United string ten, fifteen passes together before Dwight Yorke has his shot deflected off for a corner. The centre is played out to Scholes, who strikes a drive off Rui Costa for another corner. Nothing comes of the set piece.
85 A free-kick to United from the right, won after Tarozzi got tired of hearing the olés echoing round the ground following the home side's every touch. The set piece is wasted but United pick up possession easily after a poor Fiorentina clearance.
87 An opening appears for Giggs on the left side of the area. With Toldo to beat from 20 yards, his left-foot shot is dragged wide of the right-hand upright. The crowd want four and are disappointed.
90 The fourth official displays a wholly unnecessary three extra minutes to be played. Full time: Manchester United 3 - 1 Fiorentina.

Nothing comes of the set piece. 85 A free-kick to United from the right, won after Tarozzi got tired of hearing the olés echoing round the ground following the home side's every touch. The set piece is wasted but United pick up possession easily after a poor Fiorentina clearance. 87 An opening appears for Giggs on the left side of the area. With Toldo to beat from 20 yards, his left-foot shot is dragged wide of the right-hand upright. The crowd want four and are disappointed. 90 The fourth official displays a wholly unnecessary three extra minutes to be played. Full time: Manchester United 3 - 1 Fiorentina.

webTitle: Warne wraps up victory and record

fields.headline: Warne wraps up victory and record
fields.trailText: Leg-spinner Shane Warne became Australia's greatest wicket-taker in Test history with his 356th dismissal on the final day of the first Test against New Zealand at Eden Park in Auckland. Warne dismissed tailender Paul Wiseman to pass fast bowler Dennis Lillee's 16-year-old record of 355 as the tourists clinched victory by 62 runs.
fields.body:
Leg-spinner Shane Warne became Australia's greatest wicket-taker in Test history with his 356th dismissal on the final day of the first Test against New Zealand at Eden Park in Auckland. Warne dismissed tailender Paul Wiseman to pass fast bowler Dennis Lillee's 16-year-old record of 355 as the tourists clinched victory by 62 runs.

Warne had to take a back seat to fellow spinner Colin Miller, who took career best Test figures of 5-55, but finished with 2-80 off 20.3 overs as the Kiwis crumbled to 218 all out in their second innings.

Wiseman went to sweep, got a top edge off his glove for wicketkeeper Adam Gilchrist to take an easy catch and give Warne the Australian record. The record came in 30-year-old Warne's 82nd Test match.

Earlier in the day, Craig McMillan had continued his bid to inspire New Zealand to victory after the fourth day's play had been abandoned due to rain.

fields.headline: Reversing the exodus
fields.standfirst: Why is a charity, famed for its work on poverty, backing private landlords?  Richard Best  explains the change
fields.trailText: Why is a charity, famed for its work on poverty, backing private landlords? Richard Best explains the change.
fields.body:
People know the Joseph Rowntree Foundation for its studies into poverty and social problems throughout this century. But in its latest venture - the Caspar developments in Birmingham and Leeds - it is putting millions of pounds into shiny new apartments designed to help only those who can pay full market rents. So what is going on? Shouldn't the JRF be concentrating on people who could never pay the Caspar rents of £100-plus per week?

The environmentalists certainly applaud high density construction in inner-city areas. Building here saves the greenfield sites beyond the suburbs. And short journeys to work mean less traffic congestion and pollution from commuters. But although we recognise the unsustainability of urban sprawl and the global consequences of increasing C02 emissions from cars, these are not the foundation's primary concerns.

Some argue for a revival of private renting - the UK is completely out of step with Europe and the US - to meet the growing needs of single people not yet ready to settle and buy, or divorced and not in a position to take on extra financial commitments. And flexibility in the employment market means more job mobility and uncertainty - which makes renting a sensible option.

Although small numbers of trendy apartments for sale are now coming on to the market, they are out of the reach of those whose incomes disqualify them for social housing but for whom home ownership is not sensible or not affordable at these prices. The Caspar projects should reveal the extent of this unmet demand.

Since the JRF is acting here as an investor, not a donor, the projects should demonstrate to other investors that the time has come for a new style private rented sector. These totally unsubsidised developments can show a decent return - 6.2% indexed, plus capital growth - so the pension funds, insurance companies and others who have put billions into office blocks may be persuaded to consider investing in the new rented sector. Major investment in these rented homes would certainly ease other housing pressures.

But even this is not the most important consideration for the JRF. Its central concern relates to the widening gaps between richer and poorer, increasingly expressed in geographical terms. Outside London, those who are able to have been moving away from our older industrial centres, leaving behind increasing concentrations of those on the lowest incomes - often living in council or housing association property. Tens of thousands of flats and houses in our northern cities are hard to let or empty, with rapid turnover and disintegration of community life.

But it is not true that those who have left the northern conurbations have gone to live in the south-east: they have simply moved out of the major towns and cities. While the four northern regions together have been losing just 13,500 people annually ("net outward migration"), their six largest conurbations have been losing over 50,000 people each year.

Most of the JRF's efforts on the regeneration side go to supporting ideas for neighbourhood management, greater involvement by local people, action for children and young people, ways of overcoming financial exclusion, better targeted and joined up local services, etc. But it is hard to create vibrant communities when the most common aspiration is to get out.

If the urban exodus is to be reversed - if there is really to be an "urban renaissance", as Lord Rogers and his urban task force hope - then the fashion, the perception, the image of city living must change. Something has to attract and retain economically active people who are in a position to choose where they go.

Cities will be regenerated by the people who live there. The hundreds of thousands of single person households that will be formed over the next 25 years - most with middle range incomes - are not so much a threat to the countryside of England as the potential salvation for the inner city.

Single people are less bothered about schools and child safety. They are likely to work hard and play hard, making cities the places to be. And the urban ghettos of the US tell us what happens when down-town neighbourhoods only comprise the poorest and most disadvantaged: services become overloaded, good neighbourliness is overwhelmed, crime and violence can get out of hand.

Attracting middle income renters, through creating accommodation to suit today's lifestyles, just might turn the tide and stop the city flight. The environmental and economic benefits are bonuses. The real success for the JRF's surprising investment in market renting would come from attracting that spread of incomes and skills which regenerates the social fabric of our cities.

 Richard Best is director of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

webTitle: Morgan to open up Welsh cabinet minutes

fields.headline: Morgan to open up Welsh cabinet minutes
fields.trailText: March 15 2000: Minutes of the Welsh assembly cabinet are to be put on the internet within six weeks of the meeting, in the most radical move to open up government in the United Kingdom since Labour came to power.
fields.body:
Minutes of the Welsh assembly cabinet are to be put on the internet within six weeks of the meeting, in the most radical move to open up government in the United Kingdom since Labour came to power.

The move by Rhodri Morgan, the first minister, will put fresh pressure on Jack Straw, the home secretary, to make new concessions when his freedom of information bill comes back to the House of Commons for further debate.

Tony Wright, Labour chairman of the Commons public administration committee, who is planning to table amendments to the bill, said last night: "It signals an important cultural change. It is exactly what I would expect from Rhodri who is a breath of fresh air over these issues."

Mr Morgan's decision, to be announced to the assembly today, opens up a huge gulf between the release of information in different parts of the UK. In England the home secretary is insisting that much government information will remain a state secret for 30 years.

Scotland will be more open, with a bill to go through their parliament to allow the publication of policy advice on Scotish affairs.

But Wales will now go a step further - with the publication of cabinet minutes and a pledge for all Welsh bodies, including quangos, to go for "maximum voluntary disclosure".

Mr Morgan said there was no need for legislation to implement the change. "Since Wales has no responsibility for foreign affairs, defence or security I see no problem in releasing information. We are not interested in standards laid down by Whitehall - we are looking for international standards laid down under the United States and Irish freedom of information acts."

Last night a home office spokeswoman said there was nothing in Mr Straw's bill that would prevent Mr Morgan from taking such action.

 Labour was plunged into further turmoil in Wales yesterday when the party on Cardiff council suspended eight councillors after they voted against huge increases in members' allowances. The Cardiff rebels had protested at rises which made Russell Goodway, leader and lord mayor of Cardiff council, the highest-paid councillor in Britain on £58,500 a year.

fields.headline: Legal maze
fields.standfirst: Geoffrey Gibbs  on how Wales could stop commercial GM crops in the UK before they get off the ground
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Gibbs on how Wales could stop commercial GM crops in the UK before they get off the ground.
fields.body:
As the government prepares this week to unveil details of proposed farmscale trials of three GM crops across the UK, pressure is mounting on the Labour administration in Wales to strike a first blow in the campaign to turn the country into a GM-free zone.

The move could put the devolved administration in conflict with Westminster and poses a tricky dilemma for the Welsh agriculture secretary, Christine Gwyther, who may be damned from Downing Street if she does and will be damned in Wales if she doesn't.

At the heart of the issue is an application by the biotech company, Aventis, for its T25 forage maize to be included on the UK national seed list. Approval is the final regulatory barrier to be crossed before seeds can be grown commercially. And although the biotech industry has agreed a moratorium on commercial growing until farm-scale trials have been completed and assessed in 2003, campaigners believe it is vital to take a stand and block the application now.

They claim that Wales, where feelings against GM trials run high, has an effective veto because the application has to be approved jointly by ministers in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

The decision rests in the hands of Gwyther, who less than six months ago was censured by opposition members of the national assembly over her handling of the crisis affecting the farming industry in Wales.

Members of the assembly's agriculture and rural affairs committee - on which Labour is in a minority - have been given the opportunity to debate the matter and offer advice because of what the agriculture secretary has acknowledged is the widespread public interest in GM issues. Gwyther herself is known to believe that Wales would benefit from being able to present itself to the world as a GM-free area. But she has warned the committee that her decision has to be made on a lawful basis.

Although initial legal advice from the office of the counsel general suggested there were no legal grounds on which to refuse the Aventis application, Gwyther has agreed to defer her decision until the agriculture committee has had the opportunity to study legal submissions from Friends of the Earth, which challenges that opinion. The committee, which has signalled that it favours blocking the application, is also keen to study further scientific papers and will meet again at the end of this month to deliver its advice.

Gwyther is not bound to accept the committee's recommendation, but overriding it is certain to stir up a storm of protest both within the assembly and without.

"The reaction would be very hostile," says Gordon James, head of campaigns for Friends of the Earth Cymru. "It would fuel the feeling that the assembly is simply rubber stamping what Blair wants. There would be extreme concern and anger that the voice of the elected representatives of Wales is not being listened to and that we are caving into Westminster."

According to Gwyther, T25 maize, which was targeted by protesters during trials in England last summer, has already received health and environmental clearances and has completed trials showing it meets the criteria of suitability for agricultural cultivation.

But FoE Cymru claims the risk assessment processes under which the GM maize gained approval two years ago are no longer considered adequate either by the UK goverment or by the EU. "This maize is intended for cattle, yet there have been no safety assessments for animals eating GM feed," says the organisation's GM campaigner, Raoul Bhambral. "It's shocking that we don't seem to have learned from the last animal feed scare."

The group has sought to add weight to its campaign in Wales by taking independent legal advice, which, it argues, confirms that the national assembly has the power to refuse consent for a GM crop if it is unable to conclude with confidence that the crop would not harm human health or the environment and provided it remains prepared to consider representations to the contrary. A spokesman for the agriculture secretary confirmed it would be considered carefully, in conjunction with other advice, before Gwyther makes her decision.

Whichever way that goes, she can expect to face flak and a legal challenge from the disappointed parties. As she has discovered since being propelled into the cabinet by the former first secretary, Alun Michael, the position of agriculture secretary is one of the hottest political potatoes around.

webTitle: The Third Woman: The Secret Passion That Inspired The End Of The Affair by William Cash

fields.headline: The Third Woman: The Secret Passion That Inspired The End Of The Affair by William Cash
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss assesses the critical reaction to William Cash's tale of the affair between Graham Greene and Catherine Walston
Buy The Third Woman at BOL
fields.trailText: William Cash v the critics has been one of the most entertaining literary battles for years, and could be the template for future set-tos. Cash was so irritated by the panning of his book on the affair between Graham Greene and Catherine Walston, The Third Woman: The Secret Passion That Inspired The End Of The Affair (Little, Brown, £14.99), that he has set up a website dedicated to rubbishing his tormentors. It is undignified, mildly bonkers and highly entertaining.
fields.body:
William Cash v the critics has been one of the most entertaining literary battles for years, and could be the template for future set-tos. Cash was so irritated by the panning of his book on the affair between Graham Greene and Catherine Walston, The Third Woman: The Secret Passion That Inspired The End Of The Affair (Little, Brown, £14.99), that he has set up a website dedicated to rubbishing his tormentors. It is undignified, mildly bonkers and highly entertaining.

Ian Hamilton, in the Sunday Telegraph, elegantly set the scene: "Both Greene and Walston were married to other people when they met. Greene indeed had a wife, a long-serving mistress and a prostitute-friend who liked him well enough to call him up at home from time to time. Walston, for her part, was a diligent seducer and had a small troupe of admirers at her beck and call. During her time with Greene - which lasted, at full pitch, for something like four years - she was also conducting affairs with a Labour MP, an American general and an IRA chieftain. And on the side, so to put it, she dallied enthusiastically with several priests. Like Greene, Walston was a Catholic convert, and priests, it seems, were her absolutely favourite sex toys." So far, so fascinating, but there was a sting: "Cash's overall portrayal adds almost nothing to the versions we already have. And Walston, in spite of this biographer's exertions, remains fairly mysterious: as shadowy and implausible, it could be said, as Sarah Miles, the heroine of Greene's novel. But then William Cash is no biographer: his narrative is disorganised, his writing is clumsily pretentious, and he is forever pushing himself forward in one or another thoroughly ill-fitting guise... The trouble is that the tale he has to tell is simply not book-length, and he knows it. To pad things out, he jaws on about himself and about how much work he has had to put into this project, as if we should all thank him for doing us a wondrous favour. Well, we don't."

Susannah Herbert, in the Daily Telegraph, was equally dismissive: "Cash's rootlings in the archives have turned up a few new details of the lovers' shared life - he says the two exchanged marriage vows in Tunbridge Wells and that Catherine was once sexually aroused by the thought of St Therese of Lisieux - but these seem comically slight when set against the grand claims he makes for his quest. In truth, Cash brings little to the party but a puppyish enthusiasm and an unintentionally hilarious tendency to identify himself with Greene, both as writer and lover."

David Sexton, in the London Evening Standard, mocked Cash's life-into-literature pretensions: "The Third Woman, Cash says, is not just "an investigation into one of the most remarkable secret love affairs this century", it is also "an enquiry into the creative debt that literature owes to adultery". One of his tutors at Cambridge, Tony Tanner, wrote a study of Adultery and the Novel. Cash has simplified his argument into a belief that adultery is a kind of literary fertiliser. Adultery, he says sagely, "can be bad for marriage but good for literature". Indeed, he talks of it with such wholehearted enthusiasm, you might be forgiven for thinking that not only must all novelists be adulterers, but all adulterers must perforce turn novelist."

Humphrey Carpenter, in the Sunday Times, could evidently have done with more of Greene and less of Cash: "Cash belongs to the regrettably growing school of biography that believes that the author should intrude himself into the narrative as often as possible. "This book is a detective investigation," he announces at the outset, and goes on to describe himself (with a deliberate echo of another Greene book) as "a burnt-out journalist" looking for a subject after failing to write a novel: "My career needed a fresh narrative, a new plot turn." In fact, for all his "detection", he tells us little new or of significance about the affair."

By far the most hostile review (quite a palm) was by Oliver Walston ("a farmer and writer") in the Independent, but this was only to be expected as Walston is Catherine's son and has been conducting a spirited multi-media defence of his mother. Walston did not mince his words. "This is an unpleasant little book written hurriedly and carelessly to cash in on Neil Jordan's film of The End of the Affair. It is badly written, pretentious, inaccurate, trivial, salacious and, above all, tawdry." Cash in - geddit? "The only seriously interesting piece of information which Cash claims to have discovered," wrote Walston, "is that Graham and my mother were married in a Catholic church. Well, not quite married, but sort of. Well, they took vows. Well, maybe they didn't. Well, maybe there was no priest actually present. The only thing Cash is certain of is that the site of the church is today occupied by a supermarket."

The quote you are most likely to see on any future edition will be from the reliably idiosyncratic A N Wilson, who, in his Evening Standard column, called it a "succinct masterpiece", though there may have been a degree of Greene-loathing in his judgment ("Why people esteem Greene, as a man or a writer, is now even more mysterious to me").

Cash's website contains his critique of each of his critics. He shows particular contempt for Ms Herbert. "Herbert displays her embarrassingly obvious lack of intellectual qualification to write about Graham Greene by reliably informing Telegraph readers that the results of my year of research across America and Europe are "comically slight"". thunders Cash. "She has no idea what she is talking about... Herbert's aggrieved and inaccurate review is a feeble effort to distort and falsify the record. Moreover, if the results of my investigation were so "slight", why did the Daily Telegraph make a not insubstantial offer to serialise The Third Woman?... Herbert should stick to covering parties."

David Sexton also seems to have got under his skin: "The aggrieved and bleating tone of his lazy prose clearly reveals itself as a deliberately malicious effort to falsify and distort the remarkable amount of original new material and evidence I have unearthed in the book. His sixth-form style effort at a hatchet job is done with the intellectual wit of a chaffinch."

On and on he goes, flailing in all directions. The point about papers bidding for the serial rights of books they then trash is misplaced (often a rotten book can make a decent extract, and in any case rights buyers and reviewers are entirely - and happily - separate). As for the critics, they are more likely to be flattered than stung by his admonitions. Admirable though his spirit may be, his cause is hopeless: ultimately he only succeeds in making himself look bitter and foolish. But who knows - this may be the shape of things to come, the start of internet-based critical catfights.

 William Cash's website is at www.williamcash.com

David Sexton, in the London Evening Standard, mocked Cash's life-into-literature pretensions: "The Third Woman, Cash says, is not just "an investigation into one of the most remarkable secret love affairs this century", it is also "an enquiry into the creative debt that literature owes to adultery". One of his tutors at Cambridge, Tony Tanner, wrote a study of Adultery and the Novel. Cash has simplified his argument into a belief that adultery is a kind of literary fertiliser. Adultery, he says sagely, "can be bad for marriage but good for literature". Indeed, he talks of it with such wholehearted enthusiasm, you might be forgiven for thinking that not only must all novelists be adulterers, but all adulterers must perforce turn novelist." Humphrey Carpenter, in the Sunday Times, could evidently have done with more of Greene and less of Cash: "Cash belongs to the regrettably growing school of biography that believes that the author should intrude himself into the narrative as often as possible. "This book is a detective investigation," he announces at the outset, and goes on to describe himself (with a deliberate echo of another Greene book) as "a burnt-out journalist" looking for a subject after failing to write a novel: "My career needed a fresh narrative, a new plot turn." In fact, for all his "detection", he tells us little new or of significance about the affair." By far the most hostile review (quite a palm) was by Oliver Walston ("a farmer and writer") in the Independent, but this was only to be expected as Walston is Catherine's son and has been conducting a spirited multi-media defence of his mother. Walston did not mince his words. "This is an unpleasant little book written hurriedly and carelessly to cash in on Neil Jordan's film of The End of the Affair. It is badly written, pretentious, inaccurate, trivial, salacious and, above all, tawdry." Cash in - geddit? "The only seriously interesting piece of information which Cash claims to have discovered," wrote Walston, "is that Graham and my mother were married in a Catholic church. Well, not quite married, but sort of. Well, they took vows. Well, maybe they didn't. Well, maybe there was no priest actually present. The only thing Cash is certain of is that the site of the church is today occupied by a supermarket." The quote you are most likely to see on any future edition will be from the reliably idiosyncratic A N Wilson, who, in his Evening Standard column, called it a "succinct masterpiece", though there may have been a degree of Greene-loathing in his judgment ("Why people esteem Greene, as a man or a writer, is now even more mysterious to me"). Cash's website contains his critique of each of his critics. He shows particular contempt for Ms Herbert. "Herbert displays her embarrassingly obvious lack of intellectual qualification to write about Graham Greene by reliably informing Telegraph readers that the results of my year of research across America and Europe are "comically slight"". thunders Cash. "She has no idea what she is talking about... Herbert's aggrieved and inaccurate review is a feeble effort to distort and falsify the record. Moreover, if the results of my investigation were so "slight", why did the Daily Telegraph make a not insubstantial offer to serialise The Third Woman?... Herbert should stick to covering parties." David Sexton also seems to have got under his skin: "The aggrieved and bleating tone of his lazy prose clearly reveals itself as a deliberately malicious effort to falsify and distort the remarkable amount of original new material and evidence I have unearthed in the book. His sixth-form style effort at a hatchet job is done with the intellectual wit of a chaffinch." On and on he goes, flailing in all directions. The point about papers bidding for the serial rights of books they then trash is misplaced (often a rotten book can make a decent extract, and in any case rights buyers and reviewers are entirely - and happily - separate). As for the critics, they are more likely to be flattered than stung by his admonitions. Admirable though his spirit may be, his cause is hopeless: ultimately he only succeeds in making himself look bitter and foolish. But who knows - this may be the shape of things to come, the start of internet-based critical catfights.  William Cash's website is at www.williamcash.com

webTitle: Peers vote to end ballots at grammar schools

fields.headline: Peers vote to end ballots at grammar schools
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government was defeated in the Lords last night when peers narrowly pushed through a Tory move to block any further parental ballots at grammar schools.
fields.body:
The government was defeated in the Lords last night when peers narrowly pushed through a Tory move to block any further parental ballots at grammar schools.

There was further embarassment, underlining deep rifts within Labour over selection in schools, when the party's former deputy leader, Lord Hattersley, suggested that the ballot mechanism was prejudiced and inequitable, and attacked the education secretary, David Blunkett, for appearing to drop his opposition to selection.

Mr Blunkett's weekend statement that he wanted to "draw a line" under the selection row undermined the entire credibility of the government in its pursuit of a coherent education policy, claimed Lord Hattersley.

Peers voted by a slender majority of 166 to 161 to back an amendment, to an unrelated education bill, to end balloting of parents of pupils at grammar schools on whether they wished to take their school into the comprehensive system.

Last Friday, in the first grammar vote since the government introduced the policy, parents chose two to one to preserve selection at Ripon grammar school in North Yorkshire.

At the weekend Mr Blunkett appeared in an interview to indicate government reluctance to continue opposing selection.

However, the education minister, Lady Blackstone, last night made clear that the Tory amendment made to the learning and skills bill at its report stage would be reversed when the bill returned to the Commons.

While Tories claimed they were seeking to protect grammar schools from a "pernicious war of attrition", there are in fact no other ballots imminent, since the opponents of selection have yet to collect sufficient signatures from protesting parents at other grammar schools to trigger one.

Lady Blatch, the Tory education spokesman, told peers that when the government introduced the system of gathering signatures to trigger ballots to determine the fate of grammar schools "it was obvious that a relentless and pernicious war of attrition would be unleashed on these schools".

Lord Hattersley, insisting that the ballots must continue, nevertheless underlined the rifts in his party when he argued that the formula was "rigged" in favour of the status quo, since the fate of such schools was being determined only by parents with a pre-existing stake in them - a situation "so prejudiced as to be ridiculous".

He warned the government that if it "continues to develop a reputation for rigging ballots it may pay a terrible price if an election comes along which it can't fix before polling.

"The government needs to demonstrate its integrity on this matter, and its integrity is not underlined or emphasised when the secretary of state himself says he is glad the situation is now closed in Ripon, and he does not want to see an end to the grammar schools."

Lord Hattersley said that Mr Blunkett's statement that he wanted to draw a line under the matter "undermines the entire credibility of this government in its pursuit of a coherent education policy".

Ripon Campaign for State Education

Ripon Grammar School

webTitle: Hague calls Blair 'liar' on tax pledge

fields.headline: Hague calls Blair 'liar' on tax pledge
fields.trailText: Tory leader William Hague today described Labour's electoral promises as a "bare-faced lie", following Downing Street's admission yesterday that the tax burden had risen under Labour.
fields.body:
Tory leader William Hague today described Labour's electoral promises as a "bare-faced lie", following Downing Street's admission yesterday that the tax burden had risen under Labour.

During prime minister's question time, Mr Hague repeatedly charged the prime minister with having "systematically and deliberately" broken pre-election promises not to raise taxes.

"Before the election you promised that you had no plans to increase tax. Yesterday your press secretary [Alastair Campbell] said the government had increased taxes," Mr Hague said. "Will you admit that Labour's promises were a bare-faced election lie?"

Mr Blair replied: "I certainly won't. We promised we would not raise the basic, standard or higher rates of income tax and we kept that promise. For the first two years the government's duty was to cut the huge deficit we inherited.

"This financial year, however, the tax burden falls and does again next year. Future years obviously depend on budget decisions.

"We inherited a national debt double [what it is today], a borrowing requirement of £28bn. When we came to office we were paying more on interest payments on that debt than we were spending on the whole of the schools system of the UK."

Attacking the Tories' "tax guarantee" and Mr Hague's moral case for cutting taxes, he added: "If we were now to go back down the road you are proposing we would end up with cuts in public services, taxes going up and boom and bust."

Mr Hague replied: "What is moral about breaking promises and delivering worse public services? This is the government that taxes more and delivers less.

"You said you had no plans to increase tax at all," Mr Hague continued. "Was that a joke? Was it another rib-tickler from the education secretary? You said: 'Our proposals do not involve raising taxes' - August 1996. 'We want people to pay lower taxes' - September 1996. 'The programme of the Labour Party does not imply any tax increases' - January 1997.

"It wasn't a joke. It was systematic, dishonest and deliberately misleading," Mr Hague said.

As one unidentified Tory shouted "liar", Mr Blair rejected the Tory leader's charges. He said again that he made no apologies for using the first two years to get rid of the budget deficit. "Now the tax burden is falling, this year and again next year. For the first time in decades the economy has slowed without a recession.

"Debt repayments - £4 billion less this year, money that goes to public services. Interest rates - half of what they were for years under the Tories; 800,000 more jobs; higher living standards; more take home pay. We are proud of our economic record."

fields.headline: Body Shop sees net future
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Body Shop founder Anita Roddick is working on dot.com plans to boost sales. The retail empire whose name is synonymous with social and environmental activism as well as with fruit-scented shampoo and wooden back-massagers yesterday announced plans to cash in on its global brand name.
fields.body:
Body Shop founder Anita Roddick is working on dot.com plans to boost sales. The retail empire whose name is synonymous with social and environmental activism as well as with fruit-scented shampoo and wooden back-massagers yesterday announced plans to cash in on its global brand name.

Ms Roddick said she believed that Body Shop was well placed to win new business from internet shoppers.

She said: "What is exciting about e-commerce for us when we do it, is that we are such a well known brand and very little will have to go into the marketing of that."

Ms Roddick also laid out plans for a new Body Shop publishing business - with publications focusing on health and beauty alongside books by herself on issues that interest her. She is also considering the setting up of a venture with an eco-travel agency which could link with its community projects in countries such as India.

Body Shop was a hot stock of the early 1990s, when its shares changed hands at more than 350p. But they have been underperformers ever since. The chain had a bad year last year when its profits plunged from £38m to just £3.4m, but its fortunes have been improving under the guidance of chief operating officer Patrick Gournay.

First-half profits climbed 4% to £9.4m and the company is expected to deliver full year earnings of around £31m.

Yesterday Mr Gournay said the store's performance would be "on target" and underlined Ms Roddick's commitment to go dot.com. "The multi-channel strategy is something we absolutely have to go for if we want to meet our customers where they are," he said.

He predicted e-commerce and Body Shop Direct - the company's home sales business - would represent a significant portion of the company's business in the future. The shares were little moved by the e-tailing plans, closing down at 105p.

fields.headline: Child support
fields.standfirst: What should the chancellor do? Vote now
fields.trailText: The government announced last December that it plans to wrap all the existing means-tested child support benefits into one exciting new bundle, called an integrated child credit. It will take in payments made for children to families on  job-seekers allowance, income support and the working families tax credit. Confusingly, the only payment which won't be included in the ICC is child benefit which is paid to all families regardless of income.
fields.body:
The government announced last December that it plans to wrap all the existing means-tested child support benefits into one exciting new bundle, called an integrated child credit. It will take in payments made for children to families on job-seekers allowance, income support and the working families tax credit. Confusingly, the only payment which won't be included in the ICC is child benefit which is paid to all families regardless of income.

The new benefit is supposed to make the whole complex system of support for children in low income families, simpler to understand. It will be paid to the main carer - in most cases, mothers - which anti-poverty groups have hailed as a breakthrough because surveys show women spend more of their income on their children than men do, who are more likely to spend extra money on themselves.

So far, the government has not promised any extra money for low income families with children. But as part of the launch of the ICC, and given their pledge to eradicate child poverty within a generation, it is a tempting target for the Chancellor this Budget.

webTitle: Why I had to leave the police

fields.headline: Why I had to leave the police
fields.standfirst: Ike Eze-Anyika admired the police service when he joined up. Now he's written a book exposing the racism he believes is rife within the Met - especially in the canteen
fields.trailText: Ike Eze-Anyika admired the police service when he joined up. Now he's written a book exposing the racism he believes is rife within the Met - especially in the canteen
fields.body:
The drive to recruit black and Asian police officers in the wake of the Macpherson report has borne scant fruit outside London, but the Metropolitan police can boast 184 such recruits in the past year. While that is still far off Jack Straw's 10-year target of a quarter of the 26,500 workforce, it hikes the black and Asian showing in the Met to about one in 25.

Yet whether these recruits can be valued and retained, and whether their presence can make a difference, is a source of scepticism, not least among the officers themselves. Detective Inspector David Michael, who won a racial discrimination case against the Met but says he was then forced off sick by ostracism at work, began a sobering series of diaries by black and Asian police on Radio 4 two weeks ago, called Taking Note. And now a new novel by ex-policeman Ike Eze-Anyika promises to blow the lid off the Met's sealed and secret world.

Canteen Culture, which won the Saga prize for a first novel manuscript by a black Briton, was written while its author was suspended from the Golders Green division, accused of assault during an arrest. Although he was acquitted at the end of 1997 and reinstated, Eze-Anyika was on sick leave with post-traumatic stress when he heard about his £3,000 Saga award. He resigned last June, and is taking the Met to an industrial tribunal, claiming discrimination about the way the complaint against him was handled. He says the case "should never have happened".

Now 30 and living in Clapham, south London, Eze-Anyika says: "I went into the force with an open mind, admiring it and liking the idea of being part of the New Scotland Yard world elite." He smiles grimly. "I saw myself principally as a police officer who happened to be black. But I learned that people will only see you as a black police officer."

The sole black policeman in a team that stopped four white men for drink-driving, Eze-Anyika says he was set upon, racially abused and beaten during his attempt to arrest them. "As a black officer at the scene of a crime, you're vulnerable. People hurl racial abuse, because that takes the spotlight off the criminal." Yet the men's accusations led to action being taken against him. "It reeked of racism. If I was white, I wouldn't have been standing trial. But there I was, accused of beating a white man up."

Born in London to Nigerian parents - his father a lawyer, his mother a fashion designer - Eze-Anyika went to a British school, while his parents and siblings returned to Nigeria. He joined them aged 12, but returned after a year of university, and signed up in 1992. "I wanted to be part of something," he says. Advertising was aimed at black recruits. "It was alluring to be part of a vanguard of black police officers, though a lot of my friends told me not to bother."

Then began a "slow burn" of dis-illusionment. "When you walk into a canteen where 1,000 police officers are eating, it hits you that you do stand out. It's like walking into a firewall." It is this canteen culture - "a subculture within an overwhelmingly working-class culture" - that he wanted to lay bare in his novel, to "capture the police psyche, the way they think and speak; that's why there's a lot of swearing". He adds: "It's easy to modify your behaviour, mask your beliefs. But the canteen is a very safe place for police officers. Canteens, pubs and sitting in the front of a van - that's where you get an insight into what people are thinking."

Based on his own experiences and those of other police officers, the book contains a barrage of racist, misogynistic and homophobic "jokes". "It's a conformist organisation and a very macho culture; narcissistic, self- serving. And it's unbreakable: you're either in or you're out. You're in on the jokes and wisecracks, or you're not."

Beyond revealing the targeting of what Eze-Anyika calls "significant others" (black, Jewish, female, gay), the novel shows how that tight, self-reinforcing culture militates against anyone rocking the boat, lending itself to corruption, incompetence and bad policing. The plot follows the disintegration of a team of officers used to petty corruption - from smoking spliffs and drink-driving police cars to post-curry punch-ups - till they hit the big time by confiscating a car with more than £1m in cash and cocaine in the boot. Jazz, the black copper, is excluded from the conspiracy, his loyalty thought dubious. For the author, this reflects habitual suspicion of officers "caught in the middle". He says: "You're either pitied or hated, and you're often required to stand and declare. When you turn up at an incident involving black people, they look to you to take their side. But my loyalties have to lie with the officers. They're the ones you work with on night duties, watching your back. But it's not a good feeling."

While a bonding culture may be needed for the job, "no one challenges the bad practices. It's cancerous; if that can't be changed, anything else is ephemeral and superficial." For him, suspension was almost welcome. "I knew I was innocent. It was a relief to be out of what was becoming unbearable." Nor did he mind forfeiting his warrant card. "It's like saying, 'You're out of the club, son.' But I didn't want to be in their club anyway. I was beginning to see through the veneer."

It became evident that Eze-Anyika - who also did a law degree while suspended - would have to resign if his book was to be published. "I was told I'd have to submit it to the Met for approval, which I thought was absurd." He went to a tribunal after quitting last year - he felt he had no support from the Met throughout the investigation. "I was told it was like falling off a horse; you just get back on. They didn't understand what I'd been through. When I wasn't getting any answers, I lost all faith and trust."

He is sceptical of change even after the Stephen Lawrence inquiry. "None of what's being seen as change was a Met initiative. It's just that public opinion in middle England had gone against the Met. The very fact that police officers believe crime will go up means they think it's committed by black people. The average police officer isn't able to distinguish a black burglar from a black banker."

Institutional racism is little understood, he believes. "The same officers in the 80s are still there now. People won't use 'nigger' to your face, but there's a constant allusion to black people as IC3s [police jargon for black]. If a woman police officer goes out with a black man, she's labelled as 'liking IC3s'." For Eze-Anyika, the emphasis on reporting racist crime also "misses the point". "The Met's turned the culprits into racist criminals; whereas, to me, it's the canteen culture - even if most officers aren't skinhead racists, they have a low opinion of black people."

Nor is recruitment alone the answer. "When the Met has a recruitment drive it's seen as 'lowering standards'; black people are not seen as having something genuine to contribute." An accredited officer, he recalls seeking advice about joining a specialist unit. "Eighty per cent suggested the drugs squad. When I mentioned the Special Branch, they said, 'There aren't a lot of black people in Special Branch because it's not very easy to get into.'"

Now working as an IT consultant, having sold film rights to Canteen Culture, and planning more novels "with a police theme", Eze-Anyika feels he has moved on. But he warns: "I'd dissuade any black person from joining the police and, looking back, I think I never belonged. What black people are saying is, 'We want the Met to change.' It's got to prove something to us, or I'd rather see an organisation that was 100% white and we knew where we stood."

Canteen Culture is published on Monday by Faber & Faber, price £9.99. The final Taking Note is on Radio 4 on Tuesday at 9.30am.
