Based on his own experiences and those of other police officers, the book contains a barrage of racist, misogynistic and homophobic "jokes". "It's a conformist organisation and a very macho culture; narcissistic, self- serving. And it's unbreakable: you're either in or you're out. You're in on the jokes and wisecracks, or you're not." Beyond revealing the targeting of what Eze-Anyika calls "significant others" (black, Jewish, female, gay), the novel shows how that tight, self-reinforcing culture militates against anyone rocking the boat, lending itself to corruption, incompetence and bad policing. The plot follows the disintegration of a team of officers used to petty corruption - from smoking spliffs and drink-driving police cars to post-curry punch-ups - till they hit the big time by confiscating a car with more than £1m in cash and cocaine in the boot. Jazz, the black copper, is excluded from the conspiracy, his loyalty thought dubious. For the author, this reflects habitual suspicion of officers "caught in the middle". He says: "You're either pitied or hated, and you're often required to stand and declare. When you turn up at an incident involving black people, they look to you to take their side. But my loyalties have to lie with the officers. They're the ones you work with on night duties, watching your back. But it's not a good feeling." While a bonding culture may be needed for the job, "no one challenges the bad practices. It's cancerous; if that can't be changed, anything else is ephemeral and superficial." For him, suspension was almost welcome. "I knew I was innocent. It was a relief to be out of what was becoming unbearable." Nor did he mind forfeiting his warrant card. "It's like saying, 'You're out of the club, son.' But I didn't want to be in their club anyway. I was beginning to see through the veneer." It became evident that Eze-Anyika - who also did a law degree while suspended - would have to resign if his book was to be published. "I was told I'd have to submit it to the Met for approval, which I thought was absurd." He went to a tribunal after quitting last year - he felt he had no support from the Met throughout the investigation. "I was told it was like falling off a horse; you just get back on. They didn't understand what I'd been through. When I wasn't getting any answers, I lost all faith and trust." He is sceptical of change even after the Stephen Lawrence inquiry. "None of what's being seen as change was a Met initiative. It's just that public opinion in middle England had gone against the Met. The very fact that police officers believe crime will go up means they think it's committed by black people. The average police officer isn't able to distinguish a black burglar from a black banker." Institutional racism is little understood, he believes. "The same officers in the 80s are still there now. People won't use 'nigger' to your face, but there's a constant allusion to black people as IC3s [police jargon for black]. If a woman police officer goes out with a black man, she's labelled as 'liking IC3s'." For Eze-Anyika, the emphasis on reporting racist crime also "misses the point". "The Met's turned the culprits into racist criminals; whereas, to me, it's the canteen culture - even if most officers aren't skinhead racists, they have a low opinion of black people." Nor is recruitment alone the answer. "When the Met has a recruitment drive it's seen as 'lowering standards'; black people are not seen as having something genuine to contribute." An accredited officer, he recalls seeking advice about joining a specialist unit. "Eighty per cent suggested the drugs squad. When I mentioned the Special Branch, they said, 'There aren't a lot of black people in Special Branch because it's not very easy to get into.'" Now working as an IT consultant, having sold film rights to Canteen Culture, and planning more novels "with a police theme", Eze-Anyika feels he has moved on. But he warns: "I'd dissuade any black person from joining the police and, looking back, I think I never belonged. What black people are saying is, 'We want the Met to change.' It's got to prove something to us, or I'd rather see an organisation that was 100% white and we knew where we stood." Canteen Culture is published on Monday by Faber & Faber, price £9.99. The final Taking Note is on Radio 4 on Tuesday at 9.30am.

webTitle: Racist gang's threat to impale Asian

fields.headline: Racist gang's threat to impale Asian
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A British Asian yesterday described how he and his white fiancée were the victims of a racist attack that left him with two black eyes and a fractured nose and cheekbone.
fields.body:
A British Asian yesterday described how he and his white fiancée were the victims of a racist attack that left him with two black eyes and a fractured nose and cheekbone.

Sunil Modi, 32, and Claire Nichols, 22, were set upon by white youths as they drove through a Liverpool suburb. He was smashed in the face with a beer can before being dragged out of the car and kicked in the head and bitten on the hand.

The men dragged Mr Modi towards a metal fence and shouted, "Spike him, spike him - put the Paki's head on a spike", while Ms Nichols was being attacked by a woman.

The couple told at a police press conference how a man and a woman in a Ford Escort had pursued their car shout ing abuse early on Sunday morning. Mr Modi said: "As I drove close to their car both the driver and the passenger shouted a word I haven't heard for 15 years - 'Paki'. Before I could make sense of what they were saying, they tried to force me off the road."

The couple stopped opposite Liverpool cricket club to call the police, but were set upon by another two men. Mr Modi was pulled from his car so violently that his seat belt snapped out of its clip.

The woman from the Escort attacked Ms Nichols, pulling at her hair, but she managed to lock her door. The attack alerted diners at a restaurant and a party at the cricket club, and police were called.

Mr Modi, a scriptwriter from London, was given treatment at the Royal Liverpool university hospital.

fields.headline: The environment
fields.standfirst: What should the chancellor do? Vote now
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has staked his claim to being green on the introduction of the climate change levy, which taxes businesses according to the amount of carbon dioxide they pump out.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown has staked his claim to being green on the introduction of the climate change levy, which taxes businesses according to the amount of carbon dioxide they pump out.

The detailed design of the system is due to be confirmed in the Budget when the chancellor is also expected to introduce a range of other environmentally-friendly measures.

One of the major proposals under consideration is a reform of the vehicle excise duty system to encourage people to buy cleaner cars.

At the moment, people with small cars with engines of 1100cc or less pay an annual road tax bill of £100, a £55 discount on the going rate for everyone else.

Under the new system, there are expected to be four bands. While the lower limit for the smallest cars is expected to remain at around £100, there is speculation that Mr Brown may increase amount to be paid by the owners of the biggest polluters to around £180.

Also in the pipeline are plans to increase the landfill tax, designed to discourage firms burying waste under ground, and the government has floated the idea of a pesticides tax.

Not surprisingly, the latter has encountered considerable opposition from the agrochemical industry but won support from environmental groups.

Mr Brown will have to weigh up the competing interests and decide how to proceed. Signs are that he might opt for a voluntary agreement with the industry to reduce harmful use of pesticides in a move which may anger environmental groups.

fields.headline: Stamp duty
fields.standfirst: What should the chancellor do? Vote now
fields.trailText: Rising house prices in the South East are one of the biggest threats to the benign inflation outlook.
fields.body:
Rising house prices in the South East are one of the biggest threats to the benign inflation outlook.

Rather than continuing to rely on higher interest rates to cool the property market, industrialists are urging the chancellor to increase stamp duty on home sales.

They argue this will have the advantage over dearer borrowing costs of preventing a further appreciation of the exchange rate.

Mr Brown has bought this argument before. In his first mini-Budget in 1997, he increased stamp duty on house purchases worth between £250,000 and £500,000 to 2.5% from 1%. For houses costing more than £500,000 the duty was increased to 3.5%.

Further increases would go down well with hard-pressed manufacturers in the Midlands and North East, who feel the level of interest rates is being determined solely by events in the South East.

But Mr Brown will have to be careful not to antagonise the growing number of middle class voters who live, or aspire to live, in houses worth more than £250,000.

Higher stamp duty on home purchases may also make the jobs market less flexible by increasing moving costs.

To soften the blow to Middle England, the chancellor could decide to reform stamp duty on share trading. The London Stock Exchange has been campaigning hard for the 0.5% duty on UK equities to be abolished, or at least reduced.

Such a move would cement the City's competitive position in relation to other financial centres but it may also run the risk of stimulating a stock market which some believe is already in danger of overheating.

fields.headline: Legal maze
fields.standfirst: Geoffrey Gibbs  on how Wales could stop commercial GM crops in the UK before they get off the ground
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Gibbs on how Wales could stop commercial GM crops in the UK before they get off the ground.
fields.body:
As the government prepares this week to unveil details of proposed farmscale trials of three GM crops across the UK, pressure is mounting on the Labour administration in Wales to strike a first blow in the campaign to turn the country into a GM-free zone.

The move could put the devolved administration in conflict with Westminster and poses a tricky dilemma for the Welsh agriculture secretary, Christine Gwyther, who may be damned from Downing Street if she does and will be damned in Wales if she doesn't.

At the heart of the issue is an application by the biotech company, Aventis, for its T25 forage maize to be included on the UK national seed list. Approval is the final regulatory barrier to be crossed before seeds can be grown commercially. And although the biotech industry has agreed a moratorium on commercial growing until farm-scale trials have been completed and assessed in 2003, campaigners believe it is vital to take a stand and block the application now.

They claim that Wales, where feelings against GM trials run high, has an effective veto because the application has to be approved jointly by ministers in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

The decision rests in the hands of Gwyther, who less than six months ago was censured by opposition members of the national assembly over her handling of the crisis affecting the farming industry in Wales.

Members of the assembly's agriculture and rural affairs committee - on which Labour is in a minority - have been given the opportunity to debate the matter and offer advice because of what the agriculture secretary has acknowledged is the widespread public interest in GM issues. Gwyther herself is known to believe that Wales would benefit from being able to present itself to the world as a GM-free area. But she has warned the committee that her decision has to be made on a lawful basis.

Although initial legal advice from the office of the counsel general suggested there were no legal grounds on which to refuse the Aventis application, Gwyther has agreed to defer her decision until the agriculture committee has had the opportunity to study legal submissions from Friends of the Earth, which challenges that opinion. The committee, which has signalled that it favours blocking the application, is also keen to study further scientific papers and will meet again at the end of this month to deliver its advice.

Gwyther is not bound to accept the committee's recommendation, but overriding it is certain to stir up a storm of protest both within the assembly and without.

"The reaction would be very hostile," says Gordon James, head of campaigns for Friends of the Earth Cymru. "It would fuel the feeling that the assembly is simply rubber stamping what Blair wants. There would be extreme concern and anger that the voice of the elected representatives of Wales is not being listened to and that we are caving into Westminster."

According to Gwyther, T25 maize, which was targeted by protesters during trials in England last summer, has already received health and environmental clearances and has completed trials showing it meets the criteria of suitability for agricultural cultivation.

But FoE Cymru claims the risk assessment processes under which the GM maize gained approval two years ago are no longer considered adequate either by the UK goverment or by the EU. "This maize is intended for cattle, yet there have been no safety assessments for animals eating GM feed," says the organisation's GM campaigner, Raoul Bhambral. "It's shocking that we don't seem to have learned from the last animal feed scare."

The group has sought to add weight to its campaign in Wales by taking independent legal advice, which, it argues, confirms that the national assembly has the power to refuse consent for a GM crop if it is unable to conclude with confidence that the crop would not harm human health or the environment and provided it remains prepared to consider representations to the contrary. A spokesman for the agriculture secretary confirmed it would be considered carefully, in conjunction with other advice, before Gwyther makes her decision.

Whichever way that goes, she can expect to face flak and a legal challenge from the disappointed parties. As she has discovered since being propelled into the cabinet by the former first secretary, Alun Michael, the position of agriculture secretary is one of the hottest political potatoes around.

fields.headline: Income taxes
fields.standfirst: What should the chancellor do? Vote now
fields.trailText: The Chancellor grabbed the headlines in last year's Budget with his promise of an extra penny of the basic rate of income tax. But a year later, as the promised 22p rate is about to be introduced into pay packets, the political judgement behind stealing the Conservatives tax-cutting clothes is starting to be questioned. Some on the left of the party are muttering that the cost of last year's tax cut - £2.5bn - would have been better spent on health or education.
fields.body:
The Chancellor grabbed the headlines in last year's Budget with his promise of an extra penny of the basic rate of income tax. But a year later, as the promised 22p rate is about to be introduced into pay packets, the political judgement behind stealing the Conservatives tax-cutting clothes is starting to be questioned. Some on the left of the party are muttering that the cost of last year's tax cut - £2.5bn - would have been better spent on health or education.

Despite the conflict within the party, tax cuts could be on the cards again in the budget. Mr Brown needs to reduce taxes by between £2-3bn to refute the Conservative's charge that the tax burden - the proportion of national income which goes into the Treasury's coffers - has risen under Labour.

And the attractions for Labour of further reducing the basic rate should not be underestimated. Party insiders believe they lost the 1992 election because the Conservatives convinced the electorate a Labour government would drop a 'tax bombshell'. Mr Brown may yet surprise with further tax cuts - and there is something rather tidy about a three band tax schedule with rates at 10p, 20p and 40p.

fields.headline: The economic background
fields.standfirst: What should the chancellor do? Vote now
fields.trailText: The economic backdrop to a Budget can rarely have been more favourable. Growth is accelerating, inflation remains below the government's 2.5% target and the public finances are overflowing. The only blot on the landscape is the strong pound, which is crushing manufacturing and, at the same time, boosting the domestic economy.
fields.body:
The economic backdrop to a Budget can rarely have been more favourable. Growth is accelerating, inflation remains below the government's 2.5% target and the public finances are overflowing. The only blot on the landscape is the strong pound, which is crushing manufacturing and, at the same time, boosting the domestic economy.

The textbook method of correcting such an imbalance would be to tighten fiscal policy, either through reduced public spending or higher taxes.

In theory, a significant fiscal tightening aimed directly at the consumer would ease upward pressure on interest rates and the pound and help to narrow the gap between the domestic economy and the internationally exposed sectors.

It would also help bring UK interest rates more into line with those in Europe, smoothing Britain's entry to the single currency.

However, the relationship between fiscal policy and the exchange is not always as mechanistic as the textbooks suggest. In the past four years, the chancellor has tightened fiscal policy by 5% of gross domestic product, 1.2% more than that seen in Euroland. Yet sterling has appreciated substantially over this period.

The unpredictable behaviour of sterling - and the proximity of the next election - suggests that Mr Brown is unlikely to try to tighten fiscal policy much further on March 21. Indeed, he may even loosen it slightly.

With Labour anxious to shore up its core support, however, any tax cuts are likely to be modest, leaving as much scope as possible to increase public spending when the new three-year programme is unveiled in the summer.

webTitle: Greens press Shell for a place in the sun

fields.headline: Greens press Shell for a place in the sun
fields.trailText: Greenpeace has bought £160,000 worth of shares in Shell to try to force the company to invest in a new solar factory.
fields.body:
Greenpeace has bought £160,000 worth of shares in Shell to try to force the company to invest in a new solar factory.

A change in the Dutch law means Greenpeace cannot communicate with major shareholders unless it qualifies as a "major" itself, so the environmental group has taken the temporary shareholding in order to canvas support for its pro-solar policy at the May 9 annual meeting.

In England, where the rules are different, Greenpeace is mounting a similar assault on BP for its April 13 annual meeting. At this meeting "sympathetic" shareholders will be sponsoring a resolution demanding investment that will kick-start solar power.

At the core of the campaign is a KPMG report that says all the technology needs to become competitive with fossil fuels is a sizeable investment in plant to promote large scale production and so bring down the unit price to a quarter of current prices. KPMG estimate that such an investment would bring a return of 15%.

Green campaigners have already been effective with shareholdings. More than 100 British and American shareholders with 150,000 shares forced BP's Arctic ocean exploration plans on to the AGM agenda by submitting a formal resolution opposing the company's controversial Northstar oil pipeline project.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Education secretary David Blunkett is expected to propose today that the school day is extended to 5pm. Is that a good idea?
fields.trailText: Margaret Morrissey, National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations
fields.body:
Margaret Morrissey, National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations

Are educational standards so low that the government wants to pack children into school for as long as possible? Or does it just want to grab a few headlines?In theory, this might seem a good idea, particularly if you're a working parent, but you've got to think of it from the child's point of view. Is there any evidence to show that lengthening the school day would benefit children? I suspect not. School is restrictive and regimented - not the right environment for children to be for most of their waking life. We don't want to see our children ill and burned out at 16.
Verdict: No

Geoff Conway Headteacher, Grey Court School, Richmond, Surrey

I think we're all a bit confused by exactly what David Blunkett is talking about. If it's an additional 10 hours a week on the school timetable, then that would represent a 40% increase in school opening hours. Is the government going to give us 40% extra resources to cope with that? I doubt it. And in any case, would the teaching associations accept it - it would be a huge change to working practice? If, on the other hand, he's talking about extra activities at the end of the school day, then many schools like ours are doing it already.
Verdict: No

Reva Klein Author of Defying Disaffection (Trentham Books)

If the government is serious about tackling disaffection in schools, then extending the school day seems like a particularly perverse way of going about things. To enhance children's learning, we need to make schools more interactive and develop thinking skills - not lock kids up for longer. Children need more support, and more opportunities for creative and play activity - part of growing up is about acquiring freedom and being given choices. Yes, let's give them options but let THEM decide what to do and when.
Verdict: No

Tina Perridge Working Mother of four

Schools are busy, noisy places, and I don't think it would be right to expect children to spend even longer in them. My children have always been tired by the time they come home, and I think expecting them to stay there until 5pm would be really unreasonable - I'd be very upset by it. Childhood is about a lot more than school - if they were there until that time, how would they enjoy the sunshine of a summer evening? We seem to be demanding more and more of our children all the time, and I worry that we're in danger of depriving them of their childhood.
Verdict: No

Prof Clyde Chitty Head of Education Studies, Goldsmith's College, London

Nine to five seems to be a very long working day for youngsters, if children are meant to be studying for the whole of it. However, I've always thought it good for schools to be open for as long as possible - if they provide a good environment for youngsters who, for example, need somewhere quiet to do their homework. I am all for schools opening at 7.30am to provide breakfast for deprived youngsters, for example. But to supply more time that is structured and disciplined - I don't think that would be helpful.
Verdict: Not necessarily

School is restrictive and regimented - not the right environment for children to be for most of their waking life. We don't want to see our children ill and burned out at 16. Verdict: No Geoff Conway Headteacher, Grey Court School, Richmond, Surrey I think we're all a bit confused by exactly what David Blunkett is talking about. If it's an additional 10 hours a week on the school timetable, then that would represent a 40% increase in school opening hours. Is the government going to give us 40% extra resources to cope with that? I doubt it. And in any case, would the teaching associations accept it - it would be a huge change to working practice? If, on the other hand, he's talking about extra activities at the end of the school day, then many schools like ours are doing it already. Verdict: No Reva Klein Author of Defying Disaffection (Trentham Books) If the government is serious about tackling disaffection in schools, then extending the school day seems like a particularly perverse way of going about things. To enhance children's learning, we need to make schools more interactive and develop thinking skills - not lock kids up for longer. Children need more support, and more opportunities for creative and play activity - part of growing up is about acquiring freedom and being given choices. Yes, let's give them options but let THEM decide what to do and when. Verdict: No Tina Perridge Working Mother of four Schools are busy, noisy places, and I don't think it would be right to expect children to spend even longer in them. My children have always been tired by the time they come home, and I think expecting them to stay there until 5pm would be really unreasonable - I'd be very upset by it. Childhood is about a lot more than school - if they were there until that time, how would they enjoy the sunshine of a summer evening? We seem to be demanding more and more of our children all the time, and I worry that we're in danger of depriving them of their childhood. Verdict: No Prof Clyde Chitty Head of Education Studies, Goldsmith's College, London Nine to five seems to be a very long working day for youngsters, if children are meant to be studying for the whole of it. However, I've always thought it good for schools to be open for as long as possible - if they provide a good environment for youngsters who, for example, need somewhere quiet to do their homework. I am all for schools opening at 7.30am to provide breakfast for deprived youngsters, for example. But to supply more time that is structured and disciplined - I don't think that would be helpful. Verdict: Not necessarily

fields.headline: Can he play football?
fields.trailText: The lonely planet guide to Costa Rica says that "realistically, travel is very difficult for disabled people . . . streets and sidewalks are pot-holed and poorly paved, making wheelchair use frustrating everywhere . . ."
fields.body:
The lonely planet guide to Costa Rica says that "realistically, travel is very difficult for disabled people . . . streets and sidewalks are pot-holed and poorly paved, making wheelchair use frustrating everywhere . . ."

We're going anyway. Why? To visit Alex's father, whom he has hardly ever seen. As he works in the Monteverde cloud forest reserve, that's where we'll be staying, in a cabana. He has told us to bring rain gear and hiking boots, and to expect mud. Apparently, the road to Monteverde used to be an oxcart trail, and has only recently been made "barely passable" for larger vehicles. My mother thinks we are mad and, sometimes, so do I.

Fortunately, we have a special needs three-wheel all-terrain buggy. I've tried it out on beaches, through woodland, over moors and up steep hills. It does the job. We've had our jabs, I've got a list as long as my arm of things to take, including another carer and insurance to "cover replacement of carer".

Alex is really excited. Above all, about seeing his dad but also about going to the rainforest, going up in an aeroplane, staying in a cabana - everything.

But my overwhelming anxiety is how to get the buggy there intact. Last time we went abroad, Alex's wheelchair was thrown onto a conveyor belt. As it made the slow reclaimed baggage circuit, it fell off, and the brakes jammed. On the way back, I looked helplessly down into the luggage well as it was thrown onto another conveyor belt, did two complete turns on its way up, and landed on the Heathrow airport concourse upside down. The frame was irretrievably buckled.

But it's not the money or even the time spent claiming from British Airways that really bothers me. How can you relax and enjoy a holiday with someone dependent on a wheelchair if the wheelchair gets broken? And how, please, someone tell me, do you prevent it happening?

The travel agency was so reassuring and sympathetic. The check-in staff were nothing but helpful and charming. But the handling staff at the airports? To them, I guess, it was just another heavy, awkward piece of luggage.

Will send you a postcard . . .

fields.headline: Do try to keep up
fields.standfirst: So your baby doesn't recognise Bach and your toddler barely speaks one language. Help is at hand from Baby Einstein, the video that is already introducing more than a million American infants to high culture and science.  Simon Hattenstone  investigates the new hothousing
fields.trailText: So your baby doesn't recognise Bach and your toddler barely speaks one language. Help is at hand from Baby Einstein, the video that is already introducing more than a million American infants to high culture and science. Simon Hattenstone investigates the new hothousing
fields.body:
Oooh, you're looking rough. Go on admit it, you've had it up to here , just can't take another sleepless night. The baby's kept you up yet again, with her squelching and squealing, tossing and teething, and worst of all that woeful under-achieving. No matter how many times you patiently recite to her, she just can't get a grip of Einstein's theory of relativity. Not even the basics. As for her languages - she's not even mastered French and Russian, let alone Japanese. Don't tell me, it's TRAUMATIC (and I don't use capital letters lightly). Then there's the music. Six weeks old, been played the classics all her life and she still can't distinguish between Beethoven's Rondo a Capriccio Opus 129 and Rondo in C. Stupid cow.

Well don't worry. Help is at hand in the form of the Baby Einstein videos. They are enjoying their first media outings in this country, and will be released, through Abbey Home Entertainment, later this year.

The videos are the creaton of Julie Aigner-Clark and her husband Bill Clark, who live in Colorado and have two young daughters of their own. Baby Einstein is designed to "facilitate the development of the brain" of babies from one month old onwards by giving them a gentle introduction to high culture and science - a dribble of Mozart here, a smidge of Bach there, chucked in with a few of Shakespeare's most baby-friendly sonnets. One more thing - the videos introduce babies to seven languages and have sold more than one million copies in the US.

Julie Aigner-Clark is the type of woman you have to call Julie. Just like Julie Andrews. She tells me ever so softly and gently how she dreamed up Baby Einstein. She was looking for stimuli for her two babies, something that would introduce them to the beauty and creative potential of life, and the best thing on offer was Teletubbies. So Julie got to work, though she says she's the least likely entrepreneur in the world - at school she sat at the back of class reading poetry and dreaming of platting daffodils through her hair.

Why Baby Einstein? "Well, everyone aspires to having a baby Einstein, don't they?" Maybe, but then again Einstein couldn't tie his own shoe laces and I wouldn't fancy having to tie up my kids' shoes every day before they set off for work.

Julie tells me how the videos have worked for her children - five-year-old Aspen, named after the tree and two-and-a-half year-old Sierra named after the Madre. "We're big nature people," she explains. Aspen is now at a school for gifted children. "Aspen's Japanese is fabulous," she says. "The first five years of life is the perfect time to teach children languages." What can Aspen say in Japanese? "She sings Hands, Fingers, Knees and Toes."

Baby Einstein features all the bric-a-brac of a baby's life: toys and hoops and faces and simple patterns hypnotically swirling lazily as lulling voices sing nursery rhymes or count to 10 in a hatful of languages. Not only are the videos so soporific that babies are bound to fall asleep, but this is marketing genius - how to capture the world with a simple DIY video. Julie must be getting very rich very quickly. "We're getting there," she says with that lovely American openness.

Baby Einstein does not attempt to teach seven languages, simply to introduce babies to essential words such as apple. Can Aspen says apple in seven languages? "No," says Julie, a little disappointed, "only Japanese and Spanish . . . actually, German too. And English, of course."

I tell Julie that I've never managed to teach my daughters a thing, and Baby Einstein sounds the perfect package for thickos like me. And just think how proud we'll be when our kids toddle off to school and start their Sats, already proficient in Japanese.

There are quite a few party poopers who think Julie has got her priorities in a twist. Take Jan Parker, co-author of Raising Happy Children (Hodder & Stoughton, £9.99). "I don't want my children to be Baby Einsteins," she says. "The most important lesson any parent or carer can give a young child is that they matter. Young babies who grow up believing that they are worth spending time with, playing with, being cuddled and responded to are learning much more that really counts than the child put in front of a video reciting poems in five different languages".

Parker says this form of hothousing, can easily backfire. She points to evidence that overuse of television or videos can lead to delayed speech, and lack of confidence in both children and parents. "My fear is that this sort of 'educational tool' preys on parents' anxieties and vulnerabilities, rather than boosting confidence in the positive power of their growing relationship with their child. Children tend to learn most when they are enjoying themselves. To help them to learn, and to try, even when they are not assured of success, they need confidence and a sense of their own worth, and that's something that comes through interaction between human beings."

Rubbish, hey, Julie? This emotional blather is all very well, but the woman obviously has no ambition for her kids. Disappointingly, Julie seems to think Parker has a point. Baby Einstein has not been a substitute for interracting with Aspen and Sierra, she stresses. "Really, I'm a full-time Marm, couldn't be a more devoted mother, but the reality is sometimes I have to cook dinner or take a shower and when I do that I'd rather expose them to media that is developmentally apppropriate than garbage."

She couldn't think of anything worse than Aspen and Sierra slumped in front of Baby Einstein all day long. No danger of that, though - only this morning she and Sierra went down the river to feed the ducks. "If I can teach her what sink and float means by throwing things in the river then that means a lot more."

"This is not about strapping children into a chair," says Julie. "Babies luuuuurve our products." And they don't push the children - not at all. "Take Sierra, she's two and a half and she only speaks English. She does love the videos though. It has given her the opportunity to appreciate classical music in a way that is great for her. she'll tap out little things on the piano. I think she's more likely to be a composer than a linguist. Aspen's the innate linguist, and all these videos do is enhance innate skills. Sierra actually likes Bach more than Mozart, which is surprising."

Have any dissatisfied customers asked for a refund because their baby has refused to grow into a genius? No, she says. "The thing is, everyone who's had a baby wants them to be the cutest and smartest, so even if they are stupid they don't think they are."

fields.headline: Childish things
fields.standfirst: 13: A brief guide to nightlights
fields.trailText: Last May, nightlights went out all over Islington. A study published in the scientific magazine, Nature, had found that sleeping with a nightlight in the first two years of life was strongly correlated with short-sightedness later in childhood.
fields.body:
Last May, nightlights went out all over Islington. A study published in the scientific magazine, Nature, had found that sleeping with a nightlight in the first two years of life was strongly correlated with short-sightedness later in childhood. The authors of the study concluded that "it seems prudent that infants and young children sleep at night without artificial lighting in the bedroom, while the present findings are evaluated more comprehensively".

Panic. Could you risk switching off? Could you risk not switching off? Although some mothers took the view, perhaps rashly, that an increased risk of shortsightedness must be preferable to a sudden descent into darkness, their decision could be difficult to live with. Would their bespectacled children be sueing them for deliberate neglect in a few years time? More responsible parents, stoically enforcing the ban, had to endure the nightly wails of children who had never, until that helpful Nature report, known really dark, darkness. Would their child, in later life, blame them for hideous flashbacks to that night when their bedroom plunged from the familiar rosy pink, into pitch blackness? Not so much, perhaps, as those parents now blame the University of Pennyslvania for the baseless scare.

Another study, also published in the journal Nature, has now found "no link between night time lighting and the development of childhood myopia", according its author, Karla Zadnik. "In fact the proportion of myopic children across nursery lighting conditions was remarkably uniform." She says that "parents should not concern themselves with this unfounded risk."

The previous study seems not to have established whether shortsighted children's parents were also shortsighted. Parents who use nightlights might well be more likely to be shortsighted themselves. The new research, though reassuring, presents parents with a new dilemma. Could the sudden re-introduction of light be as disturbing to a sensitive child as last year's descent into darkness? Should they continue to save on electricity or take advantage of this wonderul opportunity to justify spending almost £100 on a glow-in-the-dark teddy?

There is no doubt that nightlights make life easier: blundering into a child's room in the middle of the night you can spot the telltale puddle of vomit, make out where a missing teddy hit the floor; you don't have to suddenly dazzle a miserable infant with an overhead light, adding to the drama being enacted inside the cot. So, thanks, Karla Zadnik of Ohio State University. Time to move on. Heard about microwaves and what they may - or may not - do to your child's milk?

Lumibear

Standing, £97; sitting, £87; reclining, £92. Available from Purves and Purves (020 7580 8223)

Like some vast jelly baby, this moulded plastic teddy light comes in beautifully bright colours, is as big as a six-month-old and has a grotesquely realistic bottom. The latest addition to the range is the reclining lumibear (sitting and standing versions have been in the fanciest nurseries for months). When lit, the darker colours provide the most reassuring glow, and the plastic doesn't get hot, so no burned fingers . . . but £92? No light can be worth it.

Rating: 6/10

Maisy Magic Lantern

£29.99 from Urchin (01672 872 872 or www.urchin.co.uk.)

Lucy Cousins' adorable mouse and her chums spin slowly round, driven by the heat of the bulb. Know-it-all toddlers will notice that the sheep walks backwards ("Why, mummy? Why? Why?") In this tester's experience, carousel-style lights like these tend to break easily, but then the obsession with Maisy won't last forever either. The lantern stands 20cms high and is fitted with a 15w bulb. (If Maisy is not to your taste, urchin will soon be stocking a dim light that fades slowly off after 15 minutes.)

Rating: 8/10

Tomy Fantasy Dreamshow.

£29.99. (Call 01703 662600 for stockists.)

Hi-tech version of the carousel idea. Battery-operated, the "dreamshow" projects a parade of slowly moving animals on to the ceiling, accompanied by music (it comes with two CDs). The show lasts either three or six minutes (which baby do you know falls asleep that fast?). For the full effect, you need a white ceiling and a dark room so that when the show is over, your baby will be plunged into darkness. An ugly object with nasty graphics - this is one baby will love, and parents will loathe. Sweet dreams.

Rating: 8/10

Zzzoo Light Collection by Sompex.

£35 from The Conran Shop (020 7589 7401)

A range of self-assembly lights - (we put the hedgehog together in less than 10 minutes, then spent the next half-hour trying to fit the halogen bulb, managing it two broken bulbs later). Made from tough, wipe-clean plastic, it's the most practical of the lot - if you ignore the bulb problem. There are plenty of other animals in the zzzoo: owls, giraffes, elephants. When the kids want something more grown-up, you can use it yourself.

Rating: 9/10

Nightlights from Nina Campbell

£27.50 (Nina Campbell, 020 7225 1011) Adapter is included.

These tiny lights (the shade measures only 8cm) plug straight into the wall socket and give out a very soft light. The design is a little cutesy, but innoffensive, and there are no dangling wires for little fingers to grab at (and so no smashed shades and bulbs, either). But you can have too little light - with these you can't see your baby but you will be able to find the socket for a bit of late night hoovering.

Rating: 8/10

Rabbit House Nightlight.

£24.99 from JoJo Maman Bebe (0870 241 0560)

Thirtysomethings might remember these little pottery bunny houses from their own childhood. Though the idea is still cute (the light shines through the windows of the toadstool home), the nightlight itself is clumsily executed. And one pull on that wire, and it will be smashed. Young children might be satisfied with this but older ones will soon tire of it. Nostalgic parents will be disappointed, too . They don't make 'em like they used to.

Rating: 5/10

webTitle: Poison in the well of history

fields.headline: Poison in the well of history
fields.standfirst: Living Marxism accused ITN of distorting the truth about Bosnia. Now, it faces ruin after losing the ensuing libel battle.  Ed Vulliamy  , who filed the first reports on the horrors of the Trnopolje camp, explains why an unholy alliance of Serb apologists and misguided intellectuals had to be defeated in court
fields.trailText: Some will say that Living Marxism won the "public relations battle", whatever that is. Others will cling to the puerile melodrama that ITN's victory in the high court yesterday was that of Goliath over some plucky little David who only wanted to challenge the media establishment.
fields.body:
Some will say that Living Marxism won the "public relations battle", whatever that is. Others will cling to the puerile melodrama that ITN's victory in the high court yesterday was that of Goliath over some plucky little David who only wanted to challenge the media establishment.

But history - the history of genocide in particular - is thankfully built not upon public relations or melodrama but upon truth; if necessary, truth established by law. And history will record this: that ITN reported the truth when, in August 1992, it revealed the gulag of horrific concentration camps run by the Serbs for their Muslim and Croatian quarry in Bosnia.

The law now records that Penny Marshall and Ian Williams (and myself, for that matter) did not lie but told the truth when they exposed this crime to the world, and that the lie was that of Living Marxism and its dilettante supporters who sought, in the time-honoured traditions of revisionism, to deny those camps existed.

Of course Living Marxism was unable to offer a single witness who had been at Trnopolje, the camp they claimed to be a fake, on that putrid afternoon of August 5, 1992. Indeed, they were unable to produce any witnesses at all. Unlike any member of Living Marxism or their sympathisers, I was there with ITN's cameras that day. We went to two camps: Omarska and Trnopolje.

Living Marxism does not like to mention Omarska: there, we saw little, but enough: skeletal men drilled across a yard and devouring watery stew like famished dogs before being bundled out. One man said: "I do not want to tell any lies, but I cannot tell the truth."

The truth emerged with time. Omarska turned out to be the kind of place where one prisoner was forced to bite the testicles off another, who had a live pigeon stuffed into his mouth to stifle the screams as he died in agony. The yard at Omarska was a killing field, prisoners obliged to load the mutilated corpses of their friends on to trucks by bulldozer.

Trnopolje was a marginally less satanic place, some of whose prisoners were transferred from other hideous camps to await forced deportation. Others were rounded up and herded there like cattle, or had even fled there to avoid the systematic shelling and burning of their homes. Unknown to us when we pulled up on the road, in disbelief at the sight before us, it was the former group that was held captive behind the now celebrated barbed wire fence.

At the time I paid little attention to what would become Living Marxism's myopic obsessions: such as which side of which pole the old barbed wire or fresh barbed wire was fixed. There were more important matters, such as the emaciated Fikret Alic's (accurate and vindicated) recollections of the night he had been assigned to load the bodies of 250 men killed in one night at yet another camp.

If it is still of any remote interest, I will say this: I now know the compound in which these terrified men were held captive to have been surrounded on one side by recently reinforced barbed wire, on two sides by a chain-link fence patrolled by menacing armed thugs and on a fourth side by a wall. But so what? This was a camp - I would say a concentration camp - and they were its inmates.

What does it take to convince people? The war ground on, the British foreign office and Living Marxism in perfect synergy over their appeasement of the Serbs while other, worse camps were revealed. The bench in The Hague issued its judgment on Trnopolje in 1997: a verdict that described the camp as infinitely worse than anything we reported - an infernal place of rape, murder and torture. Witness after witness confirmed this. The Financial Times enthusiastically re-iterated Living Marxism's claims of a fabrication, but published a hasty and grovelling retraction when it looked at LM's non-evidence.

It was dispiriting to have to report that in the first year of what was proclaimed as the new united, democratic Europe such places as Trnopolje and Omarska existed. It was worse still to return to London and find an obscure group of supposed intellectuals putting such effort into trying to convince society that the camps had been a fabrication and that I had committed perjury when testifying to their existence and horrors at the war crimes tribunal at The Hague My friends and colleagues Marshall and Williams - brave reporters of the highest calibre - were being branded as liars. I suffered a whole lot less but there was a steady stream of hate mail. "You piece of shit," read one letter from an LM supporter revelling in the destruction of Vukovar, "probably a nasty little Jew.'"

Those most horribly insulted, of course, were the disbelieving camp survivors and relatives of the dead. I happen to believe that those who survive and are left bereaved by such monstrous crimes are owed at least one thing. They should be given back their lives by an admission that what happened happened. Their sanity requires that history records and acknowledges the truth of the atrocities that were committed against them and those they lost.

Richard Tait, editor of ITN, realised that three things had to be reclaimed. One, the reputation of his correspondents and his programme. Two, the trustworthiness of front-line, on-site reporting in general. And three, the need to etch the truth about those camps into history. Tait was the man who in private and in his affronted, righteous anger used the words "revisionism" and "fascism" without blushing.

When ITN sued in pursuit of these aims, the company of course ran the risk that such action would draw attention to LM's revisionism. But no one could have predicted the degree to which, rather than be dismissed as a foul revisionist trick, Living Marxism's claims would become a matter for voguish tittle-tattle among bored intellectuals on the sofas of the Groucho Club.

LM played its hand well but the rot in the British intelligentsia made it easy for them to do so. LM succeeded in entwining the two issues of the libel writ and denial of the camps. Some of their supporters argued that they accepted the truth of the genocide but nevertheless felt compelled by ITN's supposedly heavy-handed use of the libel laws to speak out in favour of those who denied the carnage. But such distinctions were utterly unconvincing. Those who helped LM cannot fail to recognise that by doing so they also stirred the poison LM had dropped into the well of history, playing their own role in denying a genocide.

By this entwinement, genocide was devalued into a "media debate", something to chitter-chatter about over grilled sea bass and pale Belgian beer.

Hungry for controversy, a sizeable portion of London's intelligentsia lined up to support Living Marxism. They rallied round those who had named me and others as liars in the name of free speech - so why not name them too, the great, the good and the up-and-coming? Fay Weldon, Doris Lessing, Harold Evans, Toby Young, and even a handful of contributors to this newspaper. A diverse coterie, eager to sip Living Marxism's apparently excellent claret at the ICA, to eat their canapés and run alongside the rotten bandwagon of revisionism. But how, and why?

One could argue about post-modern ennui and the paucity of values in a society obsessed by packaging. One could argue very cogently about the complete inability to understand fascism, about "victim-hatred" and the strong historical strand of British appeasement of Europe's tyrants, from Franco and Hitler to Milosevic. There was also a mutated strand of anti-Semitism in a lot of this, the Muslims being, in their way, the Jews of Bosnia. But the most tangible answer lies, I think, in the way revisionism works in a bored society, whether you are David Irving or Living Marxism. For just as the Serbs were the tinpot Nazis of the Balkans, so Living Marxism is the tinpot Holocaust denier, appealing to the same cheap slogans.

There is at the moment a remarkable convergence of trials: ITN vs Living Marxism wraps up in the high court; in The Hague, four guards at the Omarska camp go on trial. And also in London, Irving's case against Deborah Lipstadt, for her book Denying the Holocaust, approaches its denouement.

Like Irving, Living Marxism tried - and to a degree succeeded - in couching its argument on the reality of Trnopolje as a matter of free speech. This was LM's most grotesque deceit. Free speech has nothing whatsoever to do with LM's agenda. Although it denied it in court, Living Marxism - on this issue at least - is first and foremost an apologist for the genocide orchestrated by Belgrade. Thomas Deichmann, the author of the original LM piece on Trnopolje, was a defence witness for the camp-roving thug Dusko Tadic, who in 1997 became the first man to be convicted in The Hague for crimes against humanity - many of those crimes having been committed in Trnopolje and Omarska. One of Tadic's attorneys, Mikhail Wladimiroff, has since published his own revisionist views of Trnopolje in LM.

Deichmann has also been a regular contributor since his original article: one of his less subtle efforts was a grovelling interview with the man at the apex of the Serb's genocidal command structure, Radovan Karadzic, on whose authority we went to the camps in the first place. Karadzic is not wanted in The Hague for genocide, but Deichmann's article was entitled "War Criminal or Whipping Boy?" No prizes for guessing which thinly-veiled conclusion Deichmann came to. LM's continuous flagellation, in successive articles, of us "bloody liberals" and "cosmopolitan types" who contested the genocide became almost tedious - while the views of the authors were more interesting.

As is by now well-known, Living Marxism has become adept at finding or placing supporters in what it regards as influential positions in the media. This is all perfectly above board: the Times was desperate enough to offer LM's editor, Mick Hume, his own column. The signatories of LM's letters are familiar bylines across Fleet Street. But the pivot of Living Marxism's activities in the mainstream is, for some reason, the Economist Intelligence Unit, which has at times, backstage, been torn asunder by arguments over key positions held by the group's leading members.

Two of these are a Serb called Laza Kekic, the author of some of the most virulent attacks on the "bloody liberals", and Joan Phillips, who also works under the name Joan Hoey. This is the text of an email that came my way from Kekic to Hoey, written after the Nato bombardment of 1995 that produced the Dayton agreement:

"The Serbs have come back from far more difficult moments in the past. In the meantime, should accept and swallow a lot and consolidate what's left. Can even do Eurospeak and fluff on about the Balkan peace and co-operation in the meantime. Then, at some future date, the obliteration of the Muslims, the Albanians, and last of all the Croats. That's my perspective. And there's little else left to say'.

Indeed there isn't. The message was sent from Kekic's electronic address at the Economist Intelligence Unit on September 14, 1995, at 10.11am. Others in the series of emails involve chatter about gainful contact with David Owen and friendly journalists at the BBC and Observer.

At one point during the trial, LM produced video footage shot by what it called Bosnian-Serb Television, which did indeed have a crew there that day. But these particular images, it emerges, came from a third camera, a camcorder held by a man in military fatigues I remember well; LM was serviced in that instance by Serbian military intelligence.

The point is this: "free speech" has nothing to do with what is going on. Living Marxism's attempts to re-write the history of the camps was motivated by the fact that in their heart of hearts, these people applauded those camps and sympathised with their cause and wished to see it triumph. That was the central and - in the final hour, the only - issue. Shame, then, on those fools, supporters of the pogrom, cynics and dilettantes who supported them, gave them credence and endorsed their vile enterprise.

fields.headline: Livingstone rebuked for undeclared interests
fields.trailText: London mayoral contender Ken Livingstone was today rebuked by the Commons standards and privileges committee and urged to apologise personally to MPs for failing to register properly outside interests worth £158,599.
fields.body:
London mayoral contender Ken Livingstone was today rebuked by the Commons standards and privileges committee and urged to apologise personally to MPs for failing to register properly outside interests worth £158,599.

The committee said in a report that the Brent East MP should have disclosed how much he earned from public speaking and journalism and listed his interests more fully in the register of members' interests.

Of £220,992 received by Mr Livingstone's firm Localaction Ltd between June 1998 and last month, £158,599 "was attributable to regular commitments which ought to have been registrable", the cross-party committee said.

"Mr Livingstone breached the rules on registration of his interests and did not observe the principle of openness which the code of conduct [for MPs] requires. In view of the scale of the payments and the period of time over which they increased, we recommend that Mr Livingstone make an apology to the House by means of a personal statement," the Labour-dominated committee said.

The report followed a complaint against him by a Leicestershire man, John Jones, of Shepshed.

The findings will be a blow to Mr Livingstone as he takes on the Labour party as an independent candidate in the contest to become London's mayor. He said today he was prepared to apologise to the House.

"I contacted the committee in 1996, asked their advice and I was led to believe that anything paid into my company I didn't need to actually declare.

"As soon as they raised it I was happy to declare it," he told BBC 1's lunchtime news.

The committee agreed with the parliamentary commissioner for standards that Mr Livingstone's declaration in the register was inadequate. He should have made a "comprehensive entry" covering all the services he provided regularly through Localaction, including speaking engagements as well as writing and media work, and should have made a separate entry for his column in the Evening Standard.

In response to an inquiry by the commissioner, Mr Livingstone told him in September 1996 that his other activities were "all one-off" after-dinner speeches. "Nothing is on a regular basis," the MP emphasised.

But the committee said that by 1998 and 1999 he was carrying out speaking engagements for a number of clients "on a significant commercial basis". "Many of these could be seen as amounting to frequent, as opposed to merely occasional, commitments arising from membership of the House.

"As the assurances he had given the commissioner in 1996 no longer held good, he should have put in a new entry as soon as necessary, identifying the clients for whom he was providing regular services and indicating, in appropriate bands, the fees he was receiving. He should also have deposited employment agreements."

Mr Livingstone said today: "If I'd been told in 1996, 'Yes, we want to have your list in detail,' I would have done a list in detail. "As the report makes clear, I fully co-operated with the committee."

He added: "I worked very hard [on] the after dinner circuit because I did expect to be Labour's candidate for mayor, and I did expect to make a major donation to the cost of the campaign."

The only other MP mayoral contender, Labour's Frank Dobson, listed only one interest in the register published on January 31: "Land and Property. House in Dunnington, near York. It is usually occupied but no significant income derived."

fields.headline: The heart of town
fields.standfirst: You're single, more interested in cinemas and nightclubs  than DIY and gardening, and you're not yet ready for the  burden of a mortgage. Chris Arnot reports on a housing  experiment aimed at bringing fresh life to our inner cities
fields.trailText: You're single, more interested in cinemas and nightclubs than DIY and gardening, and you're not yet ready for the burden of a mortgage. Chris Arnot reports on a housing experiment aimed at bringing fresh life to our inner cities.
fields.body:
The waterfront view from Conrad Parke's balcony is not the most attractive in the world, or even the most attractive in Birmingham. Beyond canal banks of crumbling Victorian red brick, the skyline is dominated by the angular edges of 1960s office blocks. "It's not fantastic," Parke admits. "But when you've lived in a succession of ground-floor bedsits in the suburbs, then at least it's a view of sorts.

"It's only a few minutes walk up the towpath to Brindleyplace (the development of restaurants, bars and galleries around the National Exhibition Centre) and even closer to St Paul's Square in the Jewellery quarter, which is developing a quirky, Bohemian feel. A lot of people won't believe this, but the middle of Birmingham is becoming an exciting place to live."

Parke has agreed to show off his new flat to housing minister Nick Raynsford when he officially opens the Caspar apartments in Charlotte Street tomorrow. At 36, Parke is older than the average tenant, but in other respects he fits the profile which the Joseph Rowntree Foun dation had in mind when it pioneered this experiment in urban living, both here and in the centre of Leeds. He's single, is more interested in renting than tying himself down with a mortgage, and less interested in DIY and gardening than in availing himself of the cafe-bars, nightclubs, cinemas and theatres on his doorstep.

As Richard Best, director of the Joesph Rowntree Foundation, explains in the article opposite, "the mid-market renters" are key players in revitalising city centres as places to live as well as work. "Lord Rogers' urban task force says we need an inner-city renaissance to avoid absorbing more and more green fields with new housing," he says. "It's been estimated that an extra four million households will be created over the next 25 years, and 80% of them will be made up of single people.

"It's them, rather than young families with children, who are more likely to lead this renaissance. They don't have to worry about schools, and they're relatively mobile. Yet in the centres of places like Leeds and Birmingham, the choice up to now has been between council housing or penthouse apartments. We've been missing out on the mainstream population of working single people. We think this is a big, untapped market."

fields.headline: The chosen ones
fields.standfirst: Prioritising health care is not just a British problem. Chris Ham and  Angela Coulter look at how other countries approach the issue
fields.trailText: Prioritising health care is not just a British problem. Chris Ham and Angela Coulter look at how other countries approach the issue.
fields.body:
Faced with increasing demands and limited resources, health policy makers cannot escape the need to make choices on spending priorities. Health care rationing is a global challenge, and the key questions are who should be involved in making these choices, and how should the choices be arrived at?

In a number of countries, politicians have taken a lead in being explicit about rationing. In the US, the state of Oregon was one of the first health care systems to go down this route. There, a doctor turned politician, John Kitzhaber, appointed a commission of professional and lay people to recommend a list of core services to be funded under Medicaid, the government sponsored programme of health care for people who are poor or on low incomes.

New Zealand offers a contrast to Oregon in that the committee appointed by the government to determine core services refused to identify treatments to be excluded from funding. The committee took the view that priority setting was best approached not by limiting service coverage but by targeting services on those patients most likely to benefit. It launched a programme of work designed to draw up evidence-based guidelines, with the involvement of health care professionals.

The experience of New Zealand is echoed in the Netherlands. Although some services, such as adult dental care, have been excluded from insurance coverage, most effort has gone into encouraging a culture of evidence-based medical practice. The rationale is that few, if any, treatments offer no benefits to patients and rationing is likely to be more defensible if guidelines are adopted to promote the provision of appropriate care.

An example is infertility treatment. In the Netherlands, women under 40 are entitled to three cycles of in vitro fertilisation. If they do not conceive at the end of three cycles, then the cost of further treatment becomes a matter of personal responsibility. In this case, the guideline is based on an analysis of clinical research pointing to evidence that treatment beyond three cycles is unlikely to be effective.

If rationing in other countries has relied on the results of research, it has also involved consultation with the public and patients' organisations. In Oregon, a combination of public hearings, community meetings, telephone surveys and focus groups were used to engage the public. Similar methods have been employed in New Zealand and the Netherlands with the aim of both informing the public about the need to set priorities and drawing on the public's views to assist decision making.

Many rationing decisions are likely to be contested and it is incumbent on decision makers to show that they have made their choices as a result of due process. This explains the work done in different countries to develop rigorous decision making processes in order to earn legitimacy for contested choices.

In the UK, the newly-established National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice), set up to advise the government on the funding of health technologies, will need to draw on international experience to win credibility in discharging its functions. Nice will have to be watertight in its use of the results of research on clinical and cost effectiveness. It will also have to find ways of engaging the public and patients' groups. If consensus on rationing decisions is likely to be the exception rather than the rule, then Nice will need to show that it has paid attention to all relevant issues in putting forward its recommendations.

The most important lesson for the UK from international experience is that being explicit tends to draw more resources into health care. Far from restricting coverage to a basic set of core services, those who have confronted the challenge of explicit rationing have strengthened their hand in the budget setting process within government.

 Chris Ham is director of the Health Services Management Centre at Birmingham university and Angela Coulter is chief executive of Picker Institute Europe. Their new book, The Global Challenge of Health Care Rationing, on which this article is based, has just been published by Open University Press, paperback price £19.99.

fields.headline: Who to trust?
fields.standfirst: When Pauline Hunt applied for a job on the  board, she detected the whiff of cronyism
fields.trailText: When Pauline Hunt applied for a job on the board, she detected the whiff of cronyism.
fields.body:
Until this week, most people were unaware that health boards have non-executive directors who are members of the public, but they have now erupted into public consciousness in a row about cronyism. The report of Dame Rennie Fritchie, the independent commissioner for public appointments, who set up an independent scrutiny group to look into the political bias of appointments is due any day. Advance reports predict she will uncover cronyism with Labour activists packing NHS trusts.

The job itself involves working as a lay person alongside the professionals on the management boards of hospitals, ambulance services and bodies organising care in the community.

The brief to someone fascinated as I am by health issues sounds riveting. More than that, it has the bonus that, unlike many jobs where you are trying to help the community, it is paid - just over £5,000 a year for an ordinary non-exec, who works up to five days a month.

The chairman, another non-executive, gets between £15,000 and £20,000 for around 20 days' work a month.

I applied for one of these jobs. In the application form, page upon page of mini-essays were demanded in response to questions like, what do you think your contribution could be to the future success of an NHS board given the challenges it faces?

Dame Rennie has been quoted as saying no application form should take more than 15 minutes to complete. It took me well over 15 hours to tackle it seriously, giving it the necessary thought and doing the background reading. And that is as a journalist who has written for a living full time for over 30 years.

There was, I was told, very strong competition for these jobs, of which there are about five on each board of around 370 trusts. Soon there will be more and more jobs on the primary health care trusts which the government is eager to introduce.

The official form stresses the appointments should draw on a very broad range of people and emphasises the "users and carers" of the service. One mystery in appointments of NEDS is the vexed question of political activity. The application form demands details of political activity. This stipulation was introduced after the Nolan report into standards of public life in the mid-1990s and it is made clear that this is public information.

When I asked the eastern regional office of the NHS for public information on the NEDs only two people on the Addenbrooke's board were shown as declaring political activity. One, Baroness Perry, head of a Cambridge college, speaks for the Conservatives on education in the House of Lords. Another, Ann Limb, the head of a further education college, declared her support for Labour. Mary Archer, wife of the millionaire novelist and disgraced Tory peer, was re- appointed for a third session last autumn. Having been appointed from the outset in 1993 she is due to serve more than 10 years in all.

I turned to uncover the names of the NEDs on another local NHS trust, that of Cambridge Lifespan, which covers provision outside the hospital, the "care in the community". No political activity was declared here at all.

But to a journalist most of the names were familiar. Two NEDs, appointed during the last government, had served as Conservative councillors locally. Two, appointed since Labour took over, were former Labour Cambridge city councillors.

My suspicions were first aroused that this was not the completely open system it appeared on the surface, when after filling in the forms unsuccessfully two years earlier, a Labour party activist friend in a different trust area was telephoned and asked if she would like to be a NED. When she said no, she was asked who else in the party might be interested.

Dame Rennie has said she wants other "real people" to get to the top. I wasn't aiming for the top, just one of the ordinary non-executive jobs. I did get an interview, but I did not make it to the next stage, which is a pool of names from which the secretary of state can appoint.

My initial rejection letter said only that my name would not go forward. When I asked for feedback I was told only that in comparison with the other candidates I was "less able to demon- strate the skills necessary to contribute to the work of an NHS board". That told me nothing about the skills sought.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Traffic report | Old MacDonald | GM prize
fields.body:
Lord Gus Macdonald of Tradeston keeps a low profile, but he's a rising star with Britain's lorry drivers. They sense a man who is not deeply aware that there was a fierce national debate about roads in the 1990s and one who shares their view that environmentalists have for too long driven transport policy. Here's Gus talking recently to Britain's lorry companies, the Freight Transport Association: "[Your] policy of constructive engagement backed by factual argument has been more successful than you might imagine." What can he mean? Well, consider the government's record since Gus took over the reins.

1: It has abandoned the fuel duty escalator, which will stimulate more traffic and undermine Britain's commitments to carbon reductions.
2: It has abandoned John Prescott's pledge to reduce road traffic, seeking now only to cut "pollution and congestion" in hotspots.
3: It is in the process of reactivating the road building programme.
4: It is on the point of backtracking on 44-ton lorries.
5: It has poured cold water on advanced plans to limit single carriageway roads to 50mph.

Is Lord Gus, who is expected to announce the new roadbuilding plans in the early summer, aware that road protests continue? This week, five activists came out of their tunnels in Essex after staying down for a record five weeks to halt a five-mile long road destroying ancient woodland and greenbelt. This short stretch of the A130 was justified on the grounds that freight transport will considerably increase, but its cost was glossed over. Under the PFI (private finance initiative) it looks as if it will be more than £80m a mile, or almost £400m in total over 30 years. Makes the Dome look cheap.

 Good to see that Mott MacDonalds, the builder of the Newbury bypass, has won the Concrete Society's millennium award. And that Newbury police have at last been recognised: they have been given two awards for policing the protests.

 Bows and flaming arrows, tractors, aerial bombardments, CCTV, hundreds of security guards, electric fences? With tomorrow's announcement of the GM trial crop sites, Eco Soundings is launching a competition to find the five best ways of destroying and the five best ways of protecting the huge fields of GM that will be grown this year. Answers on a postcard to: Guardian Eco Soundings, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. A bottle of champagne for the best five contributions.

fields.headline: Plane foolish
fields.standfirst: Tony Juniper  asks why the government backs super jumbos, but not the expertise to create clean energy
fields.trailText: Tony Juniper asks why the government backs super jumbos, but not the expertise to create clean energy.
fields.body:
Events during the last week show that the government's preoccupation with new technology is disastrously skewed towards unsustainable development. The imminent closure of the Harland & Wolff shipyard and the decision to spend £500m developing a new generation of vast jumbo jets are important cases in point.

News of the impending demise of Harland and Wolf came the day after the government launched its draft climate change strategy. But what seems to have been overlooked is the connection between the possible closure of Belfast's ship builder and the fact that Britain has the largest resource of offshore wind of any European country.

Wind, unlike oil and coal, remains untapped. Harland and Wolf has the world-beating marine engineering skills to capture the wind so that it can power the future British economy. But it won't until someone steps in with the orders for huge offshore turbines to do the job.

The Danes, by contrast, have already realised that the future will be renewable and now have a leading stake in the mushrooming world demand for wind hardware and expertise. On the other side of the North Sea, however, the British seem to have barely cottoned on to how support for new technology should fit with wider policy.

The consequence is that one of the world's leading engineering companies is being allowed to sink beneath the waves of global market forces, while our EU competitors employ thousands in wind power. A world class centre of expertise may well be wound up - not only with the potential loss of a great economic opportunity for the entire country but with the loss of over 1,700 jobs in an already economically hard-pressed region.

If the non-interventionist argument is that firms should compete on merits without state help, why is British Aerospace to get up to £0.5bn of government support to develop a super jumbo jet?

The reason is clearly not to promote sustainable development. Air transport emissions are one of the fastest growing sources of green house gases. Bigger aircraft are not going to solve the problem, and indeed may only fuel unsustainable development around the world.

The answer perhaps lies in what the government considers as modern technology. GM foods and giant aeroplanes qualify as benefits for the future, whereas wind turbines and organic farming techniques apparently do not.

The government seems to have forgotten that it has signed up to sustainable development. And protecting the environment need not be anti-jobs or economically unsound. For example, a recent Friends of the Earth report found that meeting the government's 20% carbon dioxide emissions reduction target could lead to a net gain of 250,000 jobs - many in renewable energy industries.

A separate Greenpeace report estimates that a 10% contribution to the UK's electricity needs from offshore wind farms - an easily achievable target of the kind adopted by the Danes - would generate some 20,000 jobs in manufacture and installation, with more than 9,000 jobs required in operation and maintenance.

That Harland & Wolff cannot be positioned at the vanguard of a UK-wide shift towards a more sustainable economy is a tragedy. In so far as it is still not too late to save jobs and signal a new direction for state intervention in industry, the DTI and PowerGen should meet with the management of the engineering firm to cook up a deal to give the Danes a run for their money.

Support for Harland & Wolff would send a strong message about what sustainable development is all about and emphasise what role new technologies should have in achieving it. Continued support for super jumbos and GM crops suggest only that British economic policy continues to tilt at windmills.
