For example, a recent Friends of the Earth report found that meeting the government's 20% carbon dioxide emissions reduction target could lead to a net gain of 250,000 jobs - many in renewable energy industries. A separate Greenpeace report estimates that a 10% contribution to the UK's electricity needs from offshore wind farms - an easily achievable target of the kind adopted by the Danes - would generate some 20,000 jobs in manufacture and installation, with more than 9,000 jobs required in operation and maintenance. That Harland & Wolff cannot be positioned at the vanguard of a UK-wide shift towards a more sustainable economy is a tragedy. In so far as it is still not too late to save jobs and signal a new direction for state intervention in industry, the DTI and PowerGen should meet with the management of the engineering firm to cook up a deal to give the Danes a run for their money. Support for Harland & Wolff would send a strong message about what sustainable development is all about and emphasise what role new technologies should have in achieving it. Continued support for super jumbos and GM crops suggest only that British economic policy continues to tilt at windmills.

fields.headline: Caring on a full stomach
fields.standfirst: Mary MacLeod urges Gordon Brown to invest in families to develop  the 'human capital' of the nation - starting by simplifying benefits
fields.trailText: Mary MacLeod urges Gordon Brown to invest in families to develop the 'human capital' of the nation - starting by simplifying benefits
fields.body:
Things are coming together for families at last. We are waking up to the facts of social life - that we are all connected to each other. Business depends on people, and people depend on business. If it takes terms like "human capital" and "family business" to persuade the hard-headed that investing in families is the only sensible course to take in social policy, that's OK.

Now is the time for the chancellor to reach into his pocket and invest in families. In his budget next week, he could do much to put substance behind the government's commitment to help families with young children. He could increase the flat rate maternity pay from £60 to £100 per week, extend the period of entitlement from 12 to 19 weeks, and increase the number of weeks paid at 90% of salary from the current six weeks to 10 weeks, allowing more mothers to stay at home in the early weeks if they want to. He could also raise the child benefit payment in the first year.

All of these will have a different effect and help different types of family. Apart from the wealthy, all families have a stake in this. But there are principles: poor families must be helped, too. This is why we are urging the chancellor to increase the £200 Sure Start maternity grant to £1,000, to provide realistic support for mothers and babies in deprived areas. There are hard decisions to take about who receives the money, since children benefit more from mothers' money than from fathers'.

At least we are seriously thinking about work-life balance - giving people time to be a family. We have the right to parental leave when the need is there, though not the means to make it a reality. We are finding ways to improve teaching in schools about relationships. We even recognise that the same skills are needed in the school, home, work place and on the streets if we are to be able to lead "the good life" together.

All the evidence from research shows that it is the quality of relationships - whether in the home or in child care - that raises children well. It's about promoting a culture of decency.

But caring has always been harder to do on an empty stomach or with worries about how to manage. This is especially so now, in the presence of conspicuous wealth and fame. Families need to be supported with money as well as words - and the money is there. We cannot remind ourselves enough that one in three children in the UK lives in poverty and that it greatly affects life chances.

We hear that many mothers who want to stay at home longer to care for their babies, can't because they fear they will lose their jobs, or the mortgage makes it impossible to think of giving up work.

We know that in the early months of their lives, babies are highly sensitive. And we have to make it possible for families to provide the best quality of care at that time, however they can manage it. This is good for baby and good for mother and father. Shame on you, parliament, for going wobbly at the sight of mothers breastfeeding. Is it too much of a reminder that all you big, grown-up, powerful people who make laws were babies once?

A few measures could transform these early months for families and for children - an investment to grow our "human capital". But the devil is in the detail. What kind of investment, to whom, when, for how long, and who pays? And the detail is certainly devilish - as anybody who has tried to explain working families tax credit can confirm.

We have spent too long putting up with a piecemeal system of family benefits, bits tacked on to bits. Let us get some joined up work to transform the mess into a transparent, understandable system where people can work out their likely entitlements without needing armies of benefits advisers to make sense of it. Given the complexity, that is a longer-term goal and it should be in every party's manifesto. But what about now?

Much as it is tempting to say "go back to the drawing board" over the whole system and set up another review - of which this government has done so many - we need something now.

Parental leave must be paid. This would be a direct contribution to poorer families. UK research has shown they are least likely to be able to take leave. Families must get extra resources to make these early vital months easier. It is simply crazy to have mothers unwilling and sad at work if they would rather be caring for their babies at home and, for the cash conscious, it is the cheapest way.

Lots of families just cannot avoid debt with mothers at home and want the "part-time" solution. The government should make it a right.

fields.headline: Cry baby, cry
fields.standfirst: For a child, the loss of a  parent or sibling can have  huge repercussions if they  are not allowed to grieve.  Hannah Foxcroft reports  on plans to help children  cope with their anguish
fields.trailText: For a child, the loss of a parent or sibling can have huge repercussions if they are not allowed to grieve. Hannah Foxcroft reports on plans to help children cope with their anguish.
fields.body:
Not a day goes by without a child in this country experiencing the death of a parent or relative. Bereavement, of course, unleashes a torrent of emotion in all of us, irrespective of age. But there is something unique about the way in which a child copes with grief - and when it is negated, as it often is, the consequences are severe.

"In many ways, a child's grief is more straightforward compared to an adult's, but adults restrict them from expressing it," explains Julie Stokes, clinical psychologist and chief executive of Winston's Wish, a project set up in 1992 to help children, parents and schools through the bereavement process.

Anne Scoging, co-ordinator of child bereavement services at Marie Curie Cancer Care, says: "A panic sets in when people know that a child is involved. People just freeze and don't know what to say."

Children become confused by this message. As Stokes points out, essentially it tells them "that they can't talk about it or, at times like this, they have to just get on with it". She believes this lack of communication is more prevalent than most of us would imagine. "Children have a remarkable ability to convince people they are fine - and that is what we all want to think," she says.

The second major way in which adults can hinder the bereavement process in a child is associated with the fact that children have the added complications of dealing with emotions that they have probably never experienced before, and certainly don't have "labels" for. They simply do not know how to deal with feelings of sadness, anger and abandonment or even understand them, and therefore need support.

The repercussions for children whose opportunity to grieve is denied are huge. They are far more likely than other children to be bullied at school and to attempt suicide. The ability to form close relationships in adult life is obstructed and the risk of mental health problems is increased.

"I felt like nobody was interested in me," explains Emma Williams, 28, who was 10 when her father died suddenly. "I was made to feel like a worthless human being."

At school, Emma's behaviour became disruptive, she was bullied and her academic work suffered. "I don't remember anyone ever asking me how I felt," she says. At 19, she was suffering severe panic attacks and finally received help in dealing with her father's death - nine years too late.

The support children need through the period of bereavement must come from parents, carers, teachers - anyone, in fact, who is involved in their life. But a key problem is that few local authorities have facilities for bereaved children, or for those who have the best intentions for a child but feel inadequately prepared in dealing with the delicate task of bringing them through their grief.

In an attempt to change this situation, Marie Curie is staging the first national conference on bereaved children and the care they receive, to be held in London on March 21. It will bring together over 700 people from a wide range of professions - from police to funeral directors, parents to policy makers - and calls will be made for widespread resources for all those who need help in supporting children to meet the huge demand.

The government has already taken steps in recognising that public awareness needs to be raised on childhood bereavement. The revised national curriculum now includes bereavement studies in the PSHE (personal, social and health education) syllabus, but this alone is not enough.

Through their experiences of dealing with bereaved children, Marie Curie has identified a spectrum of care that should be available for all bereaved children, "whatever their position, geographically and emotionally, for however long they need it".

The spectrum covers parental support relevant to most bereaved children, through to psychiatric intervention, which, it is estimated, is used only by 2%.

However, it seems that community based projects are the most effective. Winston's Wish, for example, is a service that has proved to be highly successful in allowing children to mix with other bereaved children, sharing their experiences, creating memory boxes and remembering the person who died, which in turn allows them to move on. To date, however, the availability of a successful project like this is rare.

It is hoped that by highlighting the essential needs of bereaved children, at the conference, things will begin to change. For the death of someone close to occur in your formative years can be devastating. Children are strong, but they need communication and support.

Julie Stokes says: "Holding on to memories while letting go and moving on with a new future is a huge challenge - a challenge which is at long last being embraced and will provide a lasting legacy for the thousands of children who survive a death of a mum, a dad, a brother or a sister."

 For details about the conference, contact Margaret Fitz-Hugh at the Marie Curie education department (tel: 01883 347761).

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: A man who thought he had lost £700 during a drunken night out in Southampton over Christmas has received an anonymous postcard from a cab driver thanking him for the big tip that paid for a family holiday in the Canary Islands.
fields.body:
Going swimmingly: The darts and dominoes teams at a pub in Tipton, West Midlands, claim that their recent run of victories is due to them adopting a goldfish as their mascot and carrying it in its bowl to away games.

Weight gain: Organisers of a charity competition in Bridgwater, Somerset, to guess the weight of a cake changed it to guessing the weight of a goat which had eaten the cake.

High tax: Councillors in Bury, Greater Manchester, have imposed a £50 levy on the burial of people taller than 6ft 4ins.

Force for evil: The vicar of a church near Boscastle, Cornwall, has blamed "designer garden" TV programmes such as Ground Force, starring Charlie Dimmock, for a spate of thefts of slate floors from churches.

Sweet revenge: A six-year-old schoolboy from Northwich, Cheshire, phoned the police and asked them to arrest his mother and teacher because he failed a spelling test and didn't get the reward of a sweet.

Flightless birds: The pilot of a flight from Gatwick to Malta had to abandon take-off at the last minute when cabin crew discovered four live chickens on board.

Taken for a ride: A man who thought he had lost £700 during a drunken night out in Southampton over Christmas has received an anonymous postcard from a cab driver thanking him for the big tip that paid for a family holiday in the Canary Islands.

Cabin pressure: A plane carrying passengers on a course to help them overcome their fear of flying had to make an emergency landing at Manchester airport when an oil leak caused the cabin to fill with smoke.

Far out: Faults in a new tracking system for council vans in Cupar, Fife, were detected when it gave out information that the vehicles were located in Russia and South Africa.

Out of order: A man who used his neighbour's credit card to order goods from a mail order catalogue was rumbled when they were delivered to the neighbour's house in Lancashire because he was out.

Crushing blow: Ministry of defence officials rang a man to say they had found his stolen car on a Salisbury Plain firing range, then rang back to say it had been flattened by a Chieftain tank.

Never say Dai: An ancient by-law has been discovered that makes it permissable to shoot a Welsh person in Hereford, as long as it is done with a longbow, on a Sunday and in the cathedral close.

Immobile library: The head of a school in Coulsdon, Surrey, is having to slash the budget for books because of the soaring phone bill caused by parents giving their mobiles as contact numbers.

Mute point: A wildlife expert's study of mute swans in Northumberland shows that, despite the fact that they are supposed to be monogamous, the divorce rate is now about 7%.

fields.headline: Direct route to equality
fields.standfirst: James Churchill urges the government to have the courage of its convictions  over benefit payment to people- some severely disabled - in care homes
fields.trailText: James Churchill urges the government to have the courage of its convictions over benefit payment to people- some severely disabled - in care homes.
fields.body:
Government ministers have said that they are reviewing the way social security money called preserved rights (PRs) is spent. These are payments to keep those people living in care homes on benefit who were there before the rules were changed in April 1993. People entering care homes after that date receive much lower levels of income support and have their care costs met by local authorities (after a care and financial assessment), with the client possibly making a financial contribution depending on circumstances.

So, elderly people with PRs living in care homes are usually cost-free to LAs, and "younger" people (that is, under pensionable age) in homes have their care costs (ranging up to £343 per week) met by the DSS. Since 1993, the number of elderly people on PRs has declined and younger disabled people now form the bulk of recipients. However, what started out as a support system has now become a trap for both groups (especially in the south-east). PRs payments no longer even cover basic care home costs for older people, but regulations prevent LAs from "topping up" (that is, paying the fee shortfall) for older people on PR.

There is evidence that this group may fare less well than their LA-funded post-1993 equivalents in terms of room quality, en suite facilities, access to single rooms, etc. They are, in practice, outside the LA's contract with the care home and the purchasing power of the LA ensures the best deal for its "own customers". Preserved rights now preserve inequity for this group.

Also, although many younger disabled people do have their care costs "topped up" by LAs, but find that if they move out of residential care they will lose their PRs, increa sing the cost to the LAs. Not surprisingly, many users and their families are reluctant to move and lose their PRs, even if local possibilities arise, and many LAs are not exactly pushing for such moves, because of the extra cost to them it involves.

So, having started out as a good idea, seven years later PRs are now seen by some as part of the problem. PRs produce pressures to maintain the status quo, keep dependency and stifle innovation - but change is problematic because they are still very popular with users and families. The difficulty facing the government is that simply withdrawing such payments (currently made as of right) is bound to enrage an already prickly and vociferous disabled lobby, seeing it as yet another assault on the precious few real levers of power they have. The current estimated cost of PRs to the DSS is around some £960m a year. PRs are essential to support the current levels of care in the community: without them the whole system would slide into crisis.

The quick-fix solution is to roll up all the PRs monies and give them to LAs, making LAs do proper assessments of need for everyone in a care home receiving state benefits and allowing them to top up anyone who needed it. This would not be well received by many younger users and their families, who have no great love of or faith in the ability of many LAs to meet long-term care commitments. There is a strong attraction for them in having at least some permanent secure funding as of right.

There is a more radical solution which would support the government's declared desire to promote independence, inclusion, flexibility and a user-centred approach to services. This would be to convert PR into a direct payment (DP). This is a system of paying for care and support which individual users can use to purchase whatever services they choose to meet their assessed needs.

DPs could be used to pay for domiciliary care, local drop-in support, day services, residential or nursing care home costs, or one of the many types of "housing with care and support" schemes. It would encourage flexibility and experimentation as the individual's circumstances changed. Since the PRs monies would be permanently transferred to LAs they would not be lost to the care system as people died and could be used to support the next generation.

The government has recently extended the use of DPs both to 16 and 17 years olds as well as the over 65s. Regulations restrict the purchase of residential care with DPs to very short periods, but there is no real reason why these restrictions could not be lifted. Here is an opportunity to empower service users to take control of the money used to support them to buy the service they want, rather than the one which DSS regulations now require them to have or lose altogether. This move would also receive widespread support from many service providers who dislike the restrictions current PRs rules impose.

The real change would be for LAs who have been notoriously slow to promote the uptake of DPs. There would be a real shift of power to users and encourage wider usage of DPs. All LAs would have to set up local systems to support large numbers of users, making them largely autonomous purchasers of care and support services. It would place large sums of expenditure well beyond local control, and this might be politically unwelcome in some areas.

Opportunities like this do not come often. Seldom have so many broad policy objectives been realisable within such a simple change of practice. It remains to be seen whether the government has the courage put into practice its oft stated desire to make services responsive to users' needs and wishes. Just handing all the money over to LAs will not achieve that.

Ministers have often said that DPs are the way to go for the future and criticised LAs for their slow progress on making DPs work. Changing the £842m of PR payments into DPs, rather than just giving it to the LAs, would be the best way of showing that this government says what it means and means what it says.

 James Churchill is chief executive of the Association for Residential Care. This is a personal view.

This would be to convert PR into a direct payment (DP). This is a system of paying for care and support which individual users can use to purchase whatever services they choose to meet their assessed needs. DPs could be used to pay for domiciliary care, local drop-in support, day services, residential or nursing care home costs, or one of the many types of "housing with care and support" schemes. It would encourage flexibility and experimentation as the individual's circumstances changed. Since the PRs monies would be permanently transferred to LAs they would not be lost to the care system as people died and could be used to support the next generation. The government has recently extended the use of DPs both to 16 and 17 years olds as well as the over 65s. Regulations restrict the purchase of residential care with DPs to very short periods, but there is no real reason why these restrictions could not be lifted. Here is an opportunity to empower service users to take control of the money used to support them to buy the service they want, rather than the one which DSS regulations now require them to have or lose altogether. This move would also receive widespread support from many service providers who dislike the restrictions current PRs rules impose. The real change would be for LAs who have been notoriously slow to promote the uptake of DPs. There would be a real shift of power to users and encourage wider usage of DPs. All LAs would have to set up local systems to support large numbers of users, making them largely autonomous purchasers of care and support services. It would place large sums of expenditure well beyond local control, and this might be politically unwelcome in some areas. Opportunities like this do not come often. Seldom have so many broad policy objectives been realisable within such a simple change of practice. It remains to be seen whether the government has the courage put into practice its oft stated desire to make services responsive to users' needs and wishes. Just handing all the money over to LAs will not achieve that. Ministers have often said that DPs are the way to go for the future and criticised LAs for their slow progress on making DPs work. Changing the £842m of PR payments into DPs, rather than just giving it to the LAs, would be the best way of showing that this government says what it means and means what it says.  James Churchill is chief executive of the Association for Residential Care. This is a personal view.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
I believe it was the American satirical magazine the Onion that created the fictional headline "Drugs Win Drug War". Whoever came up with the phrase deserves an award for encapsulating in four words the idiocy of all those metaphors which, together with the overblown titles such as "drug tsar", seek to suggest that the complexity of drug use can be reduced to a battle between the forces of light and darkness.

Social scientists have repeatedly railed against such reductionism, but they've now, somewhat unexpectedly, been joined by a distinguished clinician who has become sufficiently incensed by the constant misrepresentation by politicians, editorial writers and the police of drug use that he will devote a public lecture to the issue.

Next week at the Royal Geographical Society, the emeritus professor of addiction behaviour at the Institute of Psychiatry, Griffiths Edwards, will attempt to bring some intellectual rigour to the debate.

He happily admits that this is not an easy task: "The teenage gang sniffing lighter fuel, the housing estate awash with heroin, cocaine snorted in the night club, a child buying a single cigarette, the drunk in the street... Such a plethora of mind-acting substances taken in such varied ways and doses by so many different people in diverse life circumstances, so many levels of explanation ranging from what happens at the synaptic junctions in the brains of the users to the macro-economics of the drug market. How are we to make sense of such complexity?"

He finds his answer in ecology. The statistics on illicit drug use suggest a 340-fold increase in the last 40 years, and Edwards argues that this development has the familiar ring of an ecologically determined population explosion.

Why not, therefore, regard drug users as a species who inhabit a metaphorical forest. If any of the characteristics of this forest change, whether it be the character of the inhabitants, the quality or the price of the drugs they consume, then the population of drug users in the forest will rise or fall. Only if we take such a stance, argues Edwards, can we get away from the absurd notion that we can simply eliminate entire species of drug users.

Good sense, perhaps, but, as Edwards is likely to gather from any official reaction to his talk, so much less politically fruitful than the good old drugs war.

 Laurie Taylor will discuss the ecological model of drug use with Griffiths Edwards on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

webTitle: 'There is no longer such a thing as a purely natural weather event'

fields.headline: 'There is no longer such a thing as a purely natural weather event'
fields.standfirst:
Did global warming cause the floods in Mozambique? Mike Hulme analyses the scientific evidence
Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: Did global warming cause the floods in Mozambique? Mike Hulme analyses the scientific evidence.
fields.body:
With the immediate crisis in Mozambique gradually receding, now is the time to address the question I have been asked most frequently over these last two weeks, by journalists, friends and acquaintances, and even by my own seven-year-old daughter: "Were the floods caused by global warming?"

To answer this question, we need to distinguish between the meteorology of what happened - very heavy rains over several days across a very wide area - and the impacts of the rainfall upon river flows and the subsequent human dislocation and suffering.

Whether widespread heavy rain leads to extensive flooding depends on local factors such as land cover, dam management and flood control. And whether excessive flooding leads to widespread human suffering depends on where people live, what warning they are given and what options they have to remove themselves from risk.

Clearly, there are lessons to be learnt from the events in Mozambique in both of these areas, but they are not lessons directly related to global warming. The more precise question we have to answer is: "Were the heavy rains over south-eastern Africa caused by global warming?"

This question does not lend itself to a simple "yes" or "no" answer. It is not possible to prove or disprove that a given severe weather event only occurred because of a rapidly warming global climate.

We can try to argue from first principles by saying that a warmer atmosphere will hold more moisture and, therefore, have the capacity to deliver heavier rainfall. Or we can argue that warmer ocean temperatures potentially provide tropical cyclones with increased energy to make them more vigorous and the rainfall more intense. But in neither case does this convince us that these particular heavy rains were caused by global warming.

Alternatively, we can try to argue from the statistical evidence. Have such intense rainfalls been recorded before in this part of the world? Well, yes they have - in the 1950s, for example. But have such heavy rainfall events become more frequent? For this part of Africa, the data has not yet been analysed with this question in mind and nor is the data particularly long or reliable enough to yield a convincing statistical answer.

This analysis, by the way, has been performed in some other regions - the US, UK and Australia - and evidence has been found for a trend towards more intense daily rainfall totals in recent years.

For Mozambique, the definitive answer to our question continues to elude us. Indeed, it is quite possible that, in another 25 years' time, even with the world 0.5C hotter than today, climate scientists will still be saying the same thing: "We cannot say that any specific extreme weather event is caused by global warming."

If we approach our question from a different angle, however, then I believe there is something important to say about the relationship between global warming and extreme weather events - and this needs saying now, and needs repeating each time the need for action to mitigate climate change, or to adapt to its consequences, is questioned.

We know that the global climate is warming. We know that the rate of warming has accelerated in recent decades. Following the 1996 report by the UN's intergovern-mental panel on climate change, the balance of evidence reveals a detectable human influence on this warming.

A warming global climate will inevitably lead to changes in the behaviour of all weather systems - the systems that actually deliver weather to us, extreme or not. A global climate warmed by human pollution of the atmosphere must yield different magnitudes and frequencies of a whole spectrum of local weather events.

In this sense, therefore, the weather we now experience is the result of a semi-artificial climate; in a fundamental sense, it is different from the weather we would experience on a parallel planet which humans had not polluted. All weather events we experience from now on are to some indeterminable extent tainted by the human hand. There is no longer such a thing as a purely "natural" weather event.

This is the important message to take away from Mozambique, or indeed from any other extreme weather event, such as the heavy rainfalls in Venezuela before Christmas or the windstorms in France after Christmas.

We are running massive risks by altering the climate of our planet in ways we do not fully understand, let alone are able to predict with confidence. As with genetically-modified organisms, humanly-modified climates potentially expose us to risks that are largely unknown and unquantified. And the longer we continue to rely on a carbon-based energy economy, the greater these risks will be. It will take more than the 20% reduction in UK greenhouse gas emissions announced last Thursday by the government to bring these risks under control.

Gambling with our climate may be acceptable to those of us living in affluent societies in the north, reckoning that we can adapt or buy our way out of climate trouble, but this gambling mentality is not one that would find many takers in Mozambique this week.

The heat is on
 The annual mean temperature in central England for 2000 is about 1.5C above the 1961-90 average.
 The unconfirmed global mean surface air temperature anomaly for 1999 - the 5th warmest year yet recorded - was +0.33C above the 1961-90 average.
 Conditions are now warm enough for malaria-carrying mosquitoes to survive in southern England.
 British songbirds are nesting, on average, two weeks earlier than they were 10 years ago.

 Dr Mike Hulme is reader in climatology at the University of East Anglia, Norwich.

fields.headline: The acid test
fields.standfirst: Eat, drink and be wary: the  latest pills may allow us to  over indulge, but they can  also mask serious problems.  Peter Pallot reports
fields.trailText: Eat, drink and be wary: the latest pills may allow us to over indulge, but they can also mask serious problems. Peter Pallot reports.
fields.body:
Pills that let you take a vindaloo curry and a lot of beer without so much as a polite burp are a runaway success. They are gaining "lifestyle drug" status among foodies and boozers, amid fears that they are being hugely over-prescribed by doctors.

The drugs, known as proton inhibitors (PPIs), stop production of stomach acid. They are licensed to treat inflammation and ulcers in the gullet caused by acid splashing up through the food pipe, or gastric reflux. Indigestion can be triggered by greasy or spicy food, eating too fast, smoking, heavy drinking and becoming overweight.

But the new pills are so effective that they allow people to over indulge. They have become so popular that some doctors fear they are seen as a passport to long-term unhealthy living rather than a short-term treatment for ulcers. There are concerns too that prolonged use can mask danger signs, such as cancer symptoms.

The drugs - including Losec, Zoton, Protium and Pariet - are relatively cheap, at about £1 a day. But with two million users at any one time, costs have leapt from £50m in 1992 to an estimated £400m last year.

An investigation by the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice) into their use begins this month. Nice established its creden tials by barring NHS prescribing of the anti-flu drug Relenza because few old people took part in trials. The watchdog could be equally forthright with the tummy tablets.

A department of health source said: "PPIs are often prescribed inappropriately. They are so effective for ulcers that patients can eat a curry washed down with 12 pints of lager without getting symptoms.

"Correct prescription is a four-week course, followed by another four weeks if an ulcer or scarring is not fully healed. But people are on them for much longer. Once they have got to that stage they are loathe to stop because you can immediately feel the acid coming back. It becomes a habit. It's easy for the GP to hand out another prescription."

Typical of how treatment can go wrong is the case of Laurie Noble, a business executive of Peterborough, Cambridgeshire. "Back in 1995, I had a lot of stomach pain and nausea," she recalls. "A doctor put me on lansoprazole (Zoton). The pain went away but always returned. This went for almost three years and when I saw another doctor at the practice she looked concerned and arranged an endoscopy." The stomach examination revealed the bacterial infection H-pylori, which was treated with antibiotics.

Noble says: "The first doctor never stopped to ask why I was not getting better. It was easier to keep on prescribing the tablets. If I had not seen the other doctor I would still be pumping myself full of chemicals."

Such cases sparked a warning from the Medical Research Council two years ago. It criticised GPs for starting off all indigestion patients on PPIs because, it said, doctors often failed to "step down" treatment to basic remedies.

The council warned: "The possible disadvantage with the step down approach is that patients will remain on long-term PPI therapy and not be stepped down to alternative treatments. If this occurs, the step down approach has evolved into a 'single agent' approach where all patients presenting with dyspeptic symptoms are prescribed a long-term PPI.

"This approach has no benefit and is flawed in that it does not take into account disease severity, complications and benefits of individualising treatment."

According to the MRC, only one in eight PPI prescriptions is for ulcers; most are given "inappropriately". The council also cautions against using the drugs in people aged over 45. Yet they are given initially to almost seven in 10 patients over the recommended age limit.

The council said simple antacids could work just as well, while a mid-way approach was offered by H2 antagonists such as Zantac, the world's first billion-dollar drug.

Mark Hamilton, medical adviser to the Digestive Disorders Foundation, says: "PPIs are extremely effective both from the patient's perspective in the treatment of symptoms and from the medical perspective. They are also effective from an ulcer healing point of view and from the reflux, heartburn angle. The problem is they are so effective that people find that nothing works as well."

The likely fate of people on PPIs for long periods is a matter of "considerable contention" among gut specialists, says Hamilton, a consultant gastro-enterologist at the Royal Free hospital, London.

Most specialist meetings have a session on possible long-term PPI side effects because they are so much newer than H2 antagonists. Basic antacids are viewed as safe, Hamilton says, and "if Gaviscon and Rennies work, nothing else may be necessary."

Ironically, doctors urge us not to smoke, to eat less fatty food and lose weight - all factors in indigestion - while dishing out the pills that make such a lifestyle possible. At the same time, PPIs are swallowing 7% of the NHS drugs budget.

Against such a background, the Nice review, due in June, is sure to cause queasiness among manufacturers such as Astra, Wyeth, Knoll and Eisai. For taxpayers, it could be good news - even if curries lose a bit of their spice.

fields.headline: Milk
fields.trailText: 1. Plunging milk prices are threatening the future of the British pint, warn the national farmers' union.
fields.body:
1. Plunging milk prices are threatening the future of the British pint, warn the national farmers' union.

2. The amount of money farmers receive for the milk they produce has nearly fallen by a third in the last three years - they get less than 10p for every pint they sell, while supermarkets charge up to three times that amount.

3. Hitting back, the supermarkets say they make a low profit on milk and complain that the dairies squeeze out the money.

4. So the dairy farmers are off to Westminster to complain. They hope dressing their tractors up in mock fresian cow skins will make the "townie" politicians heed their plight.

5. The situation, say the farmers, is not helped by the strong pound and is so bad that they are facing bankruptcy while over 5,000 people involved in dairy farming lost their jobs last year.

6. In a demonstration earlier this month, Welsh dairy farmers took 20 tankers to a field in Monmouthshire and destroyed more than £8,000 worth of milk. Their stunt was supposed to raise public awareness.

7. It wasn't always like this. Milk used to be special: in the Bible the promised land is referred to - 20 times - as a land of milk and honey.

8. The crash isn't restricted to Britain. In the United States, the richest country on earth, dairy prices are falling from California in the west to Pennsylvania in the east.

9. Unlike the recent years of beef production, we can still count on cows to come up with the good stuff. The danger is if milk production becomes uneconomical and all but ends in the UK.

10. We drink 13bn litres of milk a year. If we can't produce it fresh then we may be forced to buy it in powdered or long life.

fields.headline: The avenger
fields.standfirst:
He put Steed and Mrs Peel through their paces, and made a shorter, better version of Titanic. Now the neglected director Roy Ward Baker is writing a book about his life in cinema. Sheila Johnston meets him

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: He put Steed and Mrs Peel through their paces, and made a shorter, better version of Titanic. Now the neglected director Roy Ward Baker is writing a book about his life in cinema. Sheila Johnston meets him
fields.body:
Pale sunlight dribbles into the book-lined living room of Roy Ward Baker's Kensington home as he pours coffee, settles into his armchair and prepares to impart the wisdom acquired from over half a century in film. His considered opinion? "Most films these days are too long. Hitchcock always said that their length should be governed by the capacity of the human bladder. You should have seen the queues for the toilets after Titanic."

Baker speaks with unassailable authority: his own movie of the Titanic story, A Night to Remember, is generally adjudged by far the best (a framed cutting from the Times of 1958 in his loo commends its "horrifying realism"), and was more than an hour shorter than James Cameron's version.

Baker takes a modest view of his craft. "I hope my audiences will take enjoyment in a piece of work well done. Occasionally, not every time. If I weren't a director I would have been a very good cabinet maker. I like the detail and precision of that work. My pictures are all very presentable. There's nothing untidy about them."

Born in 1916, Baker was at school when the talkies arrived and knew that it was the only thing for him. As tea boy at Islington's Gainsborough Studios in the 30s, he worked on 38 pictures in six years, rubbing shoulders with Claude Rains, Boris Karloff and Fay Wray. "It's the best way to learn because you can go anywhere until people tell you to mind your own business. My advice to young directors is, 'Stick close to the camera and keep your mouth shut.' "

It was 14 years before Baker was to direct his own first feature, The October Man, in 1947. Meanwhile he worked with Robert Stephenson and a young Carol Reed, and sat at the ample knee of Alfred Hitchcock - "businesslike, totally professional" - as second assistant director on The Lady Vanishes (1938).

Lured briefly to Hollywood by Darryl F Zanuck at 20th Century Fox after the war, he met Marilyn Monroe and directed her in one of her first leading roles, as a babysitter in Don't Bother to Knock (1952). "A very ordinary little picture, but it did its job and a lot of people liked it," he comments. "Films are a mass form of expression - it's no use making them for 10 friends."

Back in Britain, Baker worked with Peter Finch, Dirk Bogarde and Bette Davis, ushered Steed and Mrs Peel through the Avengers and Roger Moore through the Saint, and directed Quatermass and the Pit (1967), the third and - most buffs think - most successful film of Nigel Kneale's sci-fi cycle. "But I do think that there is a common thread of realism. fields.headline: Rover: government steps in
fields.standfirst: Read what Victor Keegan has to say about Rover
fields.trailText: The British government today contacted BMW to stress the importance of Rover amid reports that the German car maker intends to sell its ailing British subsidiary.
fields.body:
The British government today contacted BMW to stress the importance of Rover amid reports that the German car maker intends to sell its ailing British subsidiary.

"The government has been in touch with the company," said the department of trade and industry. "They have informed us that they will be considering a range of options at the supervisory board meeting tomorrow. We have stressed to them the importance of the company to the UK."

The government statement could be seen as thinly-veiled pressure on BMW to keep Rover going. Rover, dubbed the English Patient in the German media, has been waiting to receive a £152m government aid package. But the money has been held up pending a European Commission investigation to determine whether the aid constitutes an unfair subsidy. Other European car makers have objected strongly to the planned government package.

In a sign of Rover's political importance, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers cancelled a planned media call for regional journalists in Bristol about the Airbus, to return to London for "pressing business". He is being urged to make a statement to the Commons later today.

BMW for its part said German media reports that its management board has already decided on the future of Rover were "pure interpretation". A BMW spokesman emphasised that any management decision on whether to sell Rover was entirely dependent on what BMW's supervisory board decided at its meeting tomorrow.

At stake is not just the future of 16,000 Rover employees, but that of tens of thousands of others who supply parts for Rover. Tony Woodley, national officer of the Transport and General Workers Union, said he was "extremely worried" by media reports that BMW intends to sell Rover. "If the speculation is accurate then, clearly, we are looking at the potential break-up of Rover Cars," Mr Woodley said. "That does mean at least three of our plants and 16,000 direct jobs would be in jeopardy in the long term, and clearly this isn't a supportable way forward. It is not only not in the interests of Britain and British workers, I don't believe it is in the interests of BMW. They would find it incredibly difficult, having gone down in size, to compete and remain independent in a competitive global market."

An air of despondency hung over the Longbridge plant as workers arrived for their shifts. Many workers voiced fears that BMW was about to announce a decision to axe the 9,000 jobs. Keith Bagnall, who has worked at the sprawling Birmingham site for more than 30 years, said: "We have been here before and we all know that BMW are only interested in the plant at Solihull and the profitable Land Rover part of the company." Rover has been hit by low productivity, falling sales and mounting losses. BMW had previously given Rover managers until 2002 to break even, but its patience appears to be running out. Reports suggest that Rover losses ballooned to more than £800m from $600m a year earlier. BMW's threat to close Rover could be a way of applying pressure to the European Commission to quickly approve the British government loan.

"This increases the pressure on Mario Monti (the European commissioner for competition) to approve the UK support for Longbridge," said Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, adding, "I think it is very important that BMW keep their nerve. I find it difficult to see who in the industry would just buy Rover Cars in an industry where there is over-capacity."

Rover home page
Department of Trade and Industry
Transport and General Workers Union

fields.headline: A remarkable woman is suppressed
fields.standfirst: We fearlessly engage in what is called 'dialogue' with dictators
fields.trailText: We fearlessly engage in what is called 'dialogue' with dictators
fields.body:
Rebiya Kadeer was once a model figure in the new, go- getting China. A woman and a member of the Muslim Uighur minority, she made a fortune in business and was using her money and her position to encourage others - particularly women - to do likewise. While other Uighurs engaged in political rebellion against Chinese rule, Mrs Kadeer took the position that she was a businesswoman, not a politician. Her friends say she has always cared deeply for her people and her region, but she has never spoken against the government.

By any standards, Mrs Kadeer is a remarkable woman. Born in 1946 in Xinjiang, the Uighur homeland to the west of China and one of the People's Republic's least developed and least hospitable regions, she married at 16 but was divorced by her first husband after she was attacked in the Cultural Revolution as a budding entrepreneur. Times changed and she opened her first shop in Urumqi in 1982. Only 10 years later her first multi-storey commercial building was completed. Today, her Trade Building in Urumqi contains some 1,600 business units and offers employment to almost 300 paid staff.

Other distinctions followed: she was elected to the China People's Political Consultative Conference and was a member of China's delegation to the UN women's conference in Beijing in 1995. In 1997 she launched a project called the "Thousand Families' Mothers Movement" designed to encourage women to set themselves up in business. Even the mighty Bill Gates asked to meet her. She was such a success that the government appeared willing to overlook the fact that Mrs Kadeer was also the mother of 11 children when the official limit is one. But on March 10, after a perfunctory three-hour trial in which her lawyers were allowed to be present but not to present their case, she was sentenced to eight years in prison for "betraying state secrets".

Mrs Kadeer is not known to have had access to anything that could legitimately be classified as a "state secret" nor is she known to have been involved in any political opposition. The one thing that had changed in her life since the height of her success was that, in 1996, her second husband, Sidik Rouzi, fled to the United States (after an anti-government article that he had written was published in a local newspaper) and was granted political asylum. Since then he has given evidence on Chinese human rights abuses to congress. The couple's five children have left China and are living with their father.

After her husband's flight Mrs Kadeer's passport was confiscated and, in December 1997 she was taken in by the police for questioning. She was held for a few days before being ordered to report on a weekly basis to the local authorities.

A year ago, Rebiya was detained by armed police in her house for three days, coincidentally enough, the same three days that UN commissioners were visiting Urumqi.

In January, the United States took the decision to sponsor a resolution critical of China in the annual meeting of the human rights committee this month in Geneva. Next Monday, EU foreign ministers will meet to decide whether or not to support it. Given that China has one of the worst records on human rights in the world, you might expect such a decision to go through on the nod. Indeed, before the UK had an ethical dimension to its foreign policy, Britain used to support such resolutions regularly. But ethics, like statistics, can behave in curious ways.

In order to avoid upsetting Beijing the EU has adopted a diversionary strategy known as "dialogue". Dialogue, rather like the ethical dimension, is a fine sounding thing which, according to a foreign office spokesman, has achieved all manner of concessions.

The trouble is that since "dialogue" became the EU's primary instrument, the human rights situation in China has suffered a steady decline. Human Rights Watch Asia, Amnesty International and even the US State Department all say so. The FO spokesman, though, says: "We do recognise that the situation is not perfect and it's a long-term business."

The superiority of dialogue over any other approach was much touted during Jiang Zemin's state visit last October. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, fearlessly raised the cases of two political prisoners, both of them Amnesty International prisoners of conscience, in talks with his Chinese counterpart on October 20. One of them was Rebiya Kadeer. Her case was raised again in February in Beijing by officials in the latest round of the dialogue. Hardly had the meeting been concluded, apparently to everyone's satisfaction, when the unfortunate Mrs Kadeer was hauled before a kangaroo court on trumped up charges and banged up for eight years. Who needs UN resolutions, when dialogue is such a success?

fields.headline: Stabbings in the dark
fields.standfirst:
Peeping Tom: the remake

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Peeping Tom was the film that buried Michael Powell's career. Now artist Mark Lewis has remade the sequences of film that would have been shot by the serial killer anti-hero.
fields.body:
It is, literally, a sight gag. One of the most famous images in British cinema comes in A Matter of Life and Death (1946), re-released this month as part of the National Film Theatre's Powell and Pressburger season. It's a shot from inside the eye of a patient in surgery, with veiny eyelids closing over the camera lens: point-of-view taken to an absurd physical extreme.

What seems like a flippant visual pun takes on more grotesque connotations given Michael Powell's later career. The logo of Powell and Pressburger's Archers company was an image of arrows piercing a bullseye; it's seen at the start of their films together, and of Powell's 1960 film as a solo director, the notorious Peeping Tom.

Peeping Tom is full of piercings, culminating in what's effectively a symbolic stab right in the film-maker's eye. Its serial killer anti-hero uses his movie camera as a weapon: it's equipped with a stiletto and a distorting mirror. He simultaneously kills and films women, showing them their own fear in the reflection of their screaming faces. He finally commits suicide, plunging the stiletto into his throat, while gazing at his own terrified reflection. Peeping Tom effectively ended Powell's career. Critics found it hard to believe that anything so sordidly psychosexual had been made in Britain - it took the later efforts of fans such as Martin Scorsese to rehabilitate him.

Peeping Tom has now been remade - at least, parts of it have - as an installation by an artist who shares the name of Powell's murderer-voyeur, Mark Lewis. Peeping Tom, by Mark Lewis 2 (let's call him), re-creates the footage shot in the original by the amateur auteur Mark Lewis 1. We see restaged sequences including Mark's killing of a prostitute; the crime scene the next day; the dance performed by the Moira Shearer character just before her murder; and Mark's suicide - the key piece of footage that we never see in Powell's film.

Mark Lewis 2 has used some of Powell's original London locations, and retained the costume conventions of 1960, although they now take on a retro feel. His footage is in vibrant colour, close to Powell's palette, rather than Mark Lewis 1's black and white. It's also elegantly edited: where the fictional Mark left his images in a raw state, his successor uses fades and fast montage sequences, the images recurring rhythmically. This is less a remake, more a trailer for the film that the homicidal director never completed.

But what kind of film was the murderous Mark making? Played by Carl Boehm, Mark talks about making a "perfect film". At one point, he refers to it as a documentary; at others, it seems to be fiction. According to Peeping Tom's writer Leo Marks, Lewis's film actually had a story; Marks once confided its subject to Martin Scorsese, who agreed to keep the secret. We can only speculate about its nature: avant-garde confessional, quasi-New Wave fiction-reality melding, or even, with the killing of the dancer Vivian, a pioneering stab at a snuff musical?

What Lewis 2 hasn't remade is Powell's other home-movie footage: the films made by Mark's scientist father, recording the scientific experiments that used his terrified son as a guinea pig. One thing the critics found especially unsavoury was that Lewis Senior was played in these sequences by Powell himself, with his own son as the young Mark.

The new Peeping Tom is less about voyeurism than about repetition, and is part of the current trend among artists to use existing films as material for speculative remakes. Films about repetition clearly lend themselves to this treatment: last year's Hitchcock exhibition in Oxford included Stan Douglas's looped re-creation of a scene from the kleptomania story Marnie, and Pierre Huyghe's spartan shot-by-shot remake of Rear Window. In its elegant production values, Lewis's film is closer to Gus Van Sant's misunderstood Psycho - which is better viewed as big- budget conceptual art than as a standard Hollywood remake. Lewis is already a specialist at this game: another of his works re-creates the opening of Orson Welles's Touch of Evil - upside down.

Lewis has said that a prime concern in his Peeping Tom is the question of signature in film. Is Mark Lewis the artist producing a pastiche of Powell's film-within-a-film, or plagiarising the work of a dead fictional film-maker called Mark Lewis (who, as a murderous obsessive, perhaps surrenders any conventional claims to being considered an auteur)? Interestingly enough, the Mark Lewis character whom we see killing himself in Peeping Tom (2000) is not played by the living artist Mark Lewis. That would be too confusing.

Mark Lewis's Peeping Tom will be at Norwich Gallery (01603 610561) in June. A Matter of Life and Death opens at the NFT, London SE1 (0171-928 3232), and the Curzon Soho, London WC2 (0171-439 4805), on March 24.

Films about repetition clearly lend themselves to this treatment: last year's Hitchcock exhibition in Oxford included Stan Douglas's looped re-creation of a scene from the kleptomania story Marnie, and Pierre Huyghe's spartan shot-by-shot remake of Rear Window. In its elegant production values, Lewis's film is closer to Gus Van Sant's misunderstood Psycho - which is better viewed as big- budget conceptual art than as a standard Hollywood remake. Lewis is already a specialist at this game: another of his works re-creates the opening of Orson Welles's Touch of Evil - upside down. Lewis has said that a prime concern in his Peeping Tom is the question of signature in film. Is Mark Lewis the artist producing a pastiche of Powell's film-within-a-film, or plagiarising the work of a dead fictional film-maker called Mark Lewis (who, as a murderous obsessive, perhaps surrenders any conventional claims to being considered an auteur)? Interestingly enough, the Mark Lewis character whom we see killing himself in Peeping Tom (2000) is not played by the living artist Mark Lewis. That would be too confusing. Mark Lewis's Peeping Tom will be at Norwich Gallery (01603 610561) in June. A Matter of Life and Death opens at the NFT, London SE1 (0171-928 3232), and the Curzon Soho, London WC2 (0171-439 4805), on March 24.

webTitle: Hanks's sensitivity wins him Santa picture

fields.headline: Hanks's sensitivity wins him Santa picture
fields.trailText: Christmas has arrived early for Tom Hanks with the news that the actor is to produce and star in an adaptation of the children's book The Polar Express, about a child who refuses to give up his belief in Santa Claus. The picture will be backed by Castle Rock, who acquired the rights to the source book by writer-illustrator Chris Van Allsburg for a reported seven-figure sum.
fields.body:
Christmas has arrived early for Tom Hanks with the news that the actor is to produce and star in an adaptation of the children's book The Polar Express, about a child who refuses to give up his belief in Santa Claus. The picture will be backed by Castle Rock, who acquired the rights to the source book by writer-illustrator Chris Van Allsburg for a reported seven-figure sum.

Clocking in at a scant 29 pages, The Polar Express follows its child hero on a trip to Lapland aboard the eponymous magical steam-train. Hanks will play the Polar Express's jovial conductor; the film is tentatively scheduled for an American release in December 2001.

Van Allsburg is no stranger to Hollywood himself. His book Jumanji was conjured into a big-budget adventure film starring Robin Williams back in 1995, but he has until now resisted selling The Polar Express to the movie money-men. "Over the years many people have approached me about buying the film rights," the author told Variety. "None had the stature that Mr Hanks enjoyed, but more significantly, none of them showed the genuine appreciation of the book that he expressed. His sensitivity to the material makes me feel that the train is in good hands."

webTitle: Prodi rebukes EU ombudsman for urging openness

fields.headline: Prodi rebukes EU ombudsman for urging openness
fields.standfirst:
The European Commission: special report

Statewatch report
fields.trailText: Romano Prodi, the European Commission president, was last night embroiled in a furious row with the EU's own ombudsman after rebuking him for discussing freedom of information - in public.
fields.body:
Romano Prodi, the European Commission president, was last night embroiled in a furious row with the EU's own ombudsman after rebuking him for discussing freedom of information - in public.

In the latest spat in a dispute over access to official documents, the ombudsman, Jacob Söderman, rebuffed Mr Prodi's charge that he was wrong to raise the issue in the media.

Mr Söderman is chosen by the European Parliament - the EU's only directly-elected body - and is a hero in his native Finland for repeatedly challenging a lack of openness in Brussels.

"I have sworn to perform my duties with complete independence," he told the parliament's president, Nicole Fontaine. "I remain convinced that European citizens are entitled to a better law than the one the commission has proposed."

The row erupted over an article in the Wall Street Journal, entitled The EU's Transparent Bid for Opacity. In it Mr Söderman accused the commission of restricting access to papers by listing exemptions to availability "without precedent in the modern world".

Mr Prodi rejected the charge and reiterated his own commitment to reducing secrecy, which he has demonstrated by publishing a register of his correspondence - though not the actual correspondence - on his website.

In a letter to Ms Fontaine, Mr Prodi criticised Mr Söderman's article as "polemical and extreme", and "emotional and seriously erroneous". For the ombudsman to express his views publicly was "detrimental to the normal functioning of the institutions", he added.

The issue is extremely sensitive because the previous commission, under Jacques Santer, was forced to resign partly over lack of transparency.

Mr Prodi insisted that the charges that all documents could probably be withheld from public scrutiny were "wide of the mark". Some business information must remain secret but withholding of documents would be "very much the exception". He said the proposals were drawn up in consultation with the public.

But Tony Bunyan, of the London-based freedom of information and civil liberties watchdog Statewatch, said this was not true. "It was drawn up in secret and is a classic example of officials having the so-called 'space to think' shielded from undue pressure."

He added: "It is irresponsible for appointed officials to try to undermine or question the independent functioning of another EU institution whose head, Mr Söderman, derives his authority from being directly elected by the European Parliament."

The freedom of information proposals were drawn up after the 1997 Amsterdam Treaty called on the commission to "enshrine" the citizens' right of access to documents.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Cherry Falls fails to please US censors, Christian Bale ties the knot, and, on the casting couch, Courtney Love and Whoopi Goldberg go to Mars and Kate Beckinsale goes to Pearl Harbour
fields.body:
Teen flick Cherry Falls which is being touted as the next 'Scream', will have to go under the editor's knife if it is to avoid being lumbered with the prohibitive NC-17 rating. The MPAA objected to "graphic scenes of sexuality and violence", and director Geoffrey Wright will re-edit and re-shoot certain scenes. The cuts are expected to come from a big orgy scene and some murders involving a razor-tipped pencil.

Christian Bale, soon to be seen behaving very unpleasantly as yuppie serial killer in American Psycho, has got married. Entertainment Weekly's Liz Smith reveals that the actor tied the knot in Las Vegas in January. Much to the chagrin of the veteran gossip columnist, the actor is far from forthcoming about his new wife, "Her name is Sibi. That's all I want to say except that she's not an actress, and has nothing to do with the business, thank God!"

Casting couch

 Kate Beckinsale is in talks to play the female lead in Pearl Harbour, the long-awaited world war two movie set to begin shooting on 8 April in Hawaii. If she takes on the role, Beckinsale, last seen in Brokedown Palace alongside Claire Danes will play a navy nurse who falls in love with Ben Affleck.

 Courtney Love and Whoopi Goldberg are set to star in John Carpenter's next film, Ghost of Mars, which following the success of Mission to Mars jumps on the Red Planet bandwagon. Love is likely to star as the tough expedition leader, while Goldberg is marked as a possible science officer.

fields.headline: Five tasks for Jimmy Adams
fields.standfirst: Orin Gordon with a list of musts for the new West Indies captain
fields.trailText: 1 Rediscover his own form and wake up Shivnarine Chanderpaul
fields.body:
1 Rediscover his own form and wake up Shivnarine Chanderpaul

Adams's nickname, Hardcore, is a reference to his mental toughness, not his taste in movies. He's got to rediscover the focus that saw him ranked as the world's best batsman in the mid-1990s. A career average of 45-plus is nothing to be ashamed of, but it was an unreal 70 after about 20 Tests, and well over 60 halfway through his 49-match career. It couldn't last, but the steepness of the decline has been worrying. It's not just figures - he looks nothing like the adhesive player of old, and his batting technique has deteriorated. His decline is one of the main reasons for the Windies' recent batting failures, because he should be the perfect foil for the flair players. The other steady, unflashy leftie in the side has been unable to build the long innings he's capable of. A shy, quiet man when he first came into the side, Chanderpaul is discovering that attention and adulation can be difficult to handle. Observers in Guyana say he hasn't been the same since the embarrassing incident in which he accidentally shot a policeman, who surprised him and a "friend" on Georgetown's sea wall - the town's Lovers Lane. Get him to concentrate fully on what he does best, Jimmy.

2 Bring out the best in Brian Lara

It'll mean finding out real quick from the great man how short his "short break" from cricket really is. At the very least he won't be involved in the home series against Zimbabwe. Lara needs to say whether he'll be missing the Pakistan series too. Planning's got to go on and the side's got to be built. He'll have to explain too why he was jumping up in Trinidad's carnival while the other players were preparing to sweat it out for the cause. He and Adams get on well, because the Jamaican is the ultimate team player: friendly and keen, even when things are not going well on the field. Adams was the first to charge from the dressing room and lift Lara into the air when he made that astonishing 153 not out to win the Barbados Test against Australia last year. But Lara seems to have the Ken Livingstone problem: he cannot be part of a team he doesn't lead. Witness the disgraceful way in which he undermined Richie Richardson while campaigning for the captaincy. Richardson and manager Wes Hall could barely control him on the 1995 England tour. Dermot Reeve found him a handful at Warwickshire too. Have you grown up and are you ready to lead the batting, Brian? Adams deserves an answer.

3 Deliver instant success to a cricketing nation that's used to it

Very tough. There's no escaping the fact that the Windies are a bad side. Caribbean fans should not expect an instant turnaround, but they will. No disrespect to Zimbabwe, but Adams is lucky that it's them first up, and not either of the two outstanding sides at the moment, Australia and South Africa. He's also fortunate that the Windies' next opponents are Pakistan, who are even more unsettled than usual with a new captain in Moin Khan and following the noisy departure of coach Intikhab Alam. Add to this the West Indies' record at home, where they have remained almost unbeatable, and instant success is a possibility. But it's consistency and their tendency to go to pieces on tour that I worry about.

4 Get the young players to fulfil their potential

Several are in the frame, a few are Jamaican, and Adams is their captain. The left-handed opener Chris Gayle was one of the best players in the recent Busta Cup - the Windies' first-class competition - and is a possibility for a place in the middle order with Lara out. The Barbadian opening pair of Sherwin Campbell and Adrian Griffith didn't do too badly in New Zealand, where the others failed. Of the other Adams charges, Wavell Hinds looks a classy batsman, and much is expected of the hard-hitting Ricardo Powell. They're players he knows well, and, with sympathetic handling, he may be able to help develop them into consistent performers on the international stage. The problem is that there are too many left-handers in the mix and the Windies will be easier to bowl at. Adams may even get another of his cup-winning players, Franklyn Rose, to break through to the next level. Rose has bowled well when he's been in the side, but he's got a poor disciplinary record, and has not made the progress he should. Reon King came after him and has overtaken him in the queue. He should do better under his country captain.

5 Gracefully phase out Ambrose and Walsh

Adams should, on the other hand, get a fitting final fling out of Courtney Walsh. One of cricket's hard men has been prone to injury lately, and he'll need skilful handling to help him break Kapil Dev's Test record of 434 wickets, which is just nine away. Ditto Curtly Ambrose. England should realistically be the end of the road for both of them. It's Adams's job to make that clear to them, and at the same time encourage them to bowl as well as they ever have for old times' sake. Breaking the record and bowing out will generate emotional highs that can lift the team. In that short period Rose, King, Dillon et al will have to be made aware that they're about to inherit a great legacy. That twin task will not be easy. Adams will need a lot of good luck wishes.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for five years and currently works as a broadcast journalist.

webTitle: Oscar gold comes early for Cider House Rules and Miramax

fields.headline: Oscar gold comes early for Cider House Rules and Miramax
fields.trailText: Its Best Picture nomination has turned Cider House Rules into a veritable goldmine
fields.body:
Its Best Picture nomination has turned Cider House Rules into a veritable goldmine. The film, which this week expanded from 800 to 1,750 screens in the US, and opens in the UK this week, has made $17m since its nomination, taking its box office gross to a cool $40m. Its success follows in a tradition of 'sleeper' films coming good for indie studio Miramax following Oscar nominations. The Crying Game's $15.7m gross shot up to $62.5m following its six Oscar nominations in 1993. Good Will Hunting went from $70m to $138m; Il Postino went from $10.6m to $21.8m, and The English Patient went from $42m to $78.6m.

Last year, Life is Beautiful's box office gross shot from $18.8m to $57.6m, and Best Picture winner Shakespeare in Love went from $36m to $78m, a figure which then rose to $100m its Oscar success.

fields.headline: Who's behind Harry?
fields.trailText: Following Spielberg's decision to drop out of the project, it seems that British director Alan Parker is one of the front-runners to helm the adaptation of the first Harry Potter book.
fields.body:
Following Spielberg's decision to drop out of the project, it seems that British director Alan Parker is one of the front-runners to helm the adaptation of the first Harry Potter book.

Parker clearly takes no heed of the caveat 'never work with children or animals'. The director's first movie, Bugsy Malone, featured an exclusively knee-high cast, and his most recent, Angela's Ashes involved child protagonists from whom he elicited unaffected and natural performances. It remains to be seen how Parker would deal with the various toads, owls and rats that are part of Harry Potter's world.

Parker is one of four Hollywood big-hitters to have been shortlisted. The others are Brad Silberling and Chris Columbus, plus Terry Gilliam, whose name has only recently been linked to the project.

Silberling, who last directed City of Angels was thought to be the top contender, but as revealed yesterday, author JK Rowling seems to have considerable clout in who helms the picture, which is believed to be one in a three-part franchise.

Rowling feels very strongly that the film should be a live action feature - Spielberg was keen on it being computer animated - and that Potter should be played by a British actor.

Among those who recently submitted their ideas for Harry Potter were Steven Spielberg, Rob Reiner, Jonathan Demme, Mike Newell, Tim Robbins, Sam Mendes, Wolfgang Petersen and Robert Zemeckis.

webTitle: Spielberg will finish Kubrick's artificial intelligence movie

fields.headline: Spielberg will finish Kubrick's artificial intelligence movie
fields.trailText: Ending months of feverish speculation in Hollywood's high places, Steven Spielberg has announced what his next movie is to be. The director will make Stanley Kubrick's last unfinished project; A.I., a science fiction epic about artificial intelligence.
fields.body:
Ending months of feverish speculation in Hollywood's high places, Steven Spielberg has announced what his next movie is to be. The director will make Stanley Kubrick's last unfinished project; A.I., a science fiction epic about artificial intelligence.

Kubrick had been working on A.I. on and off for the last 18 years of his life (see our news story last September), and, according to the director's brother-in-law and producer Jan Harlan: "came to realise that Steven would actually be the ideal director for the project."

Hollywood's most successful director and most powerful player's next move has been the subject of much debate. Since, as we reported yesterday, Spielberg opted out of the Harry Potter adaptation (attributed by an unnamed Warner executive to "creative differences" between the director and British author JK Rowling), it seemed that Spielberg had to choose between Minority Report, with Tom Cruise, or A.I., Kubrick's philosophical tale about a misunderstood robot boy.

Spielberg, who was earlier this month awarded the Director's Guild of America's prestigious Lifetime Achievement Award, has long described Kubrick as a hero and mentor, and says that he had discussed the A.I. project over a period of many years with the great director. "Stanley had a vision for this project that was evolving over 18 years. I am intent on bringing to the screen as much of that vision as possible along with elements of my own."

Filming on A.I. will begin on 15 July, with a summer 2001 release. This by no means rules out Spielberg's involvement on Minority Report: Cruise announced last night on American TV that filming on the movie would not begin till April/May 2001.

webTitle: Legend has it he survived bullets and poison. Not so, says a new book. Rasputin was a mere mortal

fields.headline: Legend has it he survived bullets and poison. Not so, says a new book. Rasputin was a mere mortal
fields.trailText: "Then the incredible happened. Rasputin jumped to his feet," says the accepted account of the Russian monk's death throes.
fields.body:
"Then the incredible happened. Rasputin jumped to his feet," says the accepted account of the Russian monk's death throes.

"Like red-hot iron his fingers tried to grasp me by the throat. This dying, poisoned and shot-ridden creature - raised by the powers of darkness to avenge his destruction - inspired me with a feeling so terrifying, so ghastly, that the memory of it haunts me to this day."

Not so, says a book out tomorrow which claims to draw on newly available Soviet documents. Rasputin, whose priapic legend haunted the court of the last Tsar, did not prove almost indestructible and did not almost kill his attackers.

Like ordinary mortals, he succumbed to "one minor flesh wound" plus two further bullets fired by conspirators jealous of his influence.

The book, Rasputin: The Last Word, is said to be based on hundreds of full witness statements disclosed for the first time in 83 years after being given to a commission of inquiry into Rasputin's death and the Tsarist court set up by Alexander Kerensky's provisional government of 1917.

The source of these statements remains a mystery. The Russian cellist Mstislav Rostropovitch sent them five years ago to the book's Russian author, Edvard Radzinsky, who has published works on Tsar Alexander and Stalin.

Rostropovitch says he bought the "lost file" of interviews at a Sotheby's auction "somewhere on the continent" in 1995. So far Sotheby's, while casting no doubt on this, has been unable to trace the source of the papers.

Yesterday Radzinsky's publisher, Ion Trewin, the editorial director of Weidenfeld and Nicolson, said the author had compared handwriting samples from the inquiry file with other samples by the same people.

Moreover, said Mr Trewin, the scholar Robert Service, an authority on Soviet documentation, had read the book and believed the file was authentic.

Today Rostropovitch will attend the book launch in London, amid hopes that he can can remember the provenance of the documents more clearly. When he heard of the book project, he told Radzinsky: "I have found the great prize you are looking for."

The book shows that reports of Rasputin's superhuman strength and personality were concocted by communists after the Soviet revolution to discredit Tsar Nicholas and Tsarina Alexandra.

But parts of the myth are true. The monk was still breathing when his body was thrown bound but unweighted into an icy river.

He managed to partly untie his hands, as shown by a police photograph of the corpse.

And he had been extremely close to Alexandra, though a sexual relationship remains unproven. The 524-page book publishes for the first time a photograph of him in the bosom of her family with her children.

According to what it calls "newly revealed" telegrams, Alexandra wrote to Rasputin in 1914: "I shall be back in eight days. I sacrifice my husband and my heart to you. Pray and bless. Love and kisses - darling."

Only two weeks before his murder, she cabled: "You have not written anything. I have missed you terribly. Come soon. Pray for Nicholas. Kisses - darling."

According to one document, Vladimir Dzhunkovsky, governor of Moscow and head of the police, told the Kerensky commission of a drunken restaurant party where Rasputin had told girl singers: "This cloak was given to me by the old woman [Alexandra]."

Dzhunkovsky added: "Rasputin's subsequent behaviour assumed the disgraceful character of a kind of sexual psychopathology. He evidently exposed his sexual organ and - in that condition - continued his conversation with the girl singers, presenting a few of them with handwritten notes on the order of 'Love Unselfishly'.

"In reply to the comment of the leader of the ensemble, Rasputin retorted that he always treated women in that way and remained seated in the same condition."

But Dzhunkovsky did not tell the Tsar of this episode, says Radzinsky, and there is some reason to believe that part of it may have been invented by malicious informants.

Radzinsky says Rasputin was not poisoned by wine and cakes before being shot, as the account by one of his killers, Prince Felix Yusupov, claimed.

Yusupov, a transvestite, flirted with the sexually omnivorous monk and over-diluted the poisoned wine. Rasputin failed to eat the cakes.

After the first, botched shot, Rasputin was disabled by bullets in the back and head fired by another attacker.

Yusupov invented the tale of supernatural strength to hide his mistakes and make his own role more heroic.
