webTitle: The best hotel room scene: The insider

fields.headline: The best hotel room scene: The insider
fields.trailText: The Seelbach Hotel, Louisville, Kentucky. Having illicitly arranged, over the phone, to show him some documents, former tobacco corporation researcher Jeffrey Wigand (Russell Crowe) follows Sixty Minutes producer Lowell Bergman (Al Pacino) up to a room. Once inside, Bergman attempts small talk.
fields.body:
The Seelbach Hotel, Louisville, Kentucky. Having illicitly arranged, over the phone, to show him some documents, former tobacco corporation researcher Jeffrey Wigand (Russell Crowe) follows Sixty Minutes producer Lowell Bergman (Al Pacino) up to a room. Once inside, Bergman attempts small talk.

"Have you always lived in Louisville?"

"Mr. Bergman? What did you want to consult me about?"

A knock at the door; Wigand spins around.

"Who's that?"

"Room service."

Bergman opens the door.

"Come in... over here, please."

The room service waiter brings in a tray of coffee. As Bergman signs the bill, the waiter looks across at Wigand. Their eyes meet. The waiter looks away before leaving.

Lowell pours.

"Cream or black?"

"Black."

Wigand glances at his watch impatiently.

"Look, I really don't have that much time."

Bergman nods.

"Anything you want to know about me, Mr Wigand?"

"Like what? Your sign?"

Bergman smiles. Wigand does not.

"I know what I have to know."

Bergman makes sure to catch Wigand's eye.

"Just so I know you know, when I talk to people in confidence it stays that way."

Wigand looks up.

"How did a radical end up at CBS?"

"I still do the tough stories. And CBS has Sixty Minutes - it reaches a lot of people."

For a moment, Wigand's eyes wander.

"Let's see the documents..."

See also: Barton Fink, King Of New York, Some Like It Hot

Don't see also: Four Rooms

Pointless trivia: Insider director Michael Mann wrote episodes of Starsky and Hutch.

fields.headline: Good balance required
fields.standfirst: Ross Stretton, the next Royal Ballet boss, tells  Judith Mackrell  his plans
fields.trailText: Last year, when Anthony Dowell announced his retirement as director of the Royal Ballet, the company was under considerable pressure to change. It boasted a huge repertory, world-class dancers and a permanent base in the revamped Opera House, yet it lacked the confidence of its golden years under Ninette de Valois and Frederick Ashton, and had no obvious plan for the future.
fields.body:
Last year, when Anthony Dowell announced his retirement as director of the Royal Ballet, the company was under considerable pressure to change. It boasted a huge repertory, world-class dancers and a permanent base in the revamped Opera House, yet it lacked the confidence of its golden years under Ninette de Valois and Frederick Ashton, and had no obvious plan for the future. Clearly a shake-up was needed, but opinion was divided over who should administer it - a major artist who would reinvent the company in his or her own image; a radical impresario in the Diaghilev mould; or a leader with a steady hand. Ross Stretton, the 48-year-old who has just been appointed the Royal's new director, would, I think, regard himself as the last.

Talking over the phone yesterday, Stretton made it clear that he was wary of broadcasting a grand agenda. He doesn't officially start till 2001 and his current job directing the Australian Ballet hasn't brought him into close contact with the Royal. As he says, "I have to wait until I can get to know the dancers, assess their needs and see what motivates them before I come to any big decisions."

The broad picture that Stretton outlines is one of balance rather than revolution. To those concerned for the Royal's classical heritage he offers soothing words: "The classical language, in its purity and beauty, forms the base of any great company. Of course I'll be looking after the classics." He also says that historic links between the Royal and Australian ballets mean that he's very familiar with the British 20th-century classics.

Equally, Stretton is quick to insist that he's no museum curator - "Ballet needs to keep step with the other arts" - and sees "strengthening the modern repertory" as an essential part of his job. Asked which choreographers he has in mind, he cites some obvious names (Nacho Duato, Jiri Kylian, Twyla Tharp, Angelin Preljocaj and William Forsythe) but adroitly concludes, "I could rattle off a whole lot more, but until I get to know the dancers and the repertory it doesn't make sense."

The names he does mention are stars of the international repertory, and one big concern has been that the Royal might lose its distinctive British identity. Stretton promises that he'll maintain the emphasis on home-grown choreographers, then adds, somewhat optimistically, that he thinks the identity of the Royal is a given. "You only have to look at a dancer like Darcey [Bussell] to see the training and traditions of the company. Any dancer who enters the company from outside will inevitably become part of that."

Critics who feel that the Royal's style has been diluted in recent years may roll their eyes, but Stretton obviously sees tradition as evolving rather than static. "The dancers today are not the same as they were 50 years ago; they are young, fresh, vibrant and energetic."

Stretton knows that running a national ballet company requires him to be a three-headed monster. "As a director I have to be in the studio teaching the dancers, but at the same time, I have to have a repertory to teach, so I've got to be out looking for new work. But it's no good having new works if you can't sell them. Fundraising, working with the rest of the institution to present the image of the company, that's all part of the job." He admits it's "scary" but he sounds buoyant. "It's a great honour to be chosen to run a company with this kind of heritage and this kind of status. I'm very excited."

fields.headline: Coming out of the closet
fields.standfirst:
At last we can tell you what Alastair's up to

Read the transcript
fields.trailText: Today, for the first time in a British newspaper, we publish a verbatim account of what the prime minister's press secretary -that is Alastair Campbell - told journalists when they met at at their regular 4 o'clock lobby meeting.
fields.body:
Today, for the first time in a British newspaper, we publish a verbatim account of what the prime minister's press secretary -that is Alastair Campbell - told journalists when they met at at their regular 4 o'clock lobby meeting.

There is, we frankly admit, nothing sensational about these exchanges. Readers may even find them a touch on the dull side. It is probable that we will never repeat the exercise. But it seemed worth marking this small, but significant moment in the history of relations between government and press.

The moment is this: for the first time in the 70-odd year history of the parliamentary lobby, newspapers are free to tell readers what is being said on behalf of the government and - importantly - who said it. No more hiding behind archaic euphemisms or vague appellations.

This newspaper can claim some modest credit for attempting in 1986 to force this issue at a time when the cosy system of unattributable briefings was too eas ily misused as a channel for (in John Biffen's striking metaphor) the transmission of sewage. Lobby journalists voted 67-55 to keep the briefings off the record, so the Guardian withdrew from the lobby until after both Mrs Thatcher and Mr Ingham had departed and the system was marginally improved by their successors.

Today the prime minister's official spokesman is a figure firmly in the public domain: the subject of two full-length biographies and soon to be the focus of a BBC TV documentary. He had already - to his credit - begun to publish sanitised versions of the morning lobby briefings on the Downing Street website. Hiding behind a variety of official titles was becoming increasingly artificial.

Mr Campbell is reported to be keen to abolish the afternoon lobby meeting altogether. It would be an irony if - just as daylight is finally cast on this obscure channel of information - the government were to close it down.

webTitle: Voice of the lobby revealed at last

fields.headline: Voice of the lobby revealed at last
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report
Read the transcript
fields.trailText: The Guardian today publishes for the first time detailed extracts of a lobby briefing of Westminster journalists by Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman.
fields.body:
The Guardian today publishes for the first time detailed extracts of a lobby briefing of Westminster journalists by Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman.

It follows Mr Campbell's decision on Monday to bow to media demands and drop his anonymity when quoted speaking on behalf of the prime minister.

The extracts are a record of yesterday's four o'clock briefing, the second of the day, which takes place from Mondays to Thursdays in an upper room in the Commons when parliament is sitting.

Mr Campbell agreed to media requests to identify him by name after disclosing that he had decided - without waiting for feedback from reporters - to allow the journalist Michael Cockerell to film lobby briefings for a BBC documentary.

The Guardian publishes the extracts in the belief that relations between the government and media should be conducted in as open a manner as possible. The paper was one of several to boycott lobby briefings in the 1980s in protest at the then non-attributable system.

fields.headline: More holes in net privacy
fields.trailText: Charles Clarke's view of the regulation of the investigatory powers bill's decryption powers (Letters, March 10) is "we will only prosecute if you're guilty". Internet users manage a plethora of passwords to protect email, files, and website registrations. Failure to produce any password required by any public authority for any official purpose (S.46.2.b.ii) means two years' jail. The court will convict if it believes you were lying about forgetting a password, or uncooperative in finding it.
fields.body:
Charles Clarke's view of the regulation of the investigatory powers bill's decryption powers (Letters, March 10) is "we will only prosecute if you're guilty". Internet users manage a plethora of passwords to protect email, files, and website registrations. Failure to produce any password required by any public authority for any official purpose (S.46.2.b.ii) means two years' jail. The court will convict if it believes you were lying about forgetting a password, or uncooperative in finding it.

No evidence is needed of involvement in a substantive crime. Moreover, a lifetime gagging clause prevents telling what happened on penalty of a further five years (S.50). The data protection act mandates data controllers to take adequate precautions including encryption, so they are in jeopardy either way.

Caspar Bowden

Director, Foundation for Information Policy Research

cb@fipr.org

 To crack down on the black economy, the government intends to amend the data protection act to allow access to individual bank accounts and to force private companies to release data on their employees. Can we expect the same rigour and transparency in the area of public conduct? Will Peter Mandelson's bank account be made public in the interests of mortgage ethics? Will the register of members' interests be cross-referenced with bank accounts and published on the internet?

Richard Harris

Newport, Gwent

fields.headline: Lastminute paper fortune
fields.standfirst:
After all the hype, frenzied shares float leaves investors disappointed
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: After months of anticipation and hype, the internet shopping business Lastminute.com finally joined the stock market yesterday and immediately crystallised a £150m paper fortune for its founders, Brent Hoberman, 31, and Martha Lane Fox, 27.
fields.body:
After months of anticipation and hype, the internet shopping business Lastminute.com finally joined the stock market yesterday and immediately crystallised a £150m paper fortune for its founders, Brent Hoberman, 31, and Martha Lane Fox, 27.

Mr Hoberman and Ms Lane Fox, who have become pin-ups for the new breed of net entrepreneurs, were in their Mayfair offices early yesterday to watch the newly floated shares soar from a sale price of 380p to 555p in minutes, valuing the 19-month-old company at £835m at one stage. At the end of the day, after a frenzy of trading on the stock market, the price settled at 477p.

"I'm not quite myself today," said Ms Lane Fox, trying to compose herself for one of several TV interviews first thing in the morning. Under strict instructions from her American investment bankers at Morgan Stanley not to make any leading comments on the share price or value of Lastminute.com, she restricted herself to explaining how the £113m raised from the flotation will be used to finance the expansion of the Lastminute sales concept across Europe and then around the world.

But the 200,000 investors who rushed to buy shares in the flotation - registering their details in advance at the company's website - suffered severe disappointment. Shares for the public were distributed evenly among applicants, leading to allocations of 35 shares for each investor, which were worth £167 last night. After paying dealing charges and tax, any new-issue speculator selling the shares will be lucky to make a profit.

Lastminute started off by selling cheap flights online, but branched out to offer everything from flowers and chocolates to theatre tickets. Mr Hoberman and Ms Lane Fox believe there is a huge market potential in selling to "asset rich/time poor" customers who are too busy to organise their shopping and who tend to be natural last-minute purchasers.

Aside from luring regular internet shoppers, Lastminute.com also expects to see a spectacular increase in purchases made over mobile phones - travellers, for example, might book a flight that way, then also choose a restaurant at their destination through their mobile internet connection.

Lastminute is also developing services through digital TV, after signing deals with cable companies NTL and Cable & Wireless Communications.

Mr Hoberman, said his immediate task now was "to keep moving fast, to execute the business plan".

Many commentators, though, have questioned the valuation attached to a business that will not make a profit for the foreseeable future and which has transacted deals, such as flight purchases, worth only £4.3m during the last three months of 1999.

But Julie Meyer, one of the founders of First Tuesday, a networking club for budding cyberspace entrepreneurs, said she was confident about Lastminute. She pointed out that it commanded a scarcity value among investors.

"They were pioneers, out there early, and they have built a great brand name. It is now virtually impossible for someone to replicate it. As for value, it is like beauty - all in the eye of the beholder," she said, adding that Mr Hoberman and Ms Lane Fox have been instrumental in widening the popularity of the net in Britain. "These guys have changed the face of e-commerce in the UK. Great brand names do not disappear overnight."

Mr Hoberman and Ms Lane Fox believe there is a huge market potential in selling to "asset rich/time poor" customers who are too busy to organise their shopping and who tend to be natural last-minute purchasers. Aside from luring regular internet shoppers, Lastminute.com also expects to see a spectacular increase in purchases made over mobile phones - travellers, for example, might book a flight that way, then also choose a restaurant at their destination through their mobile internet connection. Lastminute is also developing services through digital TV, after signing deals with cable companies NTL and Cable & Wireless Communications. Mr Hoberman, said his immediate task now was "to keep moving fast, to execute the business plan". Many commentators, though, have questioned the valuation attached to a business that will not make a profit for the foreseeable future and which has transacted deals, such as flight purchases, worth only £4.3m during the last three months of 1999. But Julie Meyer, one of the founders of First Tuesday, a networking club for budding cyberspace entrepreneurs, said she was confident about Lastminute. She pointed out that it commanded a scarcity value among investors. "They were pioneers, out there early, and they have built a great brand name. It is now virtually impossible for someone to replicate it. As for value, it is like beauty - all in the eye of the beholder," she said, adding that Mr Hoberman and Ms Lane Fox have been instrumental in widening the popularity of the net in Britain. "These guys have changed the face of e-commerce in the UK. Great brand names do not disappear overnight."

fields.headline: Inmate died after staff 'cock-ups'
fields.trailText: "Blunders, cock-ups and incompetence" led to a prisoner hanging himself in his cell only hours after he had been found attempting suicide, the St Pancras coroner Stephen Chan said yesterday.
fields.body:
"Blunders, cock-ups and incompetence" led to a prisoner hanging himself in his cell only hours after he had been found attempting suicide, the St Pancras coroner Stephen Chan said yesterday.

Staff at The Mount prison in Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire, and Pentonville prison, north London, failed in their professional duty by not properly informing each other of the mental state of Alfonso Coley, 43, who died in August last year. He had been serving a five-year sentence for arson.

After the verdict of death through misadventure to which neglect contributed, Dr Chan said the duty of care upon staff had "been found wanting".

fields.headline: Hope, change and school failures
fields.standfirst:
Third superhead quits: Fresh starts with new teachers, better facilities and untainted names have not overcome problems

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: East Brighton College of Media Arts
fields.body:
East Brighton College of Media Arts

Ofsted inspectors arrived at the then Stanley Deason school in May 1996 and discovered that not enough children were attending school; too many were failing exams; and the school was in deficit and was going to have to make cuts to stay alive.

The Ofsted inspectors suggested it should be put into "special measures", which would mean the local education authority would have to give more support and more funding. However it would also mean the school would be branded a failure and that tag would turn prospective pupils away.

The inspectors returned in mid-1997, more than a year after Ofsted's initial visit, and said things were improving. Funding was provided for a new senior teacher and in September the school was relaunched with a new name, Marina High.

However the problems continued and inpsectors returned in November. The following month the school was warned by the LEA that it would close if there were not dramatic changes. There were not.

In February 1998 the education department visited the school and did not like what it saw.

Inspectors followed and reported that the school was still failing.

In July last year the school was closed and reopened under the fresh start initiative. Everything changed, including staff, curriculum and the name. It was reopened as the East Brighton College of Media Arts in the same buildings and with the same pupils.

While attempts at change have been made the latest school reports suggest there is just as much unrest as before, with pupil behaviour still bad and staff turnover high.

Yesterday principal Tony Garwood stepped down as head, throwing the government's fresh start policy into turmoil, as the school became the third in five days to have its superhead resign.

The Islington Arts and Media School

It opened on September 13 1998 as part of the fresh start scheme, just weeks after it had closed its gates as the George Orwell school, a notorious Islington comprehensive with poor results, high truancy rates and falling numbers.

The north London school had been given £8m for improvements. Classrooms were freshly painted, a new five-a-side football and basketball pitch were built in the playground and the returning pupils arrived back in a new uniform.

All the teachers were made redundant. They were asked to reapply for jobs that were advertised nationally and only six of the original staff were re-employed.

However the problems at the school did not disappear with the old name. Two weeks before secretary of state David Blunkett was due to visit the school for the official opening, a riot broke out in the playground. Up to 40 pupils became involved in a lunchtime row over a bag of chips. The police were called to break up the teenage mob after teachers had failed to pull them apart.

Despite the hype and all the changes, the school failed to turn around its poor record. Torsten Friedag, the "super head" who took over when the new school opened, resigned last Friday. Two weeks ago John Leovald, the former head of Acton high school in west London, was brought in as a troubleshooter, and is now acting principal.

Firfield Community School

Exam results at Blakelaw comprehensive in Newcastle were among the UK's worst, with just 9% of pupils gaining five or more GCSEs at grade C or better. Its attendance record matched.

It was a record so poor that the government decided to make Blakelaw the guinea pig for its fresh start initiative. After Ofsted failed the school in 1997 it was renamed Firfield Community and a new "superhead" was brought in.

That superhead, Carole McAlpine, resigned on Monday and will leave at the end of this term. Ms McAlpine had already turned around one failing school in Pilton, the Trainspotting suburb of Edinburgh, and expectations were high that she would be able to repeat the performance. She sacked most of the original staff, introduced a new uniform and the school was given a makeover, but for all the redesigns the old faults still remained. The school sits between two of the most deprived estates - Cowgate and Blakelaw - in the west end of Newcastle.

As part of the fresh start programme children at the school were offered cash bonuses of £80 a term for turning up.

The scheme appeared to be reducing truancy and the Newcastle education authority said that improvements had been made to the learning environment in a very short period, but added there were still urgent problems in standards of numeracy, and "inconsistency" in the quality of lessons and attendance.

webTitle: Third superhead quits fresh start school

fields.headline: Third superhead quits fresh start school
fields.trailText: The government's fresh start policy for reviving failing schools was rocked yesterday by the third resignation within five days of a "superhead" appointed to rescue pupils from indiscipline and under-achievement.
fields.body:
The government's fresh start policy for reviving failing schools was rocked yesterday by the third resignation within five days of a "superhead" appointed to rescue pupils from indiscipline and under-achievement.

Tony Garwood stepped down as principal of the East Brighton college of media arts, a problem secondary school near Roedean college that featured in last week's Guardian series on schools in crisis.

His departure followed the resignations since Friday of Carole McAlpine from a fresh start school in Newcastle upon Tyne, and Torsten Friedag from another in Islington, north London.

There are only 10 schools so far in the fresh start programme, devised by ministers to rescue chronically failing schools by reopening them under a new name, new management and a staff that excludes teachers who could not successfully reapply for their jobs.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, was last night considering what lessons could be learned from the resignation of three of the 10 heads. But there were no signs that he was ready to drop plans to expand the programme to more secondaries if they fail to meet ambitious GCSE targets in the next three years.

"There are issues around the fresh start programme which we will be addressing fairly shortly. There are things we need to learn from this," a senior department source said.

There was "no alternative" to the fresh start approach since it was usually not desirable to close failing schools and disperse the pupils, the source said. "But we need to look at ways of making sure there are sufficient targeted resources to support these schools."

It is understood that ministers will reconsider their lack of powers to influence the appointment of fresh start heads, currently under local control, and there may be more funding for the schools.

Two weeks ago Mr Blunkett warned secondaries they faced a fresh start if 15% of pupils could not achieve at least five passes at grade C or above within three years.

The first three fresh start schools reopened in 1998, and ministers say they succeeded in reducing truancy and the number of pupils leaving with no GCSE passes. Six more, including East Brighton college, opened in September last year, and another in January.

Mr Garwood, the former head of a struggling Islington school, supervised the closure and reopening of the Brighton school. He said last night: "During this year we have begun the process of creating a new college aspiring to new standards. In time this will deliver the desired academic improvements needed and it is my judgment that the college will be best served by appointing a new principal whose skills will meet closely the key tasks ahead."

His resignation followed an emergency staff meeting last week at which teachers complained that he and Frieda Warman-Brown, the chair of governors, suppressed a letter from the local education authority expressing grave concerns about the school.

They defended their decision to withhold the letter on the grounds that they feared its content would damage morale. Ms Warman-Brown resigned from the governors last week saying she needed more time for her work as executive councillor for education on the local authority.

According to one senior teacher at the college, an exodus of 18 staff in less than two terms had forced the employment of 58 supply teachers. The situation at the school was "a hundred times worse than last year".

webTitle: Blunkett bid to halt Section 28 revolt

fields.headline: Blunkett bid to halt Section 28 revolt
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: David Blunkett, the education secretary, will tomorrow seek to head off a Cabinet revolt over his handling of the repeal of Section 28 by publishing statutory guidance referring to the importance of stable relationships as well as marriage.
fields.body:
David Blunkett, the education secretary, will tomorrow seek to head off a Cabinet revolt over his handling of the repeal of Section 28 by publishing statutory guidance referring to the importance of stable relationships as well as marriage.

He will also publish guidance on sex education in schools giving teachers freedom to address teenage pregnancy and sex outside marriage.

Ministers had feared that Mr Blunkett was so intent on winning the bishops' support for repeal of Section 28 that he was willing to pass laws projecting marriage as not merely the best but the sole context for raising children. He has been in negotiations with both Anglican and Catholic bishops for nearly a month discussing the wording of the amendments to this part of the local government act.

Section 28, which was passed by the Conservatives, bans councils from promoting homosexuality in schools, but has become a lightning rod for a wider debate about equal treatment for homosexuals.

A Downing Street source said the bishops had been driving a very hard bargain, partly under pressure from their congregations. Mr Blunkett needs the churches' support if he is to overcome resistance, from mainly Conservative peers, to the repeal.

By a massive majority, the Lords rejected repeal during the passage of the local government bill, though ministers had insisted that councils no longer had a role in sex education in schools.

To try to defuse the row, Mr Blunkett will tomorrow table an amendment to the learning and skills bill, now before the Lords, setting out marriage as the foundation of society. However, the amendment will also refer to the importance of stable relationships in raising children. Liberal minded ministers will be able to interpret these words as supportive of gay partners and parents who raise children outside marriage. It will be one of the first times that ministers have set out their views on marriage in a statutory form.

Tomorrow, Mr Blunkett will also publish a draft consultation document on the teaching of sex education in schools. Ministerial sources said it would place a heavy emphasis on the need to educate children about how to avoid teenage pregnancy.

The document will closely follow the advice set out in the recent social exclusion unit report on teenage pregnancy, which called for sex education to be comprehensive and include advice about the need to use contraceptives.

Government guidelines on sex education have not been revised since 1994, and Britain has the highest level of teenage pregnancy in Europe.

The department of health and Baroness Jay, the minister for women, have warned against tabling any statutory amendment that restricts the freedom of teachers to talk to pupils about teenage sex. The guidelines will also reject stereotyping, and advocate respect for those who appear to be different.

If the bishops support the compromise, as expected, Labour will use its majority to reinstate the repeal of Section 28. Labour ministers hope Conservative resistance in the Lords will crumble if the bishops stand back.

Stonewall, the gay pressure group, said it would set greatest store by the draft guidelines, rather than the amendment to the leaning and skills bill, since the guidelines would be the document with which teachers would work.

webTitle: Blunkett plans network of city academies

fields.headline: Blunkett plans network of city academies
fields.trailText: David Blunkett will today invite businesses, churches and voluntary groups to build and manage a network of "city academies", a new type of urban secondary schools outside the control of local authorities.
fields.body:
David Blunkett will today invite businesses, churches and voluntary groups to build and manage a network of "city academies", a new type of urban secondary schools outside the control of local authorities.

The plan is closely modelled on the city technology colleges (CTCs), a Conservative initiative launched in 1988 in an attempt to introduce business methods into areas of educational disadvantage.

Mr Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, aims to have six city academies established in the first year of the programme. They will either be new-build schemes or total refurbishments of existing inner city schools.

The academies will usually replace failing or under-achieving schools and their sponsors will be expected to have plans to improve the education of all the pupils displaced by the change.

Mr Blunkett will outline the scheme in a speech today to the Social Market Foundation. "We expect in the coming months to be in a position to publish a prospectus for city academies and name the first promoters and areas," he will say.

There will be no single blueprint for the academies, but the aim will be "to improve pupil performance and break the cycle of low expectations".

This may involve different approaches to school management, governance, teaching and the curriculum.

The academies will be expected to specialise in a particular subject and share that expertise with other local schools. Although the national curriculum will still apply, the academies will be allowed to vary it and experiment with a longer school day and different patterns of terms and holidays.

There may be "new approaches to staffing", including bonuses to retain the best teachers.

But the academies will not be allowed to select the ablest pupils. A national admissions code will apply, allowing testing to secure a balanced intake across the ability range, but not departing from a comprehensive system.

The scheme will be introduced under powers in the 1988 education act which established the (CTCs). Conservative ministers were disappointed when few businesses came forward to fund the CTCs and effectively abandoned the programme in favour of converting existing secondary schools into specialist colleges.

Labour endorsed that programme and expanded it to 480 schools specialising in technology, languages, arts or sport. Mr Blunkett is promising to expand that to 800 over the next two years.

Education department sources said the new programme owed as much to the "charter school" movement in the United States as it did to the Conservative-inspired CTCs.

They said Mr Blunkett would not specify the size of investment expected of business, voluntary or church sponsors, but that they would be partners with central government rather than local education authorities, giving more flexibility than is available to voluntary-aided or foundation schools.

Mr Blunkett will present the policy as an example of the government's efforts to promote diversity in education.

webTitle: Low tax a moral duty, says Hague

fields.headline: Low tax a moral duty, says Hague
fields.trailText: Governments had a "moral duty" not to demand too much tax from the public, William Hague said last night. Paying more tax, the Conservative leader said, weakened citizens' rights to decide how to spend their income.
fields.body:
Governments had a "moral duty" not to demand too much tax from the public, William Hague said last night. Paying more tax, the Conservative leader said, weakened citizens' rights to decide how to spend their income.

He likened Gordon Brown, the chancellor, to a "giant squid" whose tentacles were slowly smothering economic freedoms.

Downing Street hit back, challenging Mr Hague to explain how he would fund tax cuts by reducing welfare benefits, and said taxation under the Tories would have been higher in a year's time.

The Conservatives are hoping their tax guarantee - to lower tax regardless of economic circumstances - will be a vote winner.

In a keynote speech to the Politeia think tank, in which Mr Hague outlined his aim of making tax a key election battleground, he warned high taxation took away the need for individuals to take responsibility for their own lives, and made citizens "cynical" about the ability of the Government to deliver.

"High taxes mean less freedom, less responsibility, less community, more dependency, a less elevated human condition," he said.

Mr Hague said Tony Blair and Mr Brown wanted to make government bigger and redistribute increasing amounts of income.

"Like some giant squid in a monster movie, the chancellor wants to gradually extend the tentacles of the treasury and suffocate our freedom without anyone even noticing."

Tax on tobacco and drink had been raised to the point where millions of law-abiding people were ready to break the law to evade the duty, he said.

"However unacceptable and illegal tax evasion is, the fact is that high taxes lead to a growth in the sly arts of dodging and weaving. How often have we heard someone say, 'It's only the tax man who loses out, and he doesn't deserve my money anyway'.

"I wonder how many people accepting the offer of a friend to buy tobacco or drink for them in Calais ponder the fact that both they and their friend are engaged in a criminal act? This is a classic case of high tax driving out good conscience and introducing corruption on a wide scale," said Mr Hague.

fields.headline: ITN in £375,000 libel victory
fields.standfirst:
ITN and war reporters win libel victory against magazine

ITN libel case: special report
fields.trailText: ITN and two reporters won a resounding £375,000 libel victory in the high court yesterday over a magazine's accusations that they had deliberately misrepresented an image that came to symbolise the atrocities of the Bosnian war.
fields.body:
ITN and two reporters won a resounding £375,000 libel victory in the high court yesterday over a magazine's accusations that they had deliberately misrepresented an image that came to symbolise the atrocities of the Bosnian war.

The news organisation and two reporters, ITV's Penny Marshall and Channel 4's Ian Williams, sued LM magazine over an article headlined "The picture that fooled the world", which questioned the credibility of their 1992 report on two Serb-run camps in Bosnia.

The two were each awarded £150,000 by the jury - the maximum suggested by the judge, Mr Justice Morland - while Independent Television News received £75,000.

LM magazine - formerly Living Marxism, and with a circulation of 10,000 - also faces a bill for costs estimated at more than £300,000. This means the magazine, its editor and its publisher - who had raised only £70,000 in donations towards their £100,000 costs - are now bankrupt.

The TV reporters had called "outrageous" an allegation that they deliberately misrep resented the image of an emaciated Bosnian Muslim, Fikret Alic, as being caged behind barbed wire at Trnopolje camp by selective use of "camera angles and editing".

The footage, which was likened to that of the Nazi concentration camps, prompted an international outcry and was credited with hastening western military involvement.

The unanimous verdict by the jury of 10 men and two women brings to an end a three-year libel battle that had threatened far-reaching implications for television news coverage of war.

The trial also raised questions about the "journalism of attachment" by war reporters, while ITN's decision to sue LM prompted debate about the strict libel laws and whether media organisations should use them against each other.

At the end of the two-week trial, the jury found that a February 1997 article by Thomas Deichmann, a German journalist, was wrong to claim that the image of Mr Alic was deliberately misrepresented by the reporters.

LM's editor, Mick Hume, and its publishers, Informinc (LM) Ltd and Helene Guldberg, had pleaded justification and fair comment. The article claimed the barbed wire was not around the camp - which Mr Deichmann said was a refugee collection centre not a prison - but around the news team, filming from a small enclosure next to the camp.

The two ITN journalists - whose news teams were accompanied to the camps by the Guardian journalist Ed Vulliamy - claimed the article and an accompanying press release and editorial amounted to a highly damaging attack on their reputations and professional integrity.

As the jury returned its unanimous verdict after four hours, a tearful Ms Marshall was comforted by Mr Williams. ITN issued a statement promising to pay any of their £75,000 damages recovered to the International Committee of the Red Cross.

Mr Williams said outside the court: "It's tremendous to be vindicated. What we have seen is a sordid attempt to rewrite history. This verdict is important for many people who suffered and died in those camps in northern Bosnia."

In a joint statement the reporters said LM had declined every opportunity to retract the allegations and apologise, adding: "There is absolutely no doubt that freedom of speech is essential to society. But the freedom to print lies masquerading as the truth, as LM did, is not."

Richard Tait, ITN's editor-in-chief, said the verdict "wholly vindicates our decision to take action against LM over the lies they told."

Both Mr Hume and Mr Deichmann refused to apologise for the article and stood by it.

Mr Hume, who denied allegations in court that he had taken a pro-Serb line during the Bosnian conflict, said: "The only thing this court case has proved beyond reasonable doubt is that English libel law is a disgrace to democracy and a menace to free press."

webTitle: One man band with 'big mouth and broad mind'

fields.headline: One man band with 'big mouth and broad mind'
fields.standfirst:
The magazine accused of being wilfully perverse

ITN libel case: special report
fields.trailText: LM, the glossy monthly magazine at the centre of the ITN libel trial describes itself as "the big-mouthed, broad-minded magazine produced in the UK that shouts what others don't dare to whisper".
fields.body:
The glossy monthly magazine at the centre of the ITN libel trial describes itself as "the big-mouthed, broad-minded magazine produced in the UK that shouts what others don't dare to whisper".

LM is "an agenda-setting publication that goes against the grain", the website says.

It is also a "shoestring operation" on the fringes of British journalism with a readership of only 10,000, the editor, Mick Hume, 40, admitted.

The magazine was born from the ashes of Living Marxism, the mouthpiece of the Revolutionary Communist party edited by Hume since its 1988 launch. Helene Guldberg and Claire Fox formed a company, Informinc, and bought the title in 1992, changing it to LM and arguing that "if Gentlemen's Quarterly had become GQ then LM could be a new current affairs magazine, post-politics".

Hume, an austere one-time communist, remained editor, and the magazine became, to all intents and purposes, a one man band. He admitted using a pen name in LM, because it was embarrassing to have so many articles by the same person in a single edition.

His critics claim that the magazine has a policy of "being against everything but for nothing", without any coherent ideology or political philosophy, and wilfully perverse on the issues it debates.

It supports scientific testing on animals and a "human-centred morality" while opposing the Gulf war, western involvement in the Bosnian conflict, environmentalism, "the counselling culture" and population control. It takes an unashamedly libertarian ap proach to personal relationships and privacy.

Nevertheless, it attracted a young, affluent, well-educated readership drawn largely from the media world, and persuaded big names from across the political spectrum to speak at its various events, conferences and seminars.

The aim of LM, the owners said, was to create a magazine that could reflect the new shift in politics, where left and right were no longer relevant labels.

It would be a publication brave enough to "put its head above the parapet" and "ask questions rather than collapsing into bland consensus", treating adults as grown-ups and seeking to ban nothing while questioning everything.

The magazine, which rarely has advertisements and does not pay its contributors, says it has no big backers from any political party or group, relying instead on small donations from dedicated readers.

As Claire Fox said earlier this year: "The whole premise of LM was that contributors would write for free under the banner of free speech.

"We think we publish a cutting edge, cultural, current affairs magazine on a shoestring budget that has made an impact on a range of debates. But in the eyes of LM's opponents, the magazine has been branded Stalinist Serbomaniac, a Monsanto-backed attack on environmentalism and a diabolical rightwing propaganda rag that hates animals and apologises for genocide."

Hume and his colleagues have made their way into mainstream media, regularly heard on Nicky Campbell's Radio 5 Live show, while Hume has a column in the Times.

According to Ian Hargreaves, journalism professor at Cardiff university: "LM has become a phenomenon, admired by the political right as well as the left." Or, as a leftwing journalist put it, "a bizarre personality cult around a non-personality".

webTitle: Minister blames UN for flood warning failures

fields.headline: Minister blames UN for flood warning failures
fields.standfirst: Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: The international development secretary, Clare Short, yesterday defended her department's role in relieving Mozambique's floods.
fields.body:
The international development secretary, Clare Short, yesterday defended her department's role in relieving Mozambique's floods.

Instead she blamed the United Nations Office for the co-ordination of humanitarian affairs (Unocha) and, at one point, the government of Mozambique, for not responding swiftly enough to the rising flood water which engulfed the country.

Appearing before a Commons committee hearing into the dispute between her department and the Ministry of Defence over the cost of sending helicopters to southern Africa, Ms Short insisted that the high cost of £2.2m initially charged by the MoD for sending RAF Puma helicopters to Mozambique had not delayed their departure. It had been more effective to hire aircraft locally earlier on.

"There was a failure of ca pacity, unsurprising in the government of Mozambique, to get information to people to go to higher ground," she told the international development committee. "A lot of people if they had been warned would have moved ... the UN was slow to move initially. We need a world-wide system that can respond to emergencies particularly in areas subject to natural disasters.

"We have the beginnings of an international (network) but it's weak and needs strengthening. We've been trying to work with the UN. With global warming there's going to be more and more of these disasters." More lives could have been saved, Ms Short con ceded, if the international community had sent in emergency rescue teams earlier. "It wasn't alert enough," she said. "It wasn't fast enough."

There had been a crucial failure in the Unocha, to which experts from the international development department had been attached, when cyclone Eline struck Mozambique after February 24. They did not warn that the situation was about to deteriorate dramatically. "We sent our experts with the (UN team) and they came out too quickly," Ms Short said. "That was deeply, deeply, deeply regrettable."

Jubilee 2000, the campaign group which has called for debt relief for the world's poorest nations, yesterday urged the Paris Club of Creditors, which includes France, Germany, the United Kingdom and the United States, to cancel all of Mozambique's debts when they review the country's finances at a meeting in Paris today.

webTitle: High stakes in battle over Serbian guilt

fields.headline: High stakes in battle over Serbian guilt
fields.standfirst:
ITN libel trial: Terrified eyes of a camp doctor said more than celebrity campaigning or the might of a giant news organisation

ITN libel case: special report
fields.trailText: ITN libel trial: Terrified eyes of a camp doctor said more than celebrity campaigning or the might of a giant news organisation
fields.body:
The credibility of television news reporting was in the dock, Britain's libel laws were under the spotlight and the truth about the atrocities of the Bosnian conflict was in question in Britain's first big libel trial of the century.

On one side, the might of Independent Television News, which provides the news for three of Britain's terrestrial television channels and boasts millions of viewers.

On the other, LM, an independent magazine with a monthly circulation of just 10,000 run as "a shoestring operation" and which had once - in its previous incarnation as Living Marxism - been the mouthpiece of the Revolutionary Communist party and was now, to all intents and purposes, a one man band.

The stakes were high for both sides. For ITN, the reputation of the company in Britain and worldwide, and those of two reporters, Penny Marshall, for ITV, and Channel 4's Ian Williams. For LM, the stakes were even higher. Losing the libel trial meant almost certain bankruptcy for the magazine, its editor Mick Hume, and Helene Guldberg, co-publisher of the magazine.

The case rested on an eight-page translation of an article by an obscure German journalist, Thomas Deichmann, published in 1997 about his investigation into a few seconds of footage from a news report about the Bosnian conflict that was by then already almost five years old.

The single image that touched the consciences of millions of viewers around the world was that of Fikret Alic, an emaciated Bosnian Muslim man standing shirtless behind a barbed wire fence in a Serb-run camp at Trnopolje, in northern Bosnia. Although just a brief moment in ITN's lengthy reports broadcast on August 6 1992, the emotive image of Alic was taken as evidence of Serb atrocities that the western powers had been waiting for. It quickly zoomed around the world, prompting numerous headlines comparing the camps in Bosnia with the those of the Holocaust.

Awards and accolades followed and the international outcry at those few seconds of footage was widely held to have been responsible for hastening western military involvement in the conflict and changing the course of the war.

It was not until much later, in January 1997, that LM first questioned the pictures of Alic, with a press release about an article in its February issue headlined The Picture That Fooled the World. In it, Deichmann claimed there was no barbed wire around Trnopolje, which was a collection centre for refugees and not a prison, and that the barbed wire was in fact around the ITN news crews who were filming from a small enclosure next to the camp.

The ITN reporters, he argued, had deliberately misrepresented the camp and, when the world's media inevitably interpreted the pictures as evidence of Serb-run concentra tion camps, they failed to correct that impression.

ITN's immediate demands that the allegations be withdrawn, an apology issued and the issue pulped, were ignored. Instead, LM held press conferences to further pro mote the article - prompting ITN to issue writs for libel.

Meanwhile, both the PR firm Two-Ten Communications (a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Press Association), which had distributed the press release, and the Financial Times, which published an article based on the claims, had apologised to ITN.

LM called ITN's actions a "crude gagging order" and succeeded in turning the dispute into a freedom of speech debate by wheeling in the sup port of some 150 journalists, authors, comedians and lawyers, including Fay Weldon, William Boyd, Doris Lessing, Auberon Waugh, Harold Evans and George Walden.

Meanwhile, the magazine set up the Off The Fence fund, which raised more than £70,000 towards the legal costs through comedy nights, rallies and donations. Supporters of LM also began a campaign against ITN, picketing its offices, making phone calls to Ms Marshall and calling on Bafta and the Royal Television Society to withdraw their awards for the broadcasts.

In turn, ITN accused LM of using the article as a publicity stunt to draw attention to the relaunch of the magazine under its new title.

But the dispute went much wider than the article, editorial and press release complained of, with ITN accusing LM of supporting the Serbs in the Bosnian conflict.

Accusations also flew around that LM had been desperate to be sued to gain the notoriety and credibility, but LM insists it had little option but to defend itself.

Conspiracy theories aboun- ded, including claims that LM was the tool of the Serbs, who wanted to discredit the ITN footage - evidence still being used against Bosnian Serbs accused of war crimes.

Had the tapes not been used in this way, after ITN agreed to send the unbroadcast footage to the Hague, Deichmann (an expert witness for the defence of Bosnian Serb Dusko Tadic at the war crimes tribunal in the Hague in 1994) might never have written his article.

Outside the court the debate raged over the rights and wrongs of a mighty media organisation using its vast resources to silence criticism and "destroy" - in Hume's words - a tiny independent magazine.

But inside court 14, the judge, Mr Justice Morland, insisted in the pre-trial hearing that this was not to be a debate about the "journalism of attachment" or the rights or wrongs of British libel law, but a look at the facts.

ITN put forward all seven of the award-winning team which visited the camps, and the ITN executives who sent them there. But LM's subpoenaed star witnesses, including BBC foreign affairs editor John Simpson, found their evidence ruled out as hearsay, leaving just Hume and Deichmann because, Hume explained, LM "could not afford to bring witnesses across London let alone from Bosnia".

In the end it was Idriz Merdzanic, a Bosnian Muslim doctor interned at Trnopolje, who was the star witness. He had appeared in the original ITN broadcasts and his terrified eyes spoke volumes.

The testimony of this slight, dignified figure in the witness box, given through an interpreter, made clear what previous and current war crimes tribunals at the Hague have already heard, that Trnopolje was a camp where Muslims were undoubtedly imprisoned, and that many were beaten, tortured, raped and killed by their Serb guards.

ITN insisted that it would not back down without an apology from LM. Legal action was, according to ITN chief executive Stewart Purvis, "the only way of nailing the lie once and for all".

webTitle: Pigs cloned for organs down at the 'pharm'

fields.headline: Pigs cloned for organs down at the 'pharm'
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Five pigs born 10 days ago in Blacksburg, Virginia - but only announced yesterday by a British firm based at Roslin in Scotland - are clones that could lead to new ways to save life.
fields.body:
Five pigs born 10 days ago in Blacksburg, Virginia - but only announced yesterday by a British firm based at Roslin in Scotland - are clones that could lead to new ways to save life.

Millie, Christa, Alexis, Carrel and Dotcom are living proof of the first step towards supplies of identical pig organs genetically engineered to be compatible with the human bodies that might need them.

In a world where patients in urgent need of spare part surgery outnumber potential donors by 20 to 1, the five piglets and their successors are claimed to be "the only near-term solution to solving the worldwide organ shortage crisis."

The market in "xenotransplanted" organs - transplanted from another species - could be worth $6bn, and clinical trials with pig organs could start in four years, providing governments give the go-ahead.

The five pigs are proof that pigs can be cloned: they will enjoy a life of comfort and celebrity. Although born in the US, they were brainchildren of PPL Therapeutics, the commercial business built on the site of the Roslin institute, progenitors of Dolly the sheep.

Millie was the name long ago selected for the world's first pig clone. Christa honours Christian Barnard, who performed the first human heart transplant in 1967. Two others salute Alexis Carrel, a 1912 Nobel prizewinner who pioneered transplantation. Dotcom was so called for luck. "Any association with dotcoms right now seems to have a very positive influence on a company's valuation," said Ron James, PPL's chief executive.

The piglets are pioneers in what is now called "pharming" - the employment of animals in the human health business. PPL already has a flock of sheep producing alpha 1-antitrypsin, a human protein for cystic fibrosis sufferers, a flock producing a protein that seals wounds and stops bleeding and another making a human enzyme that breaks down fats - urgently needed by people with pancreatic damage. It is also produced in mother's milk - and could help premature babies that cannot be breast fed. None of these products is yet in use. None of their makers is a clone, but all of them have added genes.

"What cloning allows us to do for the first time is switch off genes as well," said Ron James. The next step is to switch off a pig gene called alpha 1-3 gal transferase. This sugar group on the pig tissue signals to the human immune system that the transplanted organ was foreign: there would be a massive response, the organ would be destroyed and the patient would die. There would still be risk of rejection so the next step would be to put an extra gene in the pig - switched on at the moment of surgery - to prevent clotting in the patient's blood cells, which would starve the organ of oxygen. "We are claiming that we have the most comprehensive solution we know of," said Dr James.

PPL is not the only group hoping to use genetically engineered, human-compatible pigs for transplants of hearts, lungs, liver and other organs. webTitle: Blair and Clinton in plea over gene code

fields.headline: Blair and Clinton in plea over gene code
fields.standfirst:
Scientists urged to make new information freely available to all

Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and President Bill Clinton yesterday declared, in an unprecedented step, that the genetic code for human beings should be freely available for research everywhere.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and President Bill Clinton yesterday declared, in an unprecedented step, that the genetic code for human beings should be freely available for research everywhere.

A statement in London and at a gathering of scientists in the White House said "unencumbered access" to the human genetic code as it was deciphered "will reduce the burden of disease, improve health around the world and enhance the quality of life for all mankind."

The document agreed between Mr Blair and Mr Clinton yesterday, following months of negotiation - exclusively revealed after searches under the US freedom of information act in the Guardian last summer - is being interpreted as a warning shot to entrepreneurs in the US who have been staking wholesale patent claims on freshly discovered human genes.

The two leaders said: "We applaud the decision by scientists working on the human genome project to release raw fundamental information about the human DNA sequence and its variants rapidly into the public domain, and we commend other scientists around the world to adopt this policy."

The document is a restatement of a years-old understanding between the government and charity-funded partners who have been racing ahead to decipher the entire "text" of the 3bn letter chemical recipe for the 70,000 or so genes in the human makeup.

As the two leaders acknowledged, this would be the foundation "of a new generation of effective treatments, preventions and cures."

About two-thirds of the publicly funded effort has been in the US, and about a third in Britain, led by the Sanger Centre in Cambridge. Money has been found by governments, patients' groups and the philanthropic charity the Wellcome Trust.

But as the project, launched more than 10 years ago, gathered steam, commercial biotechnology companies in the US joined the hunt. Chief among these is Celera Genomics, led by Dr Craig Venter, who has claimed that his methods - and his enormous investment in robotics and computer power - mean that he could finish the "first draft" of humanity in June. Celera's share prices have risen 500% since December. But the official British-American human genome project is also racing to an early finish.

Dr Venter has declared that he is releasing his information to the public after three months - and after thousands of patent applications. The British and American partners have published their discoveries as they have made them. Once disclosed, these cannot be patented. Attempts to forge some kind of understanding between the commercial and public efforts broke down in acrimony 10 days ago. The Downing Street-White House initiative is seen as an effort to create a new climate of understanding.

The problem has not been patenting itself, but about what is patentable. In Britain, drug companies, scientists and government are all agreed: the DNA "blueprints" for genes themselves should be published and any patents should involve specific inventions - treatments or tests - that apply to those particular genes.

This would mean that the same genes could be patented by different groups for different inventions.

But Dr Venter and other researchers have alarmed the scientific establishment on both sides by applying for patents on lengths of DNA without, so far producing inventions to justify the application. There have been fears that this would block the data from other researchers - and fears that having staked such claims, private companies could end up "owning" much of the human genome.

Britain's science chiefs last night were convinced that the governmental accord would change attitudes. "From our perspective, it may look like an assertion of something everybody believes," said Sir Robert May, the chief scientist. "But to have it jointly signed by Clinton and Blair is less trivial."

Lord Sainsbury, the science minister, said: "What this is about is trying to encourage the information and discovery to be put in the open arena where anyone can use this for whatever purposes they wish - including possibly the development of therapeutics and diagnostic techniques."

But critics will argue that political declarations may cut no ice with big businesses which have just seen a fivefold rise in share prices.

webTitle: Cloning past and future: from potatoes to Parkinson's

fields.headline: Cloning past and future: from potatoes to Parkinson's
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: What is a clone?
fields.body:
What is a clone?

A clone is a genetically identical twin. A clone is not an exact copy of the "parent" because each creature will experience a different environment and will grow up in different ways.

What was the first clone?

Clones are normal in the vegetable garden: all potatoes are clones, as are all commercial apples. Lawns clone when they are mown. Amphibians have been cloned for decades. The honour of the first mammal clones goes to a pair of sheep born at Roslin in Scotland, called Megan and Morag. Dolly the sheep came later but stirred up more celebrity.

How do you make a clone?

Take a cell from a donor. Turn back its clock so that it ceases to be a skin cell, or a bone cell, and it will have the potential to make a whole animal. Then delicately take out the DNA and inject this into a donor egg from which the egg donor's DNA has been removed. Apply a tiny jolt of electricity and put into a surrogate mother. This is the basis of a one parent family.

Does it always work?

No. There are difficulties at every stage. It requires extraordinary skill and delicacy, and perfect timing. Many of the pregnancies that ended in Dolly - the sheep that shook the world in 1997 - failed or turned out badly.

What animals have been cloned?

So far, mice, cattle, sheep and now pigs. There have also been attempts to clone primates, and ambitious schemes to bring back recently extinct species such as the Siberian mammoth or the Tasmanian tiger, or thylacine, from the dead.

Is it a solution to human infertility?

Some groups have claimed that it is. Cloning's inventors have said repeatedly that its real value is in replicating very valuable farm animals, or in conjunction with genetic engineering for new farm products - or in finding new ways to make new human tissue to help sufferers of Parkinson's disease and other degenerative conditions. Human cloning would be a very bad idea, they say.That hasn't stopped people from claiming that they wanted to make clones - or a millionaire from paying to clone his favourite dog.

How will it help cure Parkinsonism?

The other most startling discovery of the past three years is that stem cells - the cells that make the 200 different kinds of human tissue - can be manipulated. The US group that made the breakthrough have gone into partnership with a Roslin firm to link cloning and stem cell science - in the hope of eventually growing perfectly matched brain, blood, skin or organ tissue outside the body and then transplanting it.

Why hasn't this already started?

Because to begin the work, the scientists need to conduct experiments on very new human embryos, not needed in fertility research. They would also need donated eggs. A government committee is still wrestling with the ethical challenge. So for the time being, scientists are concentrating on genetically engineered, cloned animals as a solution.

Does this present problems?

Many people are worried about the ethical implications. It is one thing to eat an animal. It seems another thing to commandeer its living organs. There is the other catch: it might not work. But groups in Europe, Japan and the US see a new future in cloned flocks which could produce human proteins that could not be synthesised, or safely gathered from donated human blood, to treat diseases now beyond treatment.

webTitle: Microsoft steps up war of words

fields.headline: Microsoft steps up war of words
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft strengthened its alliance with internet navigation firm RealNames Corporation by taking a 20% stake in the group yesterday as a direct challenge to America Online, which offers a similar product.
fields.body:
Microsoft strengthened its alliance with internet navigation firm RealNames Corporation by taking a 20% stake in the group yesterday as a direct challenge to America Online, which offers a similar product.

The deal, one of a string announced by Microsoft, means it can use the RealNames technology to allow web surfers to type keywords into a browser's address field rather than lengthy URL addresses filled with dots and slashes.

Ford, eBay and MP3.com are among the 50,000 clients of RealNames. They pay the US firm to register keywords.

For example, Ford could register "ford explorer" as a keyword and pay RealNames a licence fee or a per-visit fee; users who typed in the keyword would be taken directly to the motor group's website.

The monetary value of Microsoft's investment in RealNames was not disclosed because of mandatory curbs imposed because of the net navigation group's impending flotation, intended to raise a minimum of $80m.

AOL also has a product which uses keywords to direct users to websites of its partners.

Yusuf Mehdi, Microsoft's consumer group director, said of the RealNames technology: "This has the possibility to become the premier way people search on the Internet.

"We think it's going to give AOL a real run for its money with its closed and proprietary system." The technology includes a tracking system for monitoring the effectiveness of online advertisements.

The investment will make Microsoft the largest shareholder in RealNames, alongside Network Solutions, Draper Fisher Jurvetson and idealab! capital partners.

Last year Microsoft struck a two-year licensing and marketing agreement with RealNames to incorporate the RealNames web addressing and navigation service into MSN Search, part of the Microsoft Internet Explorer 5 browser.

Analysts said the RealNames deal might increase Microsoft's internet subscriber base by making its MSN web portal easier to use.

fields.headline: Freeserve presents picture of discontent
fields.standfirst:
Notebook Portal needs pulling power
Free internet access: the issue explained
The key players
fields.trailText: Competitive advantages are won and lost quickly in cyberspace so it should have come as little surprise when Freeserve launched unmetered internet access yesterday.
fields.body:
It should have come as little surprise that Freeserve would launch unmetered internet access yesterday (although some in the market at least were caught napping as the share price rebounded more than 8%). It was evident simply from the column inches that cable company NTL and US group AltaVista had achieved last week that the rest of the market would be forced to follow suit soon.

Competitive advantages are won and lost quickly in cyberspace - a fact Freeserve knows only too well.

It was also inevitable that unmetered access which is common in the US would make its way to these shores before long, although Freeserve may have preferred to keep it at bay a little longer.

Revenues in the last quarter were just £3.6m, of which some £2m came from Freeserve's share of phone calls - a figure which will be decimated by yesterday's offer. Far from making cash from its deal through British Telecom lines, Freeserve will effectively be subsidising the erstwhile monopoly from here on in.

Ironically in the US - the stick used to beat UK operators - unmetered access on local calls was not arrived at by market forces but as a result of social engineering by government. The pressure in the US is not for removing further barriers but rather for telecoms companies to introduce some kind of charging.

Freeserve's offer document published prior to its flotation last summer had admitted that call revenues would fall but hoped that income would be offset by the increasing amount of time people spent online. The spin meisters for Freeserve yesterday were keen to disabuse anyone who would listen that the company is an internet service provider at all.

Freeserve rather is chiefly a portal business, they intoned, which will make its revenues from e-commerce and advertising which the company claims is growing at 40% a quarter. In fairness, Freeserve had always said this side of the business would overtake call revenues but would no doubt feel more comfortable if e-commerce and advertising were already the greater share.

Unmetered access will clearly result in consumers spending more time online which should be good news for Freeserve but its portal business needs to get itself in better shape.

According to investment bank Salomon Smith Barney, Freeserve users spend an average of 15 minutes online at a time, of which only three minutes is spent at the portal. The bank compares that with America Online, the world's largest ISP, where users in the US spend an hour online of which 85% is at the AOL portal. The market can only become fiercer still and the importance of quality content will be all the more important. If Freeserve really can shrug off the drop in call revenues it needs to be doing deals with top rank providers quickly.

Go for it

There will have been a lot of back-slapping at the Canary Wharf offices of Morgan Stanley yesterday after the largely successful transfer of that ticking parcel otherwise known as Lastminute.com from private hands to the public arena. This investment bank has a reputation for getting internet flotations right in the US, but has been slow at exporting this expertise into Europe.

Whether through luck or good judgement, the end of day premium of 25% was just about "perfect" from a financial advisers point of view. Actual trading in the stock was orderly. Oh, and the flotation of Lastminute.com did not prove to be the needle which popped the supposed market bubble in internet stocks. The new economy has not been abolished.

Last week, the advice here was to avoid applying for shares in the flotation, and that proved to be a sensible course of action since the 200,000 speculators who did so received such small allocations they will be lucky to wash their faces if they sell now. Also last week, it looked as if it would be some time before a considered view could be taken on whether Lastminute.com presents good value. But already, given the orderly first day's trading, this company is looking like a short-term speculation which might sit rather better in a portfolio as a long-term investment.

Only one of the 32 major internet IPOs handled by Morgan Stanley around the world has fallen below the issue price. And whatever the daft rhetoricals about how ludicrous it is that "value" can be attributed to a company which has only ever lost money (let's start with the BBC ...) , there is an undefinable aura surrounding Lastminute.com that says it just isn't a loser.

Across the London investment scene there are all number of suspect "tech" stocks, peddled by fringe brokers and offering precious little transparency even as to their true ownership, never mind the quality of the business models. This is a market where unwary investors will lose the skin off their backs.

In contrast, the investment world knows everything it could reasonably expect to know about Lastminute.com. If you believe the internet will change the way we all work, play and communicate, be brave and buy the shares.

webTitle: Murdoch succumbs to allure of Bangalore

fields.headline: Murdoch succumbs to allure of Bangalore
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch yesterday revealed plans to invest in India's booming internet industry and expand his television empire in the world's largest democracy.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch yesterday revealed plans to invest in India's booming internet industry and expand his television empire in the world's largest democracy.

During a four-day trip to India the media tycoon said he had been impressed by the potential the country offered for software development and IT technology.

"We'll be certainly investing in some companies. We had a meeting about small investments in start-ups in dot.coms. There are as many [dot.coms] here as anywhere yet at this stage it's a very small market," he said.

fields.headline: The place to be seen
fields.standfirst:
No wonder it's so hard to get a ticket to ride the London Eye - it's jam-packed with celebs who are desperately seeking the perfect photo-op. Oliver Burkeman on why the wheel has PR companies drooling

The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: No wonder it's so hard to get a ticket to ride the London Eye - it's jam-packed with celebs who are desperately seeking the perfect photo-op.  Oliver Burkeman on why the wheel has PR companies drooling
fields.body:
Celebrity-spotting in London used to be an arduous and time-consuming occupation, strictly reserved for the stubbornest of paparazzi and the most psychotic of stalkers. Unless you could get into the right bars and restaurants - which you couldn't, of course, precisely because they were the right ones - it was a question of waiting outside movie premieres or stage doors for those fleeting transitional moments when the Famous Person is compelled to make a crossing through the real world from one protected bubble of celebrity to another.

Not any more. Head down to the south bank of the Thames near Westminster Bridge and you can hardly move for them: rock stars, actors, comedians, DJs, sportspersons, royals, politicians, the lot. This, of course, is the site of the London Eye - which, since it started revolving last month, has swiftly become the only place to stage your photo-opportunity. Everyone who's anyone - and quite a few others besides - is busting a gut to get snapped in a capsule. Paul McCartney snuck in early, days after the wheel's engineering hitches were fixed, but a stampede soon followed: Andy and Fergie, with Beatrice, Eugenie and an army of photographers in tow, all giddy smiles for Andy's 40th; Joanna Lumley and Esther Rantzen and Tim Rice and Des Lynam followed soon after.

There was Ant and Dec, plugging a TV show; Darcey Bussell, plugging a new opera; the ubiquitous Tara Palmer-Tomkinson, plugging herself. Zoe Ball has taken a spin, as has Pat Cash. Mayoral candidates Norris, Dobson and Livingstone were practically tripping over themselves to get their grinning pictures taken on London's last remaining piece of fully functioning transport infrastructure.

It's touching, in a way: throngs of the supposedly charmed and remote converging on a single spot not for some exclusionary celeb pursuit - involving overpriced holiday locations, say, or overpriced drugs - but for the most basic of adrenaline rushes: what the wheel's co-designer, David Marks, calls "the natural human desire to want to view the earth from high places". Or at least it would be touching if it wasn't for the fact that the constant stream of stars heading podwards is why it's been so damn difficult for anyone else to get an early ride, which means it's merely annoying instead.

But what explains the wheel's mysterious draw for profile-hungry publicists? "It is seen to be successful, so anybody who wants to be somebody can use it as an opportunity to have some of that success for themselves. The spectacular backcloth, all the different angles, everything," says Max Clifford. "And then it becomes a bandwagon. The first few won't be seen as a publicity stunt - that's the whole point. But then you get the Anthea Turners, the Geri Halliwells, because their PRs finally wake up to the opportunity."

Plutocrats and aspiring plutocrats have long understood the symbolic value of altitude and panoramic views: witness the multimillionaire, photographed by the window in his private jet; Jeffrey Archer in his penthouse; Branson in his balloon. A photo taken in the Dome - and there haven't been many - says: I'd like to associate myself with this squat and ill-starred edifice and, what's more, I've got enough time on my hands to schlep to Greenwich to do so. A trip on the Eye (taking a mere 30 valuable minutes) says: I scale the heights. I live in the clouds. I am close to God.

But a photo-opportunity on the Eye says something else besides. The wheel - to use an inappropriate metaphor - squares a circle the modern celebrity has always faced: how to be, simultaneously, a man or woman of the people and a higher form of life. The wheel may exude power and superiority, but it smacks of democracy too. It only costs £7.50 for a ride, after all: anyone can do it. Or at least they could, if it wasn't for all the celebrities.

All of which suggests it would be perfect publicity fodder for Tony Blair, making it even more mysterious that he hasn't yet made time to go for a trip on the wheel. He may be too late. "The clever ones have done it and moved on, long before cynical journalists start to see what's going on," says Clifford. "If you're going to win this game, you've got to have got in and scored before people even know you're playing."
