webTitle: Lib Dems urge home insulation on prescription to cut NHS bills

fields.headline: Lib Dems urge home insulation on prescription to cut NHS bills
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: GPs would be able to prescribe home insulation to patients suffering from asthma and other illnesses worsened by the cold under a package of green measures to be unveiled by the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, next weekend.
fields.body:
GPs would be able to prescribe home insulation to patients suffering from asthma and other illnesses worsened by the cold under a package of green measures to be unveiled by the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, next weekend.

Mr Kennedy will seek to brand his party as the only choice for voters concerned to protect the environment with a string of proposals ranging from neighbourhood recycling schemes to global measures such as targeting development aid to sustainable projects.

The plan to make insulation available on prescription, paid for out of the health department budget, is typical of Lib Dem moves to make green measures pay for themselves. The party cites research indicating that treating cold-related illnesses costs the NHS £1bn every year. Another local measure would see every home in the country served by a German or Dutch-style doorstep recycling scheme removing cans, bottles and paper.

Mr Kennedy is determined to put a green agenda at the heart of the Lib Dem manifesto for the next election, and will make it the centrepiece of his speech to activists at the party's spring conference in Plymouth at the weekend.

He will seek to portray environmental pollution as an issue of freedom, arguing that people living in poverty in inner cities find their lives restricted by pollution-linked illnesses.

He hopes his stance will embarrass Tony Blair, who, Lib Dems claim, has not made a speech solely on the subject of the environment since becoming prime minister.

One source close to Mr Kennedy last night claimed he had never forgotten how, after the 1989 Euro elections in which the Lib Dems slumped at the polls and the Greens gained 15%, Labour MP Mo Mowlam (now cabinet office coordinator) said to him: "You might as well join us [the Labour party] now".

"Charles remains convinced that those 15% of green votes are there to be won," the source said.

However, the Lib Dems will have to confront the reality that apparent public goodwill over green issues does little to modify opposition to congestion charging and workplace car parking charging, both also certain to be on the party's green-hued manifesto.

Mr Kennedy will also use the conference to stress Lib Dem intentions to reverse any income tax cuts introduced by the Labour government, including the 1p cut in the base rate due to come in next month.

He will seek to portray his party as the true protector of public services.

fields.headline: Painkillers cause 2,000 deaths yearly
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Popular painkillers such as aspirin and ibuprofen used to treat arthritis and back pain are killing 2,000 people in Britain a year, a study yesterday suggested.
fields.body:
Popular painkillers such as aspirin and ibuprofen used to treat arthritis and back pain are killing 2,000 people in Britain a year, a study yesterday suggested.

Doctors behind the research said 2m people in Britain were at risk of preventable deaths from the pain-relieving drugs.

Doctors have known for some years that the so-called non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs can cause serious gastro-intestinal bleeding and other complications, but this is the first time a figure has been put on the number of deaths resulting from their long term use.

Researchers in Oxford and Switzerland stressed that people using the drugs for a limited time to relieve pain should not panic. But those using them continuously for more than two months should consult their doctors.

The report's co-author, Andrew Moore of the Oxford chronic pain clinic, said side effects and treatment arising from the drugs were costing the NHS between £170m and £350m a year.

Twenty-one per cent of patients taking the drugs for more than two months have ulcers diagnosed and 12% of them will die, co author Martin Tramer of university hospital in Geneva, told a medical seminar in central London yesterday.

The department of health said it was aware of the concerns posed by the drugs and would be studying the report.

fields.headline: Travellers face double rail strike
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Passengers on some of Britain's busiest rail routes face disruption because of two planned strikes in a dispute over the sacking of a train driver.
fields.body:
Passengers on some of Britain's busiest rail routes face disruption because of two planned strikes in a dispute over the sacking of a train driver.

Members of the Rail Maritime and Transport union at South West Trains will stage walkouts on March 23 and 31 after voting by 5-1 in favour of action.

Drivers and guards at London's Waterloo station were balloted in support of Sarah Friday, who claims she was dismissed because of her union activities.

The RMT assistant general secretary, Bob Crow, said he believed Ms Friday was victimised because of her role as union health and safety representative at Waterloo.

Ms Friday said: "The company ... will have to reconsider in the light of this result."

A spokeswoman for South West Trains said: "We are obviously disappointed with the RMT announcement, particularly taking account of the low turnout for the vote."

webTitle: Call to force cuts in train fares

fields.headline: Call to force cuts in train fares
fields.standfirst: 90 different fare types are confusing passengers, says rail user body
fields.trailText: Train companies should be compelled by the government to reduce average fares by 1% every year over the life of their franchises, an influential passenger watchdog group demanded last night.
fields.body:
Train companies should be compelled by the government to reduce average fares by 1% every year over the life of their franchises, an influential passenger watchdog group demanded last night.

The central rail users' consultative committee will tell the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, that such a reduction over 10 years would cost the government £110m. This amounts to 8% of existing government support to the rail industry.

The committee called for better, clearer information on which tickets are available. Until more seats are available, it says under-utilised services should be the target of fare reductions.

Stewart Francis, the CRUCC's chairman, said: "We want to see rail fares start to fall, better information about the fares available and a simpler fares structure."

In a report on rail fares, the committee said that overall minimal fares reductions had "masked some hefty individual increases" including rises of 20%-50% on some fares.

It said that passengers were confused because there were now more than 90 different ticket types. One of the most expensive fares currently quoted is £150 for a standard return from London to Manchester, more than the air fare.

Britain's biggest rail operator, National Express, with five rail franchises, has around £400m to spend on expansion, and has several regional routes in mind.

The company's chief executive, Phil White, would not disclose which they were. But industry insiders suggested yesterday that North West Trains, Anglia and WAGN would be the prime targets.

East Anglia is becoming a favourite area for National Express because it is lining up with the airports operator, BAA, to expand the existing rail service from Stansted airport to London.

National Express reported an 8% increase in railway operating profit to £28m, while group pre-tax profits rose 18% to £113.2 m. The company incurred a £10.7m one-off costs in the rail business through redundancies and commissioning new trains.

A final 12.45p dividend makes 18.2p for the year, a 14% increase. Earnings are up 13% to 62.1p.

fields.headline: Franchise threat to Connex
fields.trailText: Connex, the poorly performing London commuter rail company, was yesterday threatened with withdrawal of its franchise by the shadow strategic rail authority.
fields.body:
Connex, the poorly performing London commuter rail company, was yesterday threatened with withdrawal of its franchise by the shadow strategic rail authority.

The SSRA's chief executive, Mike Grant, criticised Connex's new plans to operate its south central franchise as not being ambitious enough.

In a direct reference to Connex, which has had its franchise for four years, he said he was looking for evidence that operators "are committed to a radical improvement in service quality".

Connnex recently submitted a £1bn plan to improve the network over the 20-year period of a new franchise. Mr Grant clearly feels the plan does not go far enough.

Connex, owned by the French group Vivendi, faces tough competition from GoVia, which operates the Thameslink franchise.

Sir Alastair Morton, the SSRA's chairman, has warned Connex that it will need to overhaul its management if it is to stand a chance of retaining the franchise.

Its top official, Antoine Hurel, has already been lined up for a new job in another part of the company and several senior managers have started to leave.

Mr Grant has also chosen Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Rail company to compete with the Great North Eastern Railway Company, the existing franchisee, for a 20-year franchise on the east coast main line.

fields.headline: Sainsbury's hits back on vouchers
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Sainsbury's has protested to the home office that it did not want to "profit at the expense of asylum seekers" when it discovered that, as an incentive to taking part in a voucher scheme, it could keep any change due.
fields.body:
Sainsbury's has protested to the home office that it did not want to "profit at the expense of asylum seekers" when it discovered that, as an incentive to taking part in a voucher scheme, it could keep any change due.

The supermarket chain writes in a letter to the Guardian today that the home office told it Jack Straw's new immigration and asylum act made it illegal to give change to asylum seekers who used their shops.

Sodexho Pass, the company running the scheme, has told potential "trading partners" that vouchers given to asylum seekers cannot be exchanged for cash: "If the goods to the value of £4.50 are purchased with a £5 voucher the 50p change should not be handed back, but you as a trading partner will receive the full £5 value for that voucher."

Sainsbury's writes that it finally decided to take part "because the alternative is for civil servants to hand out bags of shopping to asylum seekers; taking away their right to choose what they want to buy."

Last night the refugee charity Asylum Aid said there was nothing in the primary legislation to prevent supermar kets giving change, and appealed to all shops to offer change "as a matter of fairness and principle". A home office spokeswoman confirmed that the new law did not make it illegal to give change. "That was a policy decision made by the home office," she said.

The voucher system comes into effect for 30,000 asylum seekers from April. A single adult is expected to live on £36.54 a week worth of vouchers, including a £10 weekly cash voucher, to cover daily essential needs while the asylum claim is determined. The average waiting time is 13 months.

Yvonne West, Sainsbury's voucher manager, writes that the chain raised the matter with the home office "because we do not want to keep the change and profit at the expense of asylum seekers".

She says the home office argued the mix of cash and vouchers meant the exact amount could be proffered at the check-out. "They do not have to buy everything at once, or spend all of their allowance in one shop," she explained.

Zoe Harper of Asylum Aid said: "Newly arrived asylum seekers unfamiliar with the currency will have great difficulty in juggling the vouchers with the small cash allowance, as Sainsbury's suggests."

Last night the refugee charity Asylum Aid said there was nothing in the primary legislation to prevent supermar kets giving change, and appealed to all shops to offer change "as a matter of fairness and principle". A home office spokeswoman confirmed that the new law did not make it illegal to give change. "That was a policy decision made by the home office," she said. The voucher system comes into effect for 30,000 asylum seekers from April. A single adult is expected to live on £36.54 a week worth of vouchers, including a £10 weekly cash voucher, to cover daily essential needs while the asylum claim is determined. The average waiting time is 13 months. Yvonne West, Sainsbury's voucher manager, writes that the chain raised the matter with the home office "because we do not want to keep the change and profit at the expense of asylum seekers". She says the home office argued the mix of cash and vouchers meant the exact amount could be proffered at the check-out. "They do not have to buy everything at once, or spend all of their allowance in one shop," she explained. Zoe Harper of Asylum Aid said: "Newly arrived asylum seekers unfamiliar with the currency will have great difficulty in juggling the vouchers with the small cash allowance, as Sainsbury's suggests."

fields.headline: Chinese conundrum
fields.standfirst:
The bullying of Taiwan is self-defeating
Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: The people of Taiwan will elect a new president this Saturday amid a renewed barrage of threats from China.
fields.body:
The people of Taiwan will elect a new president this Saturday amid a renewed barrage of threats from China. Beijing views Taiwan as a renegade province. A recent state council policy paper increased the pressure by warning that attempts to delay reunification indefinitely would bring a military response. In case any of Taiwan's 15m voters failed to get the message, the foreign ministry repeated it yesterday. "The Chinese people absolutely cannot sit idly by and watch any situation that leads to separatism." This verbal bullying is an improvement on the 1996 election, when China test-fired missiles in the Taiwan strait. But it is intimidation all the same.

Par for the course, perhaps. Yet there is a puzzle here. For whoever wins the election - and there are three candidates running neck-and-neck - Taiwan's current position eschewing outright independence in favour of "special state-to-state" relations with China will not change radically. Although most Taiwanese oppose reunification, they see little point in provoking their neighbour. Thus even the most bullish candidate, Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive party, is soft-pedalling. China, meanwhile, is also offering to be gin new talks on an "equal" footing. China's conduct becomes even more mystifying when the predictably negative impact of its sabre-rattling on US relations is considered. Congress is currently debating Taiwan's request to buy advanced weapons systems (which Beijing fiercely opposes), and China's application to join the World Trade Organisation. Beijing's bellicosity has increased the chances that it will achieve, in its own eyes, the wrong outcome on both issues. It has enabled conservative opponents of US engagement with "communism" to stir up old fears. And it has placed Bill Clinton's administration in the odd position of down-playing the import of Beijing's recent statements in order to further Beijing's own interests.

This confusion may be explained by divisions within China itself, between People's Liberation Army hawks and "coming men" on the one hand, and worldly-wise political operators like Prime Minister Zhu Rongji and his deputy, Qian Qichen, on the other. The redoubtable President Jiang Zemin is apparently flip-flopping somewhere in-between. Forget for a moment who will run Taiwan. The more portentous question is: who is running China?

webTitle: Refugee day out foiled by race threats

fields.headline: Refugee day out foiled by race threats
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Plans to take a group of Kosovan refugees to a football match this Saturday have been abandoned after the club concerned received letters and phone calls threatening violence if they were admitted to the ground.
fields.body:
Plans to take a group of Kosovan refugees to a football match this Saturday have been abandoned after the club concerned received letters and phone calls threatening violence if they were admitted to the ground.

Police and Millwall football club decided to abandon the day out for 25 Kosovan refugees for fear that rightwing groups and hooligans were planning violence at the match against Blackpool, which had been designated the club's annual anti-racism day. As well as the phone calls and letters, messages were posted on internet sites urging violence.

Police and Millwall officials planned the day to help the Kosovans integrate with the local community. The refugees, who are all staying at a hostel in south London, were to be bussed to the New Den, Millwall's ground, and club officals had hoped that they might start supporting the team.

Millwall's chairman, Theo Paphitis, said: "I feel sick that Millwall has worked hard against racism but has been caught up in the current backlash in the media against asylum seekers."

The plan to take the refugees to the match was devised by Southwark police in south London. Officers have been arranging football matches for the refugees and felt that watching Millwall might help to relieve the boredom many endure.

fields.headline: What's the story?
fields.standfirst:
Thatcher had a vision, even Major had a notion. Blair must offer a narrative to the Labour heartlands

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Thatcher had a vision, even Major had a notion. Blair must offer a narrative to the Labour heartlands
fields.body:
It's open season on the government. It is taking hits from every direction - from a once-seduced Tory press and an inquisitive BBC, from doctors and nurses, teachers and parents and, most damagingly of all, from its own supporters. If it isn't the Sun damning the government for letting "Gypsy scroungers" flood on to our streets, it's Panorama bashing Labour spin doctors for announcing the same "new" cash four times over - even when the cash in question is not new at all. If it isn't the Daily Mail warning of the desperate shortage of intensive care beds, it's the Tories chanting "all mouth, no delivery". All this Labour could take in its stride: what else would a government expect nearly three years into its first term?

But what really hurts is the friendly fire. As a troop of Labour loyalists - from ministers Peter Hain and David Blunkett through to grand dame Barbara Castle - are declaring ever more publicly, it is the party's heartlands that are breaking. Labour's private polling shows one in five core supporters staying home at the next election, plunging Labour's percentage share into the middle thirties. If the Conservatives stir their own faithful with a save-the-pound campaign, they might hit the same level. Hain can foresee a hung parliament - or worse: "We could lose next time."

The personification of the phenomenon is, of course, the smiling face of Ken Livingstone. His stampede toward the London mayoralty, now seen as unstoppable even by the Labour high command, shows the depth of hostility that now exists toward this government. Ken's fiercest opponents say his appeal boils down to a free kick in the shins of Tony Blair, a cheap way to poke the eye of the prime minister - implicitly admitting that the PM is so unpopular that merely offering to be a thorn in his side is enough to notch up a 55-point lead in the polls. What that figure suggests is that Livingstone has become the vessel into which all the assorted gripes against Blair and Blairism have collected. But Labourites cannot be comforted by this fact, pretending that it somehow reduces Ken's significance. On the contrary, it reveals that the most popular place to be in British politics right now is at loggerheads with Number 10.

The attempt to turn the tide has already begun. The timing of a £530m government loan to build a super-jumbo jet, creating 22,000 new jobs, may well have sprung from the desire to "do something" for the heartlands. A more subtle effort is under way to shake off Labour's reputation for control-freakery. Allowing ministers like Hain, Blunkett and others to speak out is part of it. So is the suggestion that the party should either move out of its Millbank headquarters or change the building's name, so tarred is the Millbank brand. Even allowing cameras in to Alastair Campbell's twice-daily "lobby" briefing - and ending the absurd charade which left the celebrated Mr Campbell unnamed - will be spun as a Labour effort to seem less controlling and more open.

But these moves will fail, for they go nowhere near the heart of the problem. Labour's trouble is not that it is doing nothing for its own people - but that it has found no way to communicate with them. For all the overblown tributes to New Labour's political genius, the party has failed to understand one of the inner truths of politics: like great drama or literature, it needs a story.

Offering a laundry list of accomplishments is not good enough. Tessa Jowell, the energetic junior minister, likes to kick off her constituency meetings in Dulwich with a brainstorming session of party activists: she asks them to name their favourite government accomplishment. Back comes the minimum wage, working families tax credit or increase to child benefit - all aimed at lifting people out of poverty. Others mention devolution to Scotland, Wales and, however painfully, London. Gay activists might offer the lowering of the age of consent or the war on section 28. For others, it's the removal of the hereditary peers or the Macpherson inquiry into Stephen Lawrence. It adds up to quite a list - none of which would have happened under the Tories - and, Jowell finds, it gives a positive lift to what might otherwise have been an awkward meeting.

That, more or less, is the government's approach, too. For a long while Blair's method was to borrow the line from Monty Python's Life of Brian - what did the Romans ever do for us? - and ask what Labour ever did for the country. He would then rattle off the list.

But it doesn't work. People cannot remember tallies of policies. What sticks in the brain, and occasionally the heart, is something much less tangible. It is not even a vision, so much as a narrative. Margaret Thatcher understood this perfectly: she was the grocer's daughter who was going to pick Britain up by the scruff of its neck and make it stand tall again. She would have to take on enemies, sometimes there would be reverses - but on she would go. That was her story. Even John Major had a tale for a while: he was the boy from Brixton who wanted to make Britain like him - kinder, gentler and classless.

All successful politicians have a story to tell, whether it's Bill Clinton as "the man from Hope" or Ken Livingstone as the man against the machine. Politicians like these can afford to let the detail of policy be forgotten; they know that the narrative will stay lodged in the public mind. If people like the storyline, they flow with it - even when events start to turn. That's why Thatcher could endure recession and huge unpopularity. People knew who she was and where she stood.

This government has too few people with the same knack. Mo Mowlam managed to weave her politics into a personal narrative when she was in Northern Ireland - hence the peace award she received on Monday night from Hillary Clinton in New York, where she was praised for fighting not only "political difficulties but life-threatening illness". Yet Mr Blair seems uncomfortable with Mo's brand of politician-as-human-being. He has promoted instead the colder, duller talents of technocrats like Alan Milburn, Stephen Byers and Geoff Hoon. These are people with no chance of sticking to the national cortex: we forget their faces the moment we see them. Yet Blair has demoted Mowlam and seems impatient with the likes of Clare Short and John Prescott, even though they have the knack of political storytelling.

The result is a government that can keep churning out neat programmes and generous schemes - and there will be more in next week's budget - but which still gets no credit for them. We can see the pearls, but no one is threading them into a necklace. The cabinet cannot do the job: it is too full of anonymities, most of them too cautious and buckled-up to say anything interesting. That leaves the task in the hands of one man. And yet Tony Blair has never constructed a personal story which might capture the imagination of the British people. He needs to find one soon - for himself and his government.

webTitle: MPs flatter to deceive on the Mongolian question

fields.headline: MPs flatter to deceive on the Mongolian question
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Foreign affairs questions yesterday, and British MPs asked about, among others, the following places: Uganda, Gibraltar, Burma, Mongolia, Iran, Russia, Kosovo, Egypt, Cameroon, Mozambique, Angola, Iraq, St Helena, Pakistan, Congo, Cyprus, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Nigeria, Argentina, East Timor, Australia, New Zealand, Palestine, China, Colombia,   Austria, the EU applicant countries and all the rest of the Union.
fields.body:
Foreign affairs questions yesterday, and British MPs asked about, among others, the following places: Uganda, Gibraltar, Burma, Mongolia, Iran, Russia, Kosovo, Egypt, Cameroon, Mozambique, Angola, Iraq, St Helena, Pakistan, Congo, Cyprus, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Nigeria, Argentina, East Timor, Australia, New Zealand, Palestine, China, Colombia, Austria, the EU applicant countries and all the rest of the Union.

You might wonder what business it is of ours. In fact, it turns out that it is our business, since it is the task of these other countries to emulate us in every respect.

For example, a delegation of 10 Mongolian MPs will be visiting the Commons today. MPs piled up to express their undying support for the Mongolian people, the Elysium in which they live, and their admirable desire to copy our way of doing things.

According to James Gray: "Mongolia is a beacon of pluralistic free marketing." (Translated - they are adherents of the World Institute of Thatcherology, global life president, M Thatcher.)

Peter Pike was even keener. "Every one of the Mongolian MPs has said that their prime objective is to learn about democracy while they are over here!"

John Battle, the junior minister, just couldn't wait for the return of the "productive" UK-Mongolian round table meetings.

It was a little puzzling. Didn't they know that Mongolia is rather cold and definitely not a tropical paradise with silver beaches and a variety of attractive resort hotels? What other possible reason could there be for our MPs being friendly with the place?

We shall discover today, when the Mongolian deputies attend that shining example of civilised discourse, prime minister's question time.

Next someone raised the plight of Christians in Egypt. Apparently that too would be solved if the Egyptians were more like us. "We are very proud of our multi-colour, multi-faith, multi-ethnic society," said Peter Hain. "We press that as a model for the rest of the world."

How fortunate the rest of the world is to have us as its model. I wonder if, however, they are less than grateful. In the Zimbabwean parliament do MPs press their foreign minister to "take up with the British government the wholly unacceptable rigging of the Labour candidacy for London mayor"?

Do the politicians of Cameroon denounce the treatment of asylum seekers in Britain, and urge their leaders to take it up with the relevant authorities in the strongest terms? Probably not. I suspect that the sad truth is that they are much less interested in us than we are in them.

But our MPs are very interested in each other. Unable to do much about the tyrants of Burma and China, they can take solace in the treatment meted out to poor Francis Maude, shuffled in to the Conservative foreign affairs portfolio to make way for Michael Portillo.

Mr Maude demanded less interference from Brussels. Robin Cook accused him of posturing as a champion of the veto. "He not only signed the Maastricht treaty, but said he was proud to have signed the Maastricht treaty!"

Mr Maude said sourly: "You don't understand the difference between driving to the end of the pier, and carrying on driving off the pier."

Mr Cook, who whatever his failings (we learned that the Jerusalem Post, which finds him inadequately pro-Israeli, has said, "with a diplomat like Cook at his side, how can Blair fail to look like a world statesman?") is the best in the business at repartee, said: "You speak for a party which, by the time of the last election, had indeed become an end-of-the-pier show."

Not Cook at his finest, but strangely satisfying to MPs, unlike our feeble and sadly ineffective protests to the world's great despotisms.

fields.headline: The end of the affair
fields.trailText: Much as I enjoyed Alan Rusbridger's epic piece (Sound and fury, Media, March 13) on the Guardian, Sinn Fein, the IRA and all the rest of it, and without wishing to paralyse your readers any further, the whole business boils down to four key points. We stick by our story. He sticks by his. We repeatedly offered him the space of our letters column in the Spectator, an offer he mysteriously declined. He censored my letter from the Guardian.

Boris Johnson
The Spectator

Manchester

fields.headline: Back chat
fields.trailText: Why all the sudden surprise about the capacity for knowledge of London taxi drivers (Proof that knowledge is good for the brain, March 14)? When he won Mastermind some years back, cabbie Fred Housego said that his general knowledge was no greater than any other London taxi driver but that he had merely won the raffle held among them to enter the competition.

When he won Mastermind some years back, cabbie Fred Housego said that his general knowledge was no greater than any other London taxi driver but that he had merely won the raffle held among them to enter the competition.

RJ Gibbs
Cardiff

 "We found a significant correlation, in that the pos-terior of the back part of the hippocampus increased in size. The longer you were a taxi driver the bigger it got." Conclusive proof that taxi drivers talk out of their arses?

M Hibbert
London

 What about the left-handed taxi drivers? As someone who is sinistro-manual and proud of it, I believe it is high time this discrimination should cease. Without being self-lefteous about it, can it be left that clever, delightful and generally useful members of society should be so treated?

Andrew Wale
Glasgow
a.wale@lib.gla.ac.uk

 If cabbies have such big brains, how come they can't find south London?

fields.trailText: I would like to set the record straight about asylum seekers vouchers (Keep the change, refugee vouchers stores are told, March 10; Letters, March 11). However, the home office told us that it is illegal for retailers to give back change, as set down by law in the immigration asylum act of 1999. I would like to set the record straight about asylum seekers vouchers (Keep the change, refugee vouchers stores are told, March 10; Letters, March 11). We raised the matter of giving change with the home office because we do not want to keep the change and thereby profit at the expense of asylum seekers. However, the home office told us that it is illegal for retailers to give back change, as set down by law in the immigration asylum act of 1999. We decided to go ahead with the scheme because the alternative is for civil servants to hand out bags of shopping to asylum seekers, taking away their right to choose what they want to buy.

It is stated on the vouchers that change cannot be given and asylum seekers will also receive a £10 voucher each week that they can exchange for cash at the post office. This cash and voucher system means that asylum seekers can hand over the exact amount required. They do not have to buy everything at once, or spend all of their allowance in one shop.

Yvonne West
Voucher centre manager, Sainsbury's

 Unfortunately, our government is even meaner than the Germans and won't allow asylum seekers to swap vouchers for cash. One way round this is to call on the corporate social responsibility of supermarkets. So let's see them compete with one another to raise money each week from customers for "their" registered asylum seekers. After all, supermarkets are falling over themselves to organise schemes to collect money for school computers and books.

Irene Bruegel
Miriam David
Rayah Feldman
London

 It seems we are less affronted by poverty than by the poor people we come face to face with on the tube and streets. We attack beggars and asylum seekers with a hostility verging on hysteria (East Europeans lead growing army of beggars, March 10). In an article based on a relatively humane British transport police report, you embroider the figures with prejudice. Apparently begging is illegal and begging with children worse. But surely it is more criminal to send beggars to jail?

Helen Roberts
Kingston upon Hull

fields.headline: Diamond in the rough
fields.trailText: The news of the jobs on the new jumbo is to be applauded (World's largest jet cleared for takeoff, March 14). But it was also a classic example of news management. As Stephen Byers gave us the good news, Lord Sainsbury put a torch to the science and research community of the north-west, by choosing the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory at Oxford for the new generation light source, the Diamond, instead of Daresbury (Science site move dismays north-west MPs).
fields.body:
The news of the jobs on the new jumbo is to be applauded (World's largest jet cleared for takeoff, March 14). But it was also a classic example of news management. As Stephen Byers gave us the good news, Lord Sainsbury put a torch to the science and research community of the north-west, by choosing the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory at Oxford for the new generation light source, the Diamond, instead of Daresbury (Science site move dismays north-west MPs).

The synchrotron was conceived and developed at Daresbury over 25 years and the scientific community worldwide is amazed at the decision. It would appear that the wishes of the Wellcome Trust and the French government determine our regional policy. Five hundred scientists and engineers in the north-west will be dispersed to the south-east and elsewhere - maybe abroad.

This is an act of betrayal which will not be quickly forgiven or forgotten. Once again, the metropolitan media has allowed this appalling injustice to go virtually unreported. The undermining of the scientists at Daresbury over the last year, the role of the Wellcome Trust and the prevarication of the DTI is a story that needs to be told. After this decision, 30 times as much scientific investment will be taking place in the south-east as in the north-west. The north-south divide is becoming a chasm.

Cllr Tony McDermott
Leader, Halton Borough Council
Tony.McDermott@halton-borough.gov.uk

 Is the government's decision on Diamond another snub to its heartland voters in favour of middle-class southern voters? More workers will move south, pushing up costs in an already inflated southern housing market at the expense of northern industries.

Tim Harvey
Northwich, Cheshire
Tim.Harvey@avecia.com

 To say no to this blackmail, the government would have to find £100m. But on the same day, it says it's found £500m to invest in a new plane. The decision flies in the face of the need to do something about the overheating economy in the south-east. The construction costs will be far higher in the south, as will the costs of paying people to work there, plus the redundancy costs of those staff working in Cheshire who will not move, and could not afford to move, to Oxford.

Rev Steve Parish
Warrington
steve@bloovee.freeserve.co.uk

 What could be a more fitting monument to the vast stupidity and irrationality of corporate capitalism than the creation of a "jumbo" jumbo jet? While airline executives plan for a 5% annual increase in air travel, the intergovernmental panel on climate change predicts that airliners will be responsible for 15% of all greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. While IPCC scientists tell us that a 60% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions is needed to stabilise global temperatures, the Kyoto treaty is proposing just 5.2%, and even this is being vigorously opposed by big business.

David Edwards
Bournemouth
david@awed.fsnet.co.uk

 While Peter Hetherington's analysis of the government's ambivalence on the English regional agenda (Nudge and fudge, March 13) is compelling, his statistics are not. Try plotting the Regional Development Agency's budgets per capita, either of population or of claimants. The south-east faces its own challenges, not least how to sustain its contribution to the UK's competitiveness.

Paul Bevan
Director, South East England Regional Assembly
paulbevan@southeast-ra.gov.uk

fields.headline: Our trains are on time
fields.trailText: Simon Hoggart questions my integrity when I say I'll deliver a new fleet of high-speed trains (Bullet trains or murder on the Virgin express, Saturday Review, March 11). He says: "I've said before that I'll believe in miracle trains when I ride on one. But that's unfair. When I see a train maker standing in front of even one chassis, waving the appropriate cheque from Mr Branson, then I'll accept it! But I'm not holding my breath."
fields.body:
Simon Hoggart questions my integrity when I say I'll deliver a new fleet of high-speed trains (Bullet trains or murder on the Virgin express, Saturday Review, March 11). He says: "I've said before that I'll believe in miracle trains when I ride on one. But that's unfair. When I see a train maker standing in front of even one chassis, waving the appropriate cheque from Mr Branson, then I'll accept it! But I'm not holding my breath."

Well, I'm happy to take him up on his challenge this week. Not one chassis, but 12 of the 100 made in Birmingham at Alsthom Fiat's factory. The cheque for this batch of trains (£280m) has already been paid, but I'll get a copy made for the photo op. Or he could take a trip to Bruges in Belgium and have a photo taken in front of the first batch of tilting diesel trains rolling out of the Bombardier factory (Cheque, already paid, £320m).

Had Simon Hoggart read the Guardian of December 15 1999 he would have seen a picture of me standing in front of the first to roll off the production line. I'm happy to accept criticism when it's due.

Richard Branson
Virgin Management

fields.headline: Tax cuts without tears
fields.standfirst: Mr Hague wants us not to feel guilty
fields.trailText: Mr Hague wants us not to feel guilty
fields.body:
Fewer than 30% of the British electorate voted Conservative in the general election of 1997. Somehow, the party has to remedy that by the time we next vote, perhaps in little more than a year. William Hague's speech on taxation yesterday marks an essential stage in that process, staking out the territory on which he plans to fight, after a long and desultory period in which it sometimes seemed that his only distinctive message would be bile about Europe. Taxation is destined to be the issue which in Conservative eyes tops them all: "If we do not stand for lower taxes and smaller government, we do not stand for anything."

The Tories will argue not just, as ever, that low taxation is essential to economic success and national regeneration, but more ambitiously, that people are somehow morally cleaner for having their taxes cut. "Low tax," Mr Hague declared, "gives people the means to look after themselves and acquire responsible habits. High tax drives out good conscience, drives out generous instincts, drives out the sense of personal responsibility, inculcates cynicism about the institutions that give our lives moral shape. If that is not a moral argument, I do not know what is." The calculation is plain. Even now, when its popularity ratings are dipping on many policy issues, New Labour seems to have got the message across that this is not the old Labour of promiscuous tax and spend. The Conservatives have been hammering away at the theme that while preaching prudence, the chancellor has been ratcheting up our taxes by stealth - a charge more or less admitted by Downing Street yesterday - but so far without denting Labour. Mr Hague has to find some way of repackaging the old Tory appeal to the voters' anti-tax instincts; and this at a time when opinion polls consistently re port that voters would willingly see taxes increased if it meant better public services, especially in health and education.

The Conservatives hope to meet that challenge in two ways. First, by claiming, as Michael Portillo did yesterday on the basis of an arithmetic so far denied to us, that even while promoting the moral health of the nation by cutting our taxes, they will push up public spending on the services we most cherish. And second, by trying to banish the sense of guilt about having our taxes cut when so many people in the midst of our national affluence are poor and needy, and so many essential institutions starved of sustenance. Wanting lower taxes, Mr Hague asserts, is not self-indulgence, but a blow struck for honour and decency.

Some of the case he makes is decidedly hazardous; some is downright shoddy. "Taxes," he says, "lie at the heart of state interference in our lives." But state provision, even under a William Hague government, is the one available opportunity for most people in Britain. If state interference means getting treatment for cancer or heart disease before it is too late to save them, then most people would favour more state interference, not less. Higher taxes mean not "less freedom", as Mr Hague claims, but a necessary ingredient of freedom from want, from disease and from fear. To assert, as he does, that high taxes "destroy generous instincts" would seem, after the recent response to the floods in Mozambique, a slander on the people Mr Hague hopes to govern. Still, to have the Conservatives making the moral case for lower taxation should put some real meat into next year's debate. The big question now is whether New Labour will be ready to answer it by making the moral case for higher taxation, from which it has flinched up to now.

webTitle: The longest, hardest battle: winning the peace

fields.headline: The longest, hardest battle: winning the peace
fields.standfirst:
Head of UN mission has an unenviable task

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Head of UN mission has an unenviable task
fields.body:
Bernard Kouchner has the most thankless job in the UN. A gastro-enterologist who founded the charity Médecins sans Frontières, he is now the special representative of the secretary general in Kosovo.

His mandate as the territory's administrator is unlimited and vague. As a result, the UN security council constantly second-guesses his decisions. Nominally in charge of everything, he has no control over the international peacekeeping force, K-For, which Nato insists on keeping in its grip.

He has to convince reluctant foreign governments to come up with cash and he must contend with Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav president, doing everything possible to provoke crisis and destabilisation. On top of this he has to deal with his main clients: an increasingly impatient Albanian population which complains too little is being done, and a Serb community which feels beleaguered and devoid of hope.

Faced with this catalogue of pressures, the 60-year-old doctor has to fight hard to present an optimistic front. Sitting in his office in Pristina, he calls the suggestion that the international community won the war but is losing the peace "very facile and very distant".

"Looking at Kosovo from afar, I understand that people may think like that. But it's never been possible to judge a peace process properly after such a short time," he said.

"What did the international community expect? It thought the end of the bombing was the end of the war. In the military sense of the word, perhaps it was the end of the war. But it wasn't the end of the confrontation. The roots of the conflict go too deep to be able to cut them out so fast."

Often derided as a publicity-seeker in his days with the charity, and as a socialist minister in France, he takes aim at the media's short attention span and its appetite for highlighting every new problem.

"We live in a world of images which don't last longer than a fortnight," he says. "People no longer remember the diplomatic efforts before the bombing, the progress at the Rambouillet talks, the rivers of refugees towards neighbouring states, the huge shock the international community felt, and the need for intervention to stop the ethnic cleansing.

"People also forget the return of the refugees within three months. Refugees have never come back so quickly. Destruction has never been so massive, and I don't mean by the bombing, because in Kosovo it didn't cause much.

"Kosovo had nothing, no schools, no hospitals. We've got things moving. We've got the schools and university going and the health system is working. And we've achieved demilitarisation. It's never been done so quickly to demilitarise and transform a liberation army, and provide civil security. It took 30 years in Northern Ireland."

His main problem, he acknowledges, is the level of hatred in Kosovo which makes it almost impossible to get Serbs and Albanian leaders to sit down together. He compares the Balkans unfavourably to Africa when asked if he has considered creating a Truth and Reconciliation commission for Kosovo, similar to the body set up in South Africa.

"I've been trying to do it in a way when I speak to the leaders of the two sides in Mitrovice. I would like to tell them: 'If you want to talk about the past, you have to do it more seriously. You can't just stop history and start at the date you find convenient.' But it's always like that in the Balkans. You can talk about what happened 500 years ago, not what happened five months ago," he says.

He believes that South Africa was different because it had two exceptional people, Nelson Mandela and FW de Klerk, at the helm, and because it is a big country, open to the world. "It's not a Balkan region, closed in on its past sorrows. There it's not a permanent struggle against neighbours, because your neighbour is always around. In the Balkans you're always someone's neighbour. Everyone knows each other in Mitrovice, and they detest each other.

"We've thought of having a commission on history, but we can't find participants from both sides who feel safe enough. We have to give people security, particularly the Serbs. And the other side, the Albanians are too close to their suffering to be ready.

"There are still thousands of missing people. No one knows if they're alive or not. So there are blockages in this society. They're to do with history, certainly. But also psychological. A huge amount of work has to be done inside people."

Dr Kouchner is proud of the intervention to save Kosovo's Albanians. "It is very important for me psychologically and for everyone politically, that the international community took a colossal step forward in protecting a minority beyond national borders.

"What Kofi Annan [the UN secretary general] calls humanitarian intervention is a sign of progress which could not be imagined a few years ago after this century of genocide and massacres.

"Frontiers must not be barriers to protecting people. The world belongs to everyone in their suffering. Of course we respect the sovereignty of states," he insists. "Especially of respectable states," he adds.

fields.headline: TV's silent warning
fields.standfirst:
15 died but no apology for bombing broadcasters

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: 15 died but no apology for bombing broadcasters
fields.body:
Mrs Stojanovic woke suddenly at 2.20am on the faded, chocolate-brown sofa of her two-room flat in Belgrade. It was April 23 1999, in block 39 of a complex of gloomy apartment blocks on a windy hill in the suburbs of Belgrade. She had fallen asleep with the television on; usually the Nato bombers kept her awake.

She opened her eyes and looked at the television on top of the glass cabinet where she kept her leather-bound encyclopedias. The TV picture was gone and, at that moment, she knew that the last of her five children was dead.

Zanha Stojanovic, a 63-year-old retired primary school teacher, died inside that night, when four tonnes of explosives flew through the glass-plated lobby of Belgrade's Radio Television Serbia (RTS) and killed her 26-year-old son, Nebojsa, her last surviving child.

Nato killed 15 others that night, most of them technicians in their early 20s.

"None of us know exactly what we buried. I got a small envelope with a part of his gold chain and his car keys," Mrs Stojanovic says. Nebojsa's workmate Ksenija was identified by her sock, Darko by a shoe and Bane after a DNA test on a toe.

webTitle: Don't stir up trouble, US warns Albanians

fields.headline: Don't stir up trouble, US warns Albanians
fields.standfirst:
Nato fears grow over attempts to provoke Serbs

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The US yesterday warned ethnic Albanians against provoking a conflict in Serbia's Presevo valley, amid growing concerns within Nato about attempts by hardliners to extend the conflict in the region.
fields.body:
The US yesterday warned ethnic Albanians against provoking a conflict in Serbia's Presevo valley, amid growing concerns within Nato about attempts by hardliners to extend the conflict in the region.

James Rubin, the American assistant secretary of state, said he recognised that the treatment of Albanians in the area - close to Kosovo's eastern boundary- was a serious problem. But he warned that the hardliners should not be under any illusion about the US attitude.

"Kosovo is one thing and Presevo is a different thing," he said, during a visit to the US army base at Camp Monteith in eastern Kosovo.

An armed group in the Presevo valley has vowed to defend the region's Albanian majority from alleged brutality by Serb security forces. Western governments and Nato commanders believe the group wants to provoke a Serbian backlash in the hope that Nato will intervene to help them.

More troops from the Nato-led international peacekeeping force, K-For, have recently been sent to the Kosovo border area following reports that armed Albanians were crossing into the Presevo valley. The valley is home to an estimated 70,000 ethnic Albanians, about 10% of whom have fled to Kosovo in recent months.

Mr Rubin was ending a three-day visit to Kosovo during which ethnic Albanian leaders were told they were not doing enough to stop ethnically motivated violence or crimes.

Geoffrey Hoon, the British defence secretary, yesterday voiced his concerns about recent events. He said: "On the Albanian side we see genuine refugees who simply want to return to their old homes. But we also see hardline agitators whose agenda, like Milosevic's, is ethnic purity."

Mr Hoon said K-For peacekeepers were mounting "what looks increasingly like an internal security operation rather than peacekeeping".

Nato commanders and member governments now concede that K-For troops will be in Kosovo for at least four more years.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said British judges and prosecutors would start work in Kosovo next month to help support the UN civil administration. British officials were also being sent to head the UN customs service and the trade and industry section of the province's interim administration.

Igor Ivanov, the Russian foreign minister, meanwhile, urged the major industrialised nations to help prevent tensions within Kosovo from spilling over into southern Serbia. He expressed Moscow's concern that "the very critical situation" in southern Serbia could ignite a new war.

French defence ministry officials met yesterday to discuss accusations by Amnesty International that their troops in Kosovo were guilty of human rights abuses, officials said.

Amnesty has called for an independent inquiry into the fatal shooting of an ethnic Albanian man in Mitrovice by the K-For force, which, in the divided city, is made up mostly of French troops.

A total of 49 people are said to have been detained by French troops after an outbreak of violence. They were reportedly kept in inhumane conditions and denied access to lawyers.

fields.headline: The right to say 'I don't'
fields.standfirst: The government plans to require teachers to stress the benefits of marriage. But  Melissa Benn (happily unmarried with children) argues it will bring the stigma of illegitimacy back into schools
fields.trailText: The government plans to require teachers to stress the benefits of marriage. But  Melissa Benn (happily unmarried with children) argues it will bring the stigma of illegitimacy back into schools
fields.body:
It will surely go down as one of the more illogical moral manoevres in political history. In return for the repeal of Section 28, a battle in which new Labour has posed as the defender of tolerance, the government has now pulled off a shabby little deal which will put yet another group of citizens outside the moral pale; this time, the children of the unwed.

Following talks with rebel peers and discontented churchmen, David Blunkett is imminently expected to announce legislation that will require teachers to emphasise the benefits of marriage and the importance of the traditional family unit when discussing anything to do with sex, love or morals.

According to Anne Weyman, chief executive of the FPA, none of the organisations experienced in providing sex education has been consulted about these guidelines - an omission which she describes as "a matter of great concern".

No parent can quarrel with the importance of stability for children. But many unmarried parents (and more than one in three children are born outside marriage) will have profound problems with this new interference by the state and church. The new clause will inevitably bring resistance, resentment, confusion and all shades of hypocrisy in its wake.Susan Douglas has been with her partner for nearly 20 years, "which is a lot longer than most of the parents of my children's friends," she says. She and her partner are typical of the many contented and principled cohabitees increasingly riled by New Labour interference. "I would be appalled if anybody suggested to my son and daughter that our life is any less valid than that of someone who has been through a ceremony that I consider meaningless. I have watched a lot of my friends get married . . . and then get married again."

Children are full of questions about seeds and sperm and they are always curious about weddings because of the costumes, the cake, the crowds, the decorous ritual of it all. At the marriage of a close relative last year, my eldest daughter was riveted by the spectacle of the bride, resplendent in white, smiling and sweetly speechless, with nothing to do but just be; beautiful, passive, untouchable, the pinnacle of conventional female achievement.

Every unmarried parent inevitably faces the question: why haven't you done it? For Susan Douglas, the moment of reckoning came while she was reading her morning paper. "There was this big picture on the front page of a wedding dress showing in the Milan collections. My daughter, who was then six, asked me: 'What did you wear when you got married, mum?' Here we go, I thought. So I carefully explained that although her father and I had been together for many years and we loved each other and her and her brother very much, we were not married. She was fine about it. She wasn't even particularly curious."

Many unmarried parents report the same kind of low-key exchange. As one mother of two said: "My daughter may have said once or twice, 'I wish you were married' but she has always been perfectly happy with the way our family is." Blunkett's dictum could change all that. From being a simple signifier of difference, the artefacts of marriage - the wedding dress, the marriage photos - could take on a more sinister significance. Will my daughters feel embarrassed that there is no montage of the Happy Day in their home, no apparent proof of their parents maturity? Will they become defensive, on my and my partner's behalf?

Personally, I doubt that many teachers will countenance the serious promotion of marriage as the preferred family form. Andrew O'Connor teaches 14- to 18-year-olds at a large inner-city comprehensive. He thinks Blunkett's proposal is illogical, insenstive and runs counter to the curriculum, "which encourages students to question the idea that anything, let alone marriage, is the bedrock of society. To say to most of the kids I teach, there is only one model as to how people should live their lives just doesn't make sense."

O'Connor also questions the notion that girls are particularly drawn to romance and marriage. "It's boys who are the romantics, girls who are level-headed. The boys all want to be DJs or play for Liverpool. But the girls know exactly what they are going to do. They want to make a success of school, go to university, have a career and then form some sort of relationship. But it has to be right."

And there in those six little words - but it has to be right - lies the rub. In Scotland, where the debate over Section 28 has been particularly fierce, the executive has come up with a more sensible and sensitive compromise. Children will be taught only of the importance of 'stable family relationships.' But even here one has to ask, how easy is that? Like my domestic science classes at school where I learned how to ruin kedgeree and put a nappy on a plastic doll, some skills have no meaning in the wrong context. Or rather, one has to re-learn them all over again in a world where cooking an evening meal and changing a baby has some meaning or urgency.

It is impossible to teach children the true meaning, as opposed to the symbolic value, of commitment. Even the best relationships go through periods of disappointment and estrangement, but to know at what point these emotions signify the true end of a partnership is one of the most personal questions any of us will ever have to face. The best lessons will inevitably be by personal example. Children are more likely to learn through observation of their parents over the years than by abstract instruction on what Chris Woodhead has called "the importance of moral absolutes".

Parents who have opted not to marry are used to reflecting on their choices, and increasingly, having to justify them, so they may be in a better position to discuss the reality of love and living.

Harriet Wells, happily unmarried, has two children. "I became increasingly riled by that bit in all the fairy tales that says Happy Ever After. My seven-year-old daughter was beginning to notice that lots of married people separate or eventually get divorced and this rosy version of marriage is an illusion. So, eventually I just had to say, 'Look, you know this has nothing to do with real life. In real life, two people are lucky if they like each other most of the time, if they can have a laugh, learn how to argue and then how to wrap their arms around each other and make up. That's real life.'

"And my daughter really liked me saying that. It made sense to her. Now, whenever we come to the end of a fairy tale, she wrinkles up her nose and turns to me with a grin and says: 'Happy Ever After? That's just silly isn't it, mum? Now let me tell you what really happens'"

webTitle: Southern Tuesday puts Bush and Gore on course

fields.headline: Southern Tuesday puts Bush and Gore on course
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Al Gore and George W Bush were close to clinching the Democratic and Republican presidential nominations yesterday as six southern US states voted in the latest presidential primary contests.
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush were close to clinching the Democratic and Republican presidential nominations yesterday as six southern US states voted in the latest presidential primary contests.

With Bill Bradley and John McCain now out of the running in the two party races, Mr Gore and Mr Bush were close to gaining enough national convention delegates to ensure that they will be the main contenders in the presidential election on November 7.

The primaries took place in Mr Gore's home state of Tennessee and Mr Bush's state of Texas, as well as in Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi and Oklahoma. Mr Gore was favoured to gain 566 more Democratic delegates and Mr Bush to win all 363 Republican delegates at stake yesterday.

Mr Gore seemed certain to take his delegate total past the 2,169 that he requires for a majority in the 4,337-strong Democratic convention in Los Angeles in August. Mr Bush was close to reaching the 1,034 delegates he needs to win a majority among the 2,066 attending July's Republican convention in Philadelphia.

After a primary season in which voter turnout reached record levels, yesterday's contests saw a slump in participation. In Louisiana, a turnout of under 10% was predicted due to the collapse of interest in the contest since last week's decisive Super Tuesday results.

The latest Gallup presidential poll gave Mr Bush a 49% to 43% lead over Mr Gore.

Mr Gore's support is strongest among women, minorities, the elderly, easterners, city dwellers and low-income groups. Mr Bush's appeal is strongest among men, whites, suburbanites, middle-aged voters and residents of the west and south.

fields.headline: Murderer of prostitutes gets life
fields.trailText: A 35-year-old man was yesterday sentenced to life for the murder of two prostitutes in the early 1990s.
fields.body:
A 35-year-old man was yesterday sentenced to life for the murder of two prostitutes in the early 1990s.

Alun Kyte, a former motor mechanic, strangled Samo Paull and Tracy Turner before dumping their bodies at the side of isolated country lanes in Leicestershire, Nottingham crown court heard.

Miss Paull, 20, a single mother who had been working in the Balsall Heath area of Birmingham at the time of her death in 1993, was found three weeks later near Lutterworth, Leicestershire. She was semi-naked and lying in a water-filled ditch.

A few days later the naked body of Miss Turner, 30, from Stafford, was found.

The jury heard how Kyte, also from Stafford, had boasted to prisoners while on remand how he had killed the women and disposed of their bodies.

Describing the murder of Miss Paull, he said she had laughed at his sexual prowess so he had choked her until she had stopped laughing.

During the 11-day trial four serving prisoners, including a murderer, told the court how Kyte confessed to the murders while on remand for a rape.

fields.headline: Shetlanders cleared for oil payouts
fields.trailText: The government has dropped a claim for £1m in compensation over the sinking of the Braer oil tanker off Shetland in 1993, it said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government has dropped a claim for £1m in compensation over the sinking of the Braer oil tanker off Shetland in 1993, it said yesterday.

The move by Westminster and the devolved Scottish administration will enable people in Shetland to pursue their compensation claims.

The vessel's insurers have also said they will not pursue a salvage claim. And officials said the combined effect of yesteday's moves should enable £5.2m to be made available to local people.

The sinking of the Braer off Shetland in January 1993 was one of the world's biggest oil spills. Nearly 85,000 tonnes of crude spilled into the sea in Britain's worst such calamity since the Torrey Canyon sinking in 1967.

But the widespread environmental catastrophe that was feared was averted by hurricane-force winds dispersing and breaking down nearly all the oil.

Three years later, the international oil pollution compensation fund froze compensation payouts, fearing that claims could exceed the £50m available.

Last year the fund's governing bodies agreed that payouts could resume when the outstanding claim total dropped below £20m, and yesterday's moves bring the figure within that threshold.

webTitle: MPs back detention of dangerous psychopaths

fields.headline: MPs back detention of dangerous psychopaths
fields.trailText: Plans for new laws to detain dangerous psychopaths were yesterday backed by MPs, but only on condition there would be extra human rights safeguards.
fields.body:
Plans for new laws to detain dangerous psychopaths were yesterday backed by MPs, but only on condition there would be extra human rights safeguards.

The all-party home affairs select committee said the powers proposed by the government should be used only where it was "almost certain" an individual would commit a serious offence.

Although the committee endorsed the most controversial aspect of the plans - provision to detain people who have committed no previous offence - it conceded that it would "prove exceptionally difficult" to establish that sufficient risk existed to justify such action.

The MPs also demanded that parliament should review the powers annually and that each detention should be reassessed by a judicial body at regular intervals.

The government's plans were put forward in the wake of the conviction of psychopath Michael Stone for the murder in Kent of Lyn Russell and her daughter Megan, and the attempted murder of a second daughter, Josie.

The Fallon inquiry into Ashworth special hospital on Merseyside had also recommended that patients with a psychopathic, or personality, disorder should be separated from those diagnosed as mentally ill.

After visiting such a separate service in Holland, the home affairs committee has come out in favour of setting up between 25 and 50 units for people with a personality disorder deemed to be dangerous. The units would be distinct from the hospital and prison systems.

The government has estimated that 2,500 people could be placed in the units, but the committee was warned that numbers were very likely to rise beyond that figure.

Robin Corbett, the committee's Labour chairman, said it had to be right for the state to have power to detain people assessed as being dangerous, either after they had completed a prison term "or in circumstances where they had not been convicted of an offence".

It was inevitable that some decisions to detain, or not, would be incorrect. But new assessment techniques were being tested and the safeguards suggested by the committee would help counter unwarranted detentions.

The Dutch service has been operating for more than 70 years, but applies only to personality disordered people convicted of an offence carrying a minimum penalty of four years' jail. The service is also based on an assumption that personality disorder is treatable and patients are released after an average six years. In Britain many psychiatrists believe the condition untreatable.

The committee's report, which warns that the cost of setting up a new service in Britain will be "substantial", received a conditional welcome from leading mental health groups. Cliff Prior, chief executive of the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, said: "Ministers need to face up to the fact that their plans will cost a great deal of money."

Marjorie Wallace, chief executive of schizophrenia charity Sane, said: "Only by providing special laws and services, and no longer turning away people on the ground that they are untreatable, will we be able to combat the stigma for the majority of those with mental illness and disorder who are never violent."

However, the charity Mind and Liberty, the civil rights group, both expressed doubts about the principle and practice of detaining people who may have committed no crime.

John Wadham, Liberty's director, said: "Detaining people on the basis that they might commit a serious offence in the future requires a crystal ball. Risk assessment and diagnosis are not precise sciences and there is a very real risk that individuals will be unjustly detained, particularly if they have no previous record of offending."

webTitle: RSC to caption plays for the deaf

fields.headline: RSC to caption plays for the deaf
fields.trailText: The Royal Shakespeare Company is to become the first theatre company in Britain to introduce a technique to help deaf people keep up with the action on stage as it happens.
fields.body:
The Royal Shakespeare Company is to become the first theatre company in Britain to introduce a technique to help deaf people keep up with the action on stage as it happens.

Later this month a performance of Antony and Cleopatra at the Barbican, the RSC's London base, will be accompanied by the text projected in a way similar to surtitles in opera houses, but at the side of the stage rather than above it.

Until now deaf people have had to rely on the induction loop system - which can also unfortunately pick up calls from local taxis - or on the skills of signers, who can only present a summary of the action.

But a caption technique pioneered by an American court reporter with lightning fingers will enable them to keep one eye on Shakespeare's words as they are spoken.

The text will be shown at the exact moment it is declaimed. If the actors fluff a line, the op erator will be able to make immediate alterations to the captions.

The system is already in use on Broadway in New York, where it has been used for productions including The King and I and Amadeus.

"The words will be projected in two lines of text two inches high on a screen about the size of a guitar case," said Peter Cadley, the RSC's theatres manager in London.

The move was welcomed yesterday by the Royal National Institute for Deaf People. 70,000 people can follow British sign language but 8m others with hearing prob lems cannot. "Research shows that one in four hard of hearing people would visit the theatre more often if captioned performances were available," said Marie Mangan for the RNID.

If the Barbican experiment works, captioning could eventually be used at all the RSC's theatres in London and Stratford. New developments could include a voice-activated system that would dispense with an operator.

The text for Antony and Cleopatra will be controlled at the Barbican by the system's inventor Donald DePew, who has adapted the techniques of fast stenography used for court transcripts.

"When I'm sitting in the theatre and operating the caption box during a performance, I can truly feel the emotional response of the audience as they follow the captioning along with what they see," he told the New York Post.

fields.headline: Sculptor pleads for public art
fields.trailText: The sculptor Antony Gormley yesterday denounced the stinginess and failure of imagination of authorities in London and other British cities which is driving sculptors to seek large commissions abroad.
fields.body:
The sculptor Antony Gormley yesterday denounced the stinginess and failure of imagination of authorities in London and other British cities which is driving sculptors to seek large commissions abroad.

The creator of the Angel of the North, now the most popular piece of public art, said London deserved public pieces by his contemporaries, singling out Sir Anthony Caro, Richard Deacon and Tony Cragg as glaring absences.

Derek Morris, director of the Royal Society of British Sculptors, said: "He is spot on. There is pitifully little well placed modern sculpture in London, or in most British cities. There are pieces hidden away in parks and buildings, but nobody is commissioning the really big public pieces by the most important contemporary sculptors - and if they did they'd be stuck in a quagmire of planning problems.

"Imagine a really big piece by Tony Caro slap beside St Paul's. It would be magnificent, but there would be uproar at the mere suggestion."

Caro's work will in fact be represented in the capital this year, by the new millennium footbridge linking Bankside and the City.

Gormley's work can be seen in London as a temporary installation, his giant man at the Millennium Dome. He is working on a commission for the city of Osaka in Japan. The huge piece, based like all his work on his own body, will stand 15 metres high.

Gormley was speaking as English Heritage proclaimed this the year of public sculpture, on the eve of today's unveiling in Trafalgar Square of Bill Woodrow's monumental work Regardless of History.

"Contemporary sculpture should be making a more confident contribution than the temporary use of a redundant 19th century plinth," Gormley said. "Where is the Caro, the Cragg or the Deacon ... the pieces that make people think and feel things?"

The English Heritage chairman, Sir Jocelyn Stevens, praised the Angel of the North as "a piece that makes us raise our eyes and marvel at its strange power". Gormley recalled that before it rose over the A1 near Gateshead it was ridiculed, dubbed "plane stupid" and "Nazi but nice".

fields.headline: Paired off
fields.standfirst: Tests on twins link freckles to cancer
fields.trailText: Moles and freckles, long thought to be a result of over-exposure to the sun, are genetic traits, according to research published yesterday that could result in fewer people developing the melanoma cancer.
fields.body:
Moles and freckles, long thought to be a result of over-exposure to the sun, are genetic traits, according to research published yesterday that could result in fewer people developing the melanoma cancer.

The more moles a person has the higher the risk of melanoma. Around 4,500 people develop it in the UK each year and around 1,500 of them die.

Studies on 450 pairs of twins (127 of the pairs identical) at St Thomas' hospital, London, established the genetic link.

Identical twins, who have the same genes, were more likely to have a similar number of moles and freckles than non-identical twins, who share only 50% of their genetic make-up.

Veronique Bataille, consultant dermatologist at St Thomas' hospital, said: "Around 85% of the cause of a melanoma is genetic. If we know that the number of moles is a risk factor for melanoma, isolating and studying the gene that governs it may help us understand the cancer better.

"The goal is to understand how the gene works in moles and to ask does it have a role in melanoma?" she said.

"It's a first step on the path to reducing the spread of the disease and, we hope, to finding a cure."

Dr Bataille said exposure to the sun could still play a part in melanoma development, and people should continue to be vigilant. "There is no doubt that the earlier you spot the melanoma the less likely it is to spread."

fields.headline: Plastic tank makes its debut
fields.trailText: What is billed as the world's first plastic tank was unveiled yesterday by the ministry of defence, which described it as the most revolutionary change in armoured fighting vehicle materials since the introduction of aluminium in the early 1960s.
fields.body:
What is billed as the world's first plastic tank was unveiled yesterday by the ministry of defence, which described it as the most revolutionary change in armoured fighting vehicle materials since the introduction of aluminium in the early 1960s.

The tank - in fact more akin to an armoured fighting vehicle - is made of a plastic-fibre composite called E-glass, manufactured by Vosper Thornycroft.

The vehicle was designed and built by the defence evaluation and research agency and Vickers.

The top and the hull are made entirely of the composite, though part of its armour plating is made of steel.

The agency said yesterday that the tank's main advantage lay in it being much lighter than conventional armoured vehicles and more easily transportable.

The plastic composite is not suitable for main battle tanks, which some believe are becoming obsolete in modern warfare. Other military commentators, however, say that the presence of heavy metal will continue to have a psychological effect, not least in Kosovo and Bosnia.

Meanwhile, the first of 64 Apache attack helicopters will be delivered today to the MoD. The Apache would provide the army of the 21st century with a "quantum leap in capability equivalent to the introduction of the tank in the 20th century", the ministry said.

Despite huge publicity about its prowess, the US- designed helicopter was not used in the Kosovo action. Washington believed it would be too vulnerable to attack from the Serbs.
