webTitle: Woman blind for 18 years can see again

fields.headline: Woman blind for 18 years can see again
fields.trailText: A woman who spent nearly 20 years believing she was permanently blind yesterday told of the moment her sight was restored after an optician discovered she had easily treatable cataracts.
fields.body:
A woman who spent nearly 20 years believing she was permanently blind yesterday told of the moment her sight was restored after an optician discovered she had easily treatable cataracts.

Jean Baxter, 76, from Warlingham, Surrey, resigned herself to a life in darkness 18 years ago after doctors diagnosed her as suffering from an inherited progressive condition that had struck her mother, elder sister and brother.

But late last year an optician found this diagnosis to be wrong. "She gave me a thorough examination and asked me if I knew I had cataracts," said Mrs Baxter. "I was flabbergasted."

Since having the cataracts removed six weeks ago at the East Surrey hospital in Redhill she no longer even needs to wear the glasses she donned as her vision began to falter 57 years ago.

"The doctors warned me not to expect too much because my vision could have failed over the years anyway," she said from her home yesterday. "But when they took the dressing off all I could say was 'My God!'

"My husband thought it was because I was still blind, but it was the brilliance of the colours. It was like I had been returned to this new, rich world of colour and shape - a wonderful, wonderful moment."

Mrs Baxter, who trained as an instructor in Moon, a form of Braille, once she was registered blind, said the crucial factors in having her sight restored were her having worn glasses throughout her blindness and the persistence of her husband, Arthur, 73, a retired driving instructor.

"I kept on wearing my glasses because I thought people might not recognise me, after having them for so long," she said.

"But my husband wanted me to have some more modern frames. He tried to make me appointments at several opticians, but they all turned him down until he found one last November.

"I didn't want to go but he insisted. I didn't tell [the opti cian] I was blind, I just told her about my parents, my sister and brother, and I said: 'I'm next in line.'

"She did everything under the sun to test me. Then she asked me if anyone had ever told me I had cataracts."

A cataract is an opaque area in the normally transparent lens of the eye which prevents light rays from passing through and focusing on the retina, the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye. But the cataract can be removed.

Mrs Baxter, a mother of four, said she felt angry at losing nearly 20 years of sight but had no intention of suing the hospital which wrongly diagnosed her. "I was angry when I first realised what had happened but it doesn't matter now. I'm delighted to have my vision back."

It had opened up a "whole new world". She could see her three young grandchildren for the first time and see holiday spots that she loved.

But she would keep her links with her old world, "teaching Moon to those now not as fortunate as myself".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Police seek Shayler letter
An application by Special Branch to obtain a letter and other documents connected with former MI5 officer David Shayler was adjourned at the Old Bailey yesterday. The case is being brought against the Observer and Guardian newspapers and journalist Martin Bright.
fields.body:
Police seek Shayler letter
An application by Special Branch to obtain a letter and other documents connected with former MI5 officer David Shayler was adjourned at the Old Bailey yesterday. The case is being brought against the Observer and Guardian newspapers and journalist Martin Bright.

The Met said a letter to the Observer alleged two British intelligence officers were connected with a plot to kill Libya's Colonel Gadaffi. The hearing continues.

Extradition for murder suspect
A Lisbon appeal court has ruled that Sid Ahmed Rezala, the suspected murderer of Birmingham University student, Isabel Peake, should be extradited to France to stand trial, his lawyer said yesterday. Mr Rezala, who was arrested in January, had appealed against extradition on the grounds he would not get a fair trial.

Man held over barmaid's death
Detectives involved in the six-year hunt for the killer of barmaid Wendy Speakes were last night questioning a 38-year-old man from Leeds. Mrs Speakes, 51, was stabbed to death in Wakefield.

Baby crushed in truck accident
The health and safety executive launched an investigation yesterday after a six-month-old baby, Billy McNaughton, was killed when a forklift truck laden with straw reversed over his pram at an Edinburgh riding centre on Sunday.

Brits winners in summer festival
Brits winners Travis and Macy Gray are among the acts to headline the T In The Park music festival at Balado, near Kinross, on July 8 and 9. Supergrass, Ocean Colour Scene and the Fun Lovin' Criminals will also appear.

webTitle: Robbie Williams heads top 10 of funeral songs

fields.headline: Robbie Williams heads top 10 of funeral songs
fields.trailText: Robbie Williams has long been feted by teenagers, but yesterday it emerged he is also the first choice of those at the other end of this mortal coil; his song Angels has been voted the tune most people would like played at their funeral.
fields.body:
Robbie Williams has long been feted by teenagers, but yesterday it emerged he is also the first choice of those at the other end of this mortal coil; his song Angels has been voted the tune most people would like played at their funeral.

In an annual poll of the most requested songs at funerals Williams's hit was a clear winner, ahead of Frank Sinatra's My Way, which has occupied second place since 1996, and Wind Beneath My Wings by Bette Midler.

Visitors to the Co-Operative Funeral Service website were asked to nominate the song they would most like at their funeral, and the results collated to produce their top 10 pearly greats. These included: My Heart Will Go On (Celine Dion), Who Wants to Live Forever (Queen), You'll Never Walk Alone (Gerry and the Pacemakers), Always Look on the Bright Side of Life (Monty Python), I Will Always Love You (Whitney Houston), Great Balls of Fire (Jerry Lee Lewis) and Imagine (John Lennon).

Ben Jason, sales and marketing manager, said:"These songs mean more to people now than the hymns of 50 years ago."

fields.headline: Dewar supports attack on press
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Government criticism of the Scottish press has intensified with the first minister, Donald Dewar, backing a blistering attack made yesterday by the prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell.
fields.body:
Government criticism of the Scottish press has intensified with the first minister, Donald Dewar, backing a blistering attack made yesterday by the prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell.

In an interview with the Herald newspaper, Mr Campbell accused the Scottish media of "dishonest" reporting of the Scottish parliament, and of operating a "Pravda-in-reverse" policy, putting spin before facts and producing stories which were not true.

His most devastating criticisms were aimed at the Daily Record, Scotland's biggest selling tabloid, which has campaigned against the Scottish executive's repeal of section 28 banning the promotion of homosexuality in schools. The paper, he said, had printed "complete fiction" as part of the campaign.

Mr Campbell's comments come after Tony Blair singled out the Scottish media in his first visit to the Holyrood parliament, accusing them of "corrosive cynicism", and attacking coverage of Scottish politics throughout his trip.

Last night, Mr Dewar's official spokesman, David Whitton, said the first minister agreed with Mr Campbell's comments. Mr Whitton named the Daily Record, the Sun and the Daily Mail, accusing them of publishing stories they knew were not true.

The Scottish executive minister, Sam Galbraith, said: "What we want is a fair press. We don't want a sycophantic press that takes everything given them. A vibrant, strong press is essential. But it has to be a responsible press."

Martin Clarke, editor of the Record, said the attacks were merely diversionary tactics from a troubled government and executive.

"It's a typical Campbell technique," he said. "If you are losing the argument and, more importantly, losing the byelection in Ayr, you get your retaliation in first, you come up with a diversion."

The government's main grudge centres on a belief that not enough space is devoted to issues such as jobs, education, health and crime, and too much is given over to internal crises and policy setbacks within the executive.

There has been growing criticism in the press since devolution last year over issues such as the mishandling of the repeal of section 28, the growing cost of the parliament building and a series of scandals involving a number of the first minister's close advisers.

Some senior Labour figures are known to be dismayed by the attacks on the press. They believe the government and the Scottish executive must work to keep the media on their side.

fields.headline: Section 28 overshadows Ayr's big issues
fields.standfirst:
Byelection: Local concerns and disaffection of Labour voters could bring victory for Scotland's Tories and fillip for SNP

More about section 28
fields.trailText: The seaside town which votes tomorrow in the Scottish parliament's first byelection is festooned with posters against repeal of the controversial clause. Traditionally conservative, Ayr has been portrayed as the battleground for campaigners fighting the Scottish executive to keep section 28.
fields.body:
If headlines and hoardings are a true measure of key election issues then only one concern has gripped the citizens of Ayr; and it is section 28.

The seaside town which votes tomorrow in the Scottish parliament's first byelection is festooned with posters against repeal of the controversial clause. Traditionally conservative, Ayr has been portrayed as the battleground for campaigners fighting the Scottish executive to keep section 28.

On the streets of Ayr the promotion of the acceptability of homosexuality in schools is not the first thing on people's minds. Not when the Labour-run local council is closing a much loved old folks' day centre; when jobs are disappearing, tourism suffering, shops closing and air traffic controllers at nearby Prestwick airport facing the spectre of private ownership.

Ayr came up for grabs in December when the sitting Labour member of the Scottish parliament, Ian Welsh, stood down. He took the seat - a long time Tory stronghold - in the parliamentary elections, after three recounts and with a majority of 25 votes.

Recent polls give the seat back to the Conservatives, and their candidate, John Scott. The latest push Labour's candidate, Rita Miller, down to third place behind the Scottish National party's Jim Mather.

"The story is likely to be Labour down, the SNP up and the Tories where they were," said John Curtice, professor of politics at Strathclyde university. "The Tories are likely to win thanks to the SNP. For Labour voters who are pissed off the SNP is the natural home."

And while they may not be angry about section 28, there is growing disillusionment among Labour supporters with the overall performance of the Scottish executive. Issues such as the soaring cost of the new parliament building and an apparent unwillingness to pull out all the stops in Ayr. For example Tony Blair declined to visit the constituency during his visit to Scotland last week.

Yesterday the Conservative leader, William Hague, on his second trip to Ayr, said Labour's attitude to the byelection showed signs of arrogance and desperation.

"The people of Ayr know Tony Blair is all mouth and no delivery," he said. "He needs to be forced to understand the damage that his government and their misguided policies are doing to this country."

Jim Murphy, the Labour MP for nearby Eastwood, admitted the party had difficulties in the constituency. "There's an element to which we're still struggling to get our message across. For example, the fact that youth unemployment is down 69%.

"But it is up to the people of Ayr. If you had believed the polls then we would never have won Ayr at the general election or the Scottish parliament election."

The Tory candidate, John Scott, said section 28 was a smokescreen. "Jobs are a real issue. Three years ago the average male wage was above the national average. It's now about £20 below the national average and unemployment is beginning to creep up.

"People are beginning to see that Labour promises are being broken. Ayr is a very politically aware town and they like to see their politicians standing up for what they believe in. They see how out of touch with the Scottish people Donald [Dewar] and his Labour/Lib Dem administration have become."

The SNP have run perhaps the most surprising campaign for a byelection seen initially as a two-horse race between Labour and the Tories. They have worked the constituency hard, speaking directly to two-thirds of the voters. The party's deputy leader, John Swinney, said that whatever the result there was a lesson to come out of Ayr for Labour. And it had nothing to do with section 28.

"We've spoken to the overwhelming majority of the electorate, and private polling we did showed that Labour was in deep trouble on some of their core issues like education, health and jobs," he said. "That was a very big factor in how people said they would vote."

fields.headline: Super sails
fields.standfirst: Queen names giant catamaran
fields.trailText: It is 120 feet long, cost £4m to build, has the potential to become the fastest yacht in the world and now it has been given a royal accolade.
fields.body:
It is 120 feet long, cost £4m to build, has the potential to become the fastest yacht in the world and now it has been given a royal accolade.

The Queen yesterday named Britain's largest ocean-racing yacht in a ceremony on the River Thames before scores of sailing enthusiasts. She was taken on board the catamaran by skipper Peter Goss, 38, a former Royal Marine.

The yacht, called Team Philips, will take part in a circumnavigation of the world, starting in December and known simply as The Race.

The yacht, which was built in Devon using aeronautical engineering principles, has been constructed from the types of materials used in space technology and has the capability of notching up a top speed of 40 miles per hour. Its 135ft masts have been made from carbon fibre.

webTitle: Vice-president says Law Society denied her fair trial

fields.headline: Vice-president says Law Society denied her fair trial
fields.trailText: The row at the Law Society over bullying allegations against its vice-president, Kamlesh Bahl, escalated last night when Ms Bahl accused the society of sex and race discrimination and breaching her right to a fair trial.
fields.body:
The row at the Law Society over bullying allegations against its vice-president, Kamlesh Bahl, escalated last night when Ms Bahl accused the society of sex and race discrimination and breaching her right to a fair trial.

Ms Bahl, who was last week found guilty of demeaning and humiliating staff by a panel headed by a retired law lord, said a legal opinion from her QC, Cherie Booth, stated that the society's treatment of her breached the European convention on human rights.

In a statement to be delivered tomorrow to the society's governing council, she will signal that she will not step down quietly and could embroil the society in further damaging legal proceedings.

The council must decide tomorrow what action to take on the panel's report, which has put a question mark over Ms Bahl's accession to the presidency. She had been expected to step up in July to become the first woman and first ethnic minority leader of the 80,000 solicitors in England and Wales until five staff members accused her of bullying and harassment.

Staff members of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union are due to meet today to discuss their response to the report. "We have not ruled out industrial action in the event that no firm and decisive action is taken by the Law Society," said Peter Skyte of the MSF.

In her statement, released to the media last night, Ms Bahl says: "I am driven to the inevitable conclusion that the way in which I have been treated owes little to the matters in issue but owes more to the fact that, for a small but influential group of people, my 'face did not fit' within the Law Society, given my background in industry as against private practice and my ethnicity and gender."

Ms Bahl argues that the case should have been dealt with informally instead of being referred to a retired law lord, with legal representation for all involved costing the society £500,000. She adds: "It is my view and that of my advisers that almost every conceivable principle of good practice was ignored in my case."

She claims that everyone involved in handling the complaint had conflicts of interest.

The Law Society said it "refuted entirely" the allegation that it had acted against her because of her gender and ethnicity. It acted because it had a duty to employees.

webTitle: Canal body ends search for baby

fields.headline: Canal body ends search for baby
fields.standfirst: Mother held by police after reporting pram snatch
fields.trailText: The body of a baby was found by police divers in a canal in Burnley yesterday, several hours after her mother had reported her missing.
fields.body:
The body of a baby was found by police divers in a canal in Burnley yesterday, several hours after her mother had reported her missing.

The woman, who lives in the Lancashire town, had told police that her four-month-old, named locally as Emma Jane Dyson, had been snatched in her pram from outside a public toilet in the town centre at 9.30am.

While the father as well as the mother were being interviewed, officers spent the morning organising what became a major search, until the empty pram was found by a member of the public who had responded to an appeal for help.

After the fully clothed body of the baby had been pulled from the Leeds-Liverpool canal, close to where her father lives, the mother was taken into custody.

Reporting the loss, she had told police she had come out from the toilet and found her child gone, together with its pram and a red shopping bag hanging from it.

Throughout the morning, a police helicopter led the search, which included mounted officers, while loudhailers were used to appeal to local people to join the search.

At lunchtime a member of the public found the empty pram by a bridge next to the canal on the outskirts of Burnley. Less than an hour later, divers had found the body

A post-mortem was being carried out yesterday.

Inspector David Lea, of Lancashire police, who led the search, said a woman in her late 20s or early 30s had been arrested after the body was recovered though she had not been charged with any offence. A police source indicated she was the mother. Inspector Lea said the father had been informed of what had happened.

A forensic examination of the canal scene was being done, and police were checking CCTV pictures from near the town centre toilet.

fields.headline: Insanity plea after sword rampage
fields.trailText: A man who went on the rampage with a samurai sword after his address was mistakenly published in the Macpherson report into the racist killing of Stephen Lawrence was cleared of attempted murder yesterday.
fields.body:
A man who went on the rampage with a samurai sword after his address was mistakenly published in the Macpherson report into the racist killing of Stephen Lawrence was cleared of attempted murder yesterday.

A jury accepted that Errol Kelly, 35, had a nervous breakdown when details were released in February last year along with the names of witnesses and informers involved in the police investigation.

Within four months Kelly, a carpenter, turned from a "pleasant natured, hardworking family man" into a "snarling and bulging eyed" obsessive who ran amok with the sword last June.

The jury found Kelly not guilty by reason of insanity of attempted murder, affray, possessing an offensive weapon and dangerous driving after hearing he had moved into a house in Eltham, south-east London, where a witness connected to the inquiry had lived.

Even though Kelly had nothing to do with the Lawrence case, he and his family were rehoused in the middle of the night and told the error had put them in danger of revenge attacks.

Jeremy Donne, prosecuting, said Kelly, a father of five, had been renovating the council home and was thinking of buying it when the address appeared in the appendix of Sir William's report.

The list was supposed to have been confidential but was printed because of an administrative error, the Old Bailey was told. Mr Donne said the enforced move "unsettled him so that he rapidly became unwell".

He became distrustful, developed a religious obsession and made visits to the Stephen Lawrence memorial, the court heard.

Kelly's wife, Alison, realised he was ill and warned the police that he was "going to blow". She told the court: "I desperately tried to get him help and came up against a brick wall every time."

Her husband finally "cracked" at 3.30am on June 17. Mrs Kelly awoke to find him "ranting" in the middle of the road dressed in his pyjamas.

Mr Donne said: "She saw him holding a Samurai sword. As a police vehicle approached he jumped at it, wielding the sword."

Kelly got in his own car, drove the wrong way down the street and hit another vehicle head on. When a woman in the car asked what was going on, he smashed the windscreen with his sword.

Kelly attacked a police car in similar fashion and then turned towards PC Glenn Gore, a dog handler. "His mouth was fixed in a snarl. Kelly ran at PC Gore's vehicle with the blade of the sword pointing directly in the face of the police officer," Mr Donne said.

PC Gore drove at Kelly and, with the help of several other officers, managed to restrain him.

Lord Gifford, defending Kelly, said the facts of the case were not disputed and the prosecution had accepted Kelly was insane. The jury was told the trial was a formality but that the law required members to bring a verdict of not guilty to the charges by reason of insanity.

Tony Nayani, a consultant psychiatrist, said Kelly was responding to treatment.

Making a supervision and treatment order for two years, Judge Martin Stephens said the publication error had "brought intolerable pressure on a vulnerable aspect of [Kelly's] personality".

He commended the police for their "courage and determination to do their duty to protect the public from what was a terrifying situation".

webTitle: Man who killed daughter, wife and in-laws jailed for life

fields.headline: Man who killed daughter, wife and in-laws jailed for life
fields.trailText: A man who murdered his wife, her parents and his 16-month-old daughter in a knife attack was beginning four life sentences last night.
fields.body:
A man who murdered his wife, her parents and his 16-month-old daughter in a knife attack was beginning four life sentences last night.

Ibrahim Aderdour, a Moroccan, had a record of violence towards his English wife, Sophie. Her sister, Nicky Duffy, said the case sent a clear message to victims of domestic violence: "Leave, leave now."

Aderdour, 42, fled the country after the attack, and his image was the first to be placed on Scotland Yard's "wanted men" website. He twice tried to come back to Britain. On the first occasion he was found by sniffer dogs in a ship container at Dartford, Kent. Immigration officials failed to recognise him, and he was deported. He was arrested in Holland when he tried again.

At the Old Bailey in London yesterday Aderdour was found guilty of stabbing to death his daughter Amina, Sophie, 31, and her parents John Trant, 71, and Vivien Trant, 57.

"You have committed the gravest possible crimes," the recorder of London, Judge Michael Hyam, told Aderdour yesterday. He agreed with a psychiatrist's report that Aderdour had a tremendous potential to take revenge. He had shown no remorse.

"These were a terrible series of killings all done in the house of the parents of your wife who had welcomed you into their family and against whom you had no justification for holding any grudge."

Mrs Aderdour's sisters, Elena Trant-John, 32, and Nicky Duffy, 34, wept in the public gallery.

Although the court heard that Aderdour had been angered by his wife's refusal to have their daughter raised as a Muslim, Mrs Duffy said later that she did not believe that was the principal motive for the murders: "It was more about control than religion."

After trying to restrain Aderdour with court orders, she took refuge in her parents' home in Islington, north London, but he pursued her there. He made threatening phone calls, and was seen with a knife, but Mrs Aderdour was prepared to make another attempt at a reconciliation, and the couple travelled to Morocco in September 1995.

Six days after her return, she was dead. The family's bodies were discovered at the house in October that year after screaming was heard on a 999 call to police. Shortly after the call was made, Aderdour took a taxi to Waterloo station and fled to France by train.

"The truth is that Sophie had had enough. She was going to leave him - and he was not going to let her get away with it."

In court Aderdour claimed he was not religious and said he knew of the deaths only after leaving the country. "Since then, I have tried to kill myself."

fields.headline: Libraries set to ban 'smelly' readers
fields.trailText: The unwashed are getting their marching orders from libraries in south Lanarkshire: the smelly, dirty, or diseased may be liable to fines, banning orders, or even criminal prosecution if they set foot in any of the council's 25 libraries.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The unwashed are getting their marching orders from libraries in south Lanarkshire: the smelly, dirty, or diseased may be liable to fines, banning orders, or even criminal prosecution if they set foot in any of the council's 25 libraries.

There is likely to be more public sympathy for allowing librarians to eject anyone with a persistently ringing mobile phone, but eyebrows shot up at the Library Association when it heard that South Lanarkshire council is also attempting to rule: "Any person who knows he/she is suffering from any infectious or contagious disease must not enter the library," nor may "any person who is unreasonably dirty, which includes, but is not restricted to, odour."

At the council headquarters in Hamilton a spokeswoman insisted that the rules were not a response to a sudden invasion of their public libraries by hordes of reeking and filthy readers.

"There's no particular reason for introducing them now, it's just standardising the council's rules for all our public spaces," she said.

At the Library Association, staff could see the council's point. "It sounds drastic, but the rules are really quite sensible - and not that far out of line with what most councils have for their public places," said Sherry Jesperson, director of communications.

"It's commendable of South Lanarkshire to be updating them to include things which really are a nuisance, like mobile phones, and it gives the librarians guidance on where the line should be drawn."

At the British Library, there was astonishment at the draconian sweep of the proposal . "That would probably mean most of our staff gone for a start," a spokesman said. The restrictions also jarred with the government's emphasis on social inclusion. "Public libraries were founded to give poor people access to books," he added.

South Lanarkshire councillors passed the rules in draft yesterday, and they are now up for public consultation before going back to a full council meeting next month.

fields.headline: No 10 challenged over science lab
fields.trailText: The French government last night challenged Downing Street's account of the wrangling that led ministers to base a £500m science project in Oxfordshire rather than at a leading laboratory in the north-west.
fields.body:
The French government last night challenged Downing Street's account of the wrangling that led ministers to base a £500m science project in Oxfordshire rather than at a leading laboratory in the north-west.

As Labour MPs stepped up their attacks on the government for abandoning the north, a diplomat at the French embassy in London dismissed Downing Street claims that Paris would have withdrawn its support if the project had been based in the north-west.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, tried to fend off Labour critics on Monday by insisting that the government had been forced to base the synchrotron project in Oxfordshire because of pressure from the French government. Paris is financing the project, along with the Wellcome Trust and the British government.

Pointing out that Paris and the Wellcome Trust were pushing for the south-east, Mr Campbell said: "There was a risk of losing the project had we not gone along with this."

Less than 24 hours later, the scientific counsellor at the French embassy in London, Michel Bernier, said his government had argued "unofficially" in favour of the Rutherford Appleton laboratory in Didcot because the "critical mass" of scientists in Britain were based in the south-east.

But asked whether the French government would have minded whether the contract had been awarded to the Daresbury laboratory in Cheshire, Mr Bernier told Radio 4's The World at One: "No, it would not have been an issue at all."

His remarks were last night seized on by a Labour member of the Commons select committee on science and technology. Ian Gibson, MP for Norwich North, said he believed that the Cheshire laboratory could still win the project. "I do not think it is all over because I believe that the French government may have something to say about it."

He added that scientists overwhelmingly favoured Daresbury over the Oxfordshire laboratory.

MPs on the committee yesterday wrote to the government expressing their unease at the decision.

The French embassy's intervention will embarrass the prime minister and the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers. In private meetings with Labour backbenchers from the north-west they indicated that they favoured the project being based in Cheshire but insisted that their hands were being forced by French and the Wellcome Trust.

fields.headline: Adams attacked over arms delay
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Ulster Unionists yesterday heavily criticised Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, after he ruled out any paramilitary decommissioning before May 22, the deadline in the Good Friday agreement for the completion of the disposal of all weapons.
fields.body:
Ulster Unionists yesterday heavily criticised Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, after he ruled out any paramilitary decommissioning before May 22, the deadline in the Good Friday agreement for the completion of the disposal of all weapons.

They insisted the deadline had to remain, believing there was still time for progress on decommissioning within the next two months. They said Mr Adams, who has accused the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble of acting unilaterally on decommissioning, was guilty of acting outside the 22-month-old agreement.

Mr Adams said: "It appears to me very very obvious that the May 22 deadline no longer exists."

He blamed those who made the rights of voters conditional on armed groups decommissioning, saying some had adopted it deliberately to delay implementation of the agreement.

The Ulster Unionist Michael McGimpsey, the arts minister before suspension of the power-sharing executive, said: "The agreement just doesn't belong to Gerry Adams and Sinn Fein. May 22 is the one fixed date in the agreement. If he is not working to that date, then he is walking away from the agreement."

Seamus Close, deputy leader of the Alliance party, accused Mr Adams of playing games, and of "gerry-picking" the agreement.

Angry debate raged over demilitarisation after Brian Cowen, The Irish foreign minister, again called for troop withdrawals in nationalist areas such as south Armagh. He believed that tearing down army installations would force dissident republicans to think again.

Ulster Unionists are increasingly irate at the comments of Bertie Ahern, the taoiseach, and his new foreign minister.

Meanwhile, Northern Ireland's politicians are departing en masse to Washington for St Patrick's Day, including, for the first time, the Democratic Unionist party. They insist they are going to work hard at White House meetings to breathe new life into the agreement.

webTitle: Guardian fights to keep Shayler letter

fields.headline: Guardian fights to keep Shayler letter
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: The Guardian yesterday challenged an order made in relation to an official secrets act investigation demanding it hand over a letter from the former MI5 agent David Shayler.
fields.body:
The Guardian yesterday challenged an order made in relation to an official secrets act investigation demanding it hand over a letter from the former MI5 agent David Shayler.

On the first day of a hearing at the Old Bailey lawyers for special branch argued that the full text of the letter, published in the Guardian last month under the headline, MI6 and Gadafy, might contain evidence that could be used by officers investigating whether Mr Shayler had broken the act.

He has made a number of claims in the national press that MI6 was behind a failed attempt to assassinate the Libyan leader Colonel Gadafy.

Lawyers for The Guardian said it was a "matter of principle" that the newspaper should fight the case. "Save in most exceptional circumstances they should not be the subject of compulsive orders from investigating authorities because such orders constitute an interference with freedom of expression," Michael Tugendhat QC, representing the newspaper, told the court.

It was very unlikely that the newspaper had retained the original copy of the email, the QC argued, and even if it had it was not likely to be of substantial value to any investigation.

Detective Sergeant John Flynn, from the financial investigation unit of special branch at Scotland Yard, said the full letter might reveal offences by Mr Shayler as well as his email address, possibly opening up further lines of inquiry.

The judge said, because the police had not challenged evidence submitted by the Guardian that the unpublished parts of the letter contained nothing of importance, he accepted "that the content of the letter that was excised was not remotely relevant to any possible infringement of the official secrets act."

The hearing continues today.

webTitle: Inside story of a Campbell briefing

fields.headline: Inside story of a Campbell briefing
fields.standfirst:
As No 10's man comes out of shadows the Guardian publishes a detailed transcript of yesterday's lobby meeting

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: For years it has been one of the worst-kept secrets in British politics. At 11 o'clock every weekday morning when parliament is sitting, the Downing Street spokesman, Alastair Campbell, briefs lobby correspondents on the day's agenda and fields their questions.
fields.body:
For years it has been one of the worst-kept secrets in British politics. At 11 o'clock every weekday morning when parliament is sitting, the Downing Street spokesman, Alastair Campbell, briefs lobby correspondents on the day's agenda and fields their questions.

Since the 1997 general election these exchanges have been formally on the record, quotable and attributed to "the official Downing Street spokesman". But not until today have Mr Campbell's words been attributable to him by name - though it is a household name to millions of politically minded people.

Faced with complaints this week that he is allowing Michael Cockerell, a BBC documentary-maker to film some of his daily briefings, Mr Campbell conceded that his declared desire for anonymity is getting harder to sustain.

"I don't think this adds up to a row of beans. I speak as the prime minister's spokesman. We are a parliamentary democracy and the government is accountable to parliament," he said.

Some MPs worry that Mr Campbell himself is not accountable enough. He says he is simply the conveyor of Mr Blair's words and intentions - which are often misrepresented by cynical, sensational or malign media.

Nowadays Mr Campbell briefs in the basement of 10 Downing Street where 20 to 30 correspondents sit in rows of stackable chairs.

Sir Bernard Ingham's customers perched on the arm of sofa in the press secretary's room in Lady Thatcher's day. So did those briefed by John Major's gentler spokesmen, Gus O'Donnell, Chris Meyer, now ambassador to Washington, and Jonathan Haslem, a career civil servant.

Every afternoon they would repeat the performance in a room at the top of a Gothic turret high above the Thames in the Palace of Westminster. The day's agenda would have moved on by then. Instead of evening paper reporters and the TV/radio crowd, the morning papers would be more vocal.

But times change. Academics, then columnists and leader writers deplored the secrecy of it all. The refurbished No 10 basement was part of the shake-up when 42-year-old Mr Campbell, combative former political editor of the Daily Mirror, moved into No 10 with Tony Blair in May 1997. He put his briefings on the record but kept them anonymous, to help lower his personal profile, al ready high enough for many Labour MPs and ministers.

Mr Campbell also got himself a hybrid contract - part civil servant, part political adviser - which allowed him to mix it with journalists on party politics in a way which his many predecessors had been constrained from doing.

He thus treads a fine line and critics, who include the pugnacious Sir Bernard, say he frequently steps over it.

They also say he has "politicised" the entire government information system through the pernicious use of "spin" - an aggressive pro-government gloss on the day's facts.

Yesterday's exchanges at 4 o'clock were pretty routine as Mr Campbell set out Mr Blair's day. Spokesman and reporters toss around ideas, claims and counter-claims as they always do. Few will find their way into print as stories this morning. Readers can compare his words with the summary now published daily on the Downing Street website. Critics of his deft skills will find the ammunition they want, while government loyalists will wonder at Mr Campbell's patience. He often wonders himself.

Extracts from yesterday's lobby meeting

Chairman (John Sergeant, ITN): Okey-dokey, Alastair's here.

Alastair Campbell: [Tony Blair's day] A business breakfast; schools seminar reception awards ceremony for most improved schools; the Genome project (Blair-Clinton statement) on which, I have to tell you, the depth of my knowledge has not developed during the course of the day; appointment at 5 o'clock of Scottish judges to the privy council to religious appointments.

[AC then outlines the day's key written parliamentary answers to MPs' questions] Question 1: changes made to measures against FRY (Yugoslavia), question 2 on plans to call out members of the reserve to support the UN in Sierra Leone in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Charles Clarke launching the missing children website, John Denham speech to the NHS alliance and the royal society of GPs, Geoff Hoon speech on Kosovo, and Robin and Geoff Hoon both meeting the UN secretary general.

Chairman: Ok, questions?

Q: How do you approach the issue of televised debates? (a report that William Hague and Charles Kennedy want TV debates with Mr Blair before the election).

AC: Oh, I don't know. The story in the Independent that I saw was quoting Downing Street sources saying that they were shocked that the Tories were leaking details of our negotiations. Well, we weren't aware that there were any. I think there was some event last week organised by David Butler at which there were people from the parties including Tim Collins (Tory MP), I believe. But we get letters from broadcasters the whole time saying we'd like to organise this, that and the other. But I'm not aware of any negotiations going on at all. Certainly not involving No 10.

Q: Isn't there an argument for having discussions early, though, so that you don't do it in the heat of the ...

AC: There may well be, yeah, there may well be, but we're not - I'm not aware of those discussions going on.

Q: But you're not ruling it out as a possibility? You're not saying the prime minister would not want to take part in a debate of that sort as part of an election campaign?

AC: I'm saying that the, that there's no such discussions going on at the moment, although I know the broadcasters are obviously constantly trying to sound out the various parties. But it's something that we're not currently addressing and the point about - you remember the last time - a week's worth of - where it was the dominant issue. So I agree that if it's to be sorted, better sorted in the way that you describe. But I think that stuff today in the Independent looks to me like a bit of game playing by one of the parties.

Q: Frank Dobson's challenge to the others ?

AC: No - the mayoral candidates are having lots of these televised debates - it doesn't impact upon it at all - it's obvious that television is a very important medium in any election.

Q: Is the prime minister going to turn out and support Dobbo ?

AC: It's exactly the same as it was when anybody asked about it. The answer is yes, but we don't know, haven't go the dates.

[AC then changes the subject to provide answers on tax levels which a reporter has asked for]

AC: George (Jones, Daily Telegraph), can I just say- if I haven't mislaid it - the tax burden, 97-98, 36.5% ...

Q: That's as a percentage of GDP, is it?

AC: Yes - it's the tax take as in the pre-budget report (PBR), or the budget red book. 97-98 35.6%; 98-99 37.4%; 99-00 37%; 00-01 36.8%; 01-02 37.2.% Projections under the Conservatives - if you've got them all lined up in order - it goes 36.0%; 36.4%; 36.9%; 37.4%; 37.8%. So that tax burden, assuming we continue on our course, will be lower, lower than under their projections.

Q: But under your figures 36.5%, 37%, 36.8% are higher than when you came in.

AC: Yeah - but also can I say in relation to the Tory figures don't forget that the Tory figure (in 1997) as inherited, included a £28bn borrowing requirement - which is fundamentally sorted. Please don't ask me a complicated question about taxes.

Q: No, I don't understand what you're saying --what are these figures?

AC: Those are the figures as set out in their last the PBR - either budget or, whatever, red book, the projections, Tory projections had they been - yeah - I dunno - whenever.

Q: The last budget.

AC: 96-7 yeh .

Q: You've set out the facts, do you think it's a good thing?

AC: Set out facts - I always think it's a good thing to set out facts.

Q: I'm sure you do.The facts that you set out - do you think that this trend is a good thing?

AC: Well, which trend are you referring to?

Q: That fact that its a rising trend ...

AC: Well - the important thing as we've always said in relation to the economy, and our approach to the economy on coming into office, was to sort out the public finances and deal with the £28bn borrowing requirement and to build stability, get more jobs into the economy - which we're, have done, and are continuing to do, to sort out - reform welfare, er, in the way we have done. So the -as I said this morning - the tax and spend argument is one that we've, we took on first within the party in opposition and now in government. The important thing is that you're running the economy properly, a genuine enterprising, competitive market economy. But also you are getting investment, proper investment, into public services alongside the modernisation that we're doing. So I mean, that's the approach we are taking. Now, if your question is about the morality, then I simply point out that his, their projections were for higher tax burden in the two years, this year and next year.

Q: It's just that when treasury ministers have been asked this question, and the prime minister, the answer tends to start from the middle years. So that what you seem to be suggesting now is that there is a virtue in what the government is doing ... the tax burden ... the trend is going up from the year that you came into office.

AC: Well, this year and the two years that we're in, it's falling, and then the projection's is for it to go up - but that's never been hidden. The figures are there for all to see. But what I think we are trying to do is to get over the fact that the outlook, the political argument, if you like, about the economy is not just about tax and spend. It is about the economy that you've got, it is about jobs, it is about welfare, it is about education and skills and that whole agenda and therefore that's why in our view the whole, the tax guarantee argument is flawed because you're saying that regardless of the state of the economy you're going to be cutting taxes, regardless of the state of the public finances you're going to be cutting taxes, and our argument is that in government you are constantly making - to coin a phrase - tough choices to meet all your objectives.

Q: But we are right in saying, are we not, that generally when asked, the government tends to say the tax burden has not risen since 1997, although Hague says tonight it has by 2.5 %. The treasury routinely says it has not increased taxes.

AC: The treasury do what I've just done, which is to give you the figures. But they're available. In the spirit of openness for which I'm rightly famed, I am merely giving you the facts so that you and, through you your public, can make a judgment. But you know, those figures are readily available. But this year and next year they're falling, but I do think it's important to get over this point that the figures that William Hague, well I haven't seen his speech, but if he's going back to when they were in power, it is important to bear in mind the £28bn borrowing deficit, borrowing requirement. I mean that is the reason . It's tax deferred

Q: Alastair, I remember a long session in the Commonwealth Writing Room ( another briefing room) when you weren't prepared to say yes to the question you said yes to to George today about whether the tax burden has gone up in the years since you came into power. Isn't it fairly obvious to us that you now think the virtues of saying yes is to cheer up the heartlands of voters?

AC: Look, you've got the figures there, you've got the figures there.

Q: But why have you changed the strategy?

AC: I haven't changed the strategy at all. What I won't do is play their game. Or your game. Look, you've got it, this is your little heartland.

Q: Save your heartlands game, we're trying to be helpful about it.

AC: But it's not my game, Michael (White). It's not my game. As I said yesterday, look, this is your little prism that you've got for now, right. In a couple of weeks it'll be something else. It'll be, I don't know, coastal lands or something. It could be, you know, because of the BBC roadshow. I'd take that as given, including the Times there. So it's about, if you say to me, if George says to me, its 37.0% higher or lower than 37.4%, I mean, there's not much I can do to say that's it lower. Likewise its 37.2% higher than 36.8%, it's higher.

Q: But I seem to remember that at that Commonwealth Writing Room incident you said I'll answer the question how I see fit.

AC: But that's what I've done.

Q: But you're answering it today. I just wondered why the change of strategy.

AC: It's not a change of strategy. I mean I know you sort of, I know you, oh anyway- just write what you want ..

Chair: Right, next.

Q: Does the prime minister accept William Hague's basic point, which is in saying it's morally right to tax people less, or to tax people as little as you can. People have their own money to choose how they're spending it rather than giving it to the state?

AC: Well, look, you know, as I say it's for him to describe it in whatever way he wants. Government have obligations. And that's what we're doing. And you know he's making a speech and he wants to get the coverage for the speech and it's entirely up to him how he decides to do that. I mean, I'm not going to complain about that. But, you know, I'm not a philosopher, I'm a spokesperson.

fields.bodyText: For years it has been one of the worst-kept secrets in British politics. At 11 o'clock every weekday morning when parliament is sitting, the Downing Street spokesman, Alastair Campbell, briefs lobby correspondents on the day's agenda and fields their questions. Since the 1997 general election these exchanges have been formally on the record, quotable and attributed to "the official Downing Street spokesman". But not until today have Mr Campbell's words been attributable to him by name - though it is a household name to millions of politically minded people. Faced with complaints this week that he is allowing Michael Cockerell, a BBC documentary-maker to film some of his daily briefings, Mr Campbell conceded that his declared desire for anonymity is getting harder to sustain. "I don't think this adds up to a row of beans. I speak as the prime minister's spokesman. We are a parliamentary democracy and the government is accountable to parliament," he said. Some MPs worry that Mr Campbell himself is not accountable enough. He says he is simply the conveyor of Mr Blair's words and intentions - which are often misrepresented by cynical, sensational or malign media. Nowadays Mr Campbell briefs in the basement of 10 Downing Street where 20 to 30 correspondents sit in rows of stackable chairs. Sir Bernard Ingham's customers perched on the arm of sofa in the press secretary's room in Lady Thatcher's day. So did those briefed by John Major's gentler spokesmen, Gus O'Donnell, Chris Meyer, now ambassador to Washington, and Jonathan Haslem, a career civil servant. Every afternoon they would repeat the performance in a room at the top of a Gothic turret high above the Thames in the Palace of Westminster. The day's agenda would have moved on by then. Instead of evening paper reporters and the TV/radio crowd, the morning papers would be more vocal. But times change. Academics, then columnists and leader writers deplored the secrecy of it all. The refurbished No 10 basement was part of the shake-up when 42-year-old Mr Campbell, combative former political editor of the Daily Mirror, moved into No 10 with Tony Blair in May 1997. He put his briefings on the record but kept them anonymous, to help lower his personal profile, al ready high enough for many Labour MPs and ministers. Mr Campbell also got himself a hybrid contract - part civil servant, part political adviser - which allowed him to mix it with journalists on party politics in a way which his many predecessors had been constrained from doing. He thus treads a fine line and critics, who include the pugnacious Sir Bernard, say he frequently steps over it. They also say he has "politicised" the entire government information system through the pernicious use of "spin" - an aggressive pro-government gloss on the day's facts. Yesterday's exchanges at 4 o'clock were pretty routine as Mr Campbell set out Mr Blair's day. Spokesman and reporters toss around ideas, claims and counter-claims as they always do. Few will find their way into print as stories this morning. Readers can compare his words with the summary now published daily on the Downing Street website. Critics of his deft skills will find the ammunition they want, while government loyalists will wonder at Mr Campbell's patience. He often wonders himself. fields.headline: Labour admits tax rises
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Downing Street last night finally admitted that taxes have gone up under Labour - in order to boost key public services in a booming economy.
fields.body:
Downing Street last night finally admitted that taxes have gone up under Labour - in order to boost key public services in a booming economy.

After two years in which Tony Blair and Gordon Brown have doggedly insisted "we are cutting taxes", Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, confirmed that they have gone up since Labour won power - and will dip before starting to rise again by election day.

Mr Campbell denied a subtle change in government tactics. But his admission had the effect of undercutting a major speech by William Hague last night. In it the Tory leader invoked the moral case for lower taxes - his much attacked "tax guarantee" - and said Labour will have to cut taxes by £15bn to restore the position on May 1 1997.

The independent Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) last night confirmed that £15bn is, if anything, an understatement.

Warning that every taxpayer is now paying £1,500 more - a rise of 2.5% in the total tax burden under Mr Brown's reign as chancellor - Mr Hague declared: "High taxes mean less freedom, less responsibility, less community, more dependency, a less elevated human condition."

In sharp contrast, Mr Campbell insisted that Labour had abandoned its old tax-and-spend approach in opposition. He went on to argue: "The important thing is that you're running the economy properly, a genuine enterprising competitive market economy. But, also, you are getting investment, proper investment, into public services alongside the modernisation that we're doing," he told reporters.

A week before Mr Brown's fourth budget, that amounted to a gamble on a crucial issue by inviting voters to consider what they want: Mr Hague's commitment to cut taxes - regardless of economic or social need - or what Labour regards as its own more balanced approach.

That means putting extra money into health, education and transport, as opinion polls confirm the electorate wants. Labour's disgruntled "heartland" voters may even be cheered by an open admission which may offend the Middle England Tory tabloids.

Downing St even dusted off figures buried in last autumn's treasury pre-budget report to confirm its new public spending virtue.

In the first year of the Labour government, 1997-98, net taxes and social security contributions took 36.5% of gross domestic product after Mr Brown's first July budget; in 1998-99 it was 37.4%; 1999-2000 (this year), 37%; next year 36.8%; rising again to 37.2% in 2001-02, the likely year of the election.

Downing St also argued that projections inherited from the Tories would have meant that by 2001-02 a Hague or Major government would have been taxing 37.8% - more than Mr Blair will on present trends.

Opposition politicians and tax experts can challenge these figures. They do not include the last year of Tory power, 1996-97, when the tax take was 35.3%. That comes close to justifying Mr Hague's claim of a 2.5% rise since 1997.

Under EU accounting rules, in which Mr Brown's working families tax credit would also be counted as spending, not a tax credit, the contrast is even more marked, 39.6% in 2001-2002 compared with 37.6% in 1996-97, one IFS expert said.

webTitle: Random views: What builders watch on television

fields.headline: Random views: What builders watch on television
fields.trailText: Bernard Gee: "We've just got hooked up to the net in our house. My youngest was on at me for months because she said all her friends had it, so for the first time the TV goes off and the computer goes on. I love it, much quieter, hahah! I like looking at the history stuff and I find I'm learning with her. If I did switch on the telly I think it would be to watch motor racing or a bit of comedy. Goodness Gracious Me is back and I love that. The woman who can make everything herself, she never buys anything from the shop, that's my wife."
fields.body:
Bernard Gee: "We've just got hooked up to the net in our house. My youngest was on at me for months because she said all her friends had it, so for the first time the TV goes off and the computer goes on. I love it, much quieter, hahah! I like looking at the history stuff and I find I'm learning with her. If I did switch on the telly I think it would be to watch motor racing or a bit of comedy. Goodness Gracious Me is back and I love that. The woman who can make everything herself, she never buys anything from the shop, that's my wife."

Leonard Pugh: "I can't watch the telly without someone shouting or the kids arguing. I can never hear a thing. I try and hide the remote control so there isn't a full-scale war. My mother lives with us at the moment and she's worse, wants to watch all the soaps. We've got a TV in the bedroom so I sometimes sneak up there. Who do I like? Parkinson - Parky, he's still excellent. I end up watching This Is Your Life and more the old programmes, thinking, 'I never knew he had 45 children!' That sort of thing."

Keith Jacobs: "I don't get a lot of time to watch TV to be honest. I did have a phase of watching the cookery programmes and trying to improve my skills, honest! [Laughter from others.] I'm a very good cook. I did a bit of Delia, but she does simple stuff. I did like Two Fat Ladies, because they've got a no-nonsense approach, none of this poncey stuff, no bigger than a tuppence bit on a big plate. River Cafe, those Two Posh Ladies, that was crap. My best meal? Well, I can do a mean angel's hair pasta with crab."

Jay Imani: "I like Frasier, EastEnders, Friends, Gimme Gimme Gimme, sometimes a bit of Coronation Street, those Greece Uncovered programmes or whatever they are - the holiday ones where everyone goes mad, real life stuff. In fact, I'll watch anything on a Friday night, because that's pizza night. All my mates, some tins and Pizza Hut or Domino's - Pizza Hut has gone downhill though I must say."

Interviews by Sin Pattenden

fields.headline: The meaning of Viv
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Imagine having a musical made out of your life. Sure, we can all dream about walking down the street, people bursting into song and falling into line behind us, tap-dancing their way to Sainsbury's where the check-out girls have shed their uniforms to reveal spangly hotpant-bra combos.
fields.body:
Imagine having a musical made out of your life. Sure, we can all dream about walking down the street, people bursting into song and falling into line behind us, tap-dancing their way to Sainsbury's where the check-out girls have shed their uniforms to reveal spangly hotpant-bra combos. Certainly, we can fantasise about ballads sung about our lost loved ones and we can surely envisage the big finale when we quit our lousy jobs and have our colleagues follow suit (though not before dancing on their desks and high-kicking piles of paperwork around the office). But actually having your life turned into a show to be performed outside your own head is something else. For that, you have to be somebody - somebody like Viv Nicholson.

Trouble At The Top (BBC2) recounted the often fraught relationship between the legendary 1961 pools winner, who spent all £152,000 of her winnings in 10 years, and West End producer Andre Ptaszynski, whose plans to turn her story into a musical necessitated her cooperation, much to his chagrin.

Andre needed Viv to publicise the show but wasn't remotely interested in Viv herself. It would never have done if Eva Peron had turned up to Evita, he noted, almost enviously. Andre saw Viv as a loose cannon and, it seemed, a bit common. "Fantastic raw material", was how he put it. He schmoozed potential investors for the £1.5 million to get the show on as she sold Vosene and corn plasters in the chemist's and fretted about her life becoming a national spectacle (again).

Strangely though, in the list of Things To Worry About Should Your Life Be Turned Into A Musical, the amount of sex in the show was of more concern to Viv than being played by Barbara Dickson in a pair of Frank Butcher's old glasses. Me, I would have lobbied for Elaine Paige in contact lenses.

There surely wasn't this much sex in Cardale when Drs Kevin Whately and Amanda Burton ran the surgery. Peak Practice (ITV), the televisual equivalent of a 13-tog duvet, is a veritable hotbed of passion, with Dr Andrew forever at it with Lynsey Baxter, freshly escaped from Gormenghast. In cars, in hotels, they even did some slo-mo lurve-making on the carpet as the rest of the surgery team were doing a pub quiz (though the twosome weren't in the pub at the time). Dr Joanna meanwhile has been at it with a married man and the young Dr Floppy-Hair has stolen Kerry the Physio away from the trendy vicar with lupus. The only people who weren't getting any nooky were Klive and Marion, who ran a country and western-themed cafe, and that was only because too many Rennies had made Klive impotent.

Yet, even with all this going on, Peak Practice - now in its ninth series - still proved overwhelmingly comforting and safe. Despite their tendencies towards illicit shenanigans, who wouldn't entrust their lives to the Cardale doctors? As an anaesthetic for real life, it doesn't get any more effective than Peak Practice. You are feeling sleepy, very sleepy...

Dawson's Creek (C4) provided a bit of a caffeine jolt, despite its pastel, Abercrombie and Fitch mise en scène . Slutty Jen is now chief cheerleader (cheerleader leader perhaps), gay Jack has joined the football team, and Dawson almost lost his virginity to the evil twin from Sweet Valley High.

Since last week, Eve has had her eye on popping Dawson's cherry (and she doesn't look the jam-making type neither) and almost had her wicked way with him in front of the whole school, though why anyone would go ga-ga over Dawson "Longface" Leary is a mystery. Andie and Pacey's problems escalated with her mental illness chic extending to having sex with a fellow patient in the psychiatric facility. Sadly, Joey, the Bambi-eyed goddess of the show, has been reduced to sitting at the end of Dawson's pier and gazing enigmatically into the middle distance, in search of a story for herself perhaps?

fields.bodyText: Imagine having a musical made out of your life. Sure, we can all dream about walking down the street, people bursting into song and falling into line behind us, tap-dancing their way to Sainsbury's where the check-out girls have shed their uniforms to reveal spangly hotpant-bra combos. Certainly, we can fantasise about ballads sung about our lost loved ones and we can surely envisage the big finale when we quit our lousy jobs and have our colleagues follow suit (though not before dancing on their desks and high-kicking piles of paperwork around the office). Dr Joanna meanwhile has been at it with a married man and the young Dr Floppy-Hair has stolen Kerry the Physio away from the trendy vicar with lupus. fields.headline: What's your problem?
fields.standfirst: You may have thought you'd never see it on TV, but tonight's Hollyoaks tackles a soap first: male rape. Surely, says  Jacques Peretti  , popular drama's compulsive need to address spurious 'big issues' is getting out of control
fields.trailText: You may have thought you'd never see it on TV, but tonight's Hollyoaks tackles a soap first: male rape. Surely, says Jacques Peretti , popular drama's compulsive need to address spurious 'big issues' is getting out of control
fields.body:
If you or your family have ever been affected by the surfeit of telephone numbers given at the end of every TV programme, then ring now and your call will be treated confidentially. If you feel troubled by some of the issues raised by the glut of message television on your screens, then do not fear, you are not alone.

Message telly is spreading. Once the preserve of people shows like Kilroy, for which the pay-off for half an hour of cheap voyeurism was to tag a helpline over the end-credits, the idea is fast becoming an integral part of any terrestrial TV programme with human beings involved.

This is because problems are a growth market on TV, and the idea of what constitutes a "problem" has grown infinitely in complexity over the last couple of years. Shows like Ricki and Oprah, who - in their relentless drive for ever weirder stories ("My Boyfriend Was Hitler In A Past Life") have validated ludicrous items by inventing serious tags for them: "If you or your family have ever suffered from Hitler Past Life Disorder, call..."

The sheer turnover of people shows and soaps demands that a new issue is raised every couple of days. Traditionally, TV has travelled in the slipstream of public health awareness, diligently marking No Smoking Day with two minutes of worthy monologue, crow-barred painfully into an episode of EastEnders: "Dot, do you know that every time you smoke a fag, its like inhaling the exhaust of 12 double-decker buses?"

The dilemma with traditional problems is that there's no inherent drama in giving up smoking. Hence, TV has started championing causes that dovetail better into storylines, such as Steve's addiction to tranquilisers in EastEnders. Out on a limb, soaps have even invented their own quasi-medical conditions, such as Katie's post-traumatic-stress shopping on Brookside. The soap, which has a long history of successful workaday campaigns, including adult literacy and domestic violence under its belt, has been forced to go sexy with its problems.

At the middle-class end of the market, token annual mentions of flu jabs are avoided in favour of whole seasons of programming dedicated to a single (but invariably "complex") social issue around which we can have, in the words of Mrs Merton, "a heated debate".

Because audiences are unsurprisingly wise to the crude Dot Cotton tactics of the past, seasons of programming are an attempt to make message telly more faux-inclusive. The BBC's recent Kick The Habit season was a bold effort to spread message TV across both the schedule and audience divide. The season was criticised for the very reasons the BBC thought it might work: wide fluctuations in tone. Dale Winton cheesily stubbing out fags and Leah Betts on a life support machine do not really sit easily together in a trailer.

For all its criticisms, the season was a tacit acknowledgement that message TV is all-pervasive.

Programme areas once considered off-limits are now seen as ideal vehicles for spreading the word.

A few years ago, Channel 4 ran a gameshow in which homeless people could win a house. The programme, Move On, was deemed to have gone too far. But television's notoriously short memory means several new shows in development will once again push the envelope on taste. One will give the opportunity for disabled people to attack the disabled. It's called Freakout. A sort of Move On for the Noughties.

Tonight's Hollyoaks Male Rape Special (10.55pm, Channel 4) is in some ways the apotheosis of an old style of message TV.

Luke and Mark have been arguing in the locker room after the match. One thing leads to another, and soon, before they know it, C4 has got itself a soap-opera first.

The impulse to glamorise is simply too great for a scriptwriter to miss. Invariably, however, there comes a point at which the extremity of a situation renders it irrelevent to the vast majority of viewers. The Hollyoaks male rape looks, on paper, like a Chris Morris idea. But strangely, the incongruity of happy-clappy Hollyoaks as a vehicle for such a grim, cranked-up storyline makes the whole thing oddly credible.

Soap operas were created for the express purpose of crude social tinkering. The first, the BBC's Grove Family, which began in 1954, was the everyday tale of a lower-middle-class family working hard to build a home after the hardship of war. The BBC was inundated with letters asking for building estimates from Dad, and fielded bucketloads of complaints about Grandma, who's catchphrase was "I'm starved for want of nourishment". On a visit to the studios, the Queen Mother declared herself a fan, calling the family "so English, so real".

The staggering thing about TV soap operas is how little they've travelled in half a century. Hollyoaks, which has now embarked on a late night, X-rated version for adults, is The Grove Family updated. They might be listening to The Chemical Brothers instead of ITMA, but it's still every bit as sledge-hammer. Still so English, and so real.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The extraordinary capacity some people have to dodge the reality of their own behaviour has been brought home to Julia O'Connell Davidson, Laurie Taylor's guest in Thinking Allowed (4.0pm, Radio 4).
fields.body:
The extraordinary capacity some people have to dodge the reality of their own behaviour has been brought home to Julia O'Connell Davidson, Laurie Taylor's guest in Thinking Allowed (4.0pm, Radio 4). Having had long discussions with those who travel abroad to satisfy their paedophile appetites she found that many place their activities in the socially acceptable category of "holiday romances". They often view their exploitation of their young victims as just another leisure activity.

Jesse Gelsinger thought he would receive routine treatment for his liver problem when he went into a Pennsylvania hospital last September. However, he had a fatal reaction to the genetically modified virus used experimentally by his doctors. As Peter Evans reports in Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4), the incident has caused widespread alarm. A sense of crisis now pervades the world of gene therapy.

webTitle: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Every now and then, a father-son story comes along so touching it fairly makes your cockles glow. Sadly, however, all we can do is bring you the latest sorry chapter in the Richard Pryor story, wherein the erstwhile stand-up pioneer and latter-day MS victim takes out a restraining order against his own offspring, the imaginatively named Richard Pryor Jr.
fields.body:
Every now and then, a father-son story comes along so touching it fairly makes your cockles glow. Sadly, however, all we can do is bring you the latest sorry chapter in the Richard Pryor story, wherein the erstwhile stand-up pioneer and latter-day MS victim takes out a restraining order against his own offspring, the imaginatively named Richard Pryor Jr.

The litigation, filed in LA Superior Court late last week, comes in response to the younger Pryor's attempts to take control of his father's estate, claiming Dad is now unable to "shop, prepare his own meals or bathe himself". Perhaps unsurprisingly, said allegation failed to go over at all well with Pryor Sr, who promptly fired off an application for his son to be kept at arm's length from his property and business affairs until further notice. "Unfortunately," fumed Pop's attorney Lynda Larsen, "because of Richard Jr's unwelcome and aggressive efforts to seek audience with his father, it was necessary to prepare requests for restraining orders". You get the nasty feeling this one will run and run...

Meanwhile, it's been a busy few days for the Atlanta Police Department and local resident Da Brat , after a nightclub brawl and a drive-by in the space of a weekend. The first came on the premises of neighbourhood hotspot Chilli Peppers, where the ascendant female rapper (real name Shawntae Harris) wound up pistol-whipping one Rezue Robateue during an obscurely motivated ruckus. The second, two days later, took place outside Harris's apartment, with five of her friends being repeatedly fired on from a nearby Ford Thunderbird (fortunately, no one was injured ). The cops' enquiry into what they assume to be a revenge attack goes on; for her part, Da Brat faces aggravated battery charges early next month.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Mackintosh Man
fields.body:
The Mackintosh Man

(John Huston, 1973)

8pm, Sky Cinema

There's a great deal of cinematic talent on show here, although the film never amounts to the sum of its parts. A spy story in the John Buchan vein, written by action supremo Walter Hill, it stars Paul Newman as the agent employed to flush out crooked James Mason while a bunch of Brits chip in with cameos.

Mr Nice Guy

(Sammo Hung, 1997)

10pm, Sky MovieMax

If this sort of thing happened on Can't Cook Won't Cook, you could understand why cookery shows are so popular. Jackie Chan, kung-fu's answer to Buster Keaton, stars as a TV chef who finds himself being hounded by a gang of crooks after he gets hold of an incriminating tape of their activities. But, as usual with Chan's movies, the plot is as slim as with porn, and just as unimportant. What matters here are the stunts and the humour, and Mr Nice Guy pulls off both with Chan's customary reckless flair.

Gregory's Girl

(Bill Forsyth, 1981)

10pm, FilmFour

Forsyth's ever lovable teen romance about a young lad smitten by a soccer-playing new girl at his school. It's a beautifully crafted tale, poking tender fun at adolescent courtships. Performances are brilliant: Dee Hepburn the new and gorgeous striker; John Gordon Sinclair the lovestruck youth, stuck in goal; and the extraordinary 10-year-old Allison Foster as the little sister instructing him in the ways of the world.

Oscar And Lucinda

(Gillian Armstrong, 1997)

2.50am, Sky Premier

Richly textured adaptation of Peter Carey's Booker prize-winning novel, set in the 19th-century Australian outback. Ralph Fiennes and Cate Blanchett are superb as Oscar, rebellious son of a stern minister and Lucinda, fiery founder of a glass factory, thrown together by their love of gambling. The film charts their fragile, unlikely romance while taking in the genocide committed on the Aborigines; and it seeks a glorious resolution with the construction of a glass church in the outback.

webTitle: Morgan to open up Welsh cabinet minutes

fields.headline: Morgan to open up Welsh cabinet minutes
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Minutes of the Welsh assembly cabinet are to be put on the internet within six weeks of the meeting, in the most radical move to open up government in the United Kingdom since Labour came to power.
fields.body:
Minutes of the Welsh assembly cabinet are to be put on the internet within six weeks of the meeting, in the most radical move to open up government in the United Kingdom since Labour came to power.

The move by Rhodri Morgan, the first minister, will put fresh pressure on Jack Straw, the home secretary, to make new concessions when his freedom of information bill comes back to the House of Commons for further debate.

Tony Wright, Labour chairman of the Commons public administration committee, who is planning to table amendments to the bill, said last night: "It signals an important cultural change. It is exactly what I would expect from Rhodri who is a breath of fresh air over these issues."

Mr Morgan's decision, to be announced to the assembly today, opens up a huge gulf between the release of information in different parts of the UK. In England the home secretary is insisting that much government information will remain a state secret for 30 years.

Scotland will be more open, with a bill to go through their parliament to allow the publication of policy advice on Scotish affairs.

But Wales will now go a step further - with the publication of cabinet minutes and a pledge for all Welsh bodies, including quangos, to go for "maximum voluntary disclosure".

Mr Morgan said there was no need for legislation to implement the change. "Since Wales has no responsibility for foreign affairs, defence or security I see no problem in releasing information. We are not interested in standards laid down by Whitehall - we are looking for international standards laid down under the United States and Irish freedom of information acts."

Last night a home office spokeswoman said there was nothing in Mr Straw's bill that would prevent Mr Morgan from taking such action.

 Labour was plunged into further turmoil in Wales yesterday when the party on Cardiff council suspended eight councillors after they voted against huge increases in members' allowances. The Cardiff rebels had protested at rises which made Russell Goodway, leader and lord mayor of Cardiff council, the highest-paid councillor in Britain on £58,500 a year.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Bad day
fields.body:
Bad day

London travellers. In a written answer transport minister Keith Hill confirmed that the London escalator crisis will not be sorted out completely until the autumn. He said that after the defective escalators were repaired, a new programme to replace them would begin.

Defence of day

Foreign office minister Peter Hain came to the aid of the prime minister's special Middle East envoy Lord Levy, describing a Tory attack on his role as "grubby" and "pathetic". He pointed out that Lord Levy travels at his own expense and in his own time.

Good day

Dry stone walls. Environment minister Chris Mullin held out the hope of some statutory protection. He said the government was committed to preventing the further decline of these "unique and practical" walls. Labour MP for Sheffield Hillsborough, Helen Jackson, above, had earlier said they were crumbling at an alarming rate.

Today

Commons: Northern Ireland questions. Prime Minister's questions. Terrorism bill, remaining stages. Lords: Debates on education in developing countries, and on access to performing arts.
