fields.headline: Will Roberts
fields.standfirst: Will Roberts, who has died in Neath aged 92, was one of Wales's foremost painters. While always associated with south Wales, he was born in Ruabon, and his work drew deeply on his family's roots in the county of Denbighshire.
fields.trailText: Will Roberts, who has died in Neath aged 92, was one of Wales's foremost painters. While always associated with south Wales, he was born in Ruabon, and his work drew deeply on his family's roots in the county of Denbighshire.
fields.body:
Will Roberts, who has died in Neath aged 92, was one of Wales's foremost painters. While always associated with south Wales, he was born in Ruabon, and his work drew deeply on his family's roots in the county of Denbighshire. His prime interest was the human figure; his concern was to convey the rhythms and tensions of movement in a way that defined both the figures and the landscape in which they were set.

There was always a dark and rich resonance in his broadly expressionist style and - importantly in a Wales now re-examining its visual culture - his farmers and agricultural labourers, the old men in the reading room of Neath library and the steelworkers, all had about them an intrinsic truth.

While his gift for draughtsmanship was evident from an early age, Roberts attributed his capacity to convey the essence of a figure to his studies in the life-room at Swansea school of art, where he was a part-time student for four years from 1928. Given the need for a steady income to support his widowed mother, and later on his wife and daughter, Roberts felt that realistically he could not survive as a painter.

Yet neither teaching nor commercial art seemed an acceptable compromise. In retrospect, Roberts believed that it was working by day as a jeweller and watchmaker, and at every other waking moment as a painter, that allowed him to develop as an artist. He wanted to be free to live and breathe art; he would paint into the early hours and return to the shop next morning spiritually and physically refreshed.

People fascinated him. Customers examining a brooch or watch at the counter would be unaware that they were being quietly observed. Should a strong jawline or gently flowing movement demand to be put down on paper, Roberts would reach for his sketchbook as soon as the shopdoor closed behind them.

During the war, he served as a Royal Air Force technician, and it was typical of his lifelong enthusiasm and keenness of mind that he saw the art in machines. Delighting in precision work, the intricacies of dealing with RAF "kites", oxygen equipment or fine jewellery were one to him. Natural musicianship - he was an accomplished violinist - was also part of his makeup. Stationed in Warwickshire, he continued to draw and paint in watercolours; teaching at Nuneaton art school on days off was a lifeline.

After demobilisation he returned to Wales, determined to make the transition to painting in oils. He took up a friend's suggestion that he meet the Polish artist Josef Herman (Obituary, February 22, 2000), then living in Ystradgynlais. Talk of the French expressionist Georges Rouault bonded them, and a routine was established. Once a week, Roberts would go to Herman's studio, the ballroom of the Penybont Inn, sometimes working at a canvas as Herman urged him to "let the paint flow", sometimes talking and knocking up simple wooden frames for the paintings.

The two men cut very different figures - Roberts tall and fair, Herman short and dark - and they came from utterly different worlds. But the passion was mutual, and the relationship further fuelled Roberts's self-belief as an artist.

He always acknowledged Herman's importance in broadening his outlook, yet their association too often clouded perception of Roberts's very forceful and characteristic qualities. Sharing a name with London Group vorticist and Royal Academician William Roberts (even when it led to reports of his death being "greatly exaggerated") was never a difficulty; being bracketed with Herman was probably harder. Winning the Byng-Stamper prize in 1962 was a milestone for Roberts and, by 1969, solo exhibitions in London and Cardiff enhanced his growing reputation.

In retirement, the jewellery shop became a larger studio, and the compulsion to paint could be indulged fulltime - and, over the next 20 years, Roberts had the satisfaction of being recognised as one of Wales's most important painters. In 1994, a major retrospective exhibition, seen across Wales as well as at the national eisteddfod in his hometown, showed the full range and diversity of his art, with portraiture, landscapes, flower paintings and fine drawings.

The national library of Wales in Aberystywth holds a collection of some 600 of his drawings, their bold, sweeping lines eloquent testimony of his talent. In recent months, he was still painting, relishing the new challenge of gouache, while collaborating with the library and selecting drawings for a book and exhibition.

Roberts's dignified manner masked a sharp intelligence, warmth and sense of fun. Painting - like everything about him - came from the heart. He is survived by his wife, Phyllis, and his daughter.

fields.headline: Pee Wee King
fields.standfirst: Although his career in country music spanned almost four decades, the bandleader Pee Wee King, who has died aged 86, will always be remembered first for Tennessee Waltz.
fields.trailText: Although his career in country music spanned almost four decades, the bandleader Pee Wee King, who has died aged 86, will always be remembered first for Tennessee Waltz.
fields.body:
Although his career in country music spanned almost four decades, the bandleader Pee Wee King, who has died aged 86, will always be remembered first for Tennessee Waltz. This tale of a loved one lost to a waltzing betrayer, which King recorded in 1948, was a huge hit in the country-music market and topped the pop charts in a million-selling version by Patti Page.

King co-wrote the song with one of his bandsmen, Redd Stewart, a year or two earlier, when his Golden West Cowboys were broadcasting regularly on Nashville's country show, The Grand Ole Opry. Listening to the radio one night as they drove back from engagements in Texas, they heard a fellow Opry artist, Bill Monroe, singing his Kentucky Waltz. Stewart wondered why no one had ever written a Tennessee Waltz. (In fact, an obscure Opry band, the Gully Jumpers, had done so 20 years earlier, but the record was long forgotten.)

King and Stewart promptly dreamed up two quatrains that would fit their signature tune, the No Name Waltz, and wrote them on the back of a matchbook. By 1965, an unarguable country-music standard, Tennessee Waltz was declared by Governor Frank Clement to be the state's official song.

Ironically, King himself was no Tennessean. He was born into a Polish-American family in Wisconsin, where he began playing fiddle and accordion in public while in high school, and was soon appearing on local radio shows. In 1934, he moved to station WHAS in Louisville, Kentucky, where he began to expand his repertoire beyond square-dance music by listening to the then daringly progressive Georgia Wildcats, led by fiddler Clayton McMichen. In 1936, he renamed his band the Golden West Cowboys.

After stints on stations in Chicago and Knoxville, King settled at WSM in Nashville in 1937, joining the roster of the Grand Ole Opry and soon rivalling the popularity of stars like Roy Acuff. It has become part of Opry folklore that the Golden West Cowboys were the first band permitted to use drums on the show. Several of its members became well-known in their own right, such as the singer Eddy Arnold and singer/guitarist Lloyd "Cowboy" Copas.

During his Opry years, King also made appearances in western movies, first in the Gene Autry feature Goldmine In The Sky (1938) - Autry had been one of his earliest supporters - and later in vehicles for the popular western leads Charles Starrett and Johnny Mack Brown. During the war, he toured with the Camel Caravan, playing at military bases.

In 1947, he returned to Louisville to present his own show on station WAVE, first on radio, then on television. Through the first half of the 1950s, King and the Golden West Cowboys regularly won awards in the trade papers, while they scored further hits with Slow Poke (1952), Bimbo (1955) and Bonaparte's Retreat (1964). They also provided Jo Stafford with her huge 1952 hit, You Belong To Me.

After two decades of intense television and touring activity, King more or less retired from active performance in 1969, devoting himself to booking country acts for the county-fair circuit. He was elected to the Country Music Hall of Fame in 1974 and was a board member of the Country Music Foundation.

He is survived by his wife, Lydia, a daughter, three sons, six grandchildren; and eight great-grandchildren.

fields.headline: Barbara Kirkby-Mason
fields.standfirst: Generations of young people who studied piano music from the 1950s to the 1980s would have been familiar with the piano tutors written by Barbara Kirkby-Mason, who has died aged 89.
fields.trailText: Generations of young people who studied piano music from the 1950s to the 1980s would have been familiar with the piano tutors written by Barbara Kirkby-Mason, who has died aged 89.
fields.body:
Generations of young people who studied piano music from the 1950s to the 1980s would have been familiar with the piano tutors written by Barbara Kirkby-Mason, who has died aged 89. Her albums, which include a large number of her own compositions, provided a developmental course for children of all ages.

Such was the success of the Modern Piano Course for children that she was encouraged to write The Adult Beginner. The pieces selected were chosen to give the beginner keyboard freedom; they were original, and fun to play.

Kirkby-Mason studied at the Royal Academy of Music in the 1920s and won medals, in particular, the Stemdale Bennett prize for her playing of Mozart. Later, she studied under the great Bach pianist, Harold Samuel, and her earliest published compositions date from 1931. She gave a solo debut recital on BBC radio in 1934 and would have developed her career as a concert pianist had she not married in 1940 and started a family. Her husband, Kenneth Lambert, was at that time a clergyman, but later became an eminent analytical psychologist.

Although Kirkby-Mason continued to give recitals, they became secondary to her work as a composer, lec turer and adjudicator. Apart from educational compositions, she continued general composition to a concert standard. Her piece, Fantasy-Rondo For Guitar, received its premiere at London's Wigmore Hall in 1986. Between 1931 and 1983, she had more than 70 piano publications.

Her work as a lecturer involved tours of the United Kingdom in the 1950s and, later, extensive travel all over the world. However, her professional success was clouded by unhappiness when she was divorced in 1965 after 25 years of marriage.

The popularity of Kirkby-Mason's lectures and tutors were testament to her ability to communicate musical concepts stripped of academic jargon, combined with her sense of fun. Titles of her pieces such as The Hobby Horse, Catch Me If You Can, A Fairy Lullaby and Happy Song, from the earliest piano album, are typical examples.

She made few concessions to age, continuing to lecture and teach into her 80s. She later wrote a book on the theory of piano playing and performance and was looking for a publisher when, in December 1996, she had a severe stroke. She is survived by her two sons.

Barbara Kirkby-Mason, musician, born March 7 1910; died January 31 2000

fields.headline: David Watts
fields.standfirst: David Watts, who has died at the tragically early age of 45, was one of the key figures in the Guardian's transition from 15th-century printing technology to production by silicon chip.
fields.trailText: David Watts, who has died at the tragically early age of 45, was one of the key figures in the Guardian's transition from 15th-century printing technology to production by silicon chip.
fields.body:
David Watts, who has died at the tragically early age of 45, was one of the key figures in the Guardian's transition from 15th-century printing technology to production by silicon chip. He was also the only journalist ever recruited to the paper by a conclave of editorial executives hastily gathered in an American post office.

His letter of application caught our eye immediately it arrived from Perth, where he was working for the West Australian. That was less for its content than because it was composed on a £50,000 laser typesetter. This showed an unheard-of insouciance for those of us weaned in CP Scott's puritan tradition. It also dumbfounded us by transgressing the ferociously restrictive culture of Fleet Street's printing unions, who then allowed no one but their own members to handle type.

This was late in 1986, after Rupert Murdoch had precipitated the British national newspapers' rush into new technology. The Guardian had opted for an American system, then due for its final test at the manufacturers' plant in Massachusetts. David had supervised the West Australian's conversion to computers a few years earlier and, after several phone interviews across 15 time zones, was sent an air ticket to meet us in Boston.

When Ian Wright, the Guardian's then managing editor, and I (then chief systems editor) met him at Logan airport, he was totally glazed. If there is any process more tedious than proving a computer system I hope I don't find it, but a jet-lagged David buckled down the following morning and proved astoundingly effective.

It was his first encounter with the system but, within a couple of hours, he was handling it as if he'd known it all his life. After observing this remarkable performance, Hugh Nixon, the group systems executive, Ian Wright and I held our brief conference in the local post office and invited him to become my deputy.

From then on we were all enmeshed in transforming the production of the paper, with no visible sign to the readers of what was going on. Once we had installed the computers and begun training 200 journalists how to do their job differently, David showed impressive skill in the arcane art of writing the programmes that underlie every line of type.

Computers, as we rapidly learned, are idiots, which will happily slap editorial content over advertisements, leave great holes in a page, or unquestioningly perform any other idiocy that slack programming may invite them to do. Getting it right is not only a skill but an art, at which David proved a natural.

We had agreed that the trauma of the change was enough for most people on the paper to handle without imposing the extra burden of almost illiterate jargon. Whatever gobbledygook David and I were obliged to speak to one another, we tried to keep it within our four walls. He showed a nice touch in giving typesetting formats names that the hard-pressed users could remember. One that ranged columns of type along the bottom, for example, was crisply designated "bum".

No sooner had we completed the year-long transition than the Guardian embarked on a complete re design, and David was obliged to rewrite most of his programmes from top to bottom. Then came the introduction of a new system to lay out pages automatically, and yet more rewriting. By then I had moved on to other things, and he took over as chief systems editor, with its additional administrative chores. He barely faltered in his stride.

But his heart was still in Australia and, by the end of 1990, he and his family were ready to go home. He rejoined his old paper as foreign editor, occasionally popping up as an electronic guest on the Guardian's system, double-checking that Mrs Thatcher really had resigned or whatever. In 1992, he was promoted to night editor.

Then, at the end of 1993, he began to experience double vision and gradually developed other worrying symptoms. The initial diagnosis was multiple sclerosis, but closer investigation revealed that he had an inoperable tumour in his brain stem. Within a year, he was finding it difficult to walk or talk.

He later described what followed as a descent into hell. He was forced to wear a permanent patch over his right eye and was confined to a wheel chair. But his wife Christine (who had also worked for the Guardian), and a host of friends, gradually persuaded him out of his depression, convincing him that there was still much he could do with life.

After two years of such encouragement, he gradually resumed writing for the West Australian. Over the next four years, he produced nearly 1,000 articles on topics ranging from sports to computers, from the communications revolution to a regular comment column, cheerfully designated One-Eyed View.

In a moving account he wrote for the West Australian, which the Guardian reprinted, David told the story of how he used his personal computer to communicate with more than 700 fellow sufferers and medical experts across the world. The article brought a response from another 2,000 internet correspondents.

He also continued with conventional and alternative therapies, and reported in the middle of 1996 that "to my great surprise, there has been a minor shrinkage [in the tumour]. Doctors put it down to radiotherapy, New Age acquaintances to reiki, reflexology and meditation. I put it down to everything in combination, a harmony of life-giving forces".

Unfortunately, the tumour has now done its worst. The last sentence of David's article is his best epitaph: "Getting the most out of every situation - good and bad - is what it's all about".

He is survived by Christine and his two children, Alana and Rory.

webTitle: Starving Mongolia teeters on the edge

fields.headline: Starving Mongolia teeters on the edge
fields.standfirst: The winter has wiped out more than a million livestock, leaving isolated rural communities facing catastrophe
fields.trailText: Mongolia is on the verge of disaster with half a million people from herders' communities facing starvation after the worst winter in 30 years, senior UN officials are warning.
fields.body:
Mongolia is on the verge of disaster with half a million people from herders' communities facing starvation after the worst winter in 30 years, senior UN officials are warning.

Up to half the livestock in some areas have died so fast that their carcasses are piled up around the herders' felt-roofed tents, known as yurts.

"[The sheep] eat soil and stones in desperation," one herder told a UN official, "and my surviving cow has been nibbling my two horses' tails."

Milk products on which the herding families rely have almost disappeared as cattle die or stop lactating. Mothers are being forced to feed their babies on rice water.

Without horses to ride, pregnant women about to give birth have to walk miles to hospitals which lack essential equipment. Fuel for the few ambulances must be paid for.

An emergency report from the UN disaster management team (UNDMT) says: "For most people in the affected areas, their animals are the only sources of food, transport, heating materials and purchasing power, and the access to medical services and children's education."

"All the horses disappeared during the first heavy snowfall and no one has been able to find them," reports a UN technical adviser, Damien Wohlfahrt, from Dundgobi, where entire herds have been wiped out

"Pneumonia cases are reported to be increasing," says the report. "The influenza pandemic reached Mongolia in late January ... (and) has been spreading rapidly."

Schools have stayed shut because children cannot get to classes or because their families are trekking long distances in search of fresh pasture. Other children are left behind with a grandparent - as many as 12 in the charge of one elderly adult. Experts have long warned that the crisis was waiting to happen, in a country where post-communist economic reforms worsened the position of Mongolia's already numerous poor.

"The current food emergency follows several years in which nutritional standards have been falling ... as the economy has been reoriented from one which was centrally planned to one which is market driven," said the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) at the weekend.

"Those most affected by poverty and food insecurity include the unemployed, the elderly, female headed households, pensioners and small herders," it said.

Welfare and health schemes run by the state have collapsed, and teachers are forced to raise their herds to supplement meagre incomes.

The former collective herds were split up into private companies which were frequently monopolised by local leaders, leaving most people worse off. With no controls on competition, herds have been expanded and pastures over-grazed.

Up to a quarter of Mongolia's population of 2.7m people are at risk, said the FAO. Most Mongolian households have fewer than 100 animals, which places them on the brink of poverty and unable to cope with a sudden loss.

The US ambassador in Ulan Bator, Alphonse La Porta, warns that "the human suffering will grow exponentially and there will be significant numbers of people at risk into next winter."

Temperatures fell during the winter 5 to 10C below the average: the lowest recorded was -46C. A drought last summer had already reduced the over-stretched pasture lands.

By December 1.4m registered livestock were recorded dead out of 33.5m, while another 2.2m had been forced to migrate in search of food.

The livestock mortality rate will increase during the spring when snowfalls and dust-storms are common and the grass has not yet grown. The UNDMT says: "In their ill-fed condition, many female small animals and their young are expected to perish."

Mongolia in brief: Blue sky, tough lives

 The Mongolian People's Republic, declared on 26 November 1924, was the world's second communist country

 Three times the size of France, a third of it is covered by the Gobi desert. It has an average elevation of 1580m (about 5,300ft)

 Home to famed takhi horses which Genghis Khan used in his wars of conquest

 Has more than 260 sunny days a year, but long, harsh winters

 Most of the population is nomadic, living in yurts, large round felt-roofed tents. Main industries are copper, livestock, cashmere and wool

 There is an old Mongolian saying: "Breakfast for yourself; lunch, share with your friends; dinner, give to your enemies"

Facts from Lonely Planet
fields.bodyText: Mongolia is on the verge of disaster with half a million people from herders' communities facing starvation after the worst winter in 30 years, senior UN officials are warning. Up to half the livestock in some areas have died so fast that their carcasses are piled up around the herders' felt-roofed tents, known as yurts. "[The sheep] eat soil and stones in desperation," one herder told a UN official, "and my surviving cow has been nibbling my two horses' tails." Milk products on which the herding families rely have almost disappeared as cattle die or stop lactating. Mothers are being forced to feed their babies on rice water. Without horses to ride, pregnant women about to give birth have to walk miles to hospitals which lack essential equipment. Fuel for the few ambulances must be paid for. An emergency report from the UN disaster management team (UNDMT) says: "For most people in the affected areas, their animals are the only sources of food, transport, heating materials and purchasing power, and the access to medical services and children's education." "All the horses disappeared during the first heavy snowfall and no one has been able to find them," reports a UN technical adviser, Damien Wohlfahrt, from Dundgobi, where entire herds have been wiped out "Pneumonia cases are reported to be increasing," says the report. "The influenza pandemic reached Mongolia in late January ... (and) has been spreading rapidly." Schools have stayed shut because children cannot get to classes or because their families are trekking long distances in search of fresh pasture. Other children are left behind with a grandparent - as many as 12 in the charge of one elderly adult. Experts have long warned that the crisis was waiting to happen, in a country where post-communist economic reforms worsened the position of Mongolia's already numerous poor. "The current food emergency follows several years in which nutritional standards have been falling ... as the economy has been reoriented from one which was centrally planned to one which is market driven," said the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) at the weekend. "Those most affected by poverty and food insecurity include the unemployed, the elderly, female headed households, pensioners and small herders," it said. Welfare and health schemes run by the state have collapsed, and teachers are forced to raise their herds to supplement meagre incomes. The former collective herds were split up into private companies which were frequently monopolised by local leaders, leaving most people worse off. With no controls on competition, herds have been expanded and pastures over-grazed. Up to a quarter of Mongolia's population of 2.7m people are at risk, said the FAO. Most Mongolian households have fewer than 100 animals, which places them on the brink of poverty and unable to cope with a sudden loss. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Rwandan faces genocide trial
fields.body:
Rwandan faces genocide trial

A former Rwandan army captain will be extradited to the Tanzanian-based UN international criminal tribunal to face charges of crimes against humanity, the Danish justice ministry decided yesterday.

Innocent Sagahutu, 38, allegedly participated in genocide, mass rape and the 1994 killings of 10 Belgian UN soldiers. He has appealed against the ruling. AP, Copenhagen

Cult chief 'kept corpse in hotel'

A cult leader who kept a mummified corpse for months in a hotel room near Tokyo's airport was charged with murder yesterday, an official said.

Koji Takahashi, 61, the founder of Life Space, allegedly allowed 66-year-old Shinchi Kobayashi to die without medical treatment.

Cult members allegedly allowed Kobayashi to become dehydrated and an autopsy found that he died by choking on his own phlegm. Reuters, Tokyo

'War criminal' deported by US

An alleged former Nazi concentration camp guard accused of crimes against humanity arrived in Austria yesterday after being deported from the US.

Austria said it did not plan to prosecute Croatian-born Ferdinand Hammer, 78, as it had no proof of his alleged war crimes at the Auschwitz and Sachsenhausen death camps. Kate Connolly, Vienna

Mugabe given right to snoop

Zimbabwe's parliament yesterday passed a law allowing the president to order the interception of any telecommunications including telephone calls, emails and faxes.

The bill passed its third reading with only 10 MPs present. It only needs to be signed by President Robert Mugabe to become law. Andrew Meldrum, Harare

Lost scissors found in woman

A woman who has had a pair of surgical scissors lodged in her chest for 10 years should receive compensation, the Guyana Medical Association said yesterday.

Roman Soman, 43, did not know the scissors were there until she went to Georgetown hospital for treatment last week. X-rays revealed the instrument, apparently forgotten after an operation performed at the same hospital in 1990. AP, Georgetown

Rebels advance in Congo

Congolese rebels have continued a westward advance in breach of a ceasefire and captured the town of Idumbe in eastern Congo - posing a fresh threat to the Congolese capital Kinshasa, 430 miles west, the Zimbabwean military said yesterday.

Zimbabwe has 11,000 troops supporting the Congolese president, Laurent Kabila, against rebels backed by Rwanda and Uganda. AP, Harare

Clashes follow French snub

Mobs of youths injured two policemen, looted shops and set cars ablaze in Cayenne, the capital of French Guiana, police said yesterday.

Around 10 people were detained. The riots broke out after Jean-Jack Queyranne, a visiting French junior minister, refused to meet a delegation opposed to French policy in the territory. Reuters, Cayenne

Police kill vet as tiger roams city

A vet was shot dead by police yesterday while trying to tranquillise a circus tiger running loose in a Warsaw suburb.

Police had fired shots in the air to frighten the tiger and stop it attacking him, a prosecutor said. The vet was at first believed to have died from injuries inflicted by the beast. AP, Warsaw

webTitle: Ex-Marxists defeat right at polls in El Salvador

fields.headline: Ex-Marxists defeat right at polls in El Salvador
fields.trailText: Eight years after turning in their weapons at the end of a bloody civil war, El Salvador's former Marxist rebels have scored their biggest election success yet, displacing the rightwing ruling party as the largest congressional force, and nearly doubling their number of mayors.
fields.body:
Eight years after turning in their weapons at the end of a bloody civil war, El Salvador's former Marxist rebels have scored their biggest election success yet, displacing the rightwing ruling party as the largest congressional force, and nearly doubling their number of mayors.

This will be the first time in the country's turbulent history that the left has dominated the political institutions at local and national level.

"We are now the leading political force in this country," said Fabio Castillo, the general secretary of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front (FMLN), a coalition of former guerrillas' groups that fought a 12-year civil war against successive US-backed governments.

With some results still to come in from Sunday's legislative and municipal vote, the electoral tribunal confirmed yesterday that the FMLN won 31 of the 84 seats in congress, three more than the rightwing Alliance of Republican Nationalists (Arena).

The FMLN also secured control over town councils in eight of the 14 provincial capitals, including the capital, San Salvador, where the leftwing incumbent, Hector Silva, convincingly beat the Arena candidate to win a second three-year term of office.

Former guerrillas will now run the majority of councils in the most densely populated urban centres around San Salvador.

More than 75,000 people were killed before a UN brokered peace treaty paved the way for a negotiated settlement in January 1992, under which the rebels disarmed and became a political party in return for sweeping reforms.

In their first post-war venture into electoral politics, the former rebels were easily beaten by Arena in the 1994 general elections. But three years later, FMLN made important gains in legislative and municipal elections, winning 27 seats in congress and capturing the municipality of San Salvador, suggesting that voters had lost their distrust of the former guerrillas

However, when the former rebels looked like splitting over their choice of candidate in last year's presidential elections, Arena won easily.

Yesterday Arena's leaders were trying to put a brave face on their biggest electoral set-back in the party's 20 years of existence. Arena's president, Alfredo Cristiani, said: "The population was looking for somewhat of a balance ...we don't consider that we have lost".

A worsening economic scenario, caused by plummeting world prices for the country's main export crops, with soaring crime are also seen as having worked against Arena, in power since 1989.

Arena's traditional allies in the business sector have expressed disquiet about the FMLN's intention to challenge President Francisco Flores's neo-liberal economic policies. The left's campaigning platform included proposals to reduce value added tax, exert greater control over interest rates, and stimulate credit to small and medium-size enterprises. Some rebels want to reverse the government's privatisation programme.

Despite the gains of the former rebels, Mr Flores will still be able to count on the votes of smaller rightwing parties to block any changes to key legislation.

Professor Jack Spence of the University of Massachusetts, Boston, who who has followed political developments in El Salvador for almost 20 years, said: "There are two alternatives - there will be a stalemate in congress and a stalemate in the country. Or, all sides will realise that to move things forward you need compromise."

Observers reported that both the voting and counting went off smoothly, indicating greater political tolerance between the former warring sides. Turnout was predictably low.

webTitle: Oil firm fugitive found in Manila

fields.headline: Oil firm fugitive found in Manila
fields.trailText: A fugitive former Elf oil executive who investigators believe could hold the key to France's biggest post-war corruption scandal has been traced to a clinic in the Philippines, the French foreign ministry said yesterday.
fields.body:
A fugitive former Elf oil executive who investigators believe could hold the key to France's biggest post-war corruption scandal has been traced to a clinic in the Philippines, the French foreign ministry said yesterday.

A spokeswoman said Philippine judicial authorities had told their French counterparts that Elf's former general affairs manager Alfred Sirven, who has evaded three international arrest warrants since 1997, had been seen in a Manila hospital where he was undergoing treatment.

"We are treating this information very seriously indeed," the spokeswoman said. "The Philippine authorities have told our ambassador in Manila that they will do all they can to cooperate with our inquiries."

But she could not say whether Mr Sirven had been arrested or was even under surveillance.

From 1989 to 1993, Mr Sirven, now 72, was the right-hand-man of Loik Le Floch-Prigent, the president, now disgraced, of France's then state-owned oil company.

Investigators probing the £250m scandal allege that he acted as principal bagman for the missing millions, using Swiss bank accounts to pay leading figures, including politicians, from a secret Elf slush fund.

Investigating magistrates claim some £200m passed through Mr Sirven's hands. They allege he kept some of it, and paid the rest to a number of former Elf directors and other senior figures now embroiled in l'affaire Elf .

One of those alleged to have benefited is the former foreign minister Roland Dumas, who earlier this month resigned as as the country's top legal authority and will stand trial for abuse of funds later this year.

Mr Dumas is accused of persuading Elf to employ his former mistress, Christine Deviers-Joncour, and of profiting from the £6.6m allegedly channelled to her by Mr Sirven as "commissions" for lobbying her lover to approve the 1991 sale of six frigates to Taiwan by another state-controlled French firm, Thomson.

fields.headline: Greece arrests hundreds of immigrants
fields.standfirst: Fears that racism will dominate election campaign
fields.trailText: Hundreds of illegal immigrants were arrested entering Greece last night, reinforcing fears that racism would become the hottest issue of the country's campaign for parliamentary elections on April 9.
fields.body:
Hundreds of illegal immigrants were arrested entering Greece last night, reinforcing fears that racism would become the hottest issue of the country's campaign for parliamentary elections on April 9.

As parliament was dissolved yesterday in the run-up to the polls, police said they had detained more than 350 third world migrants who had been dumped on the island of Chios after paying Turkish smugglers to take them to the west.

With widespread support for the economic and foreign policies of the ruling Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok), fears are mounting that the campaign will be fought on a xenophobic ticket.

Civil rights groups, alarmed by police sweeps and the tabling of a tough new immigration bill, have voiced concern that politicians have begun to exploit prejudice over the presence of the 700,000, mostly illegal, immigrants who have settled in Greece.

"On an almost daily basis, politicians and commentators are making the sort of xenophobic speeches and remarks that would usually be attributed to leaders like [leader of Austria's Freedom party] Jörg Haider and [ French National Front leader] Jean-Marie Le Pen," said Panayiote Dimitras, of the human rights pressure group Helsinki Monitor.

"Since votes cannot be won on major political issues they are clearly trying to capitalise on the government's weakness around law and order and the perception that migrants are responsible for so many of this country's problems," he said.

Greeks blame impoverished migrants for soaring crime and unemployment. Polls have shown that 70% of the population support the "immediate repatriation" of immigrants. Albanians, who make up more than three-fifths of the influx into the EU's only Balkan state, are particularly vilified.

Since the announcement last month of the early election by the prime minister, Costas Simitis, hostility has intensified, immigrants say.

Fear among Albanians has spurred many to avoid public spaces and speaking Albanian outside their homes.

In recent weeks, police have stormed buses and subway exits in search of the "illegals" as part of a crackdown.

Since the collapse of communism, Greece has become a magnet for migration with immigrants viewing its coastline and mountainous terrain as the most accessible back door to Fortress Europe.

Many third world immigrants risk their lives to cross Greece's heavily-mined land border with Turkey.

However, Greece still lacks a comprehensive immigration policy. Attempts to legalise the migrants - by granting them residency and work permits - have all but failed following the refusal of Greek employers to pay social security costs.

The fear and loathing of Albanians has prompted villages in far-flung border areas to set up vigilante groups.

The main opposition leader, Costas Karamanlis, toured northern Greece last week, saying he would make the fight against foreigner-related crime "a top priority".

With their eye on a third consecutive term in office, the Socialists have promised to pass what civil rights campaigners regard as draconian immigration policies. The measures will be voted through in the summer if, as looks likely, Pasok is re-elected.

"This law will rescind the few rights that immigrants have won in Greece," said Costas Argaliotis at the Network of Social Support for Refugees and Migrants.

fields.headline: Gun lobby takes on Democrats
fields.standfirst:
Firearms law set to play key role in poll as White House and National Rifle Association go to war as issue of firearms control impacts on race for presidency

Gun violence in the US: special report
fields.trailText: The White House has attacked accusations by the National Rifle Association (NRA) that President Clinton is "willing to accept" America's high murder rate because it justifies further gun control legislation. The row got what is expected to be a particularly nasty election year battle over guns off to a ferocious start.
fields.body:
The White House has attacked accusations by the National Rifle Association (NRA) that President Clinton is "willing to accept" America's high murder rate because it justifies further gun control legislation. The row got what is expected to be a particularly nasty election year battle over guns off to a ferocious start.

The White House called the NRA's accusations "sad and shameful", but the association's vice-president, Wayne LaPierre, refused to withdraw the comments.

Meanwhile the gun lobby's president, the film star Charlton Heston, 75, appeared in an NRA advertisement denouncing the president as a liar.

The heated rhetoric was a clear sign that the NRA views the 2000 election as crucial to its future. A queue of gun control measures has been held up in congress for the past eight months, but they are likely to pass if Vice-president Al Gore becomes president, and the Democrats make significant electoral gains.

In an effort to stop them, the NRA is reputed to have amassed a $25m (£15.6m) fund to back pro-gun candidates and to fund its own parallel, overwhelmingly pro-Republican, campaign.

That campaign quickly went ballistic at the weekend when Mr LaPierre said of the president: "I've come to believe that he needs a certain level of violence in this country. He's willing to accept a certain level of killing to further his political agenda and his vice-president too."

The NRA also unveiled its latest television advertisement, with Heston accusing Mr Clinton of lying about the NRA's role in blocking gun control laws. "Mr Clinton, when what you say is wrong, it's a mistake. When you know it's wrong, that's a lie," Heston says.

The president accused Heston of running a "ruthlessly brutal" organisation, and rejected the NRA expressions of regret for a recent spate of school shootings, culminating earlier this month in the Michigan killing of a schoolgirl by her six-year-old classmate.

"These crocodile tears, I don't think it will wash with the voters, even with Moses reading the script," Mr Clinton said, in a reference to Heston's role in the film The Ten Commandments.

Heston, a former Democrat who has shifted to the right as he has grown older, is no stranger to political controversy. After issuing a famous call to arms to all "decent Americans" to battle "extremists" among the ranks of the country's feminists, homosexuals and blacks, he became NRA president in 1988 and portrayed his mission as a defence of the US constitution's second amendment on the right to bear arms.

After a visit to Britain last year, he expressed sympathy for his fellow enthusiasts facing a total ban on handguns after the Dunblane massacre. "My heart goes out to them," he said.

But, since 1995, NRA membership has dropped by about 20%. The former president George Bush and many other more moderate members walked out when an NRA fundraising letter described federal agents as "jackbooted government thugs".

But the NRA still has more clout than almost any other political lobby in Washington. It has an annual budget of $137m and a die-hard core of 175,000 activists prepared to lobby for pro-gun political candidates. So far this year, the NRA's political victory fund has distributed $420,979 to candidates for federal office (82% of them Republicans).

The gun control measures held up in congress include: a ban on the import of high-capacity ammunition clips; background checks on buyers at weekend gunshows; and childproof locks on all new guns.

In the firing line on streets of America

Constitution, second amendment
A well-regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed

Numbers killed in gun violence (1997) 32,436:
Suicides 17,566
Homicides 13,252
Accidents 981

Rate of death by firearms: 12.1 per 100,000 people

Number of new guns on the market each year: 3.5m

Number of children killed by gunfire each day: 12

Guns at home: A gun in the home is 43 times more likely to be used for suicide or murder than for self-defence

Funds allocated by NRA to current election campaign: $25m

In an effort to stop them, the NRA is reputed to have amassed a $25m (£15.6m) fund to back pro-gun candidates and to fund its own parallel, overwhelmingly pro-Republican, campaign. That campaign quickly went ballistic at the weekend when Mr LaPierre said of the president: "I've come to believe that he needs a certain level of violence in this country. He's willing to accept a certain level of killing to further his political agenda and his vice-president too." The NRA also unveiled its latest television advertisement, with Heston accusing Mr Clinton of lying about the NRA's role in blocking gun control laws. "Mr Clinton, when what you say is wrong, it's a mistake. When you know it's wrong, that's a lie," Heston says. The president accused Heston of running a "ruthlessly brutal" organisation, and rejected the NRA expressions of regret for a recent spate of school shootings, culminating earlier this month in the Michigan killing of a schoolgirl by her six-year-old classmate. "These crocodile tears, I don't think it will wash with the voters, even with Moses reading the script," Mr Clinton said, in a reference to Heston's role in the film The Ten Commandments. Heston, a former Democrat who has shifted to the right as he has grown older, is no stranger to political controversy. After issuing a famous call to arms to all "decent Americans" to battle "extremists" among the ranks of the country's feminists, homosexuals and blacks, he became NRA president in 1988 and portrayed his mission as a defence of the US constitution's second amendment on the right to bear arms. After a visit to Britain last year, he expressed sympathy for his fellow enthusiasts facing a total ban on handguns after the Dunblane massacre. "My heart goes out to them," he said. But, since 1995, NRA membership has dropped by about 20%. The former president George Bush and many other more moderate members walked out when an NRA fundraising letter described federal agents as "jackbooted government thugs". But the NRA still has more clout than almost any other political lobby in Washington. It has an annual budget of $137m and a die-hard core of 175,000 activists prepared to lobby for pro-gun political candidates. So far this year, the NRA's political victory fund has distributed $420,979 to candidates for federal office (82% of them Republicans). The gun control measures held up in congress include: a ban on the import of high-capacity ammunition clips; background checks on buyers at weekend gunshows; and childproof locks on all new guns. fields.headline: No: 1594 Rasputin
fields.trailText: Age: Long dead (probably).
fields.body:
Age: Long dead (probably).

Dates: 1869-1916.

Real name: Grigory Efemovich.

Appearance: Bass guitarist with ZZ Top.

Status: Monk.

Reputation: Mad.

Russian, wasn't he? Yes, a peasant from Siberia who became a chum of Alexandra, Tsar Nicholas II's wife.

How close were they? Extremely.

Tell me more: "I sacrifice my husband and my heart to you. Love and kisses - darling."

Monk-eying around then? It rather looks that way, if a new book by Edward Radzinsky is to be believed.

Called? Rasputin: The Last Word.

And is it? Probably not. Rasputin, like Hitler, is a publishing industry.

As evil? No, but certainly sex-crazed.

I thought he was religious. He thought spirituality was intimately connected to sexual exhaustion.

It certainly sounds more fun than Anglicanism: Sorry, I'm too tired even to think about that.

Pretty unpopular, wasn't he? His enemies loathed his influence and accused him of being pro-German.

Didn't he come to a sticky end? He was poisoned, shot, clubbed and thrown, almost certainly still alive, into the waters of the river Neva.

Cold-blooded murder? You bet. A newly discovered photo shows his frozen body after it was recovered.

Yusopov was the assassin, I seem to recall from O-level: You're showing your age. In any case, the revisionist Radzinsky reckons Yusopov (a transvestite) was in love with Rasputin and made sure the attempts to kill him backfired. Other plotters proved more determined.

Where did Radzinsky get all this new info? A lot of it came from a Soviet file in the possession of the internationally renowned cellist Mstislav Rostropovich.

Not to be confused with: Vladimir "Ras" Putin.

Do say: "Ra-ra-Rasputin, lover of the Russian queen . . . O those Russians!" (© Boney M)

Don't say: "Come on in, the water's lovely."

fields.trailText: We have been asked to point out that Torsten Friedag, despite the impression we gave in a report, Head of fresh start school quits, page 7, March 11, was never appointed the head of George Orwell school in Islington, north London. He was appointed head-designate of Islington Arts and Media school, from January 1999, at a time when John Crew was head of George Orwell school, a position he retained until the school closed on August 31 last year. The school, then relaunched as Islington Arts and Media school, was refurbished at a cost of £1.3m, not £8m.
fields.body:

He was appointed head-designate of Islington Arts and Media school, from January 1999, at a time when John Crew was head of George Orwell school, a position he retained until the school closed on August 31 last year. The school, then relaunched as Islington Arts and Media school, was refurbished at a cost of £1.3m, not £8m.

We were wrong to state, page 4, March 13, that Deborah Bull was among those who applied for the post of artistic director of the Royal Ballet. She did not apply. Sorry for any embarrassment caused.

It was incorrect to say, as we did on page 7, yesterday, that Mark Hedley, a supermarket manager diagnosed with HIV, had been "sacked". Mr Hedley's solicitor has emphasised the point we correctly made in our report, that Mr Hedley is on paid "gardening leave". That means he is still employed by Aldi but not allowed to return to work.

Richard Crossman became Dick Crossland in our interview with Lord Longford, page 4, G2, March 13; and Hugh Gaitskell became Gaitskill.

In our obituary of Laurence James (Gifted novelist of many names) we accidentally called him Harris towards the end of the piece. He was born in 1942, not 1943, making him 57, not 56.

The series of books written as James Axler was called Deathlands, not Darklands.

webTitle: BP Amoco snaps up Castrol and targets Arco

fields.headline: BP Amoco snaps up Castrol and targets Arco
fields.trailText: BP Amoco is close to striking a deal with the American authorities which would revive its $27bn (£17bn) bid for the American oil company, Atlantic Richfield (Arco).
fields.body:
BP Amoco is close to striking a deal with the American authorities which would revive its $27bn (£17bn) bid for the American oil company, Atlantic Richfield (Arco).

Sir John Browne, BP Amoco's chief executive, yesterday announced a £3bn agreed bid for the Burmah Castrol lubricants group. He said: "I hope there will be a time relatively soon to talk about Arco."

The Arco bid was blocked last month by the Federal Trade Commission, which was concerned that the deal would increase BP Amoco's influence on US west coast petrol prices.

The region obtains much of its crude oil from Alaska, where the combined group would have sizeable interests. In addition Arco has two west coast oil refineries.

BP Amoco is thought to be seeking to allay the FTC's concerns by putting forward plans to sell off Arco's Alaskan oil interests. Potential buyers include Phillips Petroleum, Royal Dutch-Shell, and Chevron.

Such a sale would be an about-turn for BP Amoco, which had previously indicated that Arco's Alaskan interests, including its stake in the jointly operated Prudhoe Bay field, were central to the deal.

Industry sources said yesterday that they believed BP Amoco was prepared to sacrifice the Alaskan interests in order to avoid time-consuming litigation. BP Amoco said that about 1,700 jobs worldwide would go as a result of the Burmah Castrol takeover.

The oil company is expecting annual cost savings of £260m by 2003, mainly by eliminating duplication and by reducing staff. However it expects the cost of implementing the merger to amount to about £390m. The driving force behind the bid has been BP Amoco's desire to acquire the Castrol brands.

The group lost its earlier lubricants partner, Mobil, when the European Commission insisted a joint venture would have to be ended to clear the way for last year's $82bn merger between Mobil and Exxon Corporation.

The group is offering £16.75 cash for every Burmah share - a 74% premium over the price on the last trading day before reports of the merger.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Boards agree bank merger
fields.body:
Boards agree bank merger

The supervisory boards of Deutsche and Dresdner banks yesterday approved the companies' merger as unions pledged to fight planned job cuts.

Both banks said they would prepare for shareholders' meetings in November which are expected to give a final go-ahead for the deal.

About 100 staff and union members protested outside Dresdner's head office on Tuesday against plans to shed 16,000 of the 140,000 jobs at the combined bank. Herbert Bayer, an official at the HBV banking and insurance trade union, said he feared lay-offs could exceed the planned total. Unions would push for measures such as part-time working and shorter working hours to reduce job losses.

Shares offer to Asda staff

Checkout assistants and supermarket managers working for Asda were offered yesterday the chance to buy discount shares in the world's biggest retailer, Wal-Mart.

Shares in Asda's US owner are offered at £24 less a 20% discount.

About 35,000 employees have joined Asda's Sharesave plan and 3,000 of them were a total £6.6m richer in October last year when they swapped their Asda share options for Wal-Mart options.

500 jobs go at Courtaulds

Textiles firm Courtaulds is to shed 500 jobs and close two factories, blaming a "rapid decline" in traditional markets.

Factories will close in Mansfield, with the loss of 219 jobs, and Nottingham (181), while 97 jobs will be cut at Worksop, Notts.

The Knitwear Footwear and Apparel Trades union claimed the job losses could have been avoided. General secretary Paul Gates called for urgent talks with Courtaulds.

Kerry's £1.25bn shopping list

Irish food ingredients business Kerry wants to spend up to £1.25bn on global expansion, managing director Denis Brosnan said yesterday.

Kerry, announced a 25% increase in profits, is keen to expand in Asia but there are no companies big enough to interest it, Mr Brosnan said. Instead he is targeting one of the 10 biggest ingredients groups worldwide.

webTitle: Slug & Lettuce makes a tempting morsel

fields.headline: Slug & Lettuce makes a tempting morsel
fields.standfirst: Shares in trendy pub chain soar as it confirms a takeover approach
fields.trailText: Shares in pub chain Slug and Lettuce soared nearly 25% yesterday when the company admitted it had received a takeover approach.
fields.body:
Shares in pub chain Slug and Lettuce soared nearly 25% yesterday when the company admitted it had received a takeover approach.

The group, which operates 33 bars aimed at metropolitan "twentysomethings" mainly in the south-east, has been the subject of bid speculation for some time.

In a statement the company confirmed it had received an approach which may lead to an offer being made but said: "Discussions with this party are at a very early stage."

The company, which was formerly known as Grosvenor Inns, but reinvented itself as a focused brand four years ago, has seen its share price slump from around 300p two years ago to a low of 133p in recent days. But yesterday they added 32p, or 24%, to 165.5p as the company confirmed the takeover approach. At 165p the chain would be valued at £24m.

The Slug & Lettuce chain is the brainchild of managing director Sheila McKenzie, who also founded the Pitcher & Piano concept for the brewers, Marston's, which was one of the main attractions of Marston's when it was acquired by rivals Wolverhampton & Dudley.

The Slug business is considered by many analysts to be too small to go it alone and a potentially valuable addition to a larger group.

However the company has recently installed a new chairman and finance director and a couple of new non-executive directors who are understood to be keen to retain the company's independence and are formulating new ideas for expansion.

Slug & Lettuce said a further announcement would be made in due course.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: Ring leaders
fields.body:
Ring leaders

Yesterday's round of the auction for five high speed UK mobile phone licences saw Vodafone's £541.4m bid for licence B unchallenged. NTL Mobile increased its bid for licence A to £325.4m from £295.1m. 3GUK offered £191m for licence C, Telefonica raised its bid for licence D to £178.2m and Canadian group TIW offered £186.4m for licence E.

New gardener

The company which owns the British Gardening website, Oxalis , has been bought for £225,000 by 365 Corporation , best known for its sports and light entertainment web sites. British Gardening is to be rebranded Gardening365.

webTitle: Britain to be sized up for Nafta entry

fields.headline: Britain to be sized up for Nafta entry
fields.trailText: A team of Washington officials is due to arrive in the UK today to size up the British economy for possible membership of the North American Free Trade Area.
fields.body:
A team of Washington officials is due to arrive in the UK today to size up the British economy for possible membership of the North American Free Trade Area.

Joining the multi-billion-dollar free trade zone which encompasses Canada, the US and Mexico would almost certainly require Britain to leave the European Union and the government has ruled it out as an option. Last month, Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, described the proposals as "far-fetched".

But the inquiry is proceeding at the request of the American senate, where influential members believe there may be advantages for the US if Britain, the world's fourth-largest economy, were to become part of Nafta.

The team, from the International Trade Commission, an independent federal agency, will meet officials from the cabinet office and the foreign office as well as the TUC and CBI.

Michael Fabricant, the Conservative MP who has tabled two private members bills on the costs and benefits of Nafta versus the EU, said it was a "tempting" alternative.

"I think our economic interests lie more with the United States than with the EU," he added.

Mr Fabricant said the government ought to set up a royal commission to investigate the costs and benefits of Nafta in parallel with the US investigation.

Members of the pro-European Britain in Europe lobby group said joining Nafta would be against Britain's interests. "Leaving the EU is the real agenda of those who propose joining Nafta," said Kitty Ussher, chief economist at Britain in Europe. "But to do that would be cutting our economic nose off to spite our political face. We do 53% of our trade with the EU and only 17% with Nafta."

The ITC will present its report to the US senate in the autumn. Although individual senate members, such as Phil Gramm of Texas, a leading member of the senate finance committee, back British membership, the proposal has failed to attract any enthusiasm from the White House and an invitation to join is not thought to be on the cards.

fields.headline: Warren Buffett
fields.trailText: Back in the mid-1990s when Warren Buffett, formerly the world's greatest investor, took a stake in Guinness (pre-Diageo) the excitement was quickly followed by gnashing of teeth when the shares proceeded to under-perform and the Sage of Omaha sold out.
fields.body:
Back in the mid-1990s when Warren Buffett, formerly the world's greatest investor, took a stake in Guinness (pre-Diageo) the excitement was quickly followed by gnashing of teeth when the shares proceeded to under-perform and the Sage of Omaha sold out.

That was the great man's first foray into the London market and such was his experience that he didn't return for over four years.

When Mr Buffett eventually did, in the spring of last year, he managed to rankle the regulators here by letting slip at an investment conference that he had identified a big British company which fitted his "value" criteria, but refused to name it.

An elongated race around the nation's share registers followed as investors tried to spot the target which, after some ill-judged punting on everything from Marks & Spencer to Unilever, eventually proved to be Allied Domecq.

No sooner had the target been identified, the price began to under perform - just like Guinness. Yesterday, however, we got news that instead of selling, he has been buying again - taking the Berkshire Hathaway stake to a formally declarable 3.15%. In short, the man is still interested.

This may just prove to be a case of Mr Buffett "averaging down," buying more shares as the price falls to reduce his average acquisition cost. But if he does have a longer-term interest in the drinks group then (US) history says he will keep building his stake from here.

Last year was Mr Buffett's worst ever in terms of performance. But as an antidote to e-stuff, his lead on Allied Domecq stock - up 7p at 257p yesterday against last year's high of 390p - is worth following.

fields.headline: Ireland's software exports beat US
fields.trailText: Ireland has overtaken the United States as the world's biggest exporter of computer software, according to the West's top economic think-tank.
fields.body:
Ireland has overtaken the United States as the world's biggest exporter of computer software, according to the West's top economic think-tank.

In a report published yesterday, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development said the Republic exported almost $3.3bn (£2bn) worth of products in 1998 compared to America's $2.9bn. In third place was Britain, with software exports worth $664m. The figures come from The Information Technology Outlook 2000, the latest in a series of OECD reports covering the main trends in the IT sector in member countries. It shows that they spend on average almost 7% of GDP on IT.

The growth of the software industry in Ireland is attributed to the country's success in attracting foreign investment, especially from the US.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: London shares made modest progress, with dealers variously distracted by Cheltenham or Lastminute.com. And but for the banking sector, where some heavyweight bargain hunters were in operation, the FTSE 100 might have slipped into negative territory. In the event the premier index closed 20.2 points higher at 6487.1.
fields.body:
London shares made modest progress, with dealers variously distracted by Cheltenham or Lastminute.com. And but for the banking sector, where some heavyweight bargain hunters were in operation, the FTSE 100 might have slipped into negative territory. In the event the premier index closed 20.2 points higher at 6487.1.

Amongst the banks, Royal Bank of Scotland stood out with a 26p gain to 796p, while Alliance & Leicester gained 15p to 539p and Lloyds TSB firmed from 546p to 562p.

But the real action was in Abbey National, which attracted a flurry of late speculative buying. The shares settled 32p better at 654p as traders gossiped about a bid from Barclays which is said to be on it way by the end of the week. Shares in Barclays, meanwhile, shed 10p to £14.75.

Elsewhere, BAE Systems, a poor performer of late, proved to be one of the Footsie high flyers in reaction to Monday's news of the government funding for the new Airbus airliner. The shares gained 20p to 303p, with several investment banks issuing "buy" notes.

In a mixed telecoms sector, Energis stood out with a gain of 210p to £39.67. The impetus came from Goldman Sachs, which reinitiated coverage of the stock with a "Europe Recommended List" rating and a £50 price target.

Goldman is said to like the company's prospects in Germany after the purchase of Carrier 24 and also reckons its internet business, Planet Online, is attractive. But Footsie newcomer Kingston Communications shed 23p to £12.70 after Goldman cut its rating to regular "market outperformer" rather than "Europe recommended".

Other prominent risers included BAT Industries , up 22p at 257p and mining group Billiton (up 18p at 246p) and Rio Tinto (58p stronger at 958p). These stocks were all said to be benefiting from cross-market "bottom fishing".

Correspondingly, some of the market's recent high performers were under pressure. Pearson, for example, fell 96p to £23.69 and Reuters lost 60p to £14.84.

Reckitt Benckiser, the old Reckitt & Colman, was off 9p at 456p ahead of full year figures tomorrow.

Oil majors weakened in line with the crude price, with Shell off 12p at 465p and BP Amoco down 12p at 536p. BP Amoco was also unsettled by worries that it is overpaying for Burmah, after launching its £3bn recommended offer for the lubricants group today.

Burmah continued to top the FTSE 250 leaderboard, up 300p to £15.45 against BP's £16.75 cash offer.

fields.headline: Trafficmaster gets left on bypass
fields.trailText: Having a whizzy, net-enabled, all singing all dancing strategy isn't enough to prevent your stock being hit by the bear market gripping most of the FTSE 250, even if you are a hi-tech outfit like Trafficmaster.
fields.body:
Having a whizzy, net-enabled, all singing all dancing strategy isn't enough to prevent your stock being hit by the bear market gripping most of the FTSE 250, even if you are a hi-tech outfit like Trafficmaster.

The traffic information firm disappointed the markets with a below-forecast set of results yesterday. Pre-tax profits were up 17% to £3.8m in the year to December 31 and earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation up 42% to £5.3m.

After an initial boost, profit-taking sent shares down 116p (10.4 %) to close at 996p.

But the company could be forgiven for feeling a little hard done by. All eyes were on Lastminute.com, whose shares, as predicted, soared in value, although not quite to the £1bn market value some had predicted. Unlike the new entrant, Trafficmaster has some old-fashioned virtues - like making profits.

It has also joined the rush by old-economy companies to announce dot.com spinoffs. Trafficmaster-online.com will offer an internet-based, personal in-car service. Drivers will receive a daily bulletin on their usual route, as well as special alerts about any problems. The company says car manufacturers will install "mobile internet" as a standard feature in cars over the next few years.

It might have been the news that Trafficmaster will not be declaring a dividend that sent the shares sliding. But the ongoing European push which was behind the decision to retain profits is likely to reap long-term rewards, according to finance director Bill McIntosh.

Extending the company's dominance of the traffic information market into Germany, Italy and France will have substantial start-up costs, cutting into earnings in 2000 and 2001 but, after a fund-raising placing in December, Trafficmaster has around £70m to invest in the strategy.

"The short-term impact of these deals is likely to increase costs but not necessarily revenue in the short term because it is all about getting capabilities in the major market place first," Mr McIntosh said.

webTitle: BA loses political ground in open skies strategy

fields.headline: BA loses political ground in open skies strategy
fields.trailText: British Airways is in danger of losing political support for its US strategy in the wake of last week's ousting of Bob Ayling, the chief executive.
fields.body:
British Airways is in danger of losing political support for its US strategy in the wake of last week's ousting of Bob Ayling, the chief executive.

Frustrated UK officials in Washington are seeking clarification from the company about its position following the abrupt dismissal of one of Tony Blair's favourite corporate lieutenants. A UK government source said yesterday: "It is clearly in BA's interests to let the government know whether Ayling's dismissal means anything for their strategy in the transatlantic market."

Mr Ayling's departure comes at a particularly awkward time in the negotiations to liberalise transatlantic airline routes.

Direct talks effectively broke down in January and the negotiations have been marked by bitter and embarrassing rows ever since. Although UK government officials in Washington have made it clear that they are acting for "UK plc" and not just BA, the company's demands have helped shape government policy.

Although Mr Ayling was believed to be instrumental in the company's failure to successfully lobby politicians in Washington and Brussels, his access to UK government members was believed to be crucial in garnering political support. The company's position is now less clear.

In the wake of Mr Ayling's departure BA has reaffirmed its commitment to its premium passenger policy and, in the US, it broadly wants to fly to more destinations in conjunction with American Airlines, its US partner. However, Simon Walker, BA's director of communications, indicated that the company had to focus on "internal administrative changes" during the management upheaval before turning its attention to the US.

The company was indirectly blamed for a bill, set to be passed by the US congress yesterday, that would allow the US government to impose sanctions on UK airlines. These could include preventing Concorde from flying to New York and cutting back on other flights.

webTitle: Knutsford chairman to be replaced by Wray

fields.headline: Knutsford chairman to be replaced by Wray
fields.trailText: Michael Edelson, the man who put together the much-hyped Knutsford shell company, has stepped aside as chairman.
fields.body:
Michael Edelson, the man who put together the much-hyped Knutsford shell company, has stepped aside as chairman.

Knutsford, a small Cheshire leather company, burst into the limelight last autumn when a group of businessmen led by former Asda boss Archie Norman took control and announced a grand plan to buy up and turn around an underperforming retailer - with money no object. Mr Edelson said at the time that targets ranged from Marks & Spencer down.

Knutsford's share price rocketed as investors hoped for big things from the partners, who also included hi-fi stores millionaire Julian Richer and property men Nick Leslau and Nigel Wray. Companies ranging from M&S to Storehouse, Sainsburys and WH Smith were all pinpointed as potential Knutsord targets.

The glitter has disappeared in recent months as the men have failed to pull off a deal.

Yesterday a spokesman for Knutsford said Mr Edelson was being replaced by Nigel Wray. "Nigel has been the driving force for some time", he said. "Mr Edelson was the founder but Nigel was centrally involved in putting the team together".

Knutsford recently made it clear the four men had broadened their horizons to target businesses in retail and leisure sectors or e-commerce but it is understood that no deal is imminent.

Yesterday Knutsford shares, which peaked at 270p, lost 4p to 121p.

webTitle: Bumpy road that could lead to oblivion

fields.headline: Bumpy road that could lead to oblivion
fields.standfirst: Troubled Rover which incurred £600m deficit last year now faces loss of tens of thousands of jobs at Longbridge despite rescue plan
fields.trailText: As uncertainty last night surrounded the future of Rover cars, fears also grew for the 50,000 jobs that would be lost if the Longbridge plant were to shut down.
fields.body:
As uncertainty last night surrounded the future of Rover cars, fears also grew for the 50,000 jobs that would be lost if the Longbridge plant were to shut down.

BMW, the German owners of the British marque, who bought the company from British Aerospace in early 1994 last night would not deny press reports in Germany that they were about to sell their subsidiary, retaining only the niche players of Land Rover, MG, the Mini and Rolls.

Given the huge losses Rover has chalked up (about £600m last year) since it was bought by BMW for £800m this is hardly surprising, but the news will nevertheless dismay the already depleted Rover workforce.

Only a few months ago they were breathing a sigh of relief after a rescue plan was finally agreed to save Longbridge, the heart of Britain's car manufacturing industry, in what many hoped was the final chapter in a long-running saga.

The first major sign of trouble came in July 1998 when Rover announced it was to axe 1,500 jobs, blaming the strong pound for making it difficult to sell cars abroad. Alarm bells rang again in October when the company said production of its Rover 200 and 400 models at Longbridge would be suspended for a month following a "business realignment process", and days later Rover admitted the company's position was "extremely serious". Further job losses were being considered, as were more cost-cutting measures and again the strength of sterling was to blame. In December 1998 a deal was offered to workers, aimed at securing the company's future, but at a cost of 2,500 jobs and the introduction of radical new working conditions including the removal of overtime, once a mainstay of workers' wages.

Reluctantly, workers voted to back the deal in the hope that it would end uncertainty over the plant, and a month later fortunes appeared to have turned around with Rover announcing the creation of 550 new jobs under plans to regain control of its parts business. The company had also confirmed the new millennium Mini would be built at Longbridge as part of a £400m investment programme.

Nerves began to fray again in early 1999, leading to a boardroom battle which saw BMW chief Bernd Pischetsrieder and potential chief Wolfgang Reitzle both quit. The man chosen to take over was Joachim Milberg, who confirmed plans to build a new medium- sized car, and raised hopes by indicating that Longbridge was his preferred site.

Gloom set in soon after however, when it was announced that Rover had crashed into the red, with 1998 losses put at about £650m. By now, there were deep fears for the future of Longbridge as BMW bosses mulled over the wisdom of building a new model there. After months talks between management, unions and the government to thrash out an aid package, a huge £3bn rescue deal was announced in June 1999.

The government hailed the decision as a vote of confidence in the British motor industry, and BMW unveiled a bigger-than-expected investment package of more than £500m a year for Rover over the next six years, half of which was earmarked for Longbridge.

Celebrations were soured somewhat by the European commission subsequently announcing a formal investigation into the government's part of the deal - a £152m aid package - but at least BMW indicated that its plans to build a new small car at the plant would not be affected.

But last week, as the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, was meeting the European competition com missioner, Mario Monti, to urge him to fast-track the inquiry, unions were fearing that further calamity could be just around the corner.

Last night Birmingham Northfield MP Richard Burden, whose constituency covers Longbridge, called on BMW to clarify its plans for the plant. Mr Burden said BMW officials had personally assured him that they were committed to Longbridge "for the long term" with an investment strategy that would bring £500m a year into Rover.

"I am calling on BMW to put an end to the speculation and to reaffirm their commitment to Rover.

"In doing so I am asking them to do no more than to keep their word to me, to the British government and the 50,000 people whose jobs depend on Longbridge."

The 430-acre site at Longbridge was founded in 1894 as a tin and printing works, and was bought by Herbert (later Lord) Austin 10 years later. In its first year it produced just 23 cars, but when it reached its peak of production in 1964/65 it turned out 345,245 cars.

fields.headline: Rover fears BMW sell-off
fields.standfirst: Fears for thousands of West Midlands jobs if BMW sells off Rover
fields.trailText: A fresh and potentially terminal threat was hanging over Rover's Longbridge car assembly plant last night, putting 50,000 Midlands jobs at risk, as it emerged that Rover's German owner, BMW, is to make a decision on whether to sell the subsidiary tomorrow.
fields.body:
A fresh and potentially terminal threat was hanging over Rover's Longbridge car assembly plant last night, putting 50,000 Midlands jobs at risk, as it emerged that Rover's German owner, BMW, is to make a decision on whether to sell the subsidiary tomorrow.

As news of the plan, which also clouds the future of Rover's Cowley plant near Oxford, leaked out last night, BMW issued a statement saying it had been examining "several scenarios" on restructing the Rover group, where sales slumped 25% last year.

But a spokesman refused to rule out reports in the German press that a decision to sell the car operation, Longbridge and also the Rover brand name to an unknown buyer was simply awaiting agreement between BMW's chief executive, Joachim Milberg, and the group's BMW's supervisory board.

The reports, which first appeared in the German newspaper Süddeutsche Zeitung, speculated that the buyer may be an British-American financial consortium unassociated with any of the big motor manufacturers.

It was also suggested that BMW would keep the rights to the Land Rover and Mini models, while ridding itself of the main Rover brand.

Rover - dubbed The English Patient by the German media - has been hit by low productivity, falling sales and mounting losses. But while BMW had previously given Rover managers until 2002 to break even, reports yesterday suggested losses for 1999 had ballooned to more than £800m from £600m a year earlier.

The statement immediately set alarm bells ringing among union leaders who said they were seeking urgent talks with the company.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union (AEEU), said last night: "BMW is already pumping cash into Rover. We have had assurances over recent weeks that BMW remains committed to the company."

He added that with the European Commission having opened an investi gation in December into the government's £152m aid package for Longbridge: "This increases the pressure on Mario Monti [the European commissioner for competition] to approve the UK support for Longbridge and we will be meeting BMW as soon as possible to seek reassurances."

Tony Woodley, the national officer of the Transport and General Workers Union, said he was seeking urgent talks with the company but believed that selling off Rover would not make any sense for BMW. "It would also be unacceptable to the workforce and no doubt the British government," he said.

Unions have already warned that 50,000 jobs would be lost throughout the West Midlands if Longbridge closed.

The shadow trade and industry secretary, Angela Browning, said: "This is a blow for the Midlands when only last summer they had been anticipating a new era at Rover cars. The key will be, if BMW does sell the company, who buys it and what sort of future they envisage."

This latest question mark over Longbridge comes after two years of constant uncertainty over Rover's future.

Following last summer's intended rescue plan, unions had agreed to a string of measures aimed at closing a 30% productivity gap with BMW's German plants, including the loss of 2,500 jobs and flexible working patterns.
