fields.headline: A sadist for all seasons
fields.standfirst: Why should British theatre-goers bother with a French farce by a man most have never heard of?  Neil Bartlett, who translated the work, sets out the case for Eugène Labiche's The Threesome
fields.trailText: Eugène Labiche's play The Threesome was supposedly written in response to a critic's claim that adultery could never be funny - at least not for a polite audience. It centres on the activities of a man called Marjavel, his wife Hermance and her lover Ernest, who is also Marjavel's best friend.
fields.body:
Eugène Labiche's play The Threesome was supposedly written in response to a critic's claim that adultery could never be funny - at least not for a polite audience. It centres on the activities of a man called Marjavel, his wife Hermance and her lover Ernest, who is also Marjavel's best friend.

The play was first performed at the Thétre du Palais-Royal in Paris on January 11, 1870, under the name of Le Plus Heureux des Trois. It was written (in collaboration with playwright Edmond Gondinet) for the leading comedians of the Palais-Royal - actors whose gifts and idiosyncrasies Labiche knew intimately and who were in effect the unnamed co-creators of the piece. It was part of Labiche's extraordinarily large output, in which new comedies and vaudevilles were manufactured in almost industrial quantities. They were phenomenally popular and critically acclaimed: no less a figure than Proust's Duchesse de Guermantes boasts, "I've even read Labiche."

The first collection of Labiche's work, published in 1878, features 57 pieces - and those are just the ones he preferred, not the complete works. The sheer quantity of Labiche's writing gives it a particular quality: it is precisely the fact that this is obviously commercial theatre, churned out to satisfy the vanity and prodigious appetite for entertainment in contemporary Paris, that gives such a delicious edge to its seriousness, its ability to unsettle, to induce something like panic as well as hilarity.

Labiche's writing is a theatrical paradox. It is apparently realistic, using real urban places, habits and language: photographs of his actors show fleshy, substantial, utterly worldly people, on sets as crammed with real furniture as the plays are with concrete topical detail. It is also radically artificial: many of his plays rise from farce into vaudeville (most famously, The Italian Straw Hat), topping the intricacies of his quickfire dialogue with elaborate sung choruses. The trick that holds the paradox together is the oldest one in theatre - he constantly acknowledges and appeals to the audience. Labiche's theatre is one in which footlights exist only to be reached across - characters confide in and reveal themselves to the audience much more readily than they do to each other. They are familiar with us, and familiar to us. This apparently relaxed mood, however, can quickly spiral into anxiety as the plot tightens.

I began translating Le Plus Heureux des Trois shortly after translating and producing Marivaux's 1744 work La Dispute. Surprisingly enough, given that Marivaux is so often fanciful and aristocratic and Labiche invariably contemporary and vulgar, the first was a great preparation for the second. These two authors share a gift for the two essentials of comedy, which any translation clouds or elaborates at its peril: great concision (characters are too busy dealing with situations to explain themselves or their feelings) and great cruelty.

Labiche's theatre is remarkable for its sadism. Some of the tortures presented for our entertainment are directly physical, like the boiling water that Ernest "accidentally" pours over Marjavel's unruly groin at the close of act one. Some are more sophisticated: a claustrophobic trapped in the stuffing of a sofa, a respectable wife constantly reduced to guilty panic. Some images or sounds of violence just contribute to the general air of potential punishment: the cracking of an offstage cab-driver's whip; the mysterious Aunt Isadore, condemned to hang forever from her window.

It is a truism that farce needs to be played with "attack"; what this means, I think, is that the audience should feel that at any minute (after the first two minutes, say) there is the possibility of a character doing violence to another character, to themselves or possibly to the audience. This particular quality of attack sometimes finds climactic expression in an actual assault; often it is sublimated in apparently incidental details (as the maid Petunia says of her dusting, it's just displacement, really).

The physical world (props, furniture, costume) in farce is animated by a strange malevolence and an unexpected talent for derangement - as if the silent, inanimate trappings of comfort were exacting a surreal sort of revenge on the well-ordered opulence of 19th-century bourgeois society. In a remarkable display of casual and constant violence, people shriek, run, collapse; ostriches and chairs bite; shoes pinch; desks splinter; heads spin; clocks chime regardless of the time; cockchafers irritate; taxis cause havoc; imaginary conflagrations lead to real dousings; imaginary diamonds and imaginary indiscretion oblige people to crawl, eat letters, sieve dust, climb drainpipes and, worst of all, endure their emotions while trapped within dialogue that allows no pause for reflection, only pure plot. Every sequence of dialogue, every action, is structured around the opposition of sadist and victim.

That most of the sadism is unconscious only makes it worse. Marjavel doesn't deliberately drive the lovers into a panic; he does it calmly, generously, casually. In so doing he creates the play's most radical torment. Hermance and Ernest's desire not to be adulterers masks an even deeper desire. They long for nothing more than not to be in a farce - not to be in a panic, not to be in torment.

And what of the spectator? Is the audience expected to just laugh at the expertly staged sufferings of others? Is the audience, then, sadistic? To a degree, yes: the worse it gets, the more we love it. Their panic induces our hilarity. However, there is method in Labiche's simple madness. He claimed that the task of the comic playwright was to "donner le change" - to wrong-foot the audience. We think we are laughing at other people. Only gradually - or too late - do we realise we are laughing at ourselves. Marjavel, hearing himself described as a complacent idiot, remarks "I know a few men like that myself" - and we, remarkably, laugh at him, apparently unaware that we are the men referred to.

As the play rises to the desperate unravellings of the third act, we may feel the smile on our faces gradually changing, feel the situations of the play becoming a little too real for comfort. The tone curdles. But as Marjavel reassures us with his last line, there'll soon be a new Ernest to take the old one's place. The old order of guilt and connivance and prostitution will be restored, and Monsieur Labiche will set busily to work turning out his next entertainment.

Gordon Anderson's production of The Threesome is at the Lyric Hammersmith, London W6 (0181-741 2311), from March 30-May 6.

fields.headline: Inzamam finds antidote to Muralitharan
fields.trailText: Inzamam-ul-Haq restored some pride to Pakistani cricket yesterday with a swashbuckling innings of 138 to put his side into a commanding position in the third and final Test against Sri Lanka in Karachi.
fields.body:
Inzamam-ul-Haq restored some pride to Pakistani cricket yesterday with a swashbuckling innings of 138 to put his side into a commanding position in the third and final Test against Sri Lanka in Karachi.

Finally getting to grips with the beguiling off-spin of Muthiah Muralitharan, whose 25 wickets so far have given Sri Lanka a winning 2-0 lead in the series, Inzamam thrashed 17 fours and a six as Pakistan reached 375 for seven in their second innings at the close, a lead of 404.

"My team needed these runs," he said. "There was a plan to hit Muralitharan and use feet against him."

Inzamam, who was finally caught at long-off, attempting a lofted drive off Muralitharan, became the fifth Pakistan batsman to make 4,000 runs in Test cricket, following Javed Miandad, Salim Malik, Zaheer Abbas and Mudassar Nazar.

The day's performance certainly answered the call of Moin Khan, the new captain who, reflecting on the poor recent run which also saw Pakistan lose the one-day series 3-0 against Sri Lanka, said: "I am not afraid of failures and once we play more positively the problems will be over."

The England and Wales Cricket Board will plough £1.2m into the game's development over the next three years. The money, from the Channel 4 television contract, will be used to fund education, inner- city promotions and the Kwik Cricket Road Show among other things. Channel 4 has pledged to invest £15m in the marketing and promoting of the sport.

 The fourth day's play of the first Test in Auckland was washed out yesterday with New Zealand, on 151 for five, needing another 130 runs for victory against Australia.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sarah Hilton, 30 IT consultant
fields.body:
Sarah Hilton, 30 IT consultant

A close friend was dying of cancer and I had to get to the hospital as she had hours to live. Rather than just dropping everything, I spent half an hour arranging things and diverting calls to my mobile. At the hospital, I nipped out every so often to check my messages. She died in the evening and I went back to work the next day. Looking back, I should have put work out of my mind; thinking of checking my messages on a day like that makes me cringe now. My advice is to put the trauma first, for your own sake.

James Wilkinson, 43 banker

I went through a divorce when my children were very small. At work, I had a very male way of dealing with it: I picked up my briefcase and carried on as normal. I told my immediate boss but I didn't take a single day off. I knew if I allowed myself to sit at home turning things over in my head, I would fall apart. Work was a constant and I needed that. I also socialised a lot through work, so I overdosed on nicotine and drank myself senseless, but you can't feel guilty. You have to do whatever gets you through it.

Judith Hughes, 35 chief executive

My partner left and I was devastated. What made it worse was he worked for an organisation I had dealings with. I asked colleagues to take over any joint business until I felt better. Fairly soon after, I had to attend a meeting where I'd have to see him. I made sure I arrived in plenty of time, that I was looking good and knew lots of people I could talk to. Be practical. Take anti-depressants to kick-start coping, see a counsellor and ask colleagues for help. Trauma will always affect your work. You just have to take steps to limit it.

Suzanne Hume, 38 marketing director

I worked with very understanding people when my mother, then my father, died of cancer. I was encouraged to take as much time off as I needed which really helped, not least because it acknowledged something huge had happened. It can be harder with problems you don't want to confide: I worked through two miscarriages when colleagues didn't know I was pregnant and it was horrible suffering alone. Confide as much as you feel able - people will probably be more sympathetic than you think.

Joanna Hayworth, 28 financial manager

I'm very ambitious, but last year my job didn't take priority in my life. My father died, my mother had a nervous breakdown and was taken into hospital, and we had to sell the family home. At work, I told my boss what was going on but I didn't tell my colleagues. It wouldn't have felt right to have their sympathy. As long as they didn't know, I could act as if nothing had happened and almost pretend it wasn't affecting me. I think you should keep trauma away from the workplace.

Write to us at the Guardian, 119 Farringdon Rd, London EC1R 3ER or email workunlimited@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Cha cha cha spectacular
fields.standfirst:
Compay Segundo
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Compay Segundo
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The significance of the Buena Vista Social Club project - Ry Cooder's phenomenally successful rediscovery of classic Cuban folk music - lies in its star Compay Segundo's name. That the erstwhile Francisco Repilado should be nicknamed "Comrade Second" - because he tends to sing second harmony - bespeaks an effortlessly, indelibly musical culture. As the music of the English-speaking world suffocates in its shrink-wrapping, is it any wonder western punters are flocking to reconnect with less commercial, more spontaneous sounds?

Hence the slightly condescending, noble-savage tone of Wim Wenders' documentary of the album, which had Cuba's greatest musicians blinking childlike through the streets of New York. Here were unsullied, innocent musicians - a term which can hardly be applied to that wily old dog Segundo, who was greeted with real affection at the Festival Hall. How strange it must seem to the wizened, wickedly grinning 93-year-old - who, pre-Cooder, had languished in obscurity since the 60s - to be cheered by a capacity crowd of London's glitterati and accosted onstage by young women with flowers. Stranger still for his son, silver-haired himself and playing double bass in dad's band.

Not that Segundo looks, or acts, his age. Dancing onstage in trademark panama hat, he coyly unbuttons his jacket to show off a slinky sashay that would have put Elvis the Pelvis (two decades his junior) to shame. Standing, and shimmying, throughout the gig, he plucked nimbly at his customised guitar - a seven-string armonico he invented in the 20s - and, for percussive effect, repeatedly planted sloppy kisses on its side.

The music - Cuban son, merengue and cha cha cha of the types Segundo pioneered in the 40s - is beautiful, and performed beautifully, Se gundo's deep, gentle voice underscored distinctively by three-part clarinet harmonies. It helped that clarinettist Rafael Inciarte was a showman to rival Segundo himself, urging the crowd to clap, to dance, to sing along. One longed to be with Segundo y Sus Muchachos in a ballroom somewhere, with rum unlimited and room to dance.

And so one almost was by the concert's end, as the audience spilled from its seats, crowding the aisle and the front of the stage in shuffling, swaying delirium. The Cuban flag unfurled to cheers that bode well for Ken Livingstone. Wild whoops greeted the opening chords of Segundo's irresistible signature tune, Chan Chan, and its chant-along "Compay, Compay" refrain. Introduced before the gig as being "in the middle stage of his career", Segundo performed with the panache of a man who senses that his best years may, remarkably, be ahead of him.

fields.headline: Still worth the fight
fields.trailText: Women in the new millennium do have equal pay formally, yet women's earnings remain lower than men's. New opportunities in administration, communications, finance and the professions have opened up for some women. But even in these relatively privileged jobs, men remain at the top.
fields.body:
I was just 27 when I stood in the Oxford doorway of the trade union college of Ruskin 30 years ago, watching as more and more enthusiastic young women poured in for the first Women's Liberation conference. We had long, straight hair, ragged fur coats salvaged from grannies' cupboards and were buzzing with the discovery of more than 400 other rebels.

Some of the participants were to become well known theorists and campaigners: Juliet Mitchell, Selma James, Jean McCrindle and Audrey Wise. But there was also a class of trainee beauticians from Chesterfield and about 40 men - among them the historian Christopher Hill.

Audrey Wise, then an official in the shop workers' union, Usdaw, argued that the equal pay legislation introduced by Barbara Castle wasn't "enough". Employers could evade it; it didn't cover large numbers of low paid women workers. She said that wider, work-related issues had to be addressed - access to "male" jobs and childcare.

Shelley Wortis, a child psychologist from the US, active in the movement against the Vietnam war, challenged the exclusive preoccupation with the effect of mothers working on children. What about father deprivation, she asked?

Passers-by in the streets of Oxford in 1970 were bewildered by the phrase "women's liberation". A modern vox pop would find it more familiar. But despite all the water under the bridge in the past three decades, the themes of the original conference remain surprisingly relevant. It is the overall context which has changed.

Women in the new millennium do have equal pay formally, yet women's earnings remain lower than men's. New opportunities in administration, communications, finance and the professions have opened up for some women. But even in these relatively privileged jobs, men remain at the top. In society as a whole, inequality has become more marked and women constitute the majority of the low paid. A recent report on Asian homeworkers in the Midlands clothing industry (The Double Burden Intensified), found the women were working, in 1997, an average of 37 hours a week for £1.90 an hour.

You don't have to be poor to experience the conflicting pressures of work and child care. Britain's derisory record in the past 30 years has been way behind countries such as Denmark, Finland or France. In the early 90s, when the Conservatives were cutting our welfare state to the bone, the Finns introduced the choice of a free nursery place or the minimum wage for whichever partner decided to care for a pre-school child at home.

fields.headline: Tell it like it is
fields.standfirst: An employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: Ken had been sacked for calling his boss a "doofus". Repeatedly. Unrepentantly. This was our real problem, although I could not make Ken see it.
fields.body:
There are few grimmer sorts of day for the tribunal hack than the out-of-town hopeless case. Call it Tribunal X. It is somewhere on the South coast and you can get there in the morning - but only if you rise at 5:30 and stagger to the station with a mouth tasting of old newspaper. So tired you hallucinate fitfully on the train in the fug of the microwaved breakfast buns for an hour-and-a-half in between bouts of consciousness, during which you realise you have drooled on your brief.

And on the way to the tribunal itself, over what seem to be half-a-hundred windswept roundabouts, the wheels of your wheelie bag catch themselves in every passing rut and kerb so it bucks like a bronco. A freak rain storm speckles your specs to blindness so you take the wrong turn and get twice as wet and start to wonder seriously whether there might be easier ways to make a living.

All in all I was feeling fairly peeved by the time I met up with Ken, my client, in the waiting room. Ken had been sacked for calling his boss a "doofus". Repeatedly. Unrepentantly. This was our real problem, although I could not make Ken see it.

Me: "You see, the tribunal are likely to take the view that, regardless of the rights and wrongs of the situation that lead to you saying what you did, it simply is not acceptable for you to insult your boss. And then not to apologise."

Ken: "But he was behaving like a doofus. I was just being honest and also trying to make him change what he was doing."

Me: "But you can see why he took objection?"

Ken: "No."

The problem with being frank with your clients about their prospects is that your advice then sits about sourly with you and the client for the duration of the case, like the reek from an old kebab wrapper. Ken and I eat white bread and sticky innards sandwiches from the local petrol station at lunchtime in silent misery. Ken obviously thinks as he sighs over his Sun, that it is my pessimism which has caused the tribunal to treat his case so far with such transparent scepticism.

In the afternoon, the doofus gives evidence. And in doing so finally lights a spark of empathy for Ken in my breast. Because he is a doofus, a pedantic, clueless, over-promoted, irritating dull little man. During one particularly annoying exchange with Doofus, I catch Ken's eye and we both smile, because Ken knows that I too want to pack it all in and just say, as Ken himself did "Why are you such a complete doofus?"

But no cigar. Nonetheless, shaking hands with Ken after the case in the little shaft of bonhomie that has briefly warmed our professional relationship, I am at least partially reconciled to the dismal early mornings and the demonic wheelie bag.

At least I am the boss of myself and my wheelie bag, whereas in many, probably most of the offices and shopfloors of the monstrous mansion Work, there are doofuses lurking to boss you about. And you can't even say anything about it.

fields.headline: Soul of Algeria
fields.standfirst:
Cheikha Remitti/Lili Boniche with Maurice El Medioni/Emil Zrihan
Barbican, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Cheikha Remitti/Lili Boniche with Maurice El Medioni/Emil Zrihan
Barbican, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Algerian rai is a melting pot of rural songs, pounding beats and rock, pop and soul. One of the highlights of the African Roots and Shoots festival, this show goes back to the roots of the genre, featuring traditional stars of rai. First up is Emil Zrihan, a Moroccan Jew with a huge counter-tenor voice who bends and holds impossibly long notes with the controlled bravado of a prizefighter. There is a searing melancholy to his blend of flamenco, Moroccan mawal and liturgical music.

Zrihan's breathtaking act is followed by Maurice El Medioni, a Jewish piano player who pioneered Algerian swing in the 40s, and his collaborator Lili Boniche, a guitarist who weaves rakish Latin and European pop into local rhythms. Medioni blows kisses at the audience and plays with a baroque flourish, while Boniche totters in on the arms of two helpers, and settles himself onto a chair, his gleaming red guitar on his knee. Both men are well into their 70s, and their phlegmatic backing musicians can't be much younger, but they perform with an assured ease.

Boniche clears his throat between notes, and runs out of puff towards the end of each song, but with his slicked-back hair and zoot suit, he still has the presence of a star raconteur. He moves from Algerian jive to French chanson, even executing a few steps along the way. "I am not better than you/And you are not better than me," he croons, sending the party animals at the front into a whooping frenzy.

Although she is 76, headliner Cheikha Remitti has never played in Britain before. A tall woman with waist-length black hair and flashing eyes, Remitti is known as the "grandmother of rai", or "el ghedra" (the root). Like an Arabic Piaf, she began singing on the seaports and streets of Oranie in western Algeria, and flouted Muslim convention by singing about the pleasures of sex and alcohol. Accompanied by a sprightly band of young musicians, she slowly paces the stage, singing mesmerising drones in a deep, cavernous voice. A female dancer comes on and wiggles decoratively, but can't compete with Remitti. With just one suggestive shake of her ample hips, the older woman conjures up a musty, exotic world.

fields.headline: Brief encounters
fields.standfirst:
An employment tribunal lawyer writes

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: This week I have been co-responding. This is not as racy as it may sound. Once upon a time, of course, co-respondents were the third parties in divorce proceedings: I visualise men in trenchcoats and trilbies like Cary Grants gone bad and women in 40s hairdos and dark lipstick. In the tribunal, you co-respond when, for example, an applicant sues both the employer and a named individual for discrimination. If the employer doesn't want to throw in its lot with the individual, they get separate representation. You and your client are then co-responding with the company and its counsel.
fields.body:
This week I have been co-responding. This is not as racy as it may sound. Once upon a time, of course, co-respondents were the third parties in divorce proceedings: I visualise men in trenchcoats and trilbies like Cary Grants gone bad and women in 40s hairdos and dark lipstick. In the tribunal, you co-respond when, for example, an applicant sues both the employer and a named individual for discrimination. If the employer doesn't want to throw in its lot with the individual, they get separate representation. You and your client are then co-responding with the company and its counsel.

In this instance, I am for Mr Alleged Harasser. The company is being represented by someone I suspect of being an ex-member of the Famous Five, probably Julian.

Julian is very jolly: "We won't have too much trouble with this one." Me: "You think not?" Julian: "Well, it certainly sounds like she encouraged the chaps to take a few liberties, all that banter, showing her brassiere and so forth."

It strikes me it is not only Julian's suit that belongs to the opening years of the recently departed century. I have already advised Mr Alleged Harasser that it is unlikely the tribunal will accept that the Applicant welcomed him putting his hand down her trousers to see if she was wearing French knickers.

Since Julian is so gung-ho about the whole thing, however, he readily agrees to cross-examine first. This means I avoid having to put most of the "You liked it really, didn't you, Mrs?" questions and Julian can feel he is doing the gentlemanly thing.

And it all goes rapidly wrong. The Applicant's counsel is a large American woman with a glittering look. Julian launches boldly in: "Now, Miss Applicant, it would be right to say you could be a bit frisky with the lads in the workplace?"

"Aaaabjection!" We are all a bit startled by this, which turns out to be Applicant's counsel's standard form of objection to a line of questioning. Readers may be familiar with this transatlantic practice from episodes of Ally McBeal.

The tribunal chair makes no move to stop these interjections, so every few minutes Julian finds his increasingly spluttery questions penetrated by a nasal yowl. "Well, Miss Applicant, but it would be right to say that your workplace garb could be somewhat saucy?"

"Aaaabjection!" And so on. This is co-responding at its finest. You and your client huddle under cover while the casualties pile up.

The hearing doesn't finish in the day allotted to it, so my client won't have to give evidence until a resumed hearing. He's happy. I'm pleasantly relaxed. Julian is looking a bit bruised. He tells me most of his work is in construction and defamation. Maybe the chaps are more civilised in the High Court.

fields.headline: Going for gold
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Practically everyone in the Australian state of New South Wales is anticipating the 2000 Olympic Games with big, ocular dollar signs, none more so than those in the sex industry, who have taken the unusual step of launching a worldwide recruitment drive.
fields.body:
Practically everyone in the Australian state of New South Wales is anticipating the 2000 Olympic Games with big, ocular dollar signs, none more so than those in the sex industry, who have taken the unusual step of launching a worldwide recruitment drive. Prostitution was legalised in New South Wales in 1995 and since then has prospered hugely, although not enough to cater for an expected influx of nine million visitors.

"There are 24 pages advertising brothels and escort agencies in the Yellow Pages today," Catherine O'Malley, a Sydney madam, boasted to the BBC, but a call for overseas relief workers has gone out to meet the anticipated demand.

Visitors to the games will be hit by advertising campaigns which, industry insiders are claiming, have already seen some of the more exclusive establishments booked up for corporate use. And the Sydney authorities aren't ashamed of using the situation as one of the city's unique selling points. "Sydney's got some of the world's best prostitutes," says Maria McMahon, manager of the Sex Workers Outreach Project, with a medal-winning cool head.

webTitle: FSA warns of bad debt risk

fields.headline: FSA warns of bad debt risk
fields.standfirst: Consumer lending soars by 50% after relaxation of credit standards
fields.trailText: Consumer lending has rocketed by 50% during the past three years, risking an avalanche of bad debts for the banking system should the economy turn down, the chief City regulator, the Financial Services Authority (FSA) warned yesterday .
fields.body:
Consumer lending has rocketed by 50% during the past three years, risking an avalanche of bad debts for the banking system should the economy turn down, the chief City regulator, the Financial Services Authority (FSA) warned yesterday.

Chairman Howard Davies told MPs that Britain may be on the verge of a new era, in which individuals would carry significantly heavier debts, but that banks may not be prepared for the consequences.

Combined with the explosion in outstanding mortgage debt - now totalling nearly half a trillion pounds - the FSA fears a witches' brew of new risk for the banking and financial system.

His comments on unsecured lending follow remarks Mr Davies made last month to the Council of Mortgage Lenders about relaxed standards and aggressive competition in the homeloan market. Yesterday he repeated his mortgage concern: "There...[are] signs of a relaxation of credit standards which were the kinds of signs that we saw in the late 1980s boom," he said.

Mr Davies was speaking to the backbench treasury select committee in Westminster.

He told MPs FSA research showed the outstanding amount of unsecured consumer credit stood at £1.02bn in 1998-99, and had shot up to £1.15bn in 1999-2000, a 13% increase in one year.

This underestimates the total amount of consumer credit outstanding, because the FSA does not regulate credit created by pawnbrokers, shops or some hire-purchase companies.

Mortgage lending, he said, had surged 8% in 1999-2000, from an outstanding total of £459bn to £497bn.

Managing director Michael Foot said the authority was not trying to second-guess lenders, but was concerned to ensure "the right prudential measures are in place". The authority is conducting a full-scale review of unsecured consumer lending, although no completion date has been given.

Quizzed about the boom in hi-tech stocks, Mr Davies said that the relaxation in margin lending and credit standards by some brokers and banks had fuelled this surge in share trading in the second half of 1999 and early 2000. The FSA had warned these brokers about their more relaxed stances and had been encouraged by their response, with some subsequently tightening up their credit processes, he said.

 Lenders were warned yesterday that they face fines and possible imprisonment should they flout the rules on publishing an annual percentage rate (APR) on credit offers. The Office of Fair Trading said the rate must reflect the total cost of credit, including the expense of any insurance schemes.

fields.headline: Japanese banks in three-way union
fields.standfirst: Plan to create world's No 3
fields.trailText: Three Japanese financial institutions unveiled plans yesterday for an alliance that would create the world's third largest banking group.
fields.body:
Three Japanese financial institutions unveiled plans yesterday for an alliance that would create the world's third largest banking group.

The proposed tie-up between Sanwa, Asahi and Tokai banks is expected to complete the latest wave of mega-mergers in the Japanese commercial banking system, which teetered close to the brink of collapse in 1998.

Under a three-stage plan, the banks will form a holding company in April 2001 with combined assets of ¥103.7 trillion (£592bn). This is almost twice the size of Britain's biggest bank, HSBC, and surpassed only by the Mizuto financial group to be formed by Dai-Ichi Kangyo, Fuji and Industrial Bank of Japan, and the planned merger of Germany's Dresdner and Deutsche banks.

The three banks aim to integrate their retail and information technology operations by 2002, as well as issuing customers with a common deposit book. Two years after that, they will re-form as a new bank tailored to individual customers and small and medium-sized businesses.

The three banks said they will cut 12% of their combined 37,435 workforce by 2003, and make a similar reduction in their 1,055 branches. They predict savings of about ¥50bn (£286m) per year.

The banks will scale back their international operations by cutting 20 of their 56 overseas branches.

Since 1997, the number of major Japanese banks has shrunk from 21 to 13, and the creation of new alliances means Tokyo is now home to four of the world's five biggest banking groups.

The prime minister, Keizo Obuchi, said the latest announcement was a sign that the banking system was on the road to recovery.

The three banks said they will cut 12% of their combined 37,435 workforce by 2003, and make a similar reduction in their 1,055 branches. They predict savings of about ¥50bn (£286m) per year. The banks will scale back their international operations by cutting 20 of their 56 overseas branches. Since 1997, the number of major Japanese banks has shrunk from 21 to 13, and the creation of new alliances means Tokyo is now home to four of the world's five biggest banking groups. The prime minister, Keizo Obuchi, said the latest announcement was a sign that the banking system was on the road to recovery.

fields.headline: Hurting
fields.standfirst:
Orange Tree, Richmond
**
Till April 15. Box office: 0181-940 3633.
fields.trailText:
Hurting
Orange Tree, Richmond
**
fields.body:
The only thing that really hurts is having to endure David Lewis's pallid play, a story of lust and betrayal among the wine-bar-frequenting classes. Paul is in love with Suzie who is having an affair with Mark who can't bring himself to leave the agoraphobic Julia. A year later, Paul and Suzie are moving in together, Julia and Suzie are bosom pals and Mark is the villain of the piece. A year or two later, new shifts in partner and friendship beckon in a play that is less like La Ronde and more like a square dance.

You would assume from the title that Lewis's territory is every modern male playwright's favourite subject: the pain and passion of contemporary sexual relationships. So why is this play so prosaic? The characters are sufficiently like you and me to be of interest. But they don't behave like human beings, more like puppets. Even Julia's madness lacks an edge of pain and danger.

The evening is so devoid of subtext that it comes across like one of those adult dramas you get on ITV at 9pm, in which everyone is bonking everyone else and adultery and guilt are dealt with in soft focus among the soft furnishings. Here it is evident long before Lewis decides to spell it out in capital letters that Suzie's sexual and social confidence disguises a deep-seated need to settle down and have a baby, that Paul is only interested in women who are unavailable and won't love him back. Or that Mark is a helpless serial adulterer but in many ways more dependent on Julia than she is on him, and that Julia is not quite the Rapunzel, sitting in her tower and waiting to be rescued, that she seems.

There are some amusing lines, the acting is fine (Amanda Royle as Suzie does a particularly nice job), and Julie Nelson's design is simple and smart. But Sam Walters's portentous production can't disguise the fact that this is tosh dressed up with classical music. Schubert's string quartet is the only thing in this evening that will make your heart leap and crack.

webTitle: Our mutual friend puts it to the vote

fields.headline: Our mutual friend puts it to the vote
fields.standfirst: Members of the London stock exchange decide on the institution's structure today
fields.trailText: Today one of Britain's best known financial service providers will vote on whether to demutualise. Although the decision will be historic, it is not a case of carpetbaggers pushing a reluctant board into conversion in order to pocket the profits.
fields.body:
Today one of Britain's best known financial service providers will vote on whether to demutualise. Although the decision will be historic, it is not a case of carpetbaggers pushing a reluctant board into conversion in order to pocket the profits.

True, the change-over does hold out the prospect of substantial windfalls but, for those advocating the change, the decision of the 298 members of the London stock exchange is about facing the future in a competitive world rather than realising embedded value.

The exchange's chief executive Gavin Casey acknowledges that a decision to abandon mutuality would be significant but argues that it is one of a series that the exchange has undergone over the years.

But why should the exchange be asking members to demutualise; to formalise a separation between the role of customer and shareholder; to give up a structure which Mr Casey acknowledges has served the exchange well over the years? "We need to be more commercial. We should be able to take decisions more quickly and implement them more quickly. We need to keep the good things and reform the things that are not quite so effective."

The reality is that the exchange is coming under increasing competitive pressure. Big investors no longer see Europe as a series of separate national markets. They want to trade across borders quickly, cheaply and simply. Technology offers the possibility. What is lacking is a pan-European trading structure.

To be fair, the national exchanges have been talking about a pan-European mechanism for some time. The London stock exchange and the Frankfurt bourse announced in 1998 that they were planning an alliance. After some huffing and puffing, others said they were prepared to sign up, too.

Now a total of eight exchanges are working towards a system that will offer cross-border trading. "National investment boundaries are falling away," says Mr Casey. But while the established exchanges have been drawing up their plans others have seen an opportunity to carve out a share of the pan-European market.

Perhaps the most formidable entrant into the fray is Nasdaq which is promising pan-European trading from November. And there are plenty of others: Brussels-based Easdaq; London's Tradepoint; Jiway - a combination of Swedish stock exchange owner, OM, and several big financial institutions - and electronic networks like Posit and e-Crossnet. It is perhaps a sign of the frustration felt by big institutional players in European share trading that a number of them are backing one or more of the rivals.

Nor is it simply a question of trading systems. The pressure is on to cut costs in the settlement clearing operations as well as the dealing side. Institutions taking on the risk of a stake in a company may try to offset that risk, perhaps through the foreign exchange market if there is a currency risk, or through a derivatives market.

Though these transactions are designed to minimise the initial risk they can count as three separate transactions against which the bank or institution has to deploy expensive capital. If the deals could be "netted" - treated as one - it would save the institutions money, and would also require the markets (and regulators) to be cooperative and flexible.

Speed and flexibility are what Mr Casey and his colleagues are seeking from the demutualisation vote. "We are not saying we can't handle the competition, but we must be free to compete," he says.

To get the changes through the exchange will need 75% of the votes and though Mr Casey is extremely wary of counting chickens he does believe "there is widespread understanding of the reasons why change is necessary".

The big institutional members are likely to back the change because it would push the exchange in the direction they want to go. Smaller firms, too, seem to acknowledge that reform is necessary. "Its difficult to develop the stock exchange while it remains a mutual organisation," said one private client broker. Inevitably there are concerns about how a demutualised exchange would treat small customers. But as one member pointed out "At the end of the day there are other organisations that want [our] business. It's a competitive world."

And there is also the matter of the windfall. If the vote goes through each of the 298 single shares will be converted into 100,000 shares - allowing members to realise at least part of their holdings. But at what price? Ironically for an organisation where price formation is a crucial part of what it does, no price has yet been put on the shares. That can only happen after a yes vote when Casenove will set up a "matched bargain" system allowing the new shares to change hands.

Some guestimates put the existing single shares at between £1m and £1.5m each which would imply a market value not much in excess of that of its Aim listed and very much smaller rival, Tradepoint. There have been reports that an American consortium had been trying to buy up shares at up at around £10m each. For the very small firms even the lower valuation would make their share their single most valuable asset.

But for most, the real value of the share will hinge on how competitive the exchange is judged to be and on its ability to capture and retain business in an environment which by the end of this year looks likely to be challenging in the extreme. Making sure the structure of the exchange is right will help - but which ever way today's vote goes, the exchange is facing interesting times.

fields.headline: The quiet American
fields.standfirst:
Bill Frisell
Pizza Express Dean Street, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Bill Frisell
Pizza Express Dean Street, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
If you play your music in front of a room full of diners, you risk being reduced to the level of background noise. Some performers might respond by aggressively stamping their authority on the proceedings. Bill Frisell, by contrast, seeks to ensnare his listeners by stealth.

He shuffled out onstage with the air of a man who'd just tumbled out of bed after his alarm clock failed to go off, clutching his guitar for safety. A bumbling, bespectacled figure in blue denim, you could picture Bill as a diffident schoolteacher somewhere in the backwoods of Oregon. On the other hand, he might be a psychotic maniac. His vague resemblance to horror novelist Stephen King may have something to do with it.

"I've no idea what I'm doing here," he muttered, smiling hopelessly. "I don't have any kind of plan - but thanks for comin'." His music is determinedly non-emphatic. Pieces begin with a few glistening arpeggios or a cluster of notes, then evolve with spidery cunning into searching essays in harmony and tone colour. Frisell never finishes anything with a flourish, merely explores his way methodically to the end, and then stops.

Frisell's great gift is his instinctive ecleticism, which enables him to dart nimbly between Bach-like counter points or Spanish-sounding minor chords to blues riffs, bluegrass licks or ghostly echoes of rock'n'roll. One moment he's travelling across the great plains, the next he's up on the roof or under the boardwalk. He uses some state-of-the-art gadgetry, but deploys it with frugal minimalism. His large fingers will stretch their way around some impossible sequence of notes, then suddenly he'll kick in a chorus effect or a repeating loop and turn into a one-man guitar orchestra.

In Frisell's hands, familiar tunes yield up dimensions they never knew they had. He turns the Gershwins' My Man's Gone Now into a spectral meditation on disembodiment, the strings pinging eerily in space. John McLaughlin's Follow Your Heart is the blues, but played with a formal stateliness that verges on the baroque. For an encore, Bill played Moon River so weightlessly it was if time had been temporarily switched off. Then he ended it with a high-speed flurry from one of his machines, a rare moment of showmanship.

fields.headline: Lastminute fortune for net pin-ups
fields.standfirst:
Public loses despite share surge peak

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: After months of anticipation and hype, the internet shopping business Lastminute.com finally joined the stock market yesterday and immediately crystallised a £150m paper fortune for its founders, Brent Hoberman, 31, and Martha Lane Fox, 27.
fields.body:
After months of anticipation and hype, the internet shopping business Lastminute.com finally joined the stock market yesterday and immediately crystallised a £150m paper fortune for its founders, Brent Hoberman, 31, and Martha Lane Fox, 27.

Mr Hoberman and Ms Lane Fox, who have become pin-ups for the new breed of net entrepreneurs, were in their Mayfair offices early yesterday to watch the newly floated shares soar from a sale price of 380p to 555p in minutes, valuing the 19-month-old company at £835m at one stage. At the end of the day, after a frenzy of trading on the stock market, the price settled at 477p.

"I'm not quite myself today," said Ms Lane Fox, trying to compose herself for one of several TV interviews first thing in the morning. Under strict instructions from her American investment bankers at Morgan Stanley not to make any leading comments on the share price or value of Lastminute.com, she restricted herself to explaining how the £113m raised from the flotation will be used to finance the expansion of the Lastminute sales concept.

But the 200,000 investors who rushed to buy shares in the flotation - registering their details in advance at the company's website - suffered severe disappointment. Shares for the public were distributed evenly among applicants, leading to allocations of 35 shares for each investor, which were worth £167 last night. After paying dealing charges and tax, any new-issue speculator selling the shares will be lucky to make a profit.

Lastminute started off by selling cheap flights online, but branched out to offer everything from flowers and chocolates to theatre tickets. Mr Hoberman and Ms Lane Fox believe there is a huge market potential in selling to "asset rich/time poor" customers.

Aside from luring regular internet shoppers, Lastminute.com also expects to see a spectacular increase in purchases made over mobile phones.

Lastminute is also developing services through digital TV, after signing deals with cable companies NTL and Cable & Wireless Communications.

Mr Hoberman, said his immediate task now was "to keep moving fast, to execute the business plan".

Many commentators, though, have questioned the valuation attached to a business that will not make a profit for the foreseeable future and which has transacted deals, such as flight purchases, worth only £4.3m during the last three months of 1999.

fields.headline: Freeserve follows access leaders
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider, bowed to the inevitable yesterday and joined the growing number of companies offering unmetered web access.
fields.body:
Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider, bowed to the inevitable yesterday and joined the growing number of companies offering unmetered web access.

It will offer the service on a British Telecom line during off-peak hours for £6.99 a month. If a customer uses Energis, Freeserve's telecoms partner, access is unmetered at all times provided at least £10 a month is spent on voice calls.

Freeserve's hand was forced by rivals including Alta Vista and cable company NTL which made aggressive grabs for market share last week with unmetered access.

NTL claims to have won 100,000 new customers in four days after the launch of its service which offers entirely free access in its own cable franchise areas and unmetered access as long as customers spend £10 on voice calls outside. An NTL spokesman said take-up had been "tremendous" and continues to grow at rapid rate.

Shares in Freeserve had been battered by the rival offers and lost 40% in value last week but managed to claw some back yesterday, closing 51p higher at 631.5p.

Analysts will be watching Freeserve's third quarter figures tomorrow to see how much revenue is being generated from e-commerce and advertising on its portal.

In the second quarter, Freeserve made a pre-tax loss of £3.6m on turnover of £3.8m - some £2m of which was from Freeserve's share of call revenues, a number which will now drop sharply.

For its product via a BT line, Freeserve is paying the network operator £5.99 a month while the remaining £1 will be eaten up transferring the call to the ISP's servers. All voice call revenues from the Energis package will be retained by the telecoms company.

A Freeserve spokesman said the company was unconcerned by the potential drop in revenues because of the extra time people would spend on the internet. "We always said that we would expect e-commerce and advertising revenues to outweigh connectivity revenues, and the longer people spend online the more opportunities there are. We are not just an ISP, we are a portal which aggregates content."

Analysts remained cautious about the quality of Freeserve's content and its ability to drive e-commerce and advertising revenues. Gerard van Hamel Platerink at Salomon Smith Barney said: "The value in Freeserve is not as an ISP but as a portal so the more time people spend online the better. Freeserve now needs to do the right content deals to keep people at its site, and at the moment they haven't done enough."

Freeserve, which is 80% owned by electrical goods retailer Dixons, turned the internet access market upside down when it became the first to drop monthly subscription fees in September 1998. It rapidly became the country's leading ISP and has 1.67m users.

Internet service providers are under considerable political pressure to reduce the cost of accessing the web.

webTitle: Watch out for those lastminute lemmings

fields.headline: Watch out for those lastminute lemmings
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Yesterday's frenzied debut for Lastminute.com once again raises a question that may never be properly answered: how much is an internet company really worth?
fields.body:
Yesterday's frenzied debut for Lastminute.com once again raises a question that may never be properly answered: how much is an internet company really worth?

To many people a share is worth what the financial markets think it is, no more and no less. That would make Lastminute "worth" every penny of the £800m at which the total value of its shares were trading at one point yesterday. And no one can say investors were hoodwinked. They flocked to buy the shares despite the descant sung by analysts that they were overvalued.

The new company's £800m market capitalisation compares with actual revenue (not profits) of only £409,000 in the most recent quarter. So, if you purchased the entire company for £800m, then on annual revenues of £1.63m, it would take you nearly 500 years before revenues would cover your purchase price. And that's an unreal calculation because all of the revenue and more is being eaten up by costs.

The usual way of assessing a company's status by expressing market capitalisation as a multiple of earnings (post-tax profits) has fallen out of the window. You cannot say a web company is worth 15 times its earnings because web companies do not make profits.

Instead, analysts have devised two new yardsticks. The first is to express the market worth of rapidly expanding companies like Amazon.com or eBay.com as a multiple of present or future revenues. But this gives no indication of the quality of revenues - whether they are earned as commissions on sales or completely eaten up by marketing and infrastructure costs.

The second way - very fashionable - is to divide the market capitalisation by the number of customers. This is also used to justify takeover bids. Thus Vodafone's recent take over of Mannesmann meant that Vodafone was paying £7,850 for each customer.

But mobile phone companies have a stable customer base. The same criterion ap plied to a dot.com's customer base is dodgy because many of the customers may have registered but not be active buyers. As soon as they see something cheaper elsewhere they will be off at the touch of a mouse button.

Fortune magazine found wide variations in the valuation of dot.com companies by their customer base ranging from $244 for Lycos, the internet portal, to $4,562 for Charles Schwab, the online stockbroker which takes a commission on sales.

Internet valuations are difficult because no one knows how profitable web companies will be. Everyone accepts that the internet will change the world and transform business-to-business transactions (which get less publicity but account for nearly 80% of all internet business transactions). But in the area of business-to-consumer the very nature of the internet makes it difficult to make big profits. There are lower barriers to entry - as soon as a business looks good others can pile in. More important, it is a consumers' not a producers' paradise because people (and robotic agents) can surf the web for cheaper prices).

fields.bodyText: Yesterday's frenzied debut for Lastminute.com once again raises a question that may never be properly answered: how much is an internet company really worth? To many people a share is worth what the financial markets think it is, no more and no less. That would make Lastminute "worth" every penny of the £800m at which the total value of its shares were trading at one point yesterday. And no one can say investors were hoodwinked. They flocked to buy the shares despite the descant sung by analysts that they were overvalued. The new company's £800m market capitalisation compares with actual revenue (not profits) of only £409,000 in the most recent quarter. So, if you purchased the entire company for £800m, then on annual revenues of £1.63m, it would take you nearly 500 years before revenues would cover your purchase price. And that's an unreal calculation because all of the revenue and more is being eaten up by costs. The usual way of assessing a company's status by expressing market capitalisation as a multiple of earnings (post-tax profits) has fallen out of the window. You cannot say a web company is worth 15 times its earnings because web companies do not make profits. Instead, analysts have devised two new yardsticks. The first is to express the market worth of rapidly expanding companies like Amazon.com or eBay.com as a multiple of present or future revenues. But this gives no indication of the quality of revenues - whether they are earned as commissions on sales or completely eaten up by marketing and infrastructure costs. The second way - very fashionable - is to divide the market capitalisation by the number of customers. This is also used to justify takeover bids. Thus Vodafone's recent take over of Mannesmann meant that Vodafone was paying £7,850 for each customer. But mobile phone companies have a stable customer base. The same criterion ap plied to a dot.com's customer base is dodgy because many of the customers may have registered but not be active buyers. As soon as they see something cheaper elsewhere they will be off at the touch of a mouse button. Fortune magazine found wide variations in the valuation of dot.com companies by their customer base ranging from $244 for Lycos, the internet portal, to $4,562 for Charles Schwab, the online stockbroker which takes a commission on sales. Internet valuations are difficult because no one knows how profitable web companies will be. Everyone accepts that the internet will change the world and transform business-to-business transactions (which get less publicity but account for nearly 80% of all internet business transactions). But in the area of business-to-consumer the very nature of the internet makes it difficult to make big profits. There are lower barriers to entry - as soon as a business looks good others can pile in. More important, it is a consumers' not a producers' paradise because people (and robotic agents) can surf the web for cheaper prices). fields.headline: Screen testing
fields.standfirst:
Wake up! This is the modern world. The days of travelling halfway around the globe for a meeting with someone who may (or may not) want to do business with you are over. Stephen Ward reports on the rise of video-conferencing

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Wake up! This is the modern world. The days of travelling halfway around the globe for a meeting with someone who may (or may not) want to do business with you are over. Stephen Ward reports on the rise of video-conferencing
fields.body:
Marianne Lamberti-Aldrich has an intriguing habit at the end of business meetings. She conducts most of them via video screen rather than in person and, as the business concludes, she zooms out to reveal a picture of domesticity that lets her colleagues know she is working, as an executive at IBM, from her home in Arizona.

Few Britons share her confidence in virtual meetings. "I tried it once, from a video-conferencing suite," says one disgruntled manager at a West Country engineering company. "The quality of the pictures was no good and it was very off-putting. I'd rather talk on the telephone."

Dr Guy Fielding, a tutor in social psychology at Oxford University, agrees. "The important clues to a person lying are in the voice," he points out, "so the face is a distraction. You don't need to be able to stare people in the face - in meetings you don't look at the person you're talking to, you look at a document."

Until now, such reservations, combined with a cost per site that can run into tens of thousands of pounds, have been sufficient to limit the use of virtual meetings in Britain to carefully stage-managed events, planned well in advance. But just as the cost of computers has fallen dramatically, so technically adequate equipment is now more easily affordable - which means thousands of people will soon need, like Lamberti-Aldrich, to be as comfortable on video as on the phone.

Pockets of enthusiasm already exist in Britain. Take Cherie Booth: an adept user of tele-conferencing (it came in handy last week for a late-night discussion about blocking her nanny's story, with Alastair Campbell, Lord Falconer and her husband in his Sedgfield constituency), she has said she would also like a video-conferencing facility in Downing Street for her legal work.

David Jackson, a manager at the Environment Agency in London, already has a PC set up for video-conferencing in his office at home. "He comes to the phone at nine in the morning, in his slippers, with a cup of coffee in his hand," a colleague observes. "I only use it for meetings with colleagues, so the dress code is quite informal," Jackson says, although clearly for some users it will be an added pressure to put on make-up or a collar and tie, rather than slouching around in a dressing gown as they would for a phone call.

Experts believe the revolution is coming, however, and will happen in three stages. First, the use of TV conferencing will become more common in the workplace. Then people using it as second nature at work will want the flexibility offered by having it at home. Finally, the next generation of mobile phones will make video-conferencing on the move a normal part of working life.

Software is already available that allows industrial standard video-conferencing from any modern PC or laptop for under £100. Christopher Hilling, director of Equipindex, a London communications technology firm that has just started selling such software, believes the obstacles to wider use of video-conferencing are now cultural and psychological, rather than technical or economic. "The biggest restriction now is you need an ISDN line but those are getting cheaper all the time. Employees often already have them to link home computers to the office network."

One of the keys to successful video-conferencing is training: there is an etiquette to be observed when you attend a video conference - ignore it and you can detonate the entire event. "You have to make sure the lighting is right, for example, and you need to be told not to wear anything like a Prince of Wales check because it makes zigzags all over the screen," explains David Rodger, who co-ordinated the drive to use video-conferencing at the Environment Agency. "And you mustn't have a window behind you in daylight because you'll disappear into shadow like a photograph taken into the sun."

He also alerts people to how they are coming across: "If they are slouching or look bored, I'll let them know. The technical quality may be improving, but subtle body language is still lost on screen. It is no good just raising an eyebrow, for example. I always do a real Tony Blair smile. It's very reassuring," he insists.

Technical help needs to be on standby, along with a strong chairperson for the meeting - there is a slight delay between speaking and the words coming out at the other end, so you cannot interrupt in the same way as you could at a real meeting. You must not talk without putting your hand up and being asked to speak, and there must be no talking in the background. "You lose some of the informality," Rodger admits, "but it is a business meeting, not a school reunion, after all."

Michael Kay, a solicitor in Haringey, north London, is a new convert to video-conferencing as it allows him to take cases that would otherwise lose money. "I haven't had to travel to meet the person, so we can have four 30-minute meetings to suit us both instead of one lasting two hours. We can break off, then resume later." Kay even sees advantages in the time delay: it makes people more polite, he says, while allowing the lawyer to get a sly upper hand. "One barrister told me he can stare at a client without seeming rude."

Money is also a powerful incentive. "Between April and December last year, we saved 500,000 miles of travelling," Rodger says. "That is a saving of £600,000 just in mileage expenses. The amount of time we saved in journeys avoided was equivalent to a year's working time for five people."

While there is "no substitute for a handshake", as Rodger admits, most people who have tried the latest versions of virtual meetings concede that they are, at the very least, better than no meeting at all. Graham Edwards, sales director of Equipindex, remains confident that people will grow to love performing on screen. "You watch Match of the Day," he points out. "People in the crowd look up and see themselves on the big screens by the pitch and they always smile and wave."
